Dialogue: I’ve been thinking about names, I’m kind of torn between Einstein, Newton and Sergeant Fuzzyboots.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, do you really think you can satisfy your need for a relationship with a genetically altered cat?

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe, if it’s a cute little cuddly cat.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, come on, Leonard! This is obviously about Penny.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It doesn’t matter. The woman’s not interested in me, the woman rejected me.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, look, I think that you have as much of a chance of having a sexual relationship with Penny as the Hubble Telescope does of discovering at the centre of every black hole is a little man with a flashlight searching for a circuit breaker. Nevertheless, I do feel obligated to point out to you that she did no reject you. You did not ask her out.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right. I didn’t ask her out, I should ask her out.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. No, now that was not my point. My point was, don’t buy a cat.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, but you’re right. I should march over there and ask her out.

Scene: The flat, Leonard is entering, singing to himself a depressing emo song.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, goody, we’re getting a cat.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny(opening door)
Dialogue: Ah, hey Leonard.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good afternoon Penny, so hi, hey. Uh… I was wondering if you had plans for dinner.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, do you mean dinner tonight?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There is an inherent ambiguity in the word dinner. Technically it refers to the largest meal of the day whenever it is consumed, so, to clarify here, by dinner I mean supper.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Supper?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Or dinner. I was thinking six thirty, if you can go, or a different time.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, six thirty’s great.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really? Great!

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I like hanging out with you guys.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Us guys?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, Sheldon, Howard, Raj, who all’s coming?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They…. might all be there. Or a subset of them might be there, uh, algebraically speaking there are too many unknowns, for example Sheldon had Quizznos for lunch, sometimes he finds that filling, other times he doesn’t, it’s no fault of Quizznos, they have a varied menu.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, whatever, it sounds like fun.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great. Did we say a time?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Six thirty.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And that’s still good for you.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s fine.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Cos it’s not carved in stone.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, six thirty’s great.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ll get my chisel.

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: The hallway. Leonard knocks on Penny’s door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: To… carve the… okay, I’ll see you six thirty.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How do I look?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Could you be more specific?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can you tell I’m perspiring a little?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. The dark crescent-shaped patterns under your arms conceal it nicely. What time is your date?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Six thirty.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Perfect, that gives you two hours and fifteen minutes for that dense molecular cloud of Aramis to dissipate.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is it too much?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not if you’re a rugby team.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: By the way, if it should ever come up, you didn’t join us because you stuffed yourself with a chicken carbonara sub at Quizznos.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would I join you?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No reason. Oh, you know what, maybe this isn’t such a good idea.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no, no, no, well now, there’s always the possibility that alcohol and poor judgement on her part might lead to a nice romantic evening.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, alcohol, poor judgement, it could go well.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course, there’s the other possibility that this date kicks off a rather unpleasant six months of the two of you passing awkwardly in the hall until one of you breaks down and moves to another zip code.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You could have stopped at “it could go well.”

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I could of, I would of.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I mean, I’m a perfectly nice guy. There’s no reason we couldn’t go to the restaurant and have a lovely dinner. Maybe take a walk afterwards, talk about things we have in common, “you love pottery? I love pottery!” You know, there’s a pause, we both know what’s happening, I lean in, we kiss, it’s a little tentative at first but then I realise, she’s kissing me back, and she’s biting my lower lip, you know, she wants me, this thing is going the distance, we’re going to have sex! Oh God! Oh, my God!

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is the sex starting now?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m having a panic attack.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, okay, well then, calm down.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If I could calm down I wouldn’t be having a panic attack, that’s why they call it a panic attack.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, alright, well, just, sit down, yes, sit down, now close your eyes.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just do it.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now try to increase your alpha-wave activity.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a bio-feedback technique, it’s relaxation through brain-wave manipulation, I read a paper about it in the Journal of American Neuroscience, it was a little sparsely sourced but I think the basic science is valid, I probably have it here somewhere.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, who am I kidding, I can’t go through with this, you need to call her and cancel.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Me?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What should I tell her.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know. Tell her I’m sick.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not the kind of illness that will make her want to come over and take care of me, but nothing so critical that she’ll feel uncomfortable going out with me in the future if I want to try this again.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Got it. So I’m assuming nothing venereal. I’ll just tell her that you had a routine colonoscopy and haven’t quite bounced back.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Give me the phone.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But I thought you wanted to cancel?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I can’t because if I don’t show up she’ll still be expecting you.

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would she be expecting me?

Scene: Sheldon and Leonard’s apartment. Leonard enters from bedrooms, dressed in a smart shirt and trousers. They are covered in sweat stains.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Stop asking me all these questions, I need to take another shower.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So are the rest of the guys meeting us here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, no. Turns out that Raj and Howard had to work, and Sheldon had a colonoscopy and he hasn’t quite bounced back yet.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh, my uncle just had a colonoscopy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re kidding, well, then, that’s something we have in common.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We both have people in our lives who… want to nip intestinal polyps in the bud.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, what’s new in the world of physics?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, nothing?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, with the exception of string theory, not much has happened since the 1930’s, and you can’t prove string theory, at best you can say “hey, look, my idea has an internal logical consistency.”

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ah. Well I’m sure things will pick up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s new at the Cheesecake Factory?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, uh, not much. We do have a chocolate key lime that’s moving pretty well.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good. Good. And what about your, uh, hallway friend.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Doug? Oh, yeah, I dunno, I mean, he’s nice and funny, but…

Speaker: Waitress
Dialogue: Can I get you started with some drinks?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No,(waves her away)You were saying, but…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’d like a drink.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just say the but thing about Doug and then I’ll get her back.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, well, you know, it’s just me. I’m still getting over this break-up with Kurt, and this thing with Doug would be just rebound sex.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ugh, don’t get me started on rebound sex.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s just, it’s my pattern. I break up, then I find some cute guy, and then it’s just thirty six meaningless of… well, you know.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not sure that I do. Um, is that one thirty-six hour experience, or is it thirty six hours spread out over say, one… glorious summer.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, it’s usually over a weekend, and trust me, you do not feel good after it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, chafing, right?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Emotionally.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Of course, yeah, emotional chafing. Hey, do you want to see something cool? (Penny nods.) I can make this olive go into this glass without touching it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Physics.(He places the glass over the olive and spins it until the olive gets caught up on the side).

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, centrifugal force!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually, it’s centripetal force, which is an inward force generated by the glass acting on the olive.(The olive drops.)Excuse me.(Leonard disappears under table.)Now, if you were riding on the olive, you’d be in a non-inertial reference frame, and would(he bangs his head on the underside of the table.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I’m okay. Did you spill ketchup?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not okay.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you sure you don’t want to go to the emergency room?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, I’m okay, it’s stopped bleeding.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I know, but you did throw up. Isn’t that a sign of a concussion?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, but I get car sick too, so…

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry about your car, by the way.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, no, it’s fine, you got most of it out the window.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The poor guy on the bike. I had a nice time.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, me too. Um, good night.(Leonard turns across hallway.)Leonard?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Was this supposed to be a date?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This? No. No, of course not, this was just you and me hanging out with a bunch of guys who didn’t show up, because of work and a colonoscopy.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I was just checking.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: When I take a girl out on a date, and I do, she knows she’s been dated. Capital D. Bold face, underline, like Day-ted. I think I might have a little concussion, I’m going to go lay down for a while, good night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, how was your date?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Awesome!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Score one for liquor and poor judgement.

Speaker: Teleplay
Dialogue: Bill Prady & Steven Molaro

Speaker: Story
Dialogue: Chuck Lorre

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve been thinking about time travel again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why, did you hit a roadblock with invisibility?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Put it on the back burner. Anyway, it occurs to me, if I ever did perfect a time machine, I’d just go into the past and give it to myself, thus eliminating the need for me to invent it in the first place.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Interesting.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, it really takes the pressure off.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sounds like a breakthrough, should I call the science magazines and tell them to hold the front cover?(Exiting the apartment.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s time travel, Leonard, I will have already done that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then I guess congratulations are in order.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, congratulations will have been in order. You know, I’m not going to enjoy this party.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know, I’m familiar with you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: At the last department party, Dr Finkleday cornered me and talked about spelunking for 45 minutes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, I was there.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know what’s interesting about caves, Leonard?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well then we’ll avoid Finkleday, we’ll meet the new department head, congratulate him, shake his hand and go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How’s this? Pleased to meet you, Dr Gablehouser. How fortunate for you that the University has chosen to hire you, despite the fact that you’ve done no original research in 25 years, and instead have written a series of popular books that reduce the great concepts of science to a series of anecdotes, each one dumbed down to accommodate the duration of an average bowel movement. Mahalo.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mahalo’s a nice touch.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you know there are only eight consonants in the Hawaiian language.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Interesting, you should lead with that.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, God, Look at this buffet. I love America.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t have buffets in India?

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Of course, but it’s all Indian food. You can’t find a bagel in Mumbai to save your life. Schmear me.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well here’s an interesting turn of events.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What.(Sees Howard entering with a statuesque blonde)Howard brought a date?

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A more plausible explanation is that his work in robotics has made an amazing leap forward.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, what up, science bitches? May I introduce my special lady friend, Summer.(Puts arm around her.)

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Summer
Dialogue: I already told you, touching’s extra.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Right. Sorry.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Leonard(to Sheldon)
Dialogue: Here comes our new boss, be polite.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Hi fellas, Eric Gablehouser.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Howard Wolowitz.

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Howard, nice to meet you, and you are?

Scene: The department party. Sheldon, Raj and Leonard are at the buffet table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: An actual real scientist.(To Leonard)How was that?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building. Sheldon is carrying a box of his things.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t believe he fired me.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building. Sheldon is carrying a box of his things.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, you did call him a glorified high-school science teacher whose last successful experiment was lighting his own farts.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building. Sheldon is carrying a box of his things.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In my defence, I prefaced that by saying “with all due respect.”

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building. Sheldon is carrying a box of his things.
Dialogue: Credit sequence.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Morning

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Morning.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re making eggs for breakfast?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This isn’t breakfast, it’s an experiment.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Huh? Cos it looks a lot like breakfast.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I finally have the time to test my hypothesis, about the separation of the water molecules from the egg proteins, and its impact vis-a-vis taste.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sounds yummy. I look forward to your work with bacon.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: As do I.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, I’m sure if you just apologised to Gablehauser he would give you your job back.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t want my job back. I’ve spent the last three and a half years staring at greaseboards full of equations. Before that I spent four years working on my thesis. Before that I was in college, and before that, I was in the fifth grade. This is my first day off in decades, and I’m going to savour it.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. I’ll let you get back to fixing your eggs.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not just fixing my eggs, I’m fixing everyone’s eggs.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And we all thank you.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Dialogue: (Sheldon takes his eggs and sits down. Takes a photograph of them. Writes in his notebook, then takes a forkful. Writes in notebook again.)

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Use new eggs.(There is a knock on the door).

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny(popping her head round)
Dialogue: Hi, hey. I’m running out to the market, do you guys need anything?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, well this would be one of those circumstances that people unfamiliar with the law of large numbers would call a coincidence.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need eggs. Four dozen should suffice.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Four dozen?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, and evenly distributed amongst brown, white, free range, large, extra-large and jumbo.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, one more time?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Never mind, you won’t get it right, I’d better come with you.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon is in the kitchen cooking, Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, yay!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How come you didn’t go into work today.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m taking a sabbatical, because I won’t kow-tow to mediocre minds.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So you got canned, huh?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Theoretical physicists do not get canned. But yeah.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, maybe it’s all for the best, you know I always say, when one door closes, another one opens.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No it doesn’t. Not unless the two doors are connected by relays, or there are motion sensors involved.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, no, I meant…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or the first door closing causes a change of air pressure that acts upon the second door.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Never mind.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Slow down. Slow down, please slow down.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’re fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look, you’re not leaving yourself enough space between cars.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, sure I am.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no. Let me do the math for you, this car weighs let’s say 4,000lb, now add say 140 for me, 120 for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry, did I insult you? Is your body mass somehow tied into your self worth?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Interesting. Anyway, that gives us a total weight of, let’s say, 4,400lb.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Let’s say 4,390.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. We’re travelling forward at, good Lord, 51 miles an hour. Now let’s assume that your brakes are new and the callipers are aligned, still, by the time we come to a stop, we’ll be occupying the same space as that Buick in front of us, an impossibility that nature will quickly resolve into death, mutilation and… oh look, they built a new put-put course.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is great. Look at me, out in the real world of ordinary people, just living their ordinary, colourless, workaday lives.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, thank you. And thank you, ordinary person. Hey, you want to hear an interesting thing about tomatoes.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, no, no not really. Listen, didn’t you say you needed some eggs.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, yes, but anyone who knows anything about the dynamics of bacterial growth knows to pick up their refrigerated foods on the way out of the supermarket.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, okay, well maybe you should start heading on out then.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, this is fun. Oh, the thing about tomatoes, and I think you’ll really enjoy this, is, they’re shelved with the vegetables, but they’re technically a fruit.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Interesting.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Isn’t it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I mean what you find enjoyable.

Speaker: Sheldon(as Penny selects vitamin supplements)
Dialogue: Oh boy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What now?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, there’s some value to taking a multivitamin, but the human body can only absorb so much, what you’re buying here are the ingredients for very expensive urine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, maybe that’s what I was going for.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well then you’ll want some manganese.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That was fun. Maybe tomorrow we can go to one of those big warehouse stores.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t know Sheldon, it’s going to take me a while to recover from all the fun I had today.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you sure. There are a lot of advantages to buying in bulk. For example, I noticed that you purchase your tampons one month’s supply at a time.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well think about it, it’s a product that doesn’t spoil, and you’re going to be needing them for at least the next thirty years.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You want me to buy thirty years worth of tampons?

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, thirty, thirty five, hey, when did your mother go into menopause?

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I’m not talking about this with you.

Scene: On the stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, Penny, this is a natural human process, and we’re talking about statistically significant savings. Now, if you assume 15 tampons per cycle and a 28 day cycle, are you fairly regular?(Penny shuts door in his face.)Okay, no warehouse store, but we’re still on for put-put golf, right?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard (entering)
Dialogue: Hey, I just ran into Penny, she seemed upset about something.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think it’s her time of the month. I marked the calendar for future reference.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s with the fish?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s an experiment.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What happened to your scrambled egg research?

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that was a dead end. Scrambled eggs are as good as they’re ever going to be.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So… fish.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I read an article about Japanese scientists, who inserted DNA from luminous jellyfish into other animals, and I thought hey, fish nightlights.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fish nightlights.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a billion dollar idea. Shhhhh!

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mum’s the word. Sheldon, are you sure you don’t want to just apologise to Gablehauser and get your job back.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no, no, no. No, I’ve too much to do.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Like luminous fish.

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Shhhhh!

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right… I didn’t….

Scene: The apartment, Sheldon has several bowls containing goldfish.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s just the beginning. I also have an idea for a bulk mail-order feminine hygiene company. Oh, glow in the dark tampons! Leonard, we’re going to be rich.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you for coming on such short notice.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: You did the right thing calling.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t know what else to do, he’s lost all focus, every day he’s got a new obsession.(They enter the apartment. Sheldon is weaving on a loom. He is wrapped in a poncho.)This is a particularly disturbing one.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon(looking round)
Dialogue: Mommy.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Hi baby.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon(mouths)
Dialogue: You called my mother?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, you got yourself a loom, how nice.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Honey, why did you get a loom?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was working with luminous fish, and I thought, hey, loom! Mom, what are you doing here?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Leonard called me.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know, but why?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because one of the great minds of the twenty-first century is raising glow-in-the-dark fish and weaving sarapes.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is not a sarape. This is a poncho. A sarape is open at the sides, a poncho is closed, this is a poncho, and neither is a reason to call someone’s mother.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really, when was the last time you left the house.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I went to the market with Penny.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was three weeks ago.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well then buckle up, in the next four to eight days she’s going to get very crabby.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Sweetheart, your little friend is concerned about you.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, well I’m not a child, I’m a grown man capable of living my life as I see fit. And I certainly don’t need someone telling on me to my mother.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: To my room, and no-one’s allowed in.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: He gets his temper from his daddy.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: He’s got my eyes.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I see.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: All that science stuff, that comes from Jesus.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon? Your mum made dinner.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: I’m not hungry.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, Leonard, don’t trouble yourself, he’s stubborn. He may stay in there ‘til the Rapture.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are we so sure that’s a bad thing?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: I’ll tell ya, I love the boy to death, but he has been difficult since he fell out of me at the K-Mart.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Excuse me for being so bold, but I now see where Sheldon gets his smouldering good looks.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, honey that ain’t going to work, but you keep trying.(To Raj)I made chicken, I hope that isn’t one of the animals that you people think is magic? You know, we have an Indian gentleman at our church, a Dr Patel, it’s a beautiful story, the lord spoke to him, and moved him to give us all 20% off on lasic, you know, those that needed it.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That is a lovely story, um, are we going to do anything about Sheldon?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, we will, you have to take your time with Sheldon. His father, God rest his soul, used to say to me, Mary, you have to take your time with Sheldon.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sounds like a wise man.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, not so wise, he was trying to fight a bobcat for some licquorish. So, everybody grab a plate, and a pretty place mat that Shelly wove.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Has Shelly ever freaked out like this before.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, all the time, I remember one summer when he was thirteen, he built a small nuclear reactor in the shed and told everybody he was going to provide free electricity for the whole town, well the only problem was he had no, whatchacall, fissionable materials. Anyway, when he went on the internets to get some, a man from the government came by and sat him down real gentle and told him it’s against the law to have yellow cake uranium in a shed.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What happened?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Well, the poor boy had a fit, locked himself in his room and built a sonic death ray.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: A death ray?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Well, that’s what he called it, didn’t even slow down the neighbour kids. It pissed our dog off to no end. You know, you two make a cute couple.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Dialogue: Both Leonard and Penny laugh, a little too forced.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, we’re not, we’re not, not a couple, two singles, like those individually wrapped slices of cheese that…. are friends.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Did I pluck a nerve there?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh yeah.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Okay. Alright everybody, it’s time to eat.(Everybody begins to do so)Oh Lord, we thank you for this meal, all your bounty, and we pray that you help Sheldon get back on his rocker.(To Raj and Howard)Now after a moment of silent meditation I’m going to end with “In Jesus’ Name” but you two don’t feel any obligation to join in. Unless, of course, the holy spirit moves you.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Dialogue: Time shift

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh my God, this is the best cobbler I’ve ever had.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: It was always Sheldon’ s favourite. You know what the secret ingredient is?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Love?

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Lard.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Dialogue: Sheldon emerges from the bedroom area.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, look who’s come out….

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Shhh! You’ll spook him. He’s like a baby deer, you gotta let him come to you.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Dialogue: Sheldon crosses to the cobbler, takes some and puts it on a plate. Looks round at the group in the matter of a frightened animal. Everyone but Leonard looks down at their meal.

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is ridiculous. Dammit, Sheldon, snap out of it. You’re a physicist, you belong at the University doing research, not hiding in your room.(Sheldon scuttles away)

Scene: Everyone but Sheldon is in the kitchen of the apartment.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: You don’t hunt, do you?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper(entering)
Dialogue: Good morning, snicker-doodle.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Morning.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, well that looks awful fancy, what is that?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s my idea of what DNA would look like in a silicon based life form.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: But intelligently designed by a creator, right?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What do you want, mom?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: You know how your daddy used to say that you can only fish for so long before you got to throw a stick of dynamite in the water?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Well, I’m done fishing.(Throwing a pair of trousers on the bed)You put those on.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What for?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Because you’re going to go down to your office, you’re going to apologise to your boss, and get your job back.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: I’m sorry, did I start that sentence with the words “if it please your highness?”

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not going to apologise, I didn’t say anything that wasn’t true.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Now you listen here, I have been telling you since you were four years old, it’s okay to be smarter than everybody but you can’t go around pointing it out.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why not?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Because people don’t like it. Remember all the ass-kickings you got from the neighbour kids? Now let’s get cracking. Shower, shirt, shoes, and let’s shove off.(Exits)

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. He is building a model of some kind of double helix. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wouldn’t have been any ass-kickings if that stupid death ray had worked.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Problem solved.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really? That’s impressive.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Leonard, the Lord never gives us more than we can handle. Thankfully he blessed me with two other children who are dumb as soup.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Excuse me, Dr Gablehouser, are you busy?

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Well, actually….

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Sheldon, he’s just doodling, get in here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dr Gablehouser.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Dr Cooper.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Let’s go, baby, we’re losing daylight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Um, as you know, several weeks ago in our first encounter we may have gotten off on the wrong foot, when I called you an idiot. And I just wanted to say that I was wrong. To point it out.

Speaker: Gablehouser(to Mrs Cooper)
Dialogue: I’m sorry, we haven’t been introduced. Dr Eric Gablehouser.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Mary Cooper, Sheldon’s mom.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Now that’s impossible, you must have had him when you were a teenager.

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Oh, aren’t you sweet, his father’s dead.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Recently?

Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Long enough.

Speaker: Gablehouser(indicating chair)
Dialogue: Please. Sheldon, shouldn’t you be working?

Speaker: Sheldon(leaving)
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, how did it go?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I got my job back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really? What happened?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not quite sure. It involves a part of the human experience that has always eluded me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That narrows it down.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: I’m very proud of you honey, you showed a lot of courage today.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thanks, mom. Mom?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: Mmm-hmm?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is Dr Gablehouser going to be my new daddy?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Mrs Cooper
Dialogue: We’ll see. Sleep tight.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Dialogue: Sheldon turns over to sleep in the glow of a luminous goldfish.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Teleplay
Dialogue: David Litt & Lee Aronsohn

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Mrs Cooper is tucking him in.
Speaker: Story
Dialogue: Chuck Lorre & Bill Prady

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, I’m moving my infantry division, augmented by a battalion of Orcs from Lord of the Rings, we flank the Tennessee Volunteers, and the North once again wins the Battle of Gettysburg.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Not so fast, remember the South still has two infantry divisions, plus Superman and Godzilla.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, Orcs are magic, Superman is vulnerable to magic, not to mention, you already lost Godzilla to the Illinois Cavalry and Hulk.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why don’t you just have Robert E. Lee charge the line with Shiva and Ganesh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi, you guys ready to order?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hang on, honey. Shiva and Ganesh? The Hindu Gods against the entire Union army?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And Orcs!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’ll be back.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Excuse me, Ganesh is the remover of obstacles, and Shiva is the destroyer. When the smoke clears, Abraham Lincoln will be speaking Hindi and drinking mint juleps.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, my boss says you either have to order, or leave and never come back.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What do you recommend for someone who worked up a man-sized appetite from a morning of weight training and cardio-funk?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: A shower.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ll take the heart smart platter.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, thank you, and Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We don’t eat here, I don’t know what’s good.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it’s all good.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Statistically unlikely.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just get a hamburger, you like hamburgers.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I like the hamburgers where we usually have hamburgers, you can’t make the assumption that I’ll like the hamburgers here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry. Give him a hamburger.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, which one, the Classic Burger, the Ranch House Burger, the Barbecue Burger or the Kobe burger?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can’t we just go to Big Boy? They only have one burger. The Big Boy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: The Barbecue Burger is like the Big Boy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, in a world that already includes the Big Boy, why would I settle for something like a Big Boy?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Because you are not at Big Boy!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine, I’ll have the Barbecue Burger.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Make it two.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Waitresses don’t yell at you at Big Boy.

Speaker: Lesley(entering)
Dialogue: Hey Leonard, hi guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey Lesley.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: I didn’t know you ate here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We don’t. This is a disturbing aberration.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Lesley, this is Penny, she lives across the hall from Sheldon and me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And walks in quiet beauty like the night.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Howard, I’ve asked you not to do that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Lesley and I do research together at the University.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, wow, a girl scientist.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Yep, come for the breasts, stay for the brains. So, I’m glad I ran into you, the physics department string quartet needs a new cellist.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What happened to Elliot Wong?

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: He switched over to high energy radiation research, had a little mishap, and now the other guys are uncomfortable sitting next to him. So, are you in?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, sure, why not.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Great, we rehearse on Tuesdays at your place.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why at my place?

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Yeah, the department of energy said our regular space is kind of a hot zone. Nice meeting you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, you too. Leonard, I didn’t know you played the cello?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, my parents felt that naming me Leonard and putting me in advanced placement classes wasn’t getting me beaten up enough.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you’re into music, I happen to be a human beatbox.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really?(Howard performs some of the worst beatboxing imaginable.)I’m actually not that into music. So hey, your friend’s really cute, anything going on with you two.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Lesley? No, no-oh, what are you kidding?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He asked her out once, it was an embarrassing failure.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry, was that supposed to be a secret?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s too bad, you guys would make a cute couple.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh dear.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s the matter?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She didn’t take my order.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How can she take your order when you’re too neurotic to talk to her.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Nevertheless, this will be reflected in her tip.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What did Penny mean, you’d make a cute couple?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well I assume she meant that the two of you together would constitute a couple that others might consider cute. An alternate, and somewhat less likely interpretation, is that you could manufacture one. As in, oh look, Leonard and Lesley made Mr and Mrs Goldfarb, aren’t they adorable.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If Penny didn’t know that Lesley had already turned me down then that would unambiguously mean that she, Penny, thought that I should her, Lesley, out, indicating that she, Penny, had no interest in me asking her, Penny, out. But because she did know that I had asked Lesley out and that she, Lesley, had turned me down then she, Penny, could be offering consolation. That’s too bad, you would have made a cute couple. But while thinking, good, Leonard remains available.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re a lucky man, Leonard.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How so?

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re talking to one of the three men in the Western hemisphere capable of following that train of thought.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, what do you think.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I said I could follow it, I didn’t say I cared.

Scene: The stairwell of the apartment building.
Dialogue: Credit sequence.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: I admire your fingering.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Maybe some time you can try that on my instrument.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Dialogue: Time jump

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Goodnight guys, good job.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Male string quartettist
Dialogue: Thanks.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Female string quartettist
Dialogue: See you next week.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was fun, Lesley, thanks for including me.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: You’re welcome. If you’re up for it we could practise that middle section again.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, sure, why not.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Just so we’re clear, you understand that me hanging back to practise with you is a pretext for letting you know that I’m sexually available.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Yeah, I’m good to go.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I thought you weren’t interested in me.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: That was before I saw you handling that beautiful piece of wood between your legs.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You mean my cello?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: No, I mean the obvious crude double entendre. I’m seducing you.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No kidding?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: What can I say, I’m a passionate and impulsive woman. So how about it?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Gee, uh…

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Is it the waitress?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny? What about her?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Well, I thought I saw your pupils dilate when you looked at her, which, unless you’re a heroin addict, points to sexual attraction.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I did have a poppy seed bagel for breakfast, which could give a positive urine test for opiates but certainly not dilate my pupils, so I guess there’s no point in bringing it up.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: You and the waitress then?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. No, there’s nothing going on between Penny and me.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: So, you’re open to a sexual relationship?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Yeah, I guess I am.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Good.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah it is good. Did you want to start now?

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Why don’t we finish the section first.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Okay. A little musical foreplay. Terrific.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Dialogue: (They play, gradually going faster and faster.)

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m good, I’m good to go.

Scene: The apartment living room. The string quartet are practising.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Me too.(Exit in direction of bedrooms.)

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny(opening door)
Dialogue: Oh, hey Sheldon, what’s going on?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need your opinion on a matter of semiotics.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Semiotics. The study of signs and symbols, it’s a branch of philosophy related to linguistics.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, sweetie, I know you think you’re explaining yourself, but you’re really not.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just come with me.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Dialogue: Jump to the pair of them standing outside Leonard’s bedroom door. Bryan Adams “Have You Ever Loved A Woman” is emerging. There is a tie on the bedroom door.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well what?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What does it mean?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on, you went to college.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but I was eleven.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, look, a tie on the doorknob usually means someone doesn’t want to be disturbed because they’re, you know, getting busy.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So you’re saying Leonard has a girl in there.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, either that or he’s lost his tie rack and gotten really into Bryan Adams.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Lesley(voice off)
Dialogue: Oh Leonard, you magnificent beast.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We really shouldn’t be standing here.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon(entering living room)
Dialogue: This is very awkward.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on, you know, Leonard’s had girls over before, right?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, yes, but there’s usually planning, courtship and advance notice. Last time I was able to book a cruise to the Arctic to see a solar eclipse.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, you had to leave the state because your roommate was having sex?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I didn’t have to, the dates just happened to coincide.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, do you know who’s in there?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, there’s Leonard.(Picking up violin case)And he’s either with Lesley Winkle or a 1930’s gangster.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hmmm. Good for him. Good for Leonard. Okay, night.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, wait, hold on.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What’s the matter?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t know what the protocol is here. Do I stay, do I leave? Do I wait to greet them with a refreshing beverage?

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Gee, Sheldon, you’re asking the wrong girl. I’m usually on the other side of the tie.

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Dialogue: (Sheldon looks lost for a moment. The pulls out his mobile phone and dials.)

Scene: The hallway, Sheldon scuttles out of apartment door and crosses to Penny’s. Knocks on it urgently.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hi, Leonard. It’s me, Sheldon. In the living room. I just, I wanted you to know I saw the tie. Message received. You’re welcome. You carry on. Give my best to Lesley.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Big boy!(Wakes up, looks at watch, wraps self in blanket, walks towards kitchen)Someone touched my board. Oh God, my board. Leonard! Leonard!

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Leonard(entering)
Dialogue: Hey, what’s the matter?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My equations, someone’s tampered with my equations.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course I’m sure. Look at the beta-function of quantum chrono-dynamics, the sign’s been changed.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh yeah. But doesn’t that fix the problem you’ve been having?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you insane? Are you out of your mind? Are you…. hey look, that fixes the problem I’ve been having.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley(entering)
Dialogue: You’re welcome.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You did this?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Yeah, I noticed it when I got up to get a glass of water, so I fixed it, now you can show that quarks are asymptotically free at high energies. Pretty cool, huh?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Cool?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Listen, I got to hit the lab. Thanks for a great night.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you, I’ll see you at work.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh-duh, hold on, hold on!

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: What?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who told you you could touch my board?

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: No-one.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t come into your house and touch your board.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: There are no incorrect equations on my board.

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that is so… so…

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I’ve got to run, if you come up with an adjective, text me.(Leaves).

Scene: Living room, Sheldon is sleeping on the sofa, with his head on Lesley’s Violin case.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Inconsiderate, that is the adjective, inconsiderate.

Speaker: Leonard(exiting the apartment)
Dialogue: You can stare at your board all day Sheldon, she’s still going to be right.

Speaker: Sheldon(inside)
Dialogue: I’m not staring, I’m mulling.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hey Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, hi.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, how’s it going?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Pretty good.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Just pretty good, I’d think you were doing very good.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Pretty, very, there’s really no objective scale for delineating variations of good, why do you ask?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, a little bird told me that you and Lesley hooked up last night.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m coming.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, is it serious, do you like her?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wuh, I don’t…. th-th-th-that’s really two different questions, uh, I’m not…. Sheldon, we have to go!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Boy, you’re wound awfully tight for a man who just had sexual intercourse.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, well, I’ll talk to you later, but, I am so happy for you Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. What did she mean, she’s happy for me? Is she happy because I’m seeing someone, or is she happy because she thinks that I’m happy, because anyone who cared for someone would want them to be happy, even if the reason for their happiness made the first person unhappy. You know, because the second person, though happy, is now romantically unavailable to the first person.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you realise I may have to share a Nobel Prize with your booty call?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know what, I’m being ridiculous. But who cares what Penny thinks, Lesley is a terrific girl, she’s attractive, we like each other, she’s extremely intelligent.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She’s not that intelligent.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She fixed your equation.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She got lucky.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t believe in luck.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t have to believe in it for her to be lucky.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Regardless, I have a chance at a real relationship with Lesley, I’m not going to pass that up for some hypothetical future happiness with a woman who may or may not want me to be happy with a woman who is currently making me happy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I still don’t care.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, Lesley.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Careful  Leonard, liquid nitrogen, 320 degrees below zero.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Brrrr. Why are you smashing a flash frozen banana.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Because I’ve got a bowl of Cheerios and I couldn’t find a knife.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So anyway(puts arms around her)Hello.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Uh, what are you doing?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just extending the intimacy. Do you want to slip over to the radiation lab and share a decontamination shower?

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Okay, uh, what exactly do you think’s going on between us?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not sure, but I think I’m about to discover how the banana felt.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Listen, Leonard, neither of us are neuroscientists but we both understand the biochemistry of sex, I mean, dopamine in our brains is released across synapses causing pleasure. You stick electrodes in a rat’s brain, give him an orgasm button, he’ll push that thing until he starves to death.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who wouldn’t?

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Well, the only difference between us and a rat is that you can’t stick an electrode in our hypothalamus. That’s where you come in.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, well, I’m just glad to be a part of it. So what happens now?

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Well, I don’t know about your sex drive, but I’m probably good till New Years.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Okay. Thank you.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Thank you!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You want to make plans for New Years.

Speaker: Lesley
Dialogue: Woah, Leonard, please, you’re smothering me.

Speaker: Leonard(leaving)
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, look, it’s Doctor Stud!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Doctor what?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The blogosphere is a-buzzing with news of you and Lesley Winkle making eine kleine bang-bang music.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wha… how did it get on the internet?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I put it there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, how did you know about it?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: A little bird told us. Apparently you are a magnificent beast.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, that part’s true!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I think I may have misjudged this restaurant.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No kidding.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I won’t go out on a limb, but I think we may be looking at my new Tuesday hamburger.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Your old Tuesday hamburger will be so broken hearted.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Way ahead of you. I was thinking of moving Big Boy to Thursdays, and just dropping Soup Plantation.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, the name always confused me anyway, Soup Plantation. You can’t grow soup.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, how’s everything.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Terrific, you’ll be happy to know that I plan to come here every Tuesday night for the foreseeable future.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, oh yay!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who do I speak to about permanently reserving this table?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, I don’t know, a psychiatrist? So hey, how are things with you and Lesley?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, to be honest, I don’t think it’s going to work out.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, oh that’s too bad. Well hey, don’t worry, I’m sure there is someone out there who is just right for you.(Walks away smiling).

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well what did she mean by that? Was that just a generic platitude or was that a subtle bid for attention?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know why this hamburger surpasses the Big Boy? This is a single decker hamburger whereas the Big Boy is a double decker. This has a much more satisfying meat to bun to condiment ratio.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you even listening to me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course I’m listening. Blah blah, hopeless Penny delusion, blah blah blah.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay then. You know, you can grow the ingredients for soup.(Sheldon nods).
