Sheldon(entering in a body suit featuring black and white vertical lines)is neither sound nor light, but he’s obviously the Doppler Effect.

Dialogue: Okay.

Dialogue: See, people get it.

Dialogue: What is your move?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.

Dialogue: Where do you get this stuff?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Howard

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, if only I had his confidence. I have such difficulty speaking to women. Or around women. Or at times, even effeminate men.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If that’s a working stethoscope, maybe you’d like to hear my heart skip a beat.

Dialogue: No thanks.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, seriously, you can, I have transient idiopathic arrhythmia.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I  want to get to know Penny’s friends, I just, I don’t know how to talk to these people.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I actually might be able to help.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How so?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Like Jane Goodall observing the apes, I initially saw their interactions as confusing and unstructured, but patterns emerge, they have their own language if you will.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Go on.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, it seems that the newcomer approaches the existing group with the greeting “How wasted am I?” which is met with an approving chorus of “Dude.”

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then what happens?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s as far as I’ve gotten.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is ridiculous, I’m jumping in.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good luck.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, you’re coming with me.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I hardly think so.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Aren’t you afraid I’ll embarrass you?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes. But I need a wing-man.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, but if we’re going to use flight metaphors I’m much more suited to being the guy from the FAA, analysing wreckage.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl in Hippie Costume
Dialogue: Oh, Hi!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: So, what are you supposed to be?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Me? I’ll give you a hint. Neeeeooooowwwww!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: Uh, a choo-choo train?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Close! Neeeeeoooooowwwww!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: A brain damaged choo-choo train?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl in Butterfly Costume(dropping onto sofa next to Raj)
Dialogue: How wasted am I?(Raj shrugs.)

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Dialogue: Time shift. Sheldon and Leonard are now talking to a girl in a princess costume.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Neeeeeooooowwwwww!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: I still don’t get it.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m the Doppler Effect.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: Okay, if that is some sort of learning disability, I think it’s very insensitive.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why don’t you just tell people you’re a zebra?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, why don’t you just tell people you’re one of the seven dwarves.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because I’m Frodo.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, well, I’m the Doppler Effect.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh no.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s Penny’s ex-boyfriend.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What do you suppose he’s doing here? Besides disrupting the local gravity field.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If he were any bigger, he’d have moons orbiting him.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, snap. So I guess we’ll be leaving now.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why should we leave? For all we know, he crashed the party and Penny doesn’t even want him here.(Penny and Kurt hug).

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You have a back-up hypothesis.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe they just want to be friends.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or maybe she wants to be friends, and he wants something more.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then he and I are on equal ground.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but you’re much closer to it than he is.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, if this was 15,000 years ago, by virtue of his size and strength, Kurt would be entitled to his choice of female partners.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And male partners. Animal partners. Large primordial eggplants, pretty much whatever tickled his fancy.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, but our society has undergone a paradigm shift, in the information age, Sheldon, you and I are the alpha males. We shouldn’t have to back down.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: True. Why don’t you text him that and see if he backs down?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. I’m going to assert my dominance face to face.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Face to face? Are you going to wait for him to sit down, or are you going to stand on a coffee table?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hello Penny. Hello Kurt.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hey guys. You having a good time?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Given the reaction to my costume, this party is a scathing indictment of the American education system.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: What, you’re a zebra, right?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yet another child left behind.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: And what are you supposed to be, an Elf?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I’m a Hobbit.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: What’s the difference?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, a Hobbit is a mortal Halfling inhabitant of Middle Earth, whereas an Elf is an immortal tall warrior.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: So why the hell would you want to be a Hobbit?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because he is neither tall nor immortal, and none of us could be The Flash.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Well, whatever, why don’t you go hop off on a quest, I’m talking to Penny here.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I think we’re all talking to Penny here.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not. No offence.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Okay, maybe you didn’t hear me, go away.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright Kurt, be nice.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Aw, I am being nice. Right little buddy.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Kurt!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, I understand your impulse to try to physically intimidate me. I mean, you can’t compete with me on an intellectual level and so you’re driven to animalistic puffery.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Are you calling me a puffy animal?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Of course not, no, he’s not, you’re not, right Leonard?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I said animalistic. Of course we’re all animals, but some of us have climbed a little higher on the evolutionary tree.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If he understands that, you’re in trouble.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: So what, I’m unevolved?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re in trouble.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: You know, you use a lot of big words for such a little dwarf.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, Kurt, please.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, Penny, it’s okay, I can handle this. I’m not a dwarf, I’m a Hobbit. A Hobbit. Are misfiring neurons in your hippocampus preventing the conversion from short-term to long-term memory?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Okay, now you’re starting to make me mad.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: A homo-habilus discovering his opposable thumbs says what?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I think I’ve made my point.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Yeah, how about I make a point out of your pointy little head.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let me remind you, while my moral support is absolute, in a physical confrontation I will be less than useless.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There’s not going to be a confrontation, in fact I doubt if he can even spell confrontation.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt(physically lifting Leonard from the ground)
Dialogue: C – O – N… frontation!

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Kurt, put him down this instant.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: He started it.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t care, I’m finishing it, put him down.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Kurt
Dialogue: Fine. You’re one lucky little leprechaun.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s a Hobbit! I’ve got your back.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard, are you okay.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, no, I’m fine. It’s good, it’s a good party, thanks for having us, it’s just getting a little late so….

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, okay, alright, well thank you for coming.

Scene: The hallway. Howard knocks on Penny’s door with his bow.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Happy Halloween.(They leave)If it’s any consolation, I thought that homo-habilus line really put him in his place.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s that?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Tea. When people are upset the cultural convention is to bring them hot beverages. There there. You want to talk about it?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good. There there was really all I had.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good night Sheldon.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good night Leonard.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny(knocking on door and entering)
Dialogue: Hey Leonard.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi Penny.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, I just wanted to make sure you’re okay.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m fine.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m so sorry about what happened.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s not your fault.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes it is. That’s why I broke up with him, he always does stuff like that.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So why was he at your party?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I ran into him last week and, he was…  just, all apologetic, about how he’s changed, he was just going on and on and I believed him, and I’m an idiot because I always believe guys like that and… I can’t go back to my party because he’s there, and I know you don’t want to hear this and I’m upset and I’m really drunk and I just want to…(bursts into tears and rests head on Leonard’s shoulder.)

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There there.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: God, what is wrong with me.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nothing, you’re perfect.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Gah, I’m not perfect.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes you are.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You really think so, don’t you?(She kisses hm.)

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How much have you had to drink tonight?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Just…. a lot.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you sure that your being drunk, and your being angry with Kurt doesn’t have something to do with what’s going on here?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It might. Boy, you’re really smart.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I’m a frickin’ genius.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard, you are so great. Why can’t all guys be like you?

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because if all guys were like me, the human race couldn’t survive.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I should probably go.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Probably.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Penny(in doorway)
Dialogue: Thank you.(She kisses him again. Kurt is watching.)

Scene: The living room. Sheldon brings Leonard a cup of tea.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s right, you saw what you saw. That’s how we roll in The Shire.(Closes door quickly, locks and chains it.)

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Coming.(Opens door to Howard.)

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, have you seen Koothrapali?

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s not here. Maybe the Avenger summoned him.

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He’s not the Marvel comic story, he’s the original Norse God.

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you for the clarification.

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m supposed to give him a ride home.

Scene: The apartment, there is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well I’m sure he’ll be fine. He has his hammer.

Scene: A random bedroom. Butterfly costume girl is climbing off of Raj.
Speaker: Butterfly Girl
Dialogue: Wow, I have to say, you are an amazing man. You’re gentle and passionate, and my God, you are such a good listener!

Scene: A random bedroom. Butterfly costume girl is climbing off of Raj.
Dialogue: (Raj puts hands behind head with a smug expression on his face.)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Watch this, it’s really cool. Call Leonard Hofstadter.

Speaker: Howard’s phone
Dialogue: Did you say, call Helen Boxleitner?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No. Call Leonard Hofstadter.

Speaker: Howard’s phone
Dialogue: Did you say, call Temple Beth Sader.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here, let me try. Call McFlono McFloonyloo. Heh-heh.

Speaker: Howard’s phone
Dialogue: Calling Rajesh Koothrappali.(Raj’s phone rings).

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, that’s very impressive. And a little racist.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If we’re all through playing mock the flawed technology, can we get on with Halo night, we were supposed to start at eight, it is now 8:06.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So? We’ll start now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, first we have to decide if those lost six minutes will be coming out of game time, bathroom time or the pizza break.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We can split it two, two and two.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If we’re having anchovies on the pizza we can’t take it out of bathroom time.(There is a knock on the door.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, what fresh hell is this?

Speaker: Leonard(opening door)
Dialogue: Hey Penny, come on in.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey guys.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: See a Penny, pick her up, and all the day you’ll have good luck.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No you won’t. Uh, can I hide out here for a while.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sure. What’s going on.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, there’s this girl I know from back in Nebraska, Christie, well anyway she called me up and she’s like “Hey, how’s California,” and I’m like “Awesome” ‘cos, you know, it’s not Nebraska, and the next thing I know she’s invited herself out here to stay with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Anyway, she got here today, and she’s just been in my apartment, yakkety-yakking about every guy she’s slept with in Omaha, which is basically every guy in Omaha, and washing the sluttiest collection of underwear you have ever seen in my bathroom sink.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, is she doing it one thong at a time, or does she just throw it all in, like some sort of erotic bouillabaisse.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He really needs to dial it down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, if you don’t like this Christie, why are you letting her stay?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, she was engaged to my cousin while she was sleeping with my brother, so she’s kind of family.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I apologise for my earlier outburst, who needs Halo when we can be regaled with the delightfully folksy tale of the whore of Omaha?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t think she’s a whore.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, yeah she’s definitely a whore. I mean, she has absolutely no standards, this one time, she was at… where’s Howard?

Speaker: Howard(voice off)
Dialogue: Bonjour mademoiselle, I understand you’re new in town.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh good grief.
Credit Sequence

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ugh, I cannot believe Christie let Howard into my apartment.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And I cannot believe people pay for horoscopes, but on a more serious note it’s 8:13 and we’re still not playing Halo.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, fine, we’ll just play one on one until he gets back.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: One on one? We don’t play one on one, we play teams, not one on one. One on one!

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well the only way we can play teams at this point is if we cut Raj in half.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, sure, cut the foreigner in half, there’s a billion more where he came from.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, if you guys need a fourth, I’ll play.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great idea.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, no. The wheel was a great idea. Relativity was a great idea. This is a notion, and a rather sucky one at that.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why? Oh, Penny, Penny, Penny.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, what, what, what?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is a complex battle simulation with a steep learning curve, there are myriad weapons, vehicles and strategies to master, not to mention an extremely intricate back-story.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny(picking up a controller, there is the sound of an explosion from the television)
Dialogue: Oh cool, whose head did I just blow off?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Mine.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I got this, lock and load boys.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s the only way we can play teams.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but whoever’s her partner will be hamstrung by her lack of experience and not to mention that fact that sh….(another explosion)

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ha-ha, there goes your head again.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, this isn’t at all good sportsmanship to shoot somebody who’s just respawned, you need to give them a chance to(explosion)now come on!

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Dialogue: Time shift

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Raj, Raj, she’s got me cornered, cover me.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Cover this, suckers. Ha-ha-ha!

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, take the couch, or my bed, I just got new pillows, hypo-allergenics.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, the couch is good.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hold that thought, Leonard, a moment.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let me guess, you have a problem with this.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Where do I begin?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Your friendship means a lot to me as well, what else?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, our earthquake supplies, we have a two day, two man kit.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, if there is an earthquake and the three of us are trapped here, we could be out of food by tomorrow afternoon.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, are you suggesting that if we let Penny stay we might succumb to cannibalism?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No-one ever thinks it will happen until it does.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny, if you promise not to chew the flesh off our bones while we sleep, you can stay.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hu.. what?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s engaging in reductio-ad-absurdum. It’s the logical fallacy of extending someone’s argument to ridiculous proportions and then criticising the result, and I do not appreciate it.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ll get you a blanket and a pillow.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, well since I’m obviously being ignored here, let’s go over the morning schedule, I use the bathroom from 7 to 7:20, plan your ablutions and bodily functions accordingly.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How am I supposed to plan my bodily functions?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m listening.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s culturally universal, a bed, even a temporary bed, is always oriented with the headboard away from the door. It serves the ancient imperative of protecting oneself against marauders.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’ll risk it.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hm!

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Anything else I should know.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. If you use my toothbrush I’ll jump out that window. Please don’t come to my funeral. Have a good night.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry about that.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Got it.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, sleep tight.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thanks.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Funny expression, sleep tight. It refers to the early construction of beds which featured a mattress suspended on interlocking ropes which would occasionally… sleep tight.

Scene: Penny, Sheldon, Raj and Leonard stand in the apartment doorway. Romantic music plays from Penny’s apartment door.
Dialogue: (Penny turns off light and lies down on couch. Across the room, Raj is still in the kitchen, eating a sandwich. Realising everyone has forgotten about him, he quietly lets himself out. Penny hears the door close, looks worried, then moves her head to the other end of the couch.)

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.

Dialogue: Every Saturday since we have lived in this apartment, I have awakened at 6:15, poured myself a bowl of cereal, added a quarter cup of 2% milk, sat on this end of this couch, turned on BBC America and watched Doctor Who.

Dialogue: Uh, so Christie, what are your plans?

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let me offer a little outside the box thinking here, why doesn’t Christie stay with me.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: For one thing you live with your mother.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I do not, my mother lives with me.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well then, it’s all settled, Christie will stay with Howard, Penny can go back to her apartment, and I’ll watch the last 24 minutes of Doctor Who, although at this point it’s more like Doctor Why Bother.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon you just can’t dictate…

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No more talking, everybody go.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, what do you say, you wanna repair to Castle Wolowitz?

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Christie
Dialogue: What is that, like a Mexican deli?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I should have mentioned this earlier, my last name is Wolowitz.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Christie

Speaker: Sheldon

Speaker: Howard

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, can’t you see she’s using you?

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Who cares, last night she pulled off her blouse and I wept!

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, Howard, I know her, okay, she’ll have sex with anyone as long as they keep buying her things.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Really?

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The following morning. Sheldon is in the kitchen making breakfast. He crosses to the couch, sees Penny sleeping there, looks lost. He is about to sit down on Penny when Leonard enters.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yay! If you’ll excuse me, I have some Bar-Mizvah bonds to cash.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry, we cannot do this without Wolowitz.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We can’t order Chinese food without Wolowitz?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let me walk you through it, our standard is, the steamed dumpling appetizer, General So’s chicken, beef with broccoli, shrimp with lobster sauce and vegetable lo-main. Do you see the problem?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I see a problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Our entire order is predicated on four dumplings and four entrees divided among four people.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, we’ll just order three entrees.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine, what do you want to eliminate, and who gets the extra dumpling.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We could cut it into thirds.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then it is no longer a dumpling, once you cut it open it is at best a very small open faced sandwich.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: Hi fellas. Oh, where’s your annoying little friend who thinks he speaks Mandarin?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s putting his needs ahead of the collective good.(Pointing at waiter)Where he comes from, that’s punishable by death.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: I come from Sacramento.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can we get an order of dumplings, but with three instead of four.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: No substitutions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This isn’t a substitution, it’s a reduction.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: Okay, no reductions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine, bring us three orders of dumplings, that’s twelve, we’ll each have four.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That works.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, if we fill up on dumplings we’ll need to eliminate another entree.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: No eliminations.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If we have extra, we’ll just take the leftovers home.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And divide it how, I’m telling you we cannot do this without Wolowitz.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wolowitz is with his new girlfriend, if you had let me invite Penny then you would have had your fourth.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Have you seen Penny eat Chinese food, she uses a fork, and she double dips her egg rolls.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We don’t order egg rolls.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Exactly, but we’d have to if she was here.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can we please make a decision, not only are there children starving in India, there’s an Indian starving right here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here’s an idea, why don’t we just go out for Indian food.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uurgh.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: You are nice boys. Tell you what I’m going to do. I’m going to bring you the four dumplings. When I’m walking over to the table, maybe I get bumped, one of the dumplings falls to the floor, no-one has to know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ll know.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: (wanders away cursing in Mandarin.)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How about soup?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, we can always divide soup.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What about the won-tons?

Speaker: Penny(answering)
Dialogue: Oh, hey guys, what’s up?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s Halo night.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Okay. So?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, with Wolowitz spending all of his time with your friend Christie,

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: She’s not my friend. Friends do not get their friends care bears all sweaty.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right, anyway, uh, with Wolowitz occupied elsewhere, we had something we wanted to ask you. Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. Penny, we would very much appreciate it if you would be the fourth member of our Halo team. I don’t think I need to tell you what an honour this is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s so sweet. But I’m going out dancing with a girlfriend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can’t go out, it’s Halo night.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, for Penny it’s dancing night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You go dancing every Wednesday.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then it’s not dancing night.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, why don’t I play with you guys tomorrow?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Tonight is Halo night, it’s like talking to a wall.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, now Sheldon, you and I are about to have a problem.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, remember, we role-played this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but you didn’t portray her as completely irrational.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright fellas, I gotta go. Good luck.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe we should have asked if we could go dancing with her and her girlfriend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, assuming we could dance, which we can’t, there are three of us and two of them.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s the Chinese restaurant all over again. I assure you that cutting a dumpling in thirds is child’s play compared with three men, each attempting to dance with 67% of a woman.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aaah, for God’s sake, Sheldon, you are driving me crazy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Your anger’s not with me, sir, but with basic mathematics.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I’m pretty sure my anger’s with you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What’s happening to us? We’re falling apart.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who are you calling?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The only man who can restore any semblance of balance to our universe.

Speaker: Howard(voice)
Dialogue: Hi this is Howard Wolowitz.

Speaker: Christie(voice)
Dialogue: And this is Christie Van Der Bell.

Speaker: Howard(voice)
Dialogue: We can’t get to the phone right now because we’re having sex.

Speaker: Christie(voice)
Dialogue: You’re not going to put that on your message are you?

Speaker: Howard(voice)
Dialogue: No, I’m just kidding, I’ll re-record it.(beep)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, think this through, you’re going to ask Howard to choose between sex and Halo.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I’m going to ask him to choose between sex and Halo 3. As far as I know, sex has not been upgraded to include high-def graphics and enhanced weapon systems.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, all sex has is nudity, orgasms and human contact.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My point.

Speaker: Christie(voice from within)
Dialogue: I’m just saying, you can take the damned plastic off the couch once in a while.

Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: Why, so you and Howard can hump on it?

Speaker: Howard(voice)
Dialogue: Ladies, ladies, I’m sure there’s a middle ground.

Speaker: Christie and Howard’s Mother together
Dialogue: Shut up Howard.

Speaker: Howard(voice)
Dialogue: You girl’s talk, I’m going to take my scooter out for a little spin.

Speaker: Christie(voice as Howard emerges through door)
Dialogue: Are you happy, you drove your own son out of the house.

Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: Why don’t you stop butting in where you don’t belong.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What are you guys doing here?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s Halo night.

Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: He’s not a man, he’s a putz, and don’t you take that tone with me, you gold digger.

Speaker: Christie(voice)
Dialogue: What did you call me?

Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: You heard me, and I’ll tell you something else, you’re barking up the wrong tree, cos as long as you’re around, Howard is out of the will.

Speaker: Christie
Dialogue: (voice): You know what, I got better offers, I’m out of here.

Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: That’s right, go back to Babylon, you whore.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, Halo night, huh?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I thought she was the whore of Omaha?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Shhh!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you got him in your sights, fire, he’s charging his plasma rifle.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t shoot now, I’m cloaking.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Now, Raj, kill Sheldon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t see him.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s why the call it cloaking, dead man.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well then start throwing grenades.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m all out.

Speaker: Penny(entering with three other sexy women)
Dialogue: Hi guys, my friends and I got tired of dancing, so we came over to have sex with you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That will do, Raj, straight for the tank.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We said no tanks.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: There are no rules in hell!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Son of a bitch, medpack, I need a medpack!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Told yah!(They leave).

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There’s a sniper, use your rocket launcher.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: All I’ve got is a needler, and I’m all out of ammo.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And now you’re out of life. Why did you hit pause?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I thought I heard something.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, never mind, alright, go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Damn you, walletnook.com.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Problem?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The online description was completely misleading, they said eight slots plus removable ID, to any rational person that would mean room for nine cards, but they don’t tell you the removable ID takes up one slot, it’s a nightmare.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, now, do you really need the honorary Justice League of America membership card?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s been in every wallet I’ve owned since I was five.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It says keep this on your person at all times.(Knock on door)It’s right here under Batman’s signature.
Leonard opens door. Raj and Howard are outside. Raj is holding a laptop which is open. His parents are on the screen.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And this is Leonard and Sheldon’s apartment.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Guess whose parents just got broadband.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: May I present, live from New Delhi, Dr and Mrs V. M. Koothrappali.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Lift up the camera. I’m looking at his crotch.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry papa.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Oh, there’s much better. Hi.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And over here is Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He lives with Leonard.

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Oh, that’s nice. Like Haroun and Tanweer.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, no, not like Haroun and Tanweer.

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Such sweet young men, they just adopted the cutest little Punjabi baby.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, we’re not like Haroun and Tanweer!

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: So are you boys academics like our son?

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: And your parents are comfortable with your limited earning potential?

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Papa, please don’t start.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: God, it’s just a question, he’s so sensitive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, that’s my life, that’s my friends, good to see you, say goodbye.

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Bye!

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Wait, wait. Before you go we have good news. Put the computer down and gather your friends.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What is it papa.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Friends.

Speaker: Howard(as they gather)
Dialogue: Is it just me, or does webchatting with your clothes on seem a little pointless.

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Rajesh, do you remember Lalita Gupta?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The little fat girl that used to kick me in the samosas and call me untouchable.

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Yes. Well, now she’s a dental student at USC, so we gave her your contact information.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why did you do that?

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: You’re 26 years old Rajesh. We want grandchildren.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But Papa, I’m not supposed…

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Lalita’s parents approve the match.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: If you decide on a spring wedding, we can avoid monsoon season.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Spring wedding?

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: It’s up to you dear, we don’t want to meddle.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: If you don’t want to meddle, then why are you meddling.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I may, your parents probably don’t consider this meddling, while arranged marriages are no longer the norm, Indian parents continue to have a greater than average involvement in their children’s lives.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why are you telling me about my own culture?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You seemed confused.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry, Mommy, Papa, but with all due respect I really can’t go through…

Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Sorry darling, we have to go. Doogie Howser is on. Grandma, it’s Doogie time! Bye bye.

Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Bye bye.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t believe it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Neither do I. Doogie Howser’s been off the air for like, twenty years.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually, I read somewhere that it’s one of the most popular programmes in India.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It might speak to a cultural aspiration to have one’s children enter the medical profession.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I bet you’re right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I bet they love Scrubs.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s not to love?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Excuse me, hello? My parents are trying to marry me off to a total stranger, what am I going to do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I suggest you go through with it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Romantic love as the basis for marriage has only existed since the nineteenth century. Up until then, arranged marriages were the norm, and it served society quite well.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s the entire premise of Fiddler on the Roof.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not a big fan of musicals, but I love that show.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Me too. Of course, it speaks to me culturally.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Understandable, but there’s a universality to that story which transcends ethnicity.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let’s not forget it’s got some really catchy tunes.

Speaker: All
Dialogue: (various noises of agreement)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, I know what I’m going to do.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Find new friends.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So who wants to rent Fiddler?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No need, we have the special edition.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, maybe we are like Haroun and Tanweer.
Credits sequence

Speaker: Sheldon(on phone)
Dialogue: This is Dr Sheldon Cooper. Yeah, I need to cancel my membership to the Planetarium. Yeah, well I’m sorry too, but there’s just no room for you in my wallet. Yeah, I understand, but it was between you and the Museum of Natural History and, frankly, you don’t have dinosaurs. Well I’ll miss you too, bye bye. Okay, I know you’re texting about me, and I’d really like you to stop.

Speaker: Raj(entering)
Dialogue: Oh dear, I am rightly and truly screwed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, I thought you were finding new friends.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ve got some feelers out. In the meantime, listen to this.

Dialogue: Hi Rajesh, this is Lalita Gupta. Your mother gave my mother your phone number to give to me. So I’m calling you, and, ah… call me back. Bye.

Dialogue: Can you believe how pushy she is?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So don’t call her.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: If I don’t call her, I won’t hear the end of it from my parents.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So call her.

Dialogue: How can I call her, you know I can’t talk to women.

Dialogue: I’m done, anybody else?

Dialogue: Give me the phone.

Dialogue: Just give it to me.(Dials)

Dialogue: What are you doing?

Dialogue: Don’t worry, you’ll thank me.(In a fake Indian accent)Hello Lalita, Raj Koothrappali.(Raj starts to chase Howard across the room.)Yes it is good to talk to you too. So, what are you wearing. Oh, not important, so, anyhow, when would you like to meet. Friday works for me. And I call you with the time and place, but in the meantime, keep it real babe.(In own voice)You may now thank me.

Dialogue: For what, making me sound like a Simpsons character?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fine, next time make your own date.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I didn’t want to make this one.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look on the bright side, she might turn out to be a nice, beautiful girl.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Great, then we’ll get married, I won’t be able to talk to her, and we’ll spend the rest of our lives in total silence.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Worked for my parents.

Speaker: Penny(knocking and entering)
Dialogue: Hi guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I need some guinea pigs.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, there’s a lab animal supply company in Reseda you could try, but if your research is going to have human applications may I suggest white mice instead, their brain chemistry is far closer to ours.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I swear to God, Sheldon, one day I’m going to get the hang of talking to you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: His mom’s been saying that for years. What’s up?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I finally convinced the restaurant to give me a bar tending shift, so I need to practice making drinks.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, great, well the key to acquiring proficiency in any task is repetition.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: With certain obvious exceptions. Suicide, for example.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So Leonard, how about it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, Penny, we’d love to help you, but Raj is going through some stuff right now. And besides, he doesn’t drink, so…(Raj whispers in his ear)Really? Um, Raj is going through some stuff right now and he’d like to take up drinking.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, here you go, Leonard, one tequila sunrise.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. This drink is a wonderful example of how liquids with different specific gravities interact in a cylindrical container. Thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, Raj, what’ll it be?(Raj whispers in Leonard’s ear.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Whatever you recommend.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, how about a grasshopper. I make a mean grasshopper. Okay? Good. Coming up. Sheldon, what are you going to have?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ll have a diet coke.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, can you please order a cocktail, I need to practice mixing drinks.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. I’ll have a virgin cuba libre.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s, um, rum and coke without the rum.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes,

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So coke.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. And would you make it diet?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: There’s a can in the fridge.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A cuba libre traditionally comes in a tall glass with a lime wedge.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Then swim to Cuba.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bartenders are supposed to have people skills.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, Raj, here you go. Alright, who’s next?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’d like to try a slippery nipple.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, you’re cut off. Anybody need a refill?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Where did my life go, Penny? One day I’m a carefree batchelor, and the next I’m married and driving a minivan to peewee cricket matches in suburban New Delhi.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: A… are you talking to me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Is there another Penny here? I had such plans. I had dreams. I was going to be the Indira Gandhi of particle astro-physics. But with a penis, of course.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s amazing.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Ever since I was a little boy my father wanted me to be a gynaecologist like him. How can I be a gynaecologist, I can barely look a woman in the eye. You know what, I’m not going to let my parents control my future any longer, it’s time for a showdown. Somebody give me a computer with a webcam.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, sweetie, I think that’s the grasshopper talking.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And it’s about to tell my parents that I’m not riding an elephant down the aisle with Lalita Gupta.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, calm down, no-one can make you get married. Why don’t you just meet this girl and, see what happens.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Haven’t you been listening to me, I cannot talk to women.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Um… Raj.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, no, let’s see how long it takes him.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, Raj, honey, you say you can’t talk to women but… you’ve been talking to me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And now we’ll never know.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You’re right. I… I am talking to you. Hello Penny, how are you?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m fine.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, now I just need to make sure I have a Lalita before I meet the grasshopper. It’s a sweet green miracle.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, if you’re going to drink on this date just promise me you won’t overdo it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Overdo what? Happiness? Freedom? This warm glow inside of me that promises everything is going to be all hunky donkey?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, that. Uh, why don’t you bring her to my restaurant when I’m tending the bar so I can keep an eye on you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait a minute, what’s the plan here? Let’s say he meets her and he likes her and they get married, what’s he going to do, stay drunk for the rest of his life?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Worked for my parents.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t believe I’m sitting here next to little Lalita Gupta.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Well, you are.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Little Lalita. That’s kind of fun to say. Little Lalita, Little Lalita, Little Lalita, you should try it.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: No, it’s okay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You have lost so much weight! That must have been difficult for you because you were so, so fat! Do you remember?

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Yes, I do.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Of course you do. Who could forget being that fat?

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Well, I’ve been trying.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So you’re a dental student? Hmm, are you aware that dentists have an extremely high suicide rate? Not as high as, say, air traffic controllers, but then there are far more dentists than air traffic controllers, so in pure numbers you’re still winning.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Yay me!

Speaker: Leonard(to Penny)
Dialogue: You have a drink that’ll make him less obnoxious?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Drinks do not work that way.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’d say he was doing fine, look at her, last girl my mom set me up with had a moustache and a vestigial tail.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sorry I’m late.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nothing, I just really didn’t want to come. Virgin diet cuba libre please.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In a tall glass, with a lime wedge.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll wedge it right in there.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, how’s Koothrappali d…. oh my Lord.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s Princess Punchali.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m pretty sure her name’s Lalita.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, Princess Punchali from The Monkey and the Princess.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, I tried to watch that online, but they wanted a credit card.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a children’s story.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, no it isn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: When I was a little boy and got sick, which was most of the time, my mother would read it to me. It’s about an Indian princess who befriends a monkey, who was mocked by all the other monkeys because he was different. For some reason I related to it quite strongly.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I know the reason.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We all know the reason. Sheldon, what are you getting at?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That woman looks exactly like the pictures of Princess Punchali in the book. How often does one see a beloved fictional character come to life?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Every year at Comic Con. Every day at Disneyland you can hire Snow White to come to your house. Course they prefer it if you have a kid, but…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey guys. This is Lalita Gupta, Lalita this is Leonard and Sheldon and Howard and Penny. Isn’t it great, she isn’t fat any more!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Forgive me your highness, for I am but a monkey, and it is in my nature to climb. I did not mean to gaze upon you as you comb your hair.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: I’m sorry?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You are the living embodiment of the beautiful Princess Punchali.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Oh, no kidding? Oh, who is that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A beloved character from an Indian folk tale.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Oh. Us Indian, or “come to our casino” Indian?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You Indian.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The resemblance is remarkable. I can practically smell the lotus blossoms woven into your ebony hair.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Thanks. I imagine you smell very nice too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I shower twice a day and wash my hands as often as I can.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Really, so do I.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But you’re a dentist, he’s nuts.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Don’t be insulting Rajesh. So, Sheldon, tell me more about this princess you say I look like.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It was said that the Gods fashioned her eyes out of the stars, and that roses were ashamed to bloom in the presence of her ruby lips.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Oh my.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Back off Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: If you do not stop hitting on my lady you will feel the full extent of my wrath.

Dialogue: I’m not hitting on her.
