Dialogue: And I am not your lady.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And you have no wrath.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You are my lady. Our parents said so. We are for all intents and purposes one hundred percent hooked up.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Okay, let’s get something straight here. The only reason I came tonight was to get my parents off my case, I certainly don’t need to be getting this old world crap from you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Exactly the kind of spirit with which Princess Punchali led the monkeys to freedom.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, screw Princess Punchali.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Hey, you can’t talk to me like that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But you’re not Princess Punchali.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Luckily for you, she could have you beheaded.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you hungry?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I could eat.

Speaker: Lalita
Dialogue: Let’s go.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What just happened?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Beats the hell out of me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ll tell you what just happened, I just learned how to pick up Indian chicks.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: What are we supposed to say to Lalita’s parents?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: I play golf with her father, I won’t be able to look at him.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe you should keep your eye on the ball, Papa.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Oh, now you’re a funny man? This is not funny, Mr Funny Man.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Doctor and Mrs Koothrappali, in all fairness, it wasn’t entirely Raj’s fault.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: This is a family matter Sheldon.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I’m Leonard.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Oh, sorry, you all look alike to us.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But he’s right, Papa, listen to him.(Sheldon enters)You! You are the one who ruined everything!

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Who is it? We can’t see.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Turn us, turn us.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Go ahead, tell my parents why they won’t have any grandchildren.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How would I know, do you have a low sperm count?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This has nothing to do with my sperm count.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: You are wearing the boxers that we sent you, aren’t you Rajesh.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes Mommy.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Because you know what happens to the samosas when you wear the tidy whities.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can we please stop talking about my testicles? Sheldon, tell them what you did.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What did I do?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You left with his date. Friends don’t do that to each other.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Alright, noted. Sorry.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry? That’s all you can say is sorry?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Take it, Raj. It’s more than I’ve ever gotten.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And may I point out she wouldn’t have asked me to go with her if you hadn’t been drunk and boring.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Drunk?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And boring, her words.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: I knew it, he moves to America and becomes an alcoholic.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m not an alcoholic.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Then why were you drunk?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It was just this one time, Papa, I swear.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Are you in denial? Do we have to come over and do an intervention?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Mrs Koothrappali
Dialogue: Don’t embarrass him in front of his friends.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Alright. Carry us outside, we want to talk to you in private.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But Papa, please….

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Now, Rajesh.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj(to Leonard and Sheldon)
Dialogue: I have to go.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Dr Koothrappali
Dialogue: Now listen to me….

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Please wait until I get into the hall.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, well, good night.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hold on. What happened with you and Lalita?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We ate. She lectured me on the link between gum disease and heart attacks, nothing I didn’t already know, and I came home.

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So you’re not going to see her again?

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would I see her again? I already have a dentist.(Exits)

Scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I wonder who’s going to tell his parents they’re not having grandchildren.

Scene: Penny’s restaurant. Sheldon is on the piano, singing “To Life” from Fiddler on the Roof enthusiastically.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t believe it, what’s gotten into him?

Scene: Penny’s restaurant. Sheldon is on the piano, singing “To Life” from Fiddler on the Roof enthusiastically.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, maybe a couple of virgin cuba libres that turned out to be kind of slutty.

Scene: Penny’s restaurant. Sheldon is on the piano, singing “To Life” from Fiddler on the Roof enthusiastically.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You didn’t?

Scene: Penny’s restaurant. Sheldon is on the piano, singing “To Life” from Fiddler on the Roof enthusiastically.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, you do your experiments, I do mine.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, the X10s are online.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I am now about to send a signal from this laptop through our local ISP, racing down fibre-optic cable at the speed of light to San Francisco, bouncing off a satellite in geosynchronous orbit to Lisbon, Portugal, where the data packets will be handed off to submerged transatlantic cables terminating in Halifax, Nova-Scotia, and transferred across the continent via microwave relays back to our ISP and the X10 receiver attached to this(clicks mouse, lamp switches on)lamp.(The others cheer and clap).

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look at me, look at me, I’ve got goosebumps.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Are we ready on the stereo?

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Go for stereo.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Dialogue: (Howard clicks mouse again. Also Sprach Zarathustra begins to play. At the climactic notes, the four jump in the air and begin pretend conducting or jumping about in time to the music.)

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Hey guys.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: All(calming down, embarrassed)
Dialogue: Hello.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s a little loud.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No problem, turning it down.(Using mouse again)San Francisco, Lisbon, Halifax(the music gets quieter)et voila.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, thanks.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hang on, hang on, do you not realise what we just did.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, you turned your stereo down with your laptop.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, we turned our stereo down by sending a signal around the world via the internet.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh. You know you can just get one of those universal remotes at Radio Shack, they’re really cheap.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, no, you don’t get it, um, Howard, enable public access.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Public access enabled.(They all stare around for a moment in silence.)

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Boy, that’s brilliant, but I’ll see you.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, hang on, hang on.(The lamp goes off and on again.)See!

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Someone in Sezchuan province, China is using his computer to turn our lights on and off.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Huh, well that’s handy. Um, here’s a question, why?

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: All together
Dialogue: Because we can.(There is a loud noise)

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They found the remote controlled cars.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, wait, wait, what’s on top of them.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wireless webcams, wave hello.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The monster truck is out of Austin, Texas, and the blue Viper is being operated from suburban Tel Aviv.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You may want to put on slacks.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?(Seeing red car is trying to get between her legs)Ew, stop it, no, leave me alone.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who’s running the red Corvette?

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That would be me.

Scene: The apartment, Leonard is attaching something to a lamp.
Dialogue: Credits sequence

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, in the future, when we’re disembodied brains in jars, we’re going to look back on this as eight hours well wasted.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t want to be in a jar. I want my brain in an android body. Eight feet tall and ripped.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m with you. I just have to make sure if I’m a synthetic human I’d still be Jewish. I promised my mother.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I suppose you could have your android penis circumcised. But that’s something your Rabbi would have to discuss with the manufacturers.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not to mention you’d have to power down on Saturdays.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, why is this letter in the trash?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, there’s always the possibility that a trash can spontaneously formed around the letter, but Occam’s Razor would suggest that someone threw it out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s from the Institute for Experimental Physics. They want us to present our paper on the properties of super solids at the topical conference on Bowes-Einstein condensates.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know. I read it before I threw it out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay… if I may drill down to the bedrock of my question, why did you throw it out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because I have no interest in standing in the Rose Room of the Pasadena Marriott in front of a group of judgemental strangers, who wouldn’t recognise true genius if it were standing in front of them giving a speech. Which, if I were there, it would be.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know, Sheldon, those topical conferences on Bowes-Einstein condensates parties are legendary.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Forget the parties.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Forget the parties? What a nerd.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are there any other honours I’ve gotten that I don’t know about? Did UPS drop off a Nobel Prize with my name on it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, please don’t take this the wrong way, but the day you win a Nobel Prize, is the day I begin my research on the drag co-efficient of tassles on flying carpets.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hoo-hoo-hoo. The only thing missing from that insult was “yo mamma.”

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ve got one, hey Leonard, your mamma’s research methodology is so flawed….

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Shut up, Howard. Sheldon, we have to do this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No we don’t. We have to take in nourishment, expel waste, and inhale enough oxygen to keep ourselves from dying, everything else is optional.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, let me put it this way, I’m doing it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can’t. I’m the lead author.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, come on. The only reason you’re the lead author is because we went alphabetically.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I let you think we went alphabetically to spare you the humiliation of dealing with the fact that it was my idea. Not to put too fine a point on it, but I was throwing you a bone. You’re welcome.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me, I designed the experiment that proved the hypothesis.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It doesn’t need proving.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So the entire scientific community is just supposed to take your word?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They’re not supposed to, but they should.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, I don’t care what you say, I’m going to the conference and I’m presenting our findings.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And I forbid it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You forbid it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I’m not taking credit for our work then nobody is.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, you admit that it’s our work.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, once again, I’m throwing you a bone. And once again, you are welcome.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ah!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh no he dit’nt!

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, how’s it going with Sheldon, are you guys still not talking to each other?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not only is he still not talking to me, but there’s this thing he does where he stares at you and tries to get your brain to explode. You know, like in the classic sci-fi movie Scanners?(Put’s fingers to head)You know, bzzz-pchew! Never mind. How about this one. It says, “I know my physics, but I’m still a fun guy!”

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hey, I didn’t know they still made corduroy suits!

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They don’t, that’s why I saved this one.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, well, let’s just see what else you have. Okay, here, take this, and this, and this, and these.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is this all stuff you want me to try on?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, this is stuff I want you to throw out.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Seriously, don’t even give it to charity, you won’t be helping anyone. What’s this.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, that’s the bottled city of Kandor.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You see, Kandor was the capital city of the planet Krypton, it was miniaturised by Brainiac before Krypton exploded and then rescued by Superman.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, nice.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s a lot cooler when girls aren’t looking at it.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Here, why don’t you put these on while I find a shirt and sport-coat to match.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great, be right back.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, where you going, just put them on.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, are you shy?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I’m not shy.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Don’t worry, I won’t look.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know you won’t look, why would you look, there’s nothing to see, well, not nothing….

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sweetie, put the pants on.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Putting them on.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, you know, isn’t there maybe some way you and Sheldon could compromise on this whole presentation thing.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. No. Scientists do not compromise. Our minds are trained to synthesise facts and come to inarguable conclusions. Not to mention, Sheldon is batcrap crazy.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What is this?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, careful. That’s my original series Battlestar Galactica flight suit.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, why didn’t you wear it at Halloween?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because it’s not a costume, it’s a flight suit.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, alright, moving on, oh, wow, a paisley shirt.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh-huh, it goes with my corduroy suit.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: If you mean it should end up in the same place then, I agree. Is this your… your only tie?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ah. Technically yes, but, if you’ll notice, it’s reversible. So it works as two.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, sweetie, I don’t think it even works as one. Is this all your clothes?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Everything since the eighth grade.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: The… the eighth grade?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: My last growth spurt.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, well, I guess we’re back to the corduroy suit.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Penny is looking through his closet.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yup.(Leonard picks up paisley shirt)I said no, put it down.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey Sheldon!

Speaker: Sheldon(unlocking his mailbox)
Dialogue: Hello Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Get anything good?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, just the latest copy of Applied Particle Physics Quarterly.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, you know, that is so weird that yours came and mine didn’t.(Sheldon looks confused).It was a joke.(Sheldon gives a fake laugh.)Yup, tip your waitresses, I’m here all week.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny, just to save you from further awkwardness know that I’m perfectly comfortable with the two of us climbing the stairs in silence.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh yeah, me too. Zip it, lock it.(The begin to climb)Put it in your pocket. So you and Leonard…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh dear God!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Little misunderstanding, huh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A little misunder…. Galileo and the Pope had a little misunderstanding.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Anyway, I was talking to Leonard this morning and I think he feels really bad about it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Huh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well how do you feel?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand the question.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well I’m just asking if it’s difficult to be fighting with your best friend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. I hadn’t thought about it like that. I wonder if I’ve been experiencing physiological manifestations of some sort of unconscious emotional turmoil.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait… what?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I couldn’t poop this morning.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You should just talk to him, I’m sure you guys can work this out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s certainly preferable to my plan.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Which was?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A powerful laxative.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so you absolutely should talk to him, look, I know Leonard values you as a friend, and he told me himself that without your little idea there’s no way he could have come up with this whole experiment thing.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, little idea?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I mean he tried to explain it to me, I didn’t really understand it but…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course you didn’t, he said little idea?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, well no, no, not in… not in those words.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In what words then, exactly

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, gee, the exact words aren’t written… it’s more the spirit in which it’s

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You had a lucky hunch.

Speaker: Leonard(coming out of apartment)
Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon, I’ve been thinking, instead of arguing about this why don’t….

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t you ever speak to me again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What…(Sheldon goes into apartment and slams the door).

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, he…(makes “he’s screwy” hand movements, turns to go).

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, I’m leaving for the conference.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Have fun presenting my lucky hunch.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon I didn’t mean it like that.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then why did you say it.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know, I wasn’t choosing my…

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Were you trying to impress Penny?

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no not at all. A little bit.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How’d that work out for you?

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Leonard, ready to go?

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Libido 1, truth zero.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, I’m going to ask you one more time, we did the work together, lets present the paper together.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And I’m telling you for the last time it’s pandering, it’s undignified and bite me.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let’s go.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Bye Sheldon.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed in the corduroy suit.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Goodbye Penny.(Places fingers to head to try to make Leonard’s brain explode. Leonard leaves.)Oooh, one of these days, Pkshhhh!

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: There you go.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, this side does look better.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, no, I didn’t say better, I said less stained.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I just checked the house, there’s probably twenty, twenty-five people in there.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re kidding.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is that all?

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: All? In particle physics, twenty five is Woodstock.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, well, then good!

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I wasn’t expecting such a crowd, I’m a little nervous.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s okay, just open with a joke, you’ll be fine.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: A joke. Okay. How about this, um, okay, uh there’s this farmer, and he has these chickens, but they won’t lay any eggs. So, he calls a physicist to help. The physicist then does some calculations, and he says, um, I have a solution, but it only works with spherical chickens in a vacuum.(Raj and Howard laugh.)Right?

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, sorry, I’ve just, I’ve heard it before.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let’s roll. Hey, nice suit.

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s a classic, right?

Scene: A corridor at the conference. Penny is attaching Leonard’s name tag.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I really should have brought my own car.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, in conclusion, the data show that at temperatures approaching absolute zero, the moment of inertia changes, and the solid becomes a super-solid, which clearly appears to be a previously unknown state of matter.(Applause)Thank you.(Penny is asleep on Howard’s shoulder. Howard is taking a photograph with his camera phone.)Are there any questions?

Speaker: Voice
Dialogue: Yeah. What the hell was that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Any other questions?

Speaker: Sheldon(who previously spoke, now removing his hood and dark glasses)
Dialogue: Doctor Sheldon Cooper here, I am the lead author of this particular paper.(No reaction.)Thank you. And you, sir, you have completely skipped over the part where I was walking through the park, and I saw these children on a merry-go-round, which started me thinking about the moment of inertia in gasses like helium at temperatures approaching absolute zero.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t skip it, it’s just an anecdote. It’s not science.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I see, was the apple falling on Newton’s head, was that just an anecdote?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You are not Isaac Newton.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no that’s true, gravity would have been apparent to me without the apple.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You cannot possibly be that arrogant.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You continue to underestimate me, my good man.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, if you weren’t happy with my presentation then maybe you should have given it with me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: As I have explained repeatedly, unlike you, I don’t need validation from lesser minds. No offence.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really, so why did you come?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because I knew you’d screw this up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t screw it up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, please. I admit, that spherical chicken joke, that was hilarious. But it was straight downhill from there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ve had enough of your condescension. Maybe I didn’t go to college when I was eleven like you, maybe I got my doctorate at 24 instead of 16, but you are not the only person who is smarter than everyone else in this room. No offense. And I am clearly not the only person who is tormented by insecurity and has an ego in need of constant validation.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So you admit that you’re an egotist?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.(To audience)My name is Dr Leonard Hofstadter, and I could never please my parents so I need to get all my self-esteem from strangers like you. But he’s worse.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, that is it.(Tries to explode brain again.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You cannot blow up my head with your mind.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then I’ll settle for an aneurysm.

Speaker: Leonard(knocking his hands down)
Dialogue: Stop it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You hit me. You saw him, he hit me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You were trying to blow up my head.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So it was working.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It wasn’t, it was not, you are a nutcase.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh we’ll see about that(tries again),heads up you people in the front row, this is a splash zone.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Stop, stop it, quit it.(The start to fight.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is this usually how these physics things go?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: More often than you’d think.

Speaker: Leonard(getting Sheldon on floor)
Dialogue: Vulcan nerve pinch!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You could have offered me a ride home.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re lucky I didn’t run you over.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I really don’t understand what you’re so unhappy about, you begged me to come, I came, there’s just no pleasing you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, I’m the problem, I’m the one that needs help.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well that’s not much of an apology, but I’ll take it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me. Is there anything you’d like to apologise for?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I’m sorry I tried to blow up your head. It was uncalled for.

Speaker: Howard(entering with Raj)
Dialogue: You won’t believe this.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Somebody got the whole thing on a cell phone and put it on youtube.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now, who would do that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That would be me. Hey, check it out, it’s a featured video.(The watch).

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh jeez. Is this suit really look that bad?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Forget your suit, look at my arms waving, I’m like a flamingo on Ritalin.

Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Howard, would you like to explain to me why your facebook page has a picture of me sleeping on your shoulder captioned “Me and my Girlfriend?”

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh-oh, here comes “the talk.”
Penny tries to make Howard’s brain explode.

Scene: Captioned “Somewhere in China”, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
Speaker: Student one(in captions)
Dialogue: What losers.

Scene: Captioned “Somewhere in China”, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
Speaker: Student two
Dialogue: Yeah. Gigantic American geeks.(The lights flicker)

Scene: Captioned “Somewhere in China”, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
Speaker: Student one
Dialogue: Who’s doing that?

Scene: Captioned “Somewhere in China”, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
Speaker: Student two
Dialogue: Someone from Pasadena, California named… “Wolowizard.”

Scene: Captioned “Somewhere in China”, two Chinese students watch the video on their computer.
Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Awesome!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: See, the liquid metal Terminators were created in the future by Skynet, and Skynet was developed by Miles Dyson, but that future no longer exists, due to Dyson’s death in Terminator 2.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, then riddle me this. Assuming all the good Terminators were originally evil Terminators created by Skynet but then reprogrammed by the future John Connor, why would Skynet, an artificial computer intelligence, bother to create a petite hot 17 year-old killer robot?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Skynet is kinky? I don’t know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Artificial intelligences do not have teen fetishes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, oh wait, they use it to in…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Buzzing noise),too late, I win.

Speaker: Penny(voice off, singing, quite tunelessly)
Dialogue: Let’s go-oh-oh Ou-oooo-ut tonight. I have to go-oh-oh-oh ou-ooooo-ut tonight.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What the hell is that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t know, but if cats could sing, they’d hate it too.(The continue up the stairs and disappear from view).

Speaker: Penny(still singing off)
Dialogue: You wanna prowl, be my night owl,(Leonard and Sheldon reappear, running down the stairs)we’ll take my…(appearing)Hey guys, hi! Where you going?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What? Oh we just had to… mail some letters and(seeing Sheldon has large bag in hand and bin is nearby)throw away some chicken.(Sheldon very reluctantly does.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’ll never guess what just happened.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I give up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t guess. As a scientist I reach conclusions based on observation and experimentation, although as I’m saying this it occurs to me you may have been employing a rhetorical device rendering my response moot.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Believe it or not, personal growth. What happened?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, remember when I auditioned for that workshop production of Rent, but I didn’t get it and I couldn’t figure out why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have a conclusion based on an observation.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No you don’t. No he doesn’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, the girl they picked to play Mimi, she dropped out and they asked me to replace her.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, congratulations, what a lucky break.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s not a big deal, just a one night showcase, but they invite a lot of casting people and agents so, you never know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think I know.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No you don’t. He doesn’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s this Friday at eight, you guys want to come?

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because…. uh, Friday, we are attending a symposium on molecular positronium.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think that’s a week from Tuesday at six.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, it’s this Friday, at eight.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, too bad, well, I got to get to rehearsal, see you guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: See you.(Penny exits singing)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You just lied to Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, I did.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And you did it so casually, no rapid breathing, no increase in perspiration.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, lack of a physiological response while lying is characteristic of a violent sociopath.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you worried about your safety.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I imagine if you were going to kill me you’d have done it a long time ago.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s very true.
Leonard exits. Sheldon looks worried for a moment, then retrieves the chicken from the bin and follows.
Credits sequence

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need to speak to you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s two o’clock in the morning

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s important.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I highly doubt that. Go away.(Long pause).Are you still out there?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard(opening door)
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re right, it can wait until morning.

Speaker: Leonard(following Sheldon into living room)
Dialogue: What, what, what, what, what?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Never mind. I clearly woke you up in the middle of a REM cycle, you’re in no state to talk.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, what is it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m uncomfortable having been included in your lie to Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What was I supposed to say.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You could have told her the truth.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That would have hurt her feelings.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is that a relevant factor?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then I suppose you could have agreed to go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And what would I have said afterwards?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I would suggest something to the effect of, singing is neither an appropriate vocation nor avocation for you, and if you disagree, I’d recommend you have a CAT scan, to look for a tumour pressing on the cognitive processing centre of your brain.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I couldn’t say that, I would have to say, you were terrific and I can’t wait to hear you sing again.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s the social protocol, it’s what you do when you have a friend who’s proud of something they really suck at.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was not aware of that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well now you are.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, alright. Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: When we played chess earlier, you were terrific and I can’t wait to play you again. Goodnight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)…..

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oooaw. This would be so much easier if I were a violent sociopath.(Opening door)What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was analysing our lie, and I believe we’re in danger of Penny seeing through the ruse.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Simple. If she were to log on to
www.socalphysicsgroup.org/activities/other

, click on upcoming events, scroll down to seminars, download the pdf schedule, and look for the seminar on molecular positronium, well then, bippidy-boppidy-boo, our pants are metaphorically on fire.
Leonard closes door.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, sir, my trousers will not be igniting today.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock, knock)Penny,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Penny,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Penny,(door opens)Good morning.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you have any idea what time it is?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course I do. My watch is linked to the atomic clock in Boulder, Colorado. It’s accurate to one tenth of a second. But as I’m saying this it occurs to me that once again your question may have been rhetorical.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Remember how Leonard told you we couldn’t come to your performance because we were attending a symposium on molecular positronium?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I remember symposium.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, well, he lied.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, what?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He lied, and I’m feeling very uncomfortable about it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well imagine how I’m feeling.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hungry? Tired? I’m sorry this really isn’t my strong suit.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You told her I lied, why would you tell her I lied?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: To help you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I’m not seeing the help.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She was going to see through your lie eventually, so I told her that you were lying to protect me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I’m getting a bad feeling.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hunger? Indigestion, I’m sorry I’m really not very good at this. Anyway, Penny now believes that on Friday night, we’re going to participate in my cousin Leopold’s drug intervention.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Your cousin Leopold?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yea, who most people call Leo, but he also answers to Lee, remember that, it’s important.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s important?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Details, Leonard, the success or failure of our deceitful enterprise turns on details.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do you have a cousin Leopold.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I made him up. I think you’d call him Lee.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t get it, I already told her a lie, why replace it with a different lie?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, first of all, your lie was laughably transparent, where mine is exquisitely convoluted. While you were sleeping I was weaving an un-unravelable web.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Un-unravelable?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, if she googles Leopold Houston she’ll find a facebook page, an online blog depicting his descent into drug use, and a desperate yet hopeful listing on e-harmony.com.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, why would I go to a drug intervention for your cousing.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ah, because it’s in Long Beach, and I don’t drive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’re going to Long Beach?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, of course not, there’s no cousin Leo, there’s no intervention, focus Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, come on!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We just leave the house on Friday night, and we return in the wee hours emotionally wrung out from the work of convincing Leo to go back into rehab.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So he goes back into rehab?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but, he can relapse if Penny ever invites us to go hear her sing again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You still told her I lied.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: For a noble purpose, to spare me the social embarrassment of having a drug-addled first cousin, which I’m assuming is embarrassing, yes?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know. How am I supposed to remember all of this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s the best part, you don’t have to, see I told Penny that you would be embarrassed, if you knew that she found out that you had lied, so she’s agreed to operate as if the original lie was still in force.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So she’s expecting me to lie about going to a symposium in Pasadena, when in actuality we’re pretending to go to a drug intervention in Long Beach?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Un-unravelable.

Speaker: Leonard(opening door)
Dialogue: Oh hey Penny, wow, look at you, all ready for your showcase, you look great.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thanks. I just wanted to come by and wish you guys luck with your symposium.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, well, thankyou.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, I got to tell you, a lot of friends would let their friend go alone, but that’s not who you are, you are the kind of guy who stands by a friend when… when he has a symposium to go to.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know what to say.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s okay, Leonard(hugs him.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, okay, alright, good.

Speaker: Howard(arriving)
Dialogue: Oh boy, group hug.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh-huh!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh-huh?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh-huh!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay. So what’s up?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, uh, Penny is on her way to perform in a one night showcase production of Rent, which we are unable to attend because we are going to a symposium on molecular positronium, given by Dr Emile Farminfarmian.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Farminfarmian is speaking and you’re Bogarding the symposium.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, I’m sorry… we’re… we’re

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, no, you’re quark-blocking us.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know what to say.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, listen…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, it’s okay, it’s your Millenium Falcon, you and Chewbacca do whatever you want to do. Me and Princess Leia here will find some other way to spend the evening.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Howard, wait. Sheldon, I think we should tell them.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, sure. I don’t see a problem with that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: There’s no symposium, Leonard lied to me, isn’t that right Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well… I don’t know what to say.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s okay, I do, look, Leonard is helping Sheldon through a family crisis, he made up the whole story about the symposium with Dr Farmin..farm…ian

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good for you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hah, yeah! Because he didn’t want Sheldon to be embarrassed, and there is nothing to be embarrassed okay, every family in America has a relative holed up in a garage somewhere huffing paint thinner.

Speaker: Howard(after Raj whispers in his ear)
Dialogue: No, I’m lost too, I think she skipped a step.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, look, Sheldon’s cousin Leo escaped rehab, and he’s in a Motel 8 at Long Beach, the whole family’s going out for an intervention. Leonard is driving Sheldon down there to help him through this because he’s such a good man.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, another hug, thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright you guys, good luck.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks Penny.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, uh, break a leg.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Break a leg.(She leaves)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, road trip to Long Beach.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, we’re not going to Long Beach.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because Sheldon doesn’t have a drug addicted cousin Leopold.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, too bad. I’ve always wanted to go to Long Beach.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a very nice community. The Queen Mary is docked there, once the largest ocean liner in the world, it’s now a hotel and restaurant where they host a surprisingly gripping murder mystery dinner.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sounds fun.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m game.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Shotgun.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, no, Leonard gets nauseous unless he sits in front, and even then it’s iffy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait, are we really going to Long Beach?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard,(Knock, knock, knock, knock)Leonard…

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let it go, Sheldon, the murderer was the first mate whether it makes sense to you or not.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, that’s the least of our worries. I’ve been doing some research on addiction, both the biochemical and behavioural aspects, and I think there’s a problem with the current version of our lie.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you talking about, it’s fine, she bought it, it’s over.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sadly, it’s not. Substance abuse is a lifelong struggle, but beyond that I have realised that the Leo I described would not have agreed to go to rehab.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why not?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because Leo is a middle child.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There is no Leo, how can you say that?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You didn’t read the bio, did you? He’s not just a middle child, he’s the quintessential middle child, from a broken home to boot. Psychologically speaking, the attention he gets by rebelling even to the point of self-destruction is more emotionally valuable than the help he would get at rehab.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ve got a solution.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Great, what is it?

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Get out.

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. The bedside table is piled with Queen Mary memorabilia.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine.(He leaves. A moment later he comes back.)I’ve hesitated to point this out, but I must now remind you that we are in our current predicament because of your initial and totally inadequate deceit. I’m just trying to clean up after your mess.(Leonard throws a glass ornament at him. He just manages to shut the door in time.)We’ll talk in the morning.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Strange man
Dialogue: Morning.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who are you?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Man
Dialogue: I am Sheldon’s cousin Leo.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, God! Sheldon does not have a cousin Leo.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Au contraire. I’m 26 years old, I’m originally from(reads off crib notes)Denton, Texas, but I was a Navy brat so I was brought up on a variety of military bases around the world, as a result I’ve often felt like an outsider, never really fitting in, which is probably the reason for my substance abuse problem.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, we just went over this. As the quintessential middle child, your addiction is rooted in your unmet need for attention.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Oh, Sheldon, are we really going to go with pop psychology.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: For your information, this is all based on solid research, stick with the character profile I wrote for you.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry, Leonard, this is Toby Loobenfeld, he’s a research assistant in the particle physics lab, but he also minored in theatre at MIT.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: It was more of a double major actually. Theatre and physics. You can guess which one my bourgeois parents pushed me towards.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I got it, Sheldon, why?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, you see, while Leo would not have gone into rehab, it is completely plausible that we would have talked him into leaving the motel, and coming home with us.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh…!

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Sheldon, how about this as my motivation. When I was fourteen years old I was abused in the Philippines by a club footed Navy chaplain.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. We’re going with middle child, and a generic predisposition to inadequate serotonin production.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Swell, how do I play genetic predisposition?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Subtextually, of course.(There is a knock on the door.)Just have fun with it.(Opening door.)Morning Penny.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi. How did the intervention go.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Unfortunately, we weren’t able to convince him to go to rehab.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, based on what you told me, I’m not surprised.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But we did convince him to leave the motel. Come say hello. Leo, this is Penny, our friend and neighbour.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi Leo, how are you feeling?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Let me ask you something, Penny. Have you ever woken up in a fleabag motel, covered in your own vomit, next to a transsexual prostitute?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Then don’t ask me how I’m feeling.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, that’s Leo. Hey, um, why don’t you tell me about your showcase last night?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, it was okay I guess, wasn’t a big turn out but they both really seemed to like it.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There were only two people there?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: By the end. Yeah.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Damn you, Chaplain Horrigan!

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m… I’m sorry.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: The Philippines. 1992. The Subic Bay Naval Station. A young boy on the cusp of manhood. His only companions mongrel dogs and malarial mosquitos. Desperate and alone he reached out to a man who promised to introduce him to a merciful, loving God, but who instead introduced him to a gin pickled tongue shoved down his adolescent throat. What choice did he have but to drink, shoot and snort his pain away.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t forget his genetic predisposition towards addiction.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: That’s never been proven.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There have been studies.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: Not double blind studies.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How could there be a double blind study, who would be the control group.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: As you can see, detoxing can get pretty ugly, let’s give them some privacy.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Hey, do you want to come over to my place, have coffee?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sounds good.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I have a video of me singing last night, do you want to see it?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Gee, why wouldn’t I?

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is even better than you coming to the showcase, because now I get to watch you watch me.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah! Funny how things work out.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: And that he loved the companionship and the wisdom that his own father failed to provide.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Your parents made the right decision.

Scene: The living room. Leonard enters in his dressing gown. There is a strange man eating cereal at the kitchen table.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: I cannot work like this!

Scene: The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: This is amazing. Just sitting on a couch, watching TV with a woman. Not being drunk, or high, or… or… wondering if you’re a dude down there.

Scene: The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leo, you are a very sweet, really funny guy. You’re gonna do okay.

Scene: The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
Speaker: Toby
Dialogue: One day at a time, Penny, one day at a time.

Scene: The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How long is he going to stay here.

Scene: The apartment. Penny is on the sofa with Toby. They are watching TV.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s a homeless drug addict, Leonard, where is he going to go? Boy, you have a lot to learn about lying.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Checkmate.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.

He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, better than North Dakota!(Pause)I guess that joke’s only funny in Nebraska.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: From the data at hand you really can’t draw that conclusion. All you can say with absolute certainty is that that joke is not funny here.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon(running to opposite side of the room)
Dialogue: What kind of sick?

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, the flu I guess.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t need you to guess, I need you to know, now when did the symptoms first appear?

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Maybe Friday.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.

Dialogue: Friday, was that morning or afternoon?

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I… I don’t…

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Think woman, who blew their nose and when?

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, relax, she doesn’t have any symptoms, I’m sure she’s not contagious.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh please, if influenza was only contagious after symptoms appear it would have died out thousands of years ago. Somewhere between tool using and cave painting, homo habilus would have figured out to kill the guy with the runny nose.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny, you’ll have to excuse Sheldon, he’s a bit of a germophobe.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, it’s okay, I understand.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thanks for your consideration, now please leave.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’d better go before he starts spraying you with Lysol.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, well, thank you for getting my mail.

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No problem. Welcome home.(Sees Penny out. Turns to find Sheldon spraying the air with Lysol.)

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The living room of the apartment. Leonard and Sheldon are playing the three dimensional chess game from the original Star Trek series. It is Leonard’s move. He takes his time, moving round the board and checking things from various angles. Finally he tentatively makes a move. Sheldon moves almost immediately.
Dialogue: Credits sequence

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m making petrie dishes to grow throat cultures.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: With lime jello?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need a growth medium, and someone polished off the apricot yoghurt. Here, swab my throat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t think so.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard! If I’m going to get ahead of this thing I need to find out what’s growing in my throat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you are not sick. This is, but you are not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We have no idea what pathogen Typhoid Penny has introduced into our environment. And having never been to Nebraska I’m fairly certain that I have no cornhusking antibodies.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, don’t you think you’re overreacting?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: When I’m lying comatose in a hospital relying on inferior minds to cure me, these jello cultures and my accompanying notes will give them a fighting chance.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m going back to bed.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait.(Handing him a measuring jug)Put this in the bathroom.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need to measure my fluid intake and output to make sure my kidneys aren’t shutting down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I mix pancake batter in this!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, that measuring cup has always been for urine.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You had time to make a label for everything in this apartment, including the label maker, but you didn’t have ten seconds to make one that said urine cup?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s right here on the bottom.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Huh. I guess I owe the Betty Crocker company a letter of apology.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, dear God.(Shouting)Leonard! Leonard, I’m sick!

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Dialogue: Cut to Leonard entering living room in panic, stumbling and trying to put on a pair of trousers.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon(voice off)
Dialogue: Leonard! Leonard I’m sick!

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Dialogue: Leonard grabs jacket and leaves through front door.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon(entering, wrapped in duvet)
Dialogue: Leonard! Leonard! Leonard. Leonard, my comforter fell down, and my sinuses hurt when I bend over. Leonard?(Bends to get phone)Ow!

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard(voice on phone)
Dialogue: Hey.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, where are you?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard(running down stairs)
Dialogue: I’m at work.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: At six-thirty in the morning?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: On Sunday?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They asked me to come in.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I didn’t hear the phone ring.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They texted me.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, as I predicted, I am sick. My fever has been tracking up exponentially since 2am, and I am producing sputum at an alarming rate.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No kidding?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. Not only that, it has shifted from clear to milky green.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, well, get some rest and drink plenty of fluids.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What else would I drink? Gasses? Solids? Ionised plasma?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Drink whatever you want.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want soup.
