Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then make soup.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We don’t have soup.

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m at work, Sheldon.(A woman enters the apartment building with a barking dog.)

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is that a dog?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes,

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In the lab?

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon wakes up and coughs. Picks up an electronic thermometer and takes his temperature.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, they’re training dogs to operate the centrifuge for when they need dogs to operate the centrifuge for blind scientists, I have to go.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother(voice)
Dialogue: Howard, it’s the phone.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know it’s the phone, Ma, I hear the phone.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Well who’s calling at this ungodly hour?

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Well ask them why they’re calling at this ungodly hour.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How can I ask them when I’m talking to you!(Into phone)Hello.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, it’s Leonard, code Milky Green.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Dear Lord, not Milky Green!

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Affirmative, with fever.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Who’s on the phone.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s Leonard.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Why is he calling.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon’s sick.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Were you playing with him?

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: For God’s sake, Ma, I’m twenty six years old.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: Excuse me Mr Grown-up. Whadda-ya want for breakfast.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Chocolate milk and eggoes please!

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, listen to me.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hang on, call waiting.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard(voice)
Dialogue: No, don’t, don’t….

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hello.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard, I’m sick.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard(imitating his mother’s voice)
Dialogue: Howard’s sleeping, this is his mother. Why are you calling at this ungodly hour?

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I need soup.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Then call your own mother.(To Leonard)It was Sheldon.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I tried to stop you.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s my own fault, I forgot the protocol we put in place after the great ear infection of ’06.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You call Koothrappali, we need to find a place to lay low for the next eighteen to twenty four hours.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Stand by. Ma, can my friends come over?

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard’s Mother
Dialogue: I just had the carpets steamed.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s a negatory. But there’s a Planet of the Apes marathon at the New Art today.

Scene: Howard’s bedroom. The phone is ringing.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Five movies, two hours apiece. It’s a start.

Speaker: Waitress
Dialogue: Homeless crazy guy at table eighteen.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, just crazy. Sheldon, what are you doing here?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sick, thank you very much.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How could you have gotten it from me, I’m not sick.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re a carrier. All these people here are doomed. You’re doomed!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Shhh! Sheldon, what do you want.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want soup.

Speaker: Penny(over Sheldon’s strange throat clearance)
Dialogue: Why didn’t you just….(louder throat clearance)Why didn’t you just have soup at home.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny, I have an IQ of 187, don’t you imagine that if there were a way for me to have had soup at home I would have thought of it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You can have soup delivered.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I did not think of that. Clearly febrile delirium is setting in, please bring me some soup while I still understand what a spoon is for.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, what kind of soup do you want.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, my mother used to make me this split pea with little frankfurter slices and these home made croutons.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We have Chicken Tortilla and Potato Leek.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can I get any of those with little frankfurter slices and home made croutons?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then surprise me.(Blows nose into handkerchief. Shows it to next table)Would you call that moss green or forest green?

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look at this, everyone went chimp.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well I’d like to point out, I voted for orang-utan, but you shouted me down.(Phone rings).

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, hi Penny!

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, where are you?

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m… uh… at work.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You sound funny.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m… uh… in a… I’m in a radiation suit. What’s up?

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, well I’m at work too, and you’ll never guess who’s here infecting my entire station.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard(To Howard and Raj)
Dialogue: Sheldon’s at the Cheesecake Factory.(Into phone)Just tell him to go home.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He won’t leave, he says he’s afraid he’ll pass out on the bus and someone will harvest his organs.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard(To Howard and Raj)
Dialogue: He’s paranoid, and he’s established a nest.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Can you please come get him?

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, yeah, I’d be… I’d be happy to Penny.(Holds phone up, Howard makes warning siren noises)Oh my God there’s a breech in the radiation unit(Raj joins in)The whole city is in jeopardy, oh my God, Professor Googenfeil is melting, gotta go, bye!(To Howard and Raj)I feel really guilty.

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You did what you had to do.(Steals some of Howard’s popcorn)

Scene: The cinema. Everyone is wearing ape masks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Take your stinking paws off my popcorn you damn dirty ape.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thanks for bringing me home.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, it’s okay, I didn’t really need to work today, it’s not like I have rent or car payments or anything.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good. Good.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, well, you feel better.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait, where are you going?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, home, to write some bad cheques.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re going to leave me?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, you are a grown man, haven’t you ever been sick before?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, of course, but, not by myself.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, never?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, once. When I was fifteen, and spending the summer at the Heidelberg Institute in Germany.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Studying abroad?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, visiting professor. Anyway, the local cuisine was a little more sausage-based than I’m used to, and the result was an internal blitzkrieg with my lower intestine playing the part of Czechoslovakia.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And there was no-one there to take care of you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. No, my mum had to fly back to Texas to help my dad because the house had slipped off the cinderblocks again.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Again?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It was tornado season. And it was an aluminium house. Anyway, the housekeeper in the faculty residence didn’t speak any English, when I finally managed to convince her I was sick, she said “

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Based on what happened next, I assume it means “would you like an enema?”

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, sweetie, I’ll take care of you, what do you need?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, my mom used to give me sponge baths.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, ground rules, no sponge baths, and definitely no enemas.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Here we go, ten and a half hours of apey goodness.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh dammit, my glasses. Okay, I’m blind here guys, can you help me find them?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry.(Crunching sound)Found ‘em.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh great.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry, don’t you have a spare.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, at home.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well if you leave now, you can be back before the gorillas rip the crap out of Charlton Heston.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Unless Sheldon’s there, in which case you’ll be trapped forever in his whiny hyper neurotic snot-web.

Speaker: Leonard(Dials phone)
Dialogue: Hi, Penny. I was wondering, is Sheldon still at the restaurant? Okay, that was very nice of you. Okay, gotta go, got kind of a full blown Chernobyl thing here, gotta go, bye.(To Howard)He’s home, I’m screwed. Ten and a half hours of apey blurriness.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How about Lasic?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You want me to get eye surgery?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Would you rather go back to the apartment and deal with Sheldon, or have a stranger carve out your corneas with a laser beam?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m thinking!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, nice and cosy, okay, I’ll see you later.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait. Will you please rub this on my chest.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, Sheldon, can’t you do that yourself?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Vaporub makes my hands smell funny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: But Sheldon….

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Please, please, please, please, please, please, please.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe I’m doing this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, counter-clockwise or my chest hair mats.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can you sing “Soft Kitty”.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My mom used to sing it to me when I was sick.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry, honey, I don’t know it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ll teach you. “Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur, happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr purr purr.” Now you.

Speaker: Penny(after a loud sigh)
Dialogue: Soft kitty, warm kitty…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Little ball of fur. Keep rubbing.

Speaker: Penny(through gritted teeth)
Dialogue: Little ball of fur.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What do you see, what do you see.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The living room appears to be empty.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, he must be in his bedroom. My spare glasses are in my bedroom, on my dresser, next to my Bat-signal.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m not going in there.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Raj?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No way, Jose.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well I can’t do it, I can’t see anything.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s all right, wireless mini-cam and Bluetooth headset. We’ll be your eyes.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: One more thing. This is a subsonic impact sensor. If Sheldon gets out of bed and starts to walk, this device will register it and send a signal to the laptop. At that point, based on the geography of the apartment and the ambulatory speed of a sick Sheldon, you’ll have seven seconds to get out, glasses or no glasses.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Won’t my footsteps set it off?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, you’ll be on your hands and knees. Now you’ll need to get the sensor as close as you can to Sheldon’s room.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, how do I carry it if I’m on my hands and knees?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Dialogue: Cut to Leonard entering apartment on hands and knees, carrying the sensor in his teeth.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Stay low. Bear left. Now keep true.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It means go straight.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then just say go straight.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You don’t stay go straight when you’re giving bearings, you say keep true.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright(Bangs head on a trunk.)I just hit my head.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Because you didn’t keep true.(Time shift, Leonard is now outside bedrooms)Okay, turn right.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The… the picture’s breaking up.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Angle your head to the right. A little more. A little more.(Leonard now has his head at right angles to his body)That’s it, now just keep true. Alright, you’re close enough to Sheldon’s room, deploy the sensor. Now turn it on.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It wasn’t on?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then why did I have to crawl?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, I guess you didn’t.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, it’s on.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Good. From this point forward you will have to crawl.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hang on, the sensor’s picking up something, turn your head back.(Camera angle shows a pair of female legs.)

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You rat bastard.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Howard(running down stairs with Raj)
Dialogue: Told you the sensor would work.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi!

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You deliberately stuck me with Sheldon.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I had to, you see what he’s like.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: Penny! Penny, I’m hungry.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, it’s okay, sweetie, good news, Leonard’s home!

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No!

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Penny(handing him vaporub)
Dialogue: Here you go, good luck, bye.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: W-wait!

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, I’m hungry!

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait! Penny! Take me with you!(Runs after her and bumps into pillar. Falls semi-conscious to the floor.  Sheldon appears in his comforter.)

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want grilled cheese.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Dialogue: Time shift. Sheldon and Leonard are on the sofa. Sheldon is wrapped in his comforter, Leonard is holding an ice-pack to his head.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you think Penny will come here and take care of us?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t think Penny’s ever coming here again.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m very congested.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, so?

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can you go to the kitchen, and get me the turkey baster labelled mucus.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If I stand, I’ll vomit.

Scene: The living room door, a fibre-optic camera emerges from underneath. We see the scene from its point of view. Cut to outside. Raj is holding a laptop, Howard is feeding the camera under the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Under the sink, yellow Tupperware bowl.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Here’s the problem with teleportation.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Lay it on me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Assuming the device could be invented which would identify the quantum state of matter of an individual in one location, and transmit that pattern to a distant location for reassembly, you would not have actually transported the individual. You would have destroyed him in one location, and recreated him in another.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How about that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Personally, I would never use a transporter. Because the original Sheldon would have to be disintegrated in order to create a new Sheldon.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Would the new Sheldon be in any way an improvement on the old Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, he would be exactly the same.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That is a problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, you see it too.

Speaker: Dr Gablehouser(arriving)
Dialogue: Dr Hofstadter, Dr Cooper.

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Dr Gablehouser.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I’d like you to meet Dennis Kim. Dennis is a highly sought after Doctorial candidate and we’re hoping to have him do his graduate work here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Graduate work, very impressive.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: And he’s only fifteen years old.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not bad, I myself started graduate school at fourteen.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Well, I lost a year while my family was tunnelling out of North Korea.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Advantage Kim.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: I thought maybe you boys could show Dennis around, let him see why we’re the best physics research facility in the country.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: I already know you’re not. You don’t have an open science grid computer, or a free electron laser, and the string theory research being done here is nothing but a dead end.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, that is my research, and it is by no means a dead end.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Well, obviously you don’t see it yet, but trust me, you will.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Dennis, we discussed this, we’re in the process of updating our equipment, and we welcome your input on our research goals, and we’ve agreed to look the other way if you want to use up to 20% of the grant money you attract to smuggle your grandfather out of Pyongyang. We want him here boys, make it happen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can count on us, we’re on it. What the hell do you mean, dead end.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: I mean, the whole landscape of false vacuums in string theory could be as large as ten to the five-hundredth power. In addition… ooh, look, chocolate milk.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I sense a disturbance in the force.

Speaker: Leonard(in a Yoda voice)
Dialogue: A bad feeling I have about this, mmm-hmmm.
Credits sequence

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, Dennis, how long have you been in America.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: A year and a half.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No kidding, you speak English really well.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: So do you. Except for your tendency to end sentences with prepositions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: That.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s not wrong. Alright, and this is my office.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Is this part of the tour?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nope. Goodbye.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon, we’ve hardly shown him anything.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, alright, this is my desk, these are my books, this is my door, please close it behind you. Goodbye.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Looks like you’re doing work in quantum loop corrections.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Keen observation, goodbye.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: You see where you went wrong, don’t you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Huh, yeah?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Get him out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, Dennis, I’ll show you the rec centre, they’ve got nautilus equipment.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Do I look like I lift weights.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not heavy ones.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: It’s startling to me you haven’t considered a Lorentz invariant field theory approach.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You think I haven’t considered it? You really think I haven’t considered it?

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Have you considered it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Get him out Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, Dennis, I’ll show you the radiation lab.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Wow, you won the Stephenson award.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, in fact I am the youngest person ever to win it.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Really, how old?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fourteen and a half.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: You were the youngest person ever to win it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s like looking into an obnoxious little mirror, isn’t it?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny(to Raj)
Dialogue: Mmm, this is really delicious, isn’t it?(Raj looks uncomfortable, then nods.)Still can’t talk to me unless you’re drunk, huh?(Shakes head)Oh, sweetie, you are so damaged.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, I’m damaged too. How about a hug for Howie?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sure. Raj, hug Howard.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon(dramatically)
Dialogue: Uh-uh-uh.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Something you’d like to share? A tale of woe perhaps.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fifteen years old. Dennis Kim is fifteen years old, and he’s already correcting my work. Today I went from being Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to… you know, that other guy.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Antonio Salieri?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, God, now even you’re smarter than me.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know, Sheldon, you don’t have so many friends that you can afford to start insulting them.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just eat, Sheldon, you’ll feel better.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why waste food. In Texas when a cow goes dry they don’t keep feeding it, they just take her out and shoot her between the eyes.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m confused, did Sheldon stop giving milk?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You can’t let this kid get to you. You always knew that someday someone would come along who was younger and smarter.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but I assumed I would have been dead hundreds of years, and that there would be an asterisk by his name because he would be a cyborg.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, you’ve got a bit of competition, I really don’t see what the big deal is.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well of course you don’t, you’ve never excelled at anything.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t understand, exactly how did he get any friends in the first place?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We liked Leonard.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, what are you going to do, Sheldon, give up?

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. That’s what a rational person does when his entire life’s work is invalidated by a post-pubescent Asian wunderkind. He ceases his fruitless efforts, he donates his body to scientific research, and he waits to die.

Scene: The living room of the apartment.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, I’m confused again, is he waiting, or do we get to shoot him between the eyes?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve decided you’re right. My career is not over.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But, since the arrival of Dennis Kim has rendered my research pointless, I just have to find something else to focus on.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So I’ve decided, I’m going to collaborate with you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What exactly is it you do? I know you chatter on about it all the time, but I’ve never really paid attention.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, well, right now I’m designing an experiment to study the soft component of cosmic radiation at sea-level, but I really don’t need any help.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, sure you do. Now, see, what’s this here in the schematic, is that a laser array?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. Hmmm. What happens if you use argon lasers instead of helium neon?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It would blow up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Pretty sure.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Pretty sure’s not very scientific, is this how you normally work, just hunches and guesses and stuff?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, Sheldon, I understand that you’re going through a bit of a career crisis, you’re searching for some other area where you can feel valuable and productive but I need to tell you something and I want you to listen carefully.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Go away.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If you’re concerned about sharing credit with me, you’re name can go first… I’m going.

Speaker: Howard(into phone)
Dialogue: It’s a small brown paper bag, Ma, I’m looking at it right now.(Pause.)Why would I make that up, there’s no ding-dong in it.(Pause.)How are two ding-dongs tomorrow going to help me today?

Speaker: Sheldon(entering)
Dialogue: So, this is engineering, huh?

Speaker: Howard(into phone)
Dialogue: I’ll talk to you later.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Engineering. Where the noble semi-skilled labourers execute the vision of those who think and dream. Hello, oompah-loompahs of science.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, what are you doing here?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I just came by to say hello.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ve been at this lab for three years, you’ve never came by to say hello.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, up until now I’ve had better things to do. So, what are we making today?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: A small payload support structure for a European science experimental package that’s going up on the next space shuttle.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really, how does it work?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: When this is done, it will be attached to the payload bay, and the sensor apparatus will rest on it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, huh. So it’s a shelf?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, you don’t understand, during acceleration it needs to stay perfectly level and provide… yeah, okay, it’s a shelf.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now, I notice you’re using titanium, did you give any consideration to carbon nanotubes, they’re lighter, cheaper and half twice the tensile strength.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, there’s a diploma in my office that says I have a masters in engineering.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And you also have a note from your mother that says I love you, bubbula. But neither of those is a cogent argument for titanium over nanotubes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Go away.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Did Leonard tell you to say that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, I thought of it all by myself.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Huh. It can’t be a coincidence. There must be some causal link I’m missing.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Go away.(Sheldon exits)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Curiouser and curiouser.

Speaker: Howard(entering)
Dialogue: Is he here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If he were, I wouldn’t be.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Do you know what he did. He watched me work for ten minutes, and then started to design a simple piece of software that could replace me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is that even possible?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As it turns out, yes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Something’s got to be done about him, Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Like what? He’ll never be able to cope with the fact that some fifteen year-old kid is smarter and more accomplished than he is.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, what if something were to happen to this boy so he was no longer a threat to Sheldon?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Then our problem would be solved.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hang on, are we talking about murdering Dennis Kim? I’m not saying no.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We don’t have to go that far, there are other means available.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We can’t send him back to North Korea. He knows how to get out.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The only thing we need to do is make this Kim kid lose his focus.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That won’t happen, he’s not interested in anything but physics.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What about biology?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know, biology? The one thing that can completely derail a world class mind.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, he’s fifteen.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, so, when I was fifteen I met Denise Polmerry and my grade point average fell from a 5.0 to a 1.8.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She was sleeping with you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, I just wasted a lot of time thinking about what it would be like if she did.

Speaker: Sheldon(entering)
Dialogue: Oh, good, you’re all here. Look, I’ve decided that if the three of you drop whatever it is you’re working on and join me, we could lick cold fusion in less than a decade, twelve years tops.(They stare at him.)Go away?(They nod)Hmm. Could it be me?

Speaker: Penny(opening door)
Dialogue: Oh, hey guys, what’s up?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We need a hot fifteen year-old Asian girl with a thing for smart guys.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, that’s racist, any fifteen year-old girl will do the trick.(Penny slams door.)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s possible she may have misunderstood us.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser(entering)
Dialogue: Dr Cooper? Oh, are we interrupting?

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, please, come in. Yeah, I think you’ll appreciate this, very exciting.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Oh, what are you working on?

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Something remarkable. Since my prospects for the Nobel Prize in physics have disappeared, thank you very much, I’ve decided to refocus my efforts and use my people skills to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Look, I’m going to solve the Middle-East Crisis by building an exact replica of Jerusalem in the middle of the Mexican desert.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: To what end?

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, it’s like the baseball movie, build it and they will come.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Who will come?

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The Jewish people.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: What if they don’t come.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We’ll make it nice, put out a spread.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Okay, well, um, speaking of spreads, we’re having a small welcoming party this afternoon for Mr Kim, who’s agreed to join us here at the University.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course he has, the oracle told us little Neo was the one. You can see the Matrix, can’t you.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Okay, well, uh, obviously you’re very busy with your… uh, um, come Dennis. You’ll have to excuse Dr Cooper, he’s been under a lot of… um… he’s nuts.

Scene: Sheldon’s office. He is making measurements on maps. There is a knock on the door.
Speaker: Sheldon(voice off, sings to a Mexican tune)
Dialogue: Ah, la-la-la, Hava Nagila. They’ll come, they’ll settle and I’ll win the prize…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I really don’t understand your objections, Professor Goldfarb, why wouldn’t the Senoran Desert make a perfectly good promised land?

Speaker: Goldfarb
Dialogue: Go away.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We could call it Nuevo Cherusalem.

Speaker: Goldfarb
Dialogue: Please go away.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Said Pharoah to Moses.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Why are all these young women here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s take your daughter to work day.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Really, I was not aware of that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, yes. There was a very official email that was sent to everyone whose insurance files indicated they had daughters between the ages of 14 and 16.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Hm?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Smooth.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: There’s the man of the hour.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, so we now have a socially awkward genius in a room full of attractive age-appropriate women.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All he has to do now is hook up with one of them.(The look at Dennis, who is picking his ear.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Does anyone else see the flaw in this plan?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We need a social catalyst.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Like what? We can’t get fifteen year-old girls drunk.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Or can we?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, we can’t.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t think you mean we can’t. I think you mean we shouldn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, Howard. You’re a Jew. If there was another wailing wall, exactly like the one in Jerusalem, but close to taco stands and cheap prescription drugs, would you still be able to wail at it? Okay, it’s definitely me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, we cannot leave this to chance, lets pick a girl, and figure out how to get her together with Dennis.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. How about that one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh-uh. I know the type, cheerleader, student council, goes out with jocks, won’t even look at anybody in the gifted programme. And if, after two years of begging, she does agree to go out with you, it turns out to be a set-up and you’re in the back seat of your mom’s car with your pants off while the whole football team laughs at you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Are you crying?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, I have allergies.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, uh, how about her?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sure. If he wants to spend a couple of years doing her homework while she drinks herself into a stupor with non-fat White Russians, while you’re the one holding her head out of the toilet while she’s puking and telling you she wishes more guys were like you, and they she gets into Cornell because you wrote her essay for her, and you drive up to visit her one weekend and she acts like she doesn’t even know you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, so not her either. How about her?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Interesting, kind of pretty, a little chubby so probably low self-esteem.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I think that’s our girl. One of us should go talk to her.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t talk to her, you do it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I can’t just go up and talk to her. Howard, you talk to her.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh no, she’ll never go for the kid once she gets a peek at this.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, if we were in India this would be simpler. Five minutes with her dad, twenty goats and a laptop and we’d be done.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, we’re not in India.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Alright, why don’t we do it your way then? We’ll arrange for this girl to move in across the hall from Dennis so he can pathetically moon over her for months on end.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, that was uncalled for.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You started it, dude.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Could I have everyone’s attention please. What a wonderful occasion this is. And how fortunate that it should happen to fall on take your daughter to work day. We’re here to welcome Mr Dennis Kim to our little family.

Speaker: Sheldon(sarcastically)
Dialogue: Welcome Dennis Kim.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Mr Kim was not only the valedictorian at Stamford University, he is also the youngest recipient of the prestigious Stephenson Award.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Youngest till the cyborgs rise up!

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: And now, without any further ado, let me introduce the man of the hour, Mr Dennis Kim. Dennis! Dennis!

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Would you like to tell us a little bit about your upcoming research.

Speaker: Dennis
Dialogue: Um, no thanks. I’m going to the mall with Emma.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Well, uh, well, uh….

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The kid got a girl.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Unbelievable.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Did anyone see how he did it?

Speaker: Sheldon(to Gablehouser)
Dialogue: Don’t worry, I’ve got this. Ladies and Gentlemen, honoured daughters. While Mr Kim, by virtue of his youth and naivety, has fallen prey to the inexplicable need for human contact, let me step in and assure you that my research will go on uninterrupted, and that social relationships will continue to baffle and repulse me. Thank you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He’s back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, mission accomplished.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Forget the mission, how did that little yutz get a girl on his own?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I guess times have changed since we were young. Smart is the new sexy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, why do we go home alone every night, we’re still smart.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe we’re too smart. So smart it’s offputting.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, let’s go with that.

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Unbelievable. Components I built are on the International Space Station, and I get a ticket for launching a model rocket in the park.

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know if the ticket was so much for the launch as it was for you telling the policewoman “you have to frisk me, I have a rocket in my pants.”

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, look at that.(There is a group of youngsters on the grass, laying about. One is playing a guitar. Dennis Kim is among them. He is drinking something from a bottle in a brown paper bag.)It’s Dennis Kim.

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wow, I almost didn’t recognise him.

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, I kind of feel bad about what we did to him.(Dennis is now snogging the face off Emma)

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, we really ruined his life.

Scene: The park. The four guys are carrying remote control rockets.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Screw him, he was weak.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ooh, more details about the new Star Trek film. There’s going to be a scene depicting Spock’s birth.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’d be more interested in a scene depicting Spock’s conception.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, please. For Vulcans, mating, or, if you will, Pon Farr, it’s an extremely private matter.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Still, I’d like to know the details. His mother was human, his father was Vulcan, they couldn’t just conceive.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe they had to go to a clinic. Imagine Spock’s dad in a little room with a copy of pointy ears and shapely rears.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How come on Star Trek everybody’s private parts are the same. No alien lady ever told Captain Kirk, hey, get your thing out of my nose.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Hi, can you help me, I was writing an email and the A key got stuck. Now it’s just going “aaaaaaa”.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What did you spill on it?

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Nothing. Diet coke. And yoghurt. A little nail polish.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ll take a look at it.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Gentlemen, switching to local nerd news. Fishman, Chen, Chowdry, McNair aren’t fielding a team in the university physics bowl this year.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re kidding, why not?

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: They formed a barbershop quartet, and got a gig playing Knotsbury Farm.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, so in your world, you’re like, the cool guys.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Recognise.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is our year! With those guys out, the entire physics bowl will kneel before Zod.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Zod?

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Kryptonian villain. Long story.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Good story.(Clasps hands to mouth in shock.)

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well count me out.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What? Why?

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You want me to use my intelligence in a tawdry competition? Would you ask Picasso to play Pictionary? Would you ask Noah Webster to play Boggle? Would you ask Jacques Cousteau to play Go Fish?

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, you need a four person team, we’re four people.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: By that reasoning we should also play bridge, hold up a chuppah and enter the Olympic bobsled competition.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I want tickets to that please.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, what, do I need to quote Spock’s dying words to you.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, don’t.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The needs of the many.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Outweigh the needs of the few.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or the one. Dammit, I’ll do it.

Scene: The apartment. Howard is looking at his mobile phone.
Dialogue: Credits sequence

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. First order of physics bowl business. We need a truly kick-ass team name. Suggestions.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How about the perpetual motion squad? It’s beyond the laws of physics, plus a little heads up for the ladies.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The ladies?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Perpetual motion squad, we can go all night.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I like it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t. Teams are traditionally named after fierce creatures, thus intimidating ones opponent.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Then we can be the Bengal Tigers.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Poor choice. Gram for gram, no animal exceeds the relative fighting strength of the army ant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe so. But you can’t incinerate a Bengal Tiger with a magnifying glass.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let’s put it to a vote. All those in favour….

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Point of order. I move that any vote on team names should be unanimous. No man should be forced to emblazon his chest with the bengal tiger, when common sense dictates it should be an army ant.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Will the gentleman from the great state of denial yield for a question?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I will yield.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: After we go through the exercise of an annoying series of votes, all of which the gentleman will lose, does he then intend to threaten to quit if he does not get his way?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He does.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I move we are the Army Ants, all those in favour?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Good afternoon, and welcome to today’s physics bowl practice round. I’m Penny, and I’ll be your host, because apparently I didn’t have anything else to do on a Saturday afternoon, and isn’t that just a little sad? Gentlemen, are you ready?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fire away.(Raj puts his thumb up.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, it’s none of my business, but isn’t a guy who can’t speak in front of women going to hold you back a little?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, uh, he’ll be okay once the women are mixed into the crowd. He only has a problem when they’re one on one and smell nice.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, thanks Raj, it’s vanilla oil.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I was actually the one who noticed, okay, let’s just start.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, the first question is on the topic of optics. What is the shortest light pulse ever produced? Dr Cooper.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And of course, the answer is 130 adoseconds.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That is correct.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I knew that too.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Good for you, sweetie. Okay, next question. What is the quantum mechanical effect used to encode data on hard disk drives? Howard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And of course, the answer is giant magneto resistance.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, I buzzed in.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But I answered, it’s called teamwork.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t you think I should answer the engineering questions? I am an engineer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: By that logic I should answer all the anthropology questions because I’m a mammal.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just ask another one.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. What artificial satellite has seen glimpses of Einsteins predicted frame dragging?(Raj buzzes.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And of course it’s Gravity Probe B.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you have to let somebody else answer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Because it’s polite.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What do manners have to do with it? This is war. Were the Romans polite when they salted the ground of Carthage to make sure nothing would ever grow again?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard, you said I only had to ask questions.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The objective of the competition is to give correct answers, if I know them, why shouldn’t I give them?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Some of us might have the correct answers too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh please, you don’t even have a PhD.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Alright, that’s it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, sit down.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: maybe we should take a little break.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good idea, I need my wrist brace, all this button pushing is aggravating my old Nintendo injury.

Speaker: Howard(after Raj whispers in his ear)
Dialogue: I agree.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He compared Sheldon to a disposable feminine cleansing product one might use on a summer’s eve.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, and the bag it came in.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, excellent, I want to show you something.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can it wait, I need to talk to you.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just look. I’ve designed the perfect uniforms for our team. The colours are based on Star Trek, the original series. The three of you will wear support red, and I will wear command gold.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why do they say AA?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Army Ants.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Isn’t that confusing? AA might mean something else to certain people.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would a physics bowl team be called anodised aluminium?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I meant…. never mind. Hey, check it out. I got you a Batman cookie jar!

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh neat, what’s the occasion?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, you’re a friend, and you like Batman, and cookies, and you’re off the team.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, Raj and I just had a team meeting.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No you didn’t.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes we did, I just came from it.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, I don’t know where you just came from, but it couldn’t have been a team meeting because I’m on the team and I wasn’t there, ergo the team did not meet.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, let me try it this way, uh, I was at a coffee klatch with a couple of friends and one thing led to another and it turns out you’re off the team.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because you’re taking all the fun out of it.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m sorry, is the winner of the physics bowl the team that has the most fun?

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, let me try it this way, you’re annoying and no-one wants to play with you any more.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I see. Well. At this point I should inform you that I intend to form my own team and destroy the molecular bonds that bind your very matter together, and reduce the resulting particulate chaos to tears.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks for the heads up.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re welcome. One more thing.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Scene: The same, later. Sheldon is on his laptop. Leonard enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s on, bitch.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So who’d he get to be on his team.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He won’t say. He just smiles, and eats macaroons out of his bat jar.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He’s using psychological warfare. We must reply in kind. I say we wait until he looks at us, then laugh like, yes, you are a smart and strong competitor, but we are also smart and strong and we have a reasonable chance of defeating you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How exactly would that laugh go?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That sounds more like, we are a tall thin woman who wants to make a coat out of your Dalmatians.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Guys, let’s remember that Sheldon is still our friend and my room mate.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So nothing, let’s destroy him.

Speaker: Sheldon(walking past)
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, we’re going to need a strong fourth for our team.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know who’s apparently very smart, is the girl who played TV’s Blossom. She got a PhD in neuroscience or something.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Raj, we’re not getting TV’s Blossom to join our physics bowl team.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How about the girl from the Wonder Years?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I believe I’ve found the solution to all our problems.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We can’t ask Leslie Winkle.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why? Because you slept together and when she was done with you she discarded you like last night’s chutney?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sometimes you’ve got to take one for the team.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah. Sack up, dude.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine. Here I go, taking one for the team. In the sack. Hey Leslie.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Hi guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Leslie, I have a question for you, and it might be a little awkward, you know, given that I…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hit that thang.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Leonard, there’s no reason to feel uncomfortable just because we’ve seen each other’s faces and naked bodies contorted in the sweet agony of coitus.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There’s not? Gee, cos it sure sounds like there should be.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Rest assured that any aspects of our sexual relationship regarding your preferences, your idiosyncrasies, your performance, are still protected by the inherent confidentiality of the bedroom.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s all very comforting, but if it’s okay, I’d like to get on with my question now.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We are entering the physics bowl and we need a fourth for our team.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: No thanks, I’m really busy with my like sign dilepton super symmetry search.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Dilepton, schmilepton, we need you.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, we tried. Just have to face Sheldon mano-e-mano-e-mano. A-mano.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Wait, you’re going up against Sheldon Cooper?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: That arrogant, misogynistic East-Texas doorknob that told me I should abandon my work with high energy particles for laundry and child bearing?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She’s in.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, how do you feel? Nice and loose? Come to play? Got your game face on?(The guys look confused.)Are you ready?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. You know you don’t have to stay for the whole thing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, no, no, I want to. It sounds really interesting.

Speaker: Sheldon(entering in his Star Trek themed shirt)
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hee hee hee hee hee hee hee hee.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon. I’m just going to sit down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, is that your team.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Actually, I don’t need a team, I could easily defeat you single-handedly. But the rules require four, so may I introduce, the third floor janitor, he lady from the lunchroom, and, my Spanish is not good, either her son or her butcher. And what about your team? What rat have you recruited to the SS Sinking Ship?

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Hello, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leslie Winkle?

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Yeah, Leslie Winkle. The answer to the question, who made Sheldon Cooper cry like a little girl?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, well, I’m polymerised tree sap and you’re non-organic adhesive so, whatever verbal projectile you launch in my direction is reflected off of me, returns on its original trajectory, and adheres to you.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Oh, ouch.

Speaker: Dr Gablehouser
Dialogue: Okay, if everyone could please take your seats.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here’s your tee-shirt.(Hands her a tee-shirt with PMS on it. Takes jacket off to reveal similar.)

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: PMS? It’s a couple of days early, but…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, it stands for Perpetual Motion Squad.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Oh, right, of course, what was I thinking?

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Good afternoon everyone, and welcome to this year’s physics bowl. Today’s preliminary match features two great teams… AA versus PMS.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All night long, y’all!(Stands and turns round to reveal the back of the tee-shirt which reads “We Can Go All Night”.)

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Okay, well let’s jump right in, first question, for ten points. What is the isospan singlet partner of the Pi Zero Meson?(Buzz)PMS?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The Eta Meson.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Correct.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Formal protest.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: On what grounds?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The Velcro on my wrist brace caught on my shirt.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Denied. Alright, for ten points, what is the lightest element on earth with no stable isotope.(Buzz)AA?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And of course, the answer is Technetium.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Terrific. Next question, what is the force between two uncharged plates due to quantum vacuum fluctuation.(Buzz)PMS?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sheldon can suck on, the Casimir Effect.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Correct.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: How does a quantum computer factor large numbers.(Buzz)PMS?

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Shor’s Algorithm.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Correct.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: 4.1855 times ten to the seventh ergs per calorie.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Prevost’s theory of exchanges.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Lamda equals one over Pi R squared N
(Time shift)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: 760 degrees celsius, the approximate temperature of the young lady in the front row.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Mr Wolowitz, this is your second warning.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A sigma particle.
(Time shift)

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Yes, assuming the hypothetical planet has a mass greater than the earth.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Correct. Ladies and gentlemen, I hold in my hand the final question. The score now stands AA 1150, PMS 1175. So, for one hundred points, and the match, please turn your attention to the formula on the screens. Solve the equation.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Holy crap.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What the hell is that.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It looks like something they found on the ship at Roswell.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, think, Leslie.

Speaker: Leslie
Dialogue: Leonard, it’s not going to work if you rush me, you have to let me get there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re never going to let that go, are you?

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Ten seconds.(Buzz)PMS.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry, I panicked.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Then guess.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Um, eight.(Gablehouser stares at him.)Point four.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: I’m sorry, that’s incorrect. AA, if you can answer correctly, the match is yours.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He doesn’t have it. He’s got squat.
(Sheldon looks more and more uncomfortable, so much he is involuntarily twitching.)

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: AA, I need your answer.(Buzz)

Speaker: Third Floor Janitor
Dialogue: The answer is minus eight by alpha.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hang on, hang on a second, that’s not our answer. What are you doing?

Speaker: Third Floor Janitor
Dialogue: Answering question. Winning physics bowl.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How do you know anything about physics?

Speaker: Third Floor Janitor
Dialogue: Here I am janitor, in former Soviet Union I am physicist. Leningrad Politechnica. Go Polar Bears.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well that’s a delightful little story, but our arrangement was that you sit here and not say anything, I answer the questions.

Speaker: Third Floor Janitor
Dialogue: You didn’t answer question.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey look, now maybe you have democracy now in your beloved Russia, but on this physics bowl team I rule with an iron fist.(Makes fist in the air).Ow!

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: AA, I need your official answer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well it’s not what he said.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Then what is it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want a different question.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: You can’t have a different question.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Formal protest.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Denied.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Informal protest.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Denied. I need your official answer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. I decline to provide one.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Well, that’s too bad, because the answer your teammate gave was correct.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s your opinion.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: Alright, the winner of the match is…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hang on. Sheldon, is proving that you are single-handedly smarter than everyone else so important that you would rather lose by yourself than win as part of a team.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand the question.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: Gablehouser
Dialogue: The winner is PMS!

(We Are The Champions by Queen plays as the team celebrate in slow motion and Sheldon puts his head in his hands. The celebration ends with Howard on his knees ripping his shirt in half and waving it round his head before throwing it to the audience.)

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry, somebody’s sitting there.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: My Physics Bowl Trophy!

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That trophy is meaningless, I forfeited, therefore you did not win.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know someone who would disagree.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: My Physics Bowl Trophy!(In weird voice)“Leonard is so smart, Sheldon who?”

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright that is very immature.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, I’m sorry.(In voice, waving trophy in Sheldon’s face)I’m not!

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Okay, new contest.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m settling once and for all who is the smartest around here. Okay, are you ready?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Bring it on.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Marsha, Jan and Cindy were the three daughters of what TV family?(They stare at her.)The Brady Bunch. Okay, Sammy Hagar replaced David Lee Roth as the lead singer in what group?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon(after they look at each other in confusion)
Dialogue: The Brady Bunch?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Van Halen. Alright, Madonna was married to this Ridgemont High alum.(Pause)Oh my God, Sean Penn!

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How do you know these things?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I go outside and I talk to people. Alright, here, what actor holds the record for being named people magazine’s sexiest man alive?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: William Shatner.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait, I don’t think it’s Shatner.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then it’s got to be Patrick Stewart.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Formal protest.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, singer who sang “Oops I Did It Again.”(Sheldon starts involuntarily twitching again.)Okay, Tweetie Bird, taught he taw a what?

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Sheldon(after they pass a smug look between each other)
Dialogue: Romulan.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes. He taught he taw a Romulan.

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.
Dialogue: (Sheldon and Leonard do a victory hand slide.)

Speaker: Sheldon
