Dialogue: Well, this sandwich is an unmitigated disaster. I asked for turkey and roast beef with lettuce and swiss on wholewheat.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What did they give you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Turkey and roast beef with swiss and lettuce on wholewheat. It’s the right ingredients but in the wrong order. In a proper sandwich the cheese is adjacent to the bread to create a moisture barrier against the lettuce. They might as well have dragged this thing through a car wash.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t believe it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know, it’s basic culinary science.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Some guy is auctioning off a miniature time machine prop from the original film and no-one is bidding on it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: A time machine from the movie The Time Machine?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, a time machine from Sophie’s Choice.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Boy, Sophie could have used a time machine in that movie. Did you see it, it’s rough.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, that’s cool.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s only $800?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. And that’s my bid.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You bid $800.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It was a spur of the moment thing, I figured it would go for thousands and I just wanted to be a part of it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s only 30 seconds left in the auction.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do you have $800?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not to blow on a miniature time machine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t worry, the way these things work there’s people waiting ‘til the last second to bid, and then they swoop in and get it, it’s called sniping.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Fifteen seconds.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, snipers.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Ten, nine, eight…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where are your snipers?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Five.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Snipe.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Snipe.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Three.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Snipe!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: SNIPE!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: One.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aaaa-aw!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Congratulations, you are the proud owner of a miniature time machine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You lucky duck.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I wonder why no-one else bid, this is a classic piece of sci-fi movie memorabilia.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I know, I still can’t afford it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why don’t we share it? We’ll each put in two hundred bucks and we’ll take turns having it in our homes.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: A time share time machine? I’m in. Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Need you ask? But I still don’t understand why no-one else bid.

Scene: The lobby. The guys stand around a full sized time machine.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I understand why no-one else bid.

Scene: The lobby. The guys stand around a full sized time machine.
Dialogue: Credits sequence

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Did the listing actually say miniature?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I just assumed. Who sells a full sized time machine for $800?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In a venn diagram, that would be an individual located within the intersection of the sets “no longer want my time machine” and “need $800”.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s actually a tremendous bargain, even with shipping it works out to less than four dollars a pound.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Cocktain shrimp are $12.50.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How are we going to get it upstairs?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If we take the dish off it might fit in the elevator.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes but the elevator’s been broken for two years.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve been meaning to ask you, do you think we should make a call about that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Not necessary, I have a masters in engineering, I remotely repair satellites on a regular basis. I troubleshoot space shuttle payloads. When the Mars rover started pulling to the left I performed a front end alignment from 62 million miles away.(Presses lift button. Nothing happens.)No, that baby’s broken.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, guys, push.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Howard(off)
Dialogue: If I push any harder I’m going to give birth to my colon.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Raj(off)
Dialogue: I can’t feel my fingers, hurry up.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s the same amount of work no matter how fast you go, basic physics.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sheldon?

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: If my fingers ever work again, I’ve got a job for the middle one.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny(coming out of her apartment)
Dialogue: Oh, hey guys.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard(letting go of time machine, as does Sheldon)
Dialogue: Uh, hi Penny.(Raj and Howard are heard to scream as the time machine slides back down the stairs.)Take a break, guys!

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, just, you know, moving… something upstairs.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What is it?

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s… you know, time machine.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, okay, neat, but I really got to get to work, so….

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, just give us a few minutes.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t have a few minutes, I’m running really late.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then I have a simple solution, go up to the roof, hop over to the next building, there’s a small gap, don’t look down if you’re subject to vertigo, and use their stairwell.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re joking, right?

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I never joke when it comes to vertigo.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Damn, okay, I’ll just take the roof.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, if you wait for us to set up the time machine, I can drop you off at work yesterday. Time travel joke, it’s not… never mind.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: For what it’s worth, I thought it was humorous.

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let’s just do this. Guys, ready to push?

Scene: The stairwell, approaching the apartment door. Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the last part of the stairs.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: In a minute. Howard stepped outside to throw up.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t know what you were worried about. I think it really works in the room.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. It is by far the coolest thing I have ever owned.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The exact time machine that carried actor Rod Taylor from Victorian England into the post-apocalyptic future, which society had splintered into two factions, the sub-terranean Morlocks, who survived by feasting on the flesh of the gentle surface dwelling Eloy.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Talk about your chick magnets.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh yeah. The guy who lives next to me is always like, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony. But wait until I tell him, I’ve got a time machine on my balcony. Stuff that in your speedos, Jacuzzi Bob!

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I know we said we’d take turns, but I think you’d agree that practicality dictates it remain here.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can’t just keep it here, what if I meet a girl and say, “you wanna come up and see my time machine, it’s at my friends house,” how lame is that?

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He’s got a point.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, I think we’re going to need some ground rules, in addition to the expected no shoes in the time machine and no eating in the time machine, I propose that we add pants must be worn at all times in the time machine.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Seconded.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I was going to put down a towel.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I still want it on my balcony. I say we move it on a bi-monthly basis.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That sounds fair.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hold on. Bi-monthly is an ambiguous term, do you mean move it every other month, or twice a month?

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Twice a month.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then no.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, every other month.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you can’t be selfish, we all paid for it, so it belongs to all of us. Now out of the way so I can sit in my time machine.(Sits and turns it on. The three lights on the front illuminate. All let out an “oh”.)Okay, I am setting the dials for March 10th, 1876.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Good choice, Alexander Graham Bell invents the telephone and calls out for Dr Watson.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait a minute, I’d want to see that too.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, when it’s your turn you can.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But if we all go back to the same point in time, Bell’s lab is going to get very crowded, he’ll know something’s up.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Also, since the time machine doesn’t move in space, you’ll end up in 1876 Pasadena.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And even if you can make it to Boston, what are you going to do, knock on the door and say to Mrs Bell, “hey Mrs Bell, big fan of your husband, can I come in and watch him invent the telephone?”

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Mrs Bell was deaf, she’s not even going to hear you knock.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I have a solution, first go into the future and obtain a cloaking device.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Ooh, how far into the future?

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I remember correctly, Captain Kirk will steal a cloaking device from the Romulans on Stardate 5027.3, which will be January 10th2328 by pre-federation reckoning.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, I am setting the dials for January 10th, 2328. Here we go into the future.(Pulls lever, the disk begins to spin. The other guys all run around the flat as if moving in fast motion.)That was fun.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My turn.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Okay, first of all, what you call a gap was nearly three feet wide, I slipped and skinned my knee.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Zzz-zz-zz-zz! Second of all, the door to the stairwell of the other building was locked, so I had to go down the fire escape which ends on the third floor, forcing me to crawl through the window of a lovely Armenian family, who insisted I stay for lunch.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That doesn’t sound too bad.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It was eight courses of lamb, and they tried to fix me up with their son.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Not done. By the time I finally got to work, they’d given my shift away. Yeah, that’s right, I’ve lost an entire day’s pay thanks to this… this…

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Time machine.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The lights flash and the dish spins, you wanna try it?

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No! I don’t want to try it, my God, you are grown men, how could you waste your lives with these stupid toys and costumes and comic books and… and now that… that…

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Again, time machine.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh please, it’s not a time machine, if anything it looks like something Elton John would drive through the Everglades.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It only moves in time. It would be worse than useless in a swamp.

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Pathetic. All of you, completely pathetic.(Storms out. A beat, and then…)

Scene: The living room. The time machine is set up.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My turn!

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, it’s two in the morning.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So it’s my turn. Why did you set it for the day before yesterday?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because I want to go back and keep myself from getting a time machine.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can’t. If you were to prevent yourself from buying it in the past, you would not have it available in the present to travel back and stop yourself from buying it, ergo you would still have it. This is a classic rookie time travel mistake.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can I go back and prevent you from explaining that to me?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Same paradox. If you were to travel back in time and, say, knock me unconscious, you would not then have the conversation that irritated you, motivating you to go back and knock me unconscious.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What if I knocked you unconscious right now?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It won’t change the past.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: But it would make the present so much nicer.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you upset about something?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What was your first clue?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, it was a number of things. First the late hour, then your demeanour seems very low energy, plus your irritability…

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes I’m upset.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh! I don’t usually pick up on those things. Good for me.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, good for you.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, wait. Did you want to talk about what’s bothering you?

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know. Maybe.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wow, I’m on fire tonight.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, here’s the thing. Girls like Penny never end up with guys who own time machines.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I disagree. Your inability to successfully woo Penny long predates your acquisition of the time machine. That failure clearly stands on its own.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks for pointing it out.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In addition, your premise is flawed. In the original film, Rod Taylor got Yvette Mimeaux with that very time machine. In Back to the Future, Marty McFly got the opportunity to hook up with his extremely attractive young mother.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Those are movies.

Scene: Later that night, Leonard is sitting in the time machine, turning the lights on and off. Sheldon enters.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well of course they’re movies. Were you expecting me to come up with an example involving a real life time machine? That’s absurd.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, guys, push.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Howard(off)
Dialogue: If I push any harder I’m going to give birth to my colon.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny(coming out of her apartment)
Dialogue: Oh, hey guys.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard(letting go of time machine, as does Sheldon)
Dialogue: Uh, hi Penny.(Raj and Howard are heard to scream as the time machine slides back down the stairs.)Take a break, guys!

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, just, you know, moving a… time machine.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, okay, neat, but I really got to get to work, so….

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No problem.(Removes glasses, pulls down out of order tape from lift doors, and forces them open.)Hang on.(Takes Penny in his arms as he holds onto the lift cable.)

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: But, what about your time machine.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Some things are more important than toys.(She puts her arms around his neck as he dangles from the cable.)

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’m scared.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Don’t worry baby, I’ve got you.

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, Leonard.(Kisses him as they descend from view. Leonard wakes up still sitting in the time machine.)

Scene: The stairwell. It is the previous day, and again Leonard and Sheldon are pulling the time machine up the stairs.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s still my turn.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m packing up all my collectibles and taking them down to the comic book store to sell.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well is that really necessary. If you need money you can always sell blood. And semen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s not about money.

Speaker: Raj(entering)
Dialogue: We brought food.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Lox and bagels, the breakfast of time travellers.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Terrific, does anyone want to buy my share of the time machine?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because I don’t want it any more.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just… personal reasons.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My spidey-sense tells me this has something to do with Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, do you want to buy me out or not?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ll give you a hundred dollars, which will make me half owner, and we’ll put it on my balcony.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Screw his balcony, I’ll give you a hundred and twenty and we’ll put it in my garage.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I paid two hundred dollars for my share.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dude, everyone knows a time machine loses half its value the minute you drive it off the lot.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ll go for two hundred, that time machine stays right where it is.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Three hundred, and I’ll throw in my original 1979 Mattel Millenium Falcon with real light speed sound effects.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no more toys or action figures or props or replicas or costumes or robots or Darth Vader voice changers, I’m getting rid of all of it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can’t do that, look what you’ve created here, it’s like nerdvana.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: More importantly, you’ve a Darth Vader voice changer?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not for long.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I call dibs on the Golden Age Flash.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hang on, I need that to complete my Justice Society of America collection.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Too bad, I called dibs.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well you can’t just call dibs.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can and I did, look up dibs on Wikipedia.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dibs doesn’t apply in a bidding war.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s not a bidding war, I’m selling it all to Larry down at the comic book store.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why Larry? Did Larry call dibs?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Will you forget dibs!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He offered me a fair price for the whole collection.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s the number, I’ll match it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ll match it, plus a thousand rupees.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s the exchange rate.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: None of your business. Take it or leave it.

Speaker: Howard(on phone)
Dialogue: Mom, my bar-mizvah bonds, how much do I got? Thanks. I can go twenty six hundred dollars and two trees in Israel.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Forget it guys, if I sell to one of you, the other two are going to be really mad at me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who cares, as long as you pick me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, Leonard, put down the box, let’s talk.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry Raj, my mind is made up.

Speaker: Sheldon(moving to block his path)
Dialogue: No. I can’t let you do this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, get out of my way.

Speaker: Sheldon(brandishing toy sword from Leonard’s box)
Dialogue: None shall pass.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. I did not want to do this but, I have here the rare mint condition production error Star Trek: The Next Generation Geordi LaForge, without his visor in the original packaging. If you do not get out of my way, I will open it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay man, be cool, we’re all friends here.

Speaker: Penny(coming out of her flat)
Dialogue: What the hell’s going on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You hypocrite!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Little Miss “grown ups don’t play with toys”. If I were to go into that apartment right now, would I find Beanie Babies? Are you not an accumulator of Care Bears and My Little Ponies? And who is that Japanese feline I see frolicking on your shorts? Hello,Hello Kitty!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, okay look, if this is about yesterday, Leonard, I am really sorry about what I said, I was just a bit upset.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I needed to hear it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No you didn’t. Look, you are a great guy, and it is things you love that make you who you are.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I guess that makes me large breasts.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Still, I think it’s time for me to get rid of this stuff and… you know… move on with my life.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh. Wow. Good for you.(Kisses his cheek.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks. Hey, do you want to, I don’t know, later…

Speaker: Good looking man coming up stairs
Dialogue: Excuse me. Hey, Penny!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi Mike.

Speaker: Mike
Dialogue: Are you ready to go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I just have to change.

Speaker: Mike
Dialogue: I’ll give you a hand.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, stop it! Bye guys.

Speaker: Leonard(after a long pause)
Dialogue: My turn on the time machine.

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It worked. It really worked. They said I was mad, but it worked.(Large hairy creatures with glowing eyes emerge from the forest and walk towards him menacingly.)Oh no, not Morlocks! Not flesh-eating Morlocks! He-e-e-e-e-e-e-elp!(With a yelp, he wakes up in the time machine in the living room.)

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you okay?

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We have to get rid of the time machine.

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It is a little big for the living room, isn’t it?

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s the problem, it’s too big.

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m glad you agree. I hired some guys to help us move it, come on in fellas.(A pair of Morlocks come through the door.)

Scene: A jungle. As the camera moves, the time machine becomes visible. Sheldon is sitting in it The disk stops spinning, and he looks around. The dials read APR 28 802,701.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh no, Morlocks? Eat him, eat him. Aaaaargh.(Sheldon wakes up in his own bed.)Leonard!!!!!!!!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: On the other hand, some physicists are concerned that if the super collider actually works, it will create a black hole and swallow up the Earth ending life as we know it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Psh, what a bunch of crybabies. No guts, no glory man.

Speaker: Leonard(looking at an orange notice on the noticeboard)
Dialogue: Hey, check it out, the school of pharmacology is looking for volunteers.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We are testing a new medication for social anxiety, panic attacks, agoraphobia and obsessive compulsive disorder. Why would they be looking for test subjects here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know, Raj. Maybe the comic book store doesn’t have a bulletin board.(Sees crowds in the corridor)What’s going on?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Shhh! Hot girl in Sheldon’s office.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon’s office? Is she lost?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t think so. I followed her here from the parking lot.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe she’s his lawyer.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well she’s free to examine my briefs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know, I’m disgusting, I should be punished. By her, oh look, I did it again.

Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: Well, that should do it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you for coming by.(He rises from his desk. Everyone rushes to look nonchalant.)Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, hey buddy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Buddy.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry I’m late, I’m working on a project that may take me up on the next space shuttle.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How can you be late, I wasn’t expecting you at all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Nobody ever expects me, sometimes you just look and… BAM!(shakes girl’s hand)Howard Wolowitz.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you going to introduce us?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, alright, this is Missy, Missy this is Leonard and Rajesh and you’ve already met Howard.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: It’s nice to meet you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You too, swell, also.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, how do you two know each other.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Oh, he once spent nine months with my legs wrapped around his head.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She’s my twin sister, she thinks she’s funny but frankly I’ve never been able to see it.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: It’s because you have no measurable sense of humour, Shelly.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How exactly would one measure a sense of humour? A humourmometer?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I think you’re delightfully droll. Or as the French say, Tres Drole.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Okay, so let me see if I got this. Leonard, Howard and… I’m sorry what was your name again.(Raj looks uncomfortable, turns and walks away, disappears round corner. He then reappears, takes the orange paper from the noticeboard and leaves again.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Rajesh.
Credits sequence

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So Missy, what brings you all the way from Texas?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Was it perhaps destiny, I think it was destiny.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: My friend’s getting married in Disneyland tomorrow night.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Destiny, thy name is Anaheim.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: And I had to drop off some papers for Shelly to sign for my dad’s estate.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The papers could have been mailed, Mom just sent you here to spy on me, didn’t she.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: I guess that’s why they call you a genius.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They call me a genius because I’m a genius. Tell Mom that I currently weigh 165 pounds, and that I’m having regular bowel movements. Enjoy the wedding, goodbye.

Speaker: Leonard and Howard together
Dialogue: Woah, woah.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If the wedding’s not until tomorrow, why don’t you stay with us tonight?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t think so. Shelly doesn’t like company. Even as a little boy he’d send his imaginary friends home at the end of the day.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They were not friends, they were imaginary colleagues.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, you’re here, we have plenty of room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No we don’t.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, Shelly, she’s family.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So what? I don’t issue invitations to your mother.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Well it would be nice not to have to drive out to Anaheim in rush hour.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And don’t ever call me Shelly.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So it’s settled. You’ll stay with us.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ll walk you to your car. You’re in structure 3 level C, right?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What just happened?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: So anyway, we’re eight years old, and Sheldon converts my easy-bake oven to some kind of high-powered furnace.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hee-hee, just classic.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I needed a place to fire ceramic semi-conductor substrates for home-made integrated circuits.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: He was trying to build some kind of armed robot to keep me out of his room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Made necessary by her insistence on going into my room.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Anyway, I go to make those little corn muffins they give you, there’s a big flash, next thing you know my eyebrows are gone.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ha-ha, not your eyebrows?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Yep. I had to go through the entire second grade with crooked eyebrows my Mom drew on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is that what that was? I just assumed that the second grade curriculum had rendered you quizzical.

Speaker: Penny(knocking and entering, holding up a pair of superman undershorts.)
Dialogue: Hey, Leonard, you left your underwear in the dryer downstairs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Those are not mine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, they have your little name label in them.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, no, I do, I use those… uh… just to polish up my… spear-fishing equipment. I spear fish. When I’m not crossbow hunting, I spear fish. Uh, Penny, this is Sheldon’s twin sister, Missy. Missy, this is our neighbour Penny.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, you don’t look that much alike.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Can I get a hallelujah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fraternal twins come from two separate eggs, they are no more alike than any other siblings.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hallelujah.

Speaker: Raj(running in)
Dialogue: Hey, guess what. I’ve been accepted as a test subject for a new miracle drug to overcome pathological shyness.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, good for you, Raj.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, I’m very hopeful. Hello Missy.(He waves his hand. It keeps waving.)They mentioned there may be side effects.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So, Missy. Have you ever met a man from the exotic subcontinent of India?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Well, there’s Dr Patel at our church.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Ah yes, Dr Patel, good man.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do you like motorcycles, ‘cos I ride a hog.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: A hog? You have a two cylinder scooter with a basket on the front.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You still have to wear a helmet.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Have you ever heard of the Kama Sutra?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: The sex book?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The Indian sex book. In other words if you wonder wonder who wrote the book of love, it was us.

Speaker: Penny(to Leonard)
Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon’s sister’s pretty cute, I w….

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I wasn’t staring!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I didn’t say you were, I just said she was cute.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Huh, um, maybe, if you like women who are tall… and perfect.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, why are you ignoring your sister?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not ignoring my sister. I’m ignoring all of you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I brought snacks.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Oh my! Gherkins and….

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Onion dip, it’s onion dip.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We don’t entertain much.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Missy, do you enjoy pajamas?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: I guess.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We Indians invented them. You’re welcome.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, well my people invented circumcision. You’re welcome!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Missy, I’m going to go get my nails done. Do you want to come?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: God yes. Thanks.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re welcome.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Bye guys.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Bye Missy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Bye Missy, see you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Goodbye Leonard!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, yeah, no, uh, bye Penny.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, you two have to back off.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why should I back off, you back off dude.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me, this is my apartment and she’s my roommate’s sister.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So what, you’ve already got Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How do I have Penny? In what universe do I have Penny?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So I can have Penny?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hell, no!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, can I interject something. I’m ordering pizza online, is everyone okay with pepperoni?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, can I talk to you in private?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I guess. Don’t worry, I was going to order you cheeseless.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s okay. Lactose intolerance is nothing to be embarrassed about.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m a fancy Indian man, we invented pajamas!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, look at me, I don’t have a foreskin.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you aware that your sister is an incredibly attractive woman?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmmm? She certainly has the symmetry and low body fat that western culture deems desirable. It’s noteworth that at other points in history, heavier women were the standard for beauty because their girth suggested affluence.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s fascinating, but I…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I didn’t say it was fascinating, I said it was noteworthy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, noted. But my point is that Koothrappali and Wolowitz… they’re hitting on your sister.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Okay. You know, I don’t want to criticise your rhetorical style but, we’d be a lot further along in this conversation if you’d begun with that thought.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s great, but I….

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What I’m saying is that we took quite an unnecessary detour from what I now understand to be your thesis.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Whatever. You have to do something about it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because she’s your sister.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand. Yes, we shared a uterus for nine months, but since then we’ve pretty much gone our own separate ways.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, uh…. oh, consider this. With your father gone, it is your responsibility to make sure that Missy chooses a suitable mate.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hadn’t considered that. We do share DNA.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So there is the possibility, however remote, that resting in her loins is the potential for another individual as remarkable as myself.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Exactly. And, you owe it to yourself and to posterity to protect the genetic integrity of your sister’s future offspring.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re right. If someone wants to get at Missy’s fallopian tubes, they’ll have to go through me.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I am Shiva the destroyer, I will have the woman!

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m warning you, I was judo champion at math camp.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, that’s enough juvenile squabbling, stop it, stop it I say. I’m going to settle this right now. Neither of you are good enough for my sister.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Who are you to decide that?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He’s the man of his family, you have to respect his wishes.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re out too, by the way.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Say what?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s nothing personal, I’d just prefer if my future niece or nephew didn’t become flatulent every time they eat an Eskimo pie.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Howard(to Raj, who is smiling)
Dialogue: What are you so happy about?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m not happy, it’s the medication, I can’t stop smiling.(Waves hand at mouth. It keeps waving.)

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now that Leonard’s made me aware of how high the genetic stakes are, we have to face the fact that none of you are suitable mates for my sister.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Leonard made you aware of that?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We all make mistakes, let’s move on.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Excuse me, but I think you’re missing a big opportunity here.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How so?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Everybody knows genetic diversity produces the strongest offspring. Why not put a little mocha in the family latte.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In principle you have a point, but as a practical matter, need I remind you that it takes experimental pharmaceuticals to simply enable you to speak to the opposite sex.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Raj(waving finger at him)
Dialogue: I think you’re focussing entirely too much on the drugs.(Finger keeps waving. Leonard has to reach out and stop it.)

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Is it ‘cause I’m Jewish, ‘cause I’d kill my Rabbi with a porkchop to be with your sister.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This has nothing to do with religion. This has to do with the fact that you’re a tiny, tiny man who still lives with his mother.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you are really being unreasonable.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Am I? Here. Eat this cheese without farting and you can sleep with my sister.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Missy(who has just entered)
Dialogue: Oh really?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oops.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Shelly, can I speak to you for a minute? Alone?

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why does everyone suddenly want to talk to me alone? Usually nobody wants to be alone with me.

Scene: The living room. Raj and Howard are on the floor, fighting.
Speaker: Leonard(to Penny who is standing next to him grinning)
Dialogue: We all make mistakes, let’s move on.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Okay. I’m not even going to ask why you’re pimping me out for cheese. But since when do you care at all about who I sleep with?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Truthfully, I’ve never given it any thought, but it has been pointed out to me that you carry DNA of great potential.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: What on earth are you talking about?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let me explain. You see, I’m a superior genetic mutation, an improvement on the existing mediocre stock.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: And what do you mean, mediocre stock?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That would be you. But residing within you is the potential for another me. Perhaps even taller, smarter and less prone to freckling, a Sheldon 2.0 if you will.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Sheldon 2.0?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Exactly. Now, I am not saying that I should be the sole decider of who you mate with. If you’re not attracted to the suitor then the likelihood of conception would be reduced.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: You have got to be kidding me!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not at all. Frequent coitus dramatically increases the odds of fertiliziation.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Okay Shelly, sit down. Now I’ve lived my whole life dealing with the fact that my twin brother is, as Mom puts it, one of God’s special little people.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I always thought I was more like a cuckoo bird. You know, a superior creature whose egg is placed in the nest of ordinary birds. Of course the newly hatched cuckoo eats all the food, leaving the ordinary siblings to starve to death. Luckily for you, that’s where the metaphor ended.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: I thought it ended at cuckoo. Now you listen to me, if you want to start acting like a brother who cares about me, then terrific. Bring it on. But you try one time to tell me who I should be sleeping with, and you and I are going to go round and round the way we did when we were little. Remember?(Sheldon hurriedly crosses his legs.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have an alternate proposal.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You donate eggs. We will place them in cryogenic storage. I will find an appropriate sperm donor for your eggs, have them fertilized and implanted in you, that way everybody wins.

Scene: The living room. Sheldon enters limping, holding his groin area.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Correction. Missy can date whoever she wants.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, we have to settle this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I agree. Sheldon’s sister is hiding at Penny’s because we’ve all been hitting on her at the same time.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She’s not hiding. She needed privacy to call her grandmother who’s apparently very sick. Oh, and then I believe she has to wash her hair.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, you poor, deluded bastard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t start with me dude.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You want to go again? Let’s go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If we’re going to fight over Missy, let’s do it the right way. The honourable way.
(Time shift. Sheldon enters to hear sounds of fighting. It becomes apparent that the guys are playing a boxing game on a Nintendo Wii.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And he’s down!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, come on, get up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Stay down, bitch. Yeah, ha ha, natural selection at work.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I weep for humanity.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me while I go tell Missy the good news.(Leaves and knocks on Penny’s door.)

Speaker: Penny(answering)
Dialogue: Ah, hey Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi Penny, how’s it going. Listen, that guy Mike that you were dating, is that still going on?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, pretty much, why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nothing, just catching up. By the way, may I speak to Missy please?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Hi, Leonard, what’s up?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, since you’re leaving tomorrow I was wondering if you’d like to go out to dinner with me?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: That’s so sweet. But no thanks.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. You have other plans, or…?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Alright uh… enjoy the rest of your evening.

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Thanks. See you.

Speaker: Leonard(returning)
Dialogue: Um, here’s something we didn’t anticipate.
(Time shift. Penny opens door to Howard.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What do you want, Howard?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m fine, thanks for asking. I’ve come to call on Missy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Missy?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Hi Howard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The amazing Howard. Do you like magic?

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Not really. No.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Then you are in for a treat. Behold, an ordinary cane.(Taps against doorpost. While humming he tries to perform a trick, but the cane falls in half with a yellow handkerchief flying out. Howard has to retrieve the pieces.)Da-dah!(Emerges with the handkerchief, on which are written the words “will you go out with me?”)

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay.(Does something with hands, from which another yellow handkerchief emerges. This one reads “are you sure?” Missy closes the door.)
(Time shift. Penny opens the door to Raj.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Missy?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you. I apprec….(looks panicked)apprec…. appreeee…. oh-oh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, honey, is your medication wearing off?(Raj nods.)

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Oh, hi, cutie pie. I was hoping you’d show up.
(Raj attempts to speak. All that emerges is a high pitched wail. After a few more attempts he turns and leaves down the stairs, still making the same sound.)

Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: We had a dog who made a noise like that. Had to put him down.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Any news you want me to pass along to Mom?

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, she might be interested to know that I have refocused my research from bosonic string theory to heteronic string theory.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Yeah, I’ll just tell her you said hey.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, well, it was pleasant seeing you, other than that business with my testicles.(Holds out hand to shake.)

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Come on, Shelly.(Hugs him. He looks uncomfortable, then hugs back half heartedly.)I want you to know I’m very proud of you.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really?

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Yup, I’m always bragging to my friends about my brother the rocket scientist.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You tell people I’m a rocket scientist?

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Well yeah.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m a theoretical physicist.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: What’s the difference?

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s the difference?

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Missy
Dialogue: Goodbye Shelly.

Scene: The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My God! Why don’t you just tell them I’m a toll taker at the Golden Gate Bridge? Rocket scientist, how humiliating.

Scene: The Cheesecake Factory. Raj and Sheldon are arm wrestling while playing tetris. There is a cacophony of cries such as “take him down” and “he’s got you, Sheldon.”
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, guys, guys, some of the other waitresses wanted me to ask you something.

Dialogue: No. But it was okay. I mean, when I was little I’d think maybe my parents would change their mind, and surprise me with a party, like this one birthday I came home from my Cello lesson, and I saw a lot of strange cars parked out front, and when I got to the door I could hear people whispering, and I could smell German chocolate cake, which is my favourite.

Scene: The Cheesecake Factory. Raj and Sheldon are arm wrestling while playing tetris. There is a cacophony of cries such as “take him down” and “he’s got you, Sheldon.”

Scene: The Cheesecake Factory. Raj and Sheldon are arm wrestling while playing tetris. There is a cacophony of cries such as “take him down” and “he’s got you, Sheldon.”
Dialogue: Credits sequence.

Speaker: Howard(voice from inside)
Dialogue: Make sure they remember no peanuts.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, every Thai restaurant in town knows you can’t eat peanuts. They see me coming they go “ah, no peanut boy!”
(Leonard exits down stairs. A moment later, Penny peeks out of her apartment, checks the coast is clear, and crosses the hall to the guys apartment. Knocks.)

Speaker: Sheldon(answering)
Dialogue: Hello Penny. Leonard just left.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I know. I want to talk to you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What would we talk about? We’ve no overlapping areas of interest I’m aware of, and you know I don’t care for chit-chat.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, can you just let me in.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well alright, but I don’t see this as a promising endeavour.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, here’s the deal, we are going to throw Leonard a kick-ass surprise party for his birthday on Saturday.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hardly think so, Leonard made it very clear he doesn’t want a party.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Did someone say party?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He just doesn’t know he wants one because he’s never had one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I suppose that’s possible, but for the record, I’ve never had a threesome and yet I still know I want one.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Howard, here’s the difference. The possibility exists that Leonard could have a birthday party before hell freezes over.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fine. If I do have a threesome, you can’t be part of it. I’m just kidding, yes you can. Can you bring a friend?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think a birthday party is a terrible idea. I envy Leonard for growing up without that anguish.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Anguish?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Year after year, I had to endure wearing conical hats while being forced into the crowded sweaty hell of bouncy castles, not to mention being blindfolded and spun towards a grotesque tailless donkey as the other children mocked my disorientation.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, sweetie, I understand you have scars that no non-professional can heal, but nevertheless we are going to throw Leonard a birthday party.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Have I pointed out that I am extremely uncomfortable with dancing, loud music and most other forms of alcohol induced frivolity.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Nevertheless we are….

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In addition I really don’t think that Leonard wants a…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, here’s the deal, you either help me throw Leonard a birthday party or, so help me God, I will go into your bedroom and I will unbag all of your most valuable mint condition comic books. And on one of them, you won’t know which, I’ll draw a tiny happy face in ink.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can’t do that, if you make a mark on a mint comic book it’s no longer mint.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, do you understand the concept of blackmail?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well of course I… oh! Yeah, I have an idea, let’s throw Leonard a kick ass birthday party.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s not the secret knock. This is the secret knock.(He knocks two, one, two.)

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: What difference does it make?

Dialogue: Well, Raj got him an awesome limited edition Dark Knight sculpture based on Alex Ross’s definitive Batman, and I got him this amazing autographed copy of the Feynman lectures on physics.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: That’s because I didn’t bring one.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well why not?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t ask.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The entire institution of gift giving makes no sense.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Too late.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let’s say that I go out and I spend fifty dollars on you, it’s a laborious activity, because I have to imagine what you need, whereas you know what you need. Now I can simplify things, just give you the fifty dollars directly and, you could give me fifty dollars on my birthday, and so on until one of us dies leaving the other one old and fifty dollars richer. And I ask you, is it worth it?

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Told you not to ask.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, Sheldon, you’re his friend. Friends give each other presents.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I accept your premise, I reject your conclusion.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Try telling him it’s a non-optional social convention.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: Just do it.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: It’s a non-optional social convention.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Fair enough.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He came with a manual.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Question, how am I going to get Leonard a present before the party? I don’t drive, and the only things available within walking distance are a Thai restaurant and a gas station. I suppose I could wrap up an order of mee krob and a couple of lottery scratchers.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: Okay, let’s do this, um, I will drive Sheldon to get a present, and Howard, you need to get rid of Leonard for about two hours.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: No problem.

Dialogue: And then Raj, you bring the stuff across the hall and start setting up.

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Dialogue: What if guests show up?

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
Speaker: Penny

Scene: Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard(entering)
Dialogue: Hey!

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How’s it going?

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, listen, the New Art is showing the revised definitive cut of Blade Runner.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Seen it.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, you’ve seen the 25thanniversary final cut. This one has eight seconds of previously unseen footage. They say it completely changes the tone of the film.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Pass.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, afterwards there’s a Q & A with Harrison Ford’s body double.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, I am in the Halo battle of my life here, there’s this kid in Copenhagen, he has no immune system so all he does is sit in his bubble and play Halo 24/7.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Can’t you play him some other time?

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not if you believe his doctors.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh my God, do you smell gas.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, no.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, you know they have DVDs over there.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, but they have DVD burners over here. Leonard needs a DVD burner.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, a gift shouldn’t be something someone needs, it should be something fun, you know, something they wouldn’t buy for themselves.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You mean, like a sweater?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it’s a fun sweater, it’s got a bold geometric print.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is it the geometry that makes it fun.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, the point is, one of the ways we show we care about people is by putting thought and imagination into the gifts we give them.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, I see, so not a DVD burner.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Something he wouldn’t buy for himself. Something fun. Something like… oh, an 802.11n wireless router.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here you go, Copenhagen boy, how about a taste of Hans Christian Hand Grenade.(Raj enters carrying party supplies. Howard waves him away while in the background Leonard is heard saying “oh, that did not feel good.”)Come on, come on, oh you clever little…. Come on, come on, take that!

Speaker: Howard(picks up a granola bar from the table, breaks off half and puts it in his back pocket.)
Dialogue: Oh-oh.(Louder)Oh-oh!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s the matter?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: This granola bar, there’s peanuts in it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh my God, why did you eat it?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know, it was just there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well if I had a gun there, would you have shot yourself?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t yell at me, I’ve got to go to the emergency room.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, after my tongue has swollen to the size of a brisket.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, um, just, uh, let me get my keys.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh God, oh God, oh God, oh….(into phone after Leonard leaves room)The laundry is out of the hamper.(Looks exasperated)Okay Sheldon, what was it supposed to be? Fine, it’s out of the washer. I’ll call you when it’s in the dryer.

Speaker: Leonard(running in)
Dialogue: Alright, let’s go.(They exit, with Howard making croaking noises.)

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What do you think.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny(pointing randomly)
Dialogue: Um, that one.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because of the two additional Ethernet ports.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sure.
