Dialogue: He doesn’t need them, he’s already got a 640 connect switch

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, okay then this one.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know, the man on the box looks so happy.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny! If I’m going to buy Leonard a gift, I’m going to do it right. I refuse to let him experience the same childhood trauma I did.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I know I’m going to regret this but, what trauma?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: On my twelfth birthday I really wanted a titanium centrifuge, so, you know, I could separate radioactive isotopes.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Of course.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Instead of a titanium centrifuge, my parents bought me… wow, this is hard. They got me… a motorised dirt bike.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What twelve year old boy wants a motorised dirt bike?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All of them.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Huh?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so we’re getting this one?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I suppose.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, let’s go.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Random woman
Dialogue: Excuse me, do you know anything about this stuff?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know everything about this stuff.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Woman
Dialogue: Okay, I have my own wholesale flower business, and I want to hook up my computer in the front entrance with the one in my refrigerated warehouse.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Here, buy this one. Look, it’s the one we’re getting, see, happy guy available.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, she doesn’t want that, she needs a point to point peer network with a range extender.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Woman
Dialogue: Thank you.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Random guy
Dialogue: Which hard drive do I want, firewire or USB?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It depends on what Bus you have.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Guy
Dialogue: I drive a Chevy Cavalier.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, dear lord.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, we have to go.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is looking at two routers.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not now, Penny, this poor man needs me.(To woman approaching)You hold on, I’ll be right with you. What computer do you have, and please don’t say a white one?

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Fill this out, have a seat.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, listen, see we’re throwing my friend a surprise party and I’m supposed to keep him out of his apartment for two hours.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Uh-huh, fill this out and have a seat.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, see, the only way I could get him to leave is to tell him I ate a peanut. Because I’m allergic to peanuts.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Oh, well in that case fill this out and have a seat.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, all I need from you is to take me in the back and give me a band-aid so I can pretend I had a shot of epinephrine and they you tell my friend you need to keep me under observation for about an hour, hour and a half.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Is that all you need?

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Get out of my ER.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, you don’t understand.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Oh, I understand, but unfortunately this hospital is not equipped to treat stupid.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, I get it, I know how the world works, how about if I were to introduce you(holding up a five dollar bill)to the man who freed your people.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Dialogue: Nurse, unless my people were freed by Benjamin Franklin and his five twin brothers you are wasting your time.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Leonard(running in)
Dialogue: Hey, sorry I couldn’t find a parking spot, how are you doing.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Bad, very bad.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really, ‘cos you don’t look like you’re swelling up at all, maybe we should just pick up some benedryl at the drug store and go home.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We can’t go home.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why not?

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Becauth(pretends tongue has swollen up)Becauth-th-th. Brissket, Brissket! Water, need water.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright, I’ll be right back.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard(into phone)
Dialogue: Penny, look, I’ve got a problem.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny(with Sheldon in background at the head of a large queue of customers)
Dialogue: Yeah, well so do I, look you’ve got to stall Leonard a little longer.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t think I can.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You have to, we all have to be there at the same time to yell “surprise!”

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, you have to understand something, we’re in a hospital right now.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why, is Leonard okay.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Leonard’s fine. I’m fine, thanks for asking, by the way.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I don’t need your attitude, just hold him there a little longer.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, I’ve done my best but he wants to go home and I don’t know how to stop him.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, how about this. You keep him there a little longer and when you get to the party I’ll point out which of my friends are easy.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t toy with me, woman.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’ve got a hot former fat girl with no self-esteem, I’ve got a girl who punishes her father by sleeping around and an alcoholic who’s two tequila shots away from letting you wear her like a hat.

Scene: The hospital. Howard runs in and up to the counter.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thy will be done.(Thinks. Reaches into back pocket, finds the half a granola bar from earlier. Looks down.)I’m doing this for you, little buddy.(Takes a bite.)

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, we don’t have that in stock, but I can special order it for you.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Penny(with shop assistant, points at Sheldon)
Dialogue: Him.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Assistant
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir, you don’t work here.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, well, apparently neither does anyone else.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, we have to go.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, for one thing, we’re late for Leonard’s birthday party. And for another, I told him to call security.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Sheldon(to customer)
Dialogue: Good luck.(To assistant)By the way, a six year-old could hack your computer system.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Keep walking.

Scene: The store. Sheldon is on the in-store computer.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, 1-2-3-4 is not a secure password.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me, my friend is having an allergic reaction to peanuts.

Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: No he’s not.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes he is.

Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Look, sir we are very busy here and I just don’t…(sees Leonard whose face has swollen all over)holy crap!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Pees hep me!

Speaker: Nurse
Dialogue: Code 4, I need a gurney, right away, right away.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fank-u.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Say what you will about the healthcare system in this country, but when they’re afraid of lawsuits they sure test everything.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I really don’t think the colonoscopy was necessary.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, before you got all swollen up, I actually thought you were trying to keep me out of the apartment so you could throw me a surprise party.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, right, it’s your birthday, I had no idea it was your birthday, I completely forgot, wow, what a lousy way to spend a birthday, well it’s all over now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There is a party, isn’t there.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Are you mad?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: how could I be mad? You actually risked your life because you cared about me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s why I did it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Alright. Here we go. My first birthday party.

(Opens door. Raj is drunkenly singing True Colors very badly into a microphone with his shirt off and a bandana round his head while waving a beer bottle. Penny and Sheldon are asleep on the couch and armchair respectively.)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dude! Everybody left an hour ago! Surprise!
Time shift. View of a mobile phone video screen. Raj has a woman sitting on his shoulders.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay Leonard, here I am at your birthday party, I don’t know where you are dude, but it’s really kick-ass. Everyone is very very drunk, and uh…(girl pours booze into his mouth)Oh look, there’s a girl taking her shirt off.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s my friend Carol. Remind me, I’ve got to introduce her to Howard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh sweet Krishna, shake it, that-a rupee maker.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m so sorry you didn’t get your party.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, it’s okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Happy birthday anyways.(She kisses him full on the lips.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey Penny, when, uh, when’s your birthday?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wo de zhing shi Sheldon.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, it’s Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon.(Makes a hand movement with every syllable.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon.(Copies hand movements.)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s this?(Repeats hand movements.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s what you did. I assumed as in a number of languages that the gesture was part of the phrase.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well it’s not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How am I supposed to know that? As the teacher it’s your obligation to separate your personal idiosyncrasies from the subject matter.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know, I’m really glad you decided to learn Mandarin.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Once you’re fluent you’ll have a billion more people to annoy instead of me.

Speaker: Leonard(entering)
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Mai du lui tsa.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You just called Leonard a syphilitic donkey.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My apologies Leonard, I’m only as good as my teacher.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why are you learning Chinese?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I believe the Szechuan Palace has been passing off orange chicken as tangerine chicken and I intend to confront them.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If I were you, I’d be more concerned by what they’re passing off as chicken.

Speaker: Penny(storming in)
Dialogue: I need to use your window.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, no, sure, go ahead.

Speaker: Penny(opening window)
Dialogue: Hey Jerkface, you forgot your iPod!(Throws it out.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s going on?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll tell you what’s going on, that stupid self-centred bastard wrote about our sex life in his blog.(Out of window)Drop dead, you stupid self-centred bastard!(To Leonard)Thank you.(exit)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, where were we?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Not now, I have a blog to find.
(Credits sequence)

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny, are you okay?

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Penny(voice off)
Dialogue: I’m fine, Leonard, just go away.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, I understand that breaking up with someone can be very painful….

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: GO AWAY!

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, feel better, bye.(Goes back to apartment)She doesn’t want to talk.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not surprising. Penny’s emotional responses originate from the primitive portion of the brain known as the Amygdala, while speech is centred in the much more recently developed Neocortex. The former can easily overpower the latter giving scientific credence to the notion of being rendered speechless.(Leonard stares at him.)Or maybe she just doesn’t want to talk.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Raj(entering)
Dialogue: Hey, look, I found an iPod.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s smashed beyond repair, what are you going to do with it?

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What else? Sell it on ebay as slightly used.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It was Penny’s boyfriend’s, they broke up.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Apparently he posted intimate details of their physical relationship on his blog, which I cannot find anywhere.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know what, I’m going to go back and try talking to her again.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Good idea. Sit with her, hold her, comfort her, and if the moment feels right, see if you can cop a feel.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not going to do that, Howard.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not aware of any social convention that requires you to intervene at all.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What about “damsel in distress?”

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Twelfth century code of chivalry, not exactly current. You’d also have to be knighted for that to apply.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t care. She’s upset, I’m going over there.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Remember to sit on your hands a bit so they’re warm.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m her friend, I’m not going to take advantage of her vulnerability.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What, so you’re saying that if in the depths of despair she throws herself at you and demands you take her, right there, right now, you’ll just walk away?

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door and knocks.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I said I’m her friend. Not her gay friend.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard(knocking and entering)
Dialogue: Hey, listen, I know you said that you didn’t want to talk…

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard(leaving)
Dialogue: Sorry.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait, did you say wait?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Tell me the truth. Am I just an idiot who picks giant losers?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. No.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so I pick good guys, but turn them into losers.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Of course not.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it’s got to be one or the other, which is it?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, what were the choices again?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I really thought Mike was different, I thought he was sensitive and smart. I mean, not you smart, normal non-freaky smart.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, no, sure.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, and then he just goes and has to humiliate me by writing about me on his blog so the entire world can read it.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually it’s not all that easy to find.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, really, well my friends at work found it, my sister found it, judging by my email a number of prisoners at the Michigan State Penitentiary found it.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, well, what exactly did this guy write, not that I need to know the details of your sex life, I just thought…. never mind.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Nope, you know what, you might as well read it, everybody else has, go ahead. Oh God, I just feel so betrayed and embarrassed. I just want to crawl into a hole and die.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, well, you know, this isn’t that bad. It just paints the picture of a very affectionate woman who’s open to expressing her affection in non traditional locales.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh God!

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Elevators, parks, movie theatres, out of curiosity, is this subway the transportation system or subway the sandwich shop?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sandwich shop.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Doesn’t that violate the health code?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, at the sub shop we were only making out.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Huh. Okay. But my point is that you have absolutely no reason to be embarrassed.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, do you think I overreacted?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe a little.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: ‘Cause I do that, I do overreact. Maybe I should call Mike and apologise.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. No, no, that, that would be underreacting. He did break the implied confidentiality of the bedroom and, in your case, the elevator, parks and fast food franchise.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes. You’re right. I should just say I’m done with him.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, you should, go ahead, say it.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: But I never gave the man a chance to explain.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What is there to explain, it’s all right here, it’s a betrayal.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, you were right the first time, this is a man who loves me, but in his own stupid way he was just trying to show people how he feels.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m pretty sure I never said that.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, you did better than that, you helped me see it on my own.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aw, good for me. Where are you going?

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m going over to Mike’s. Leonard, thank you so much.

Scene: Penny’s flat. Penny is eating ice cream from the tub.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, sure. Huh, maybe I am her gay friend.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard, I’m going to need another Mandarin lesson. I obviously didn’t make my point with those people.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: For God’s sake, Sheldon, if you don’t like the tangerine chicken, don’t order the tangerine chicken.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I like tangerine chicken, I’m not getting tangerine chicken.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can we please change the subject.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sure. Tell us again how you screwed up and got Penny back together with her old boyfriend.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just roll the dice.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Raj(rolls and moves)
Dialogue: Enslaved by warlocks, stay here till you roll 2, 4 or 6…7

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She was mad at him. She was done with him, the relationship was broken beyond repair and I walked over there and I fixed it!

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Boy, that story gets better every time you hear it.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Actually, I thought the first two renditions were far more compelling. Previously I felt sympathy for the Leonard character, now I just find him to be whiny and annoying.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just eat your tangerine chicken.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’d love to, but I don’t have tangerine chicken.

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Penny(storming in)
Dialogue: Thank you so much for your stupid advice.(Slams door again.)

Scene: The apartment. The guys are playing a board game and eating Chinese food.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Incredible. You managed to screw up the screw-up.

Speaker: Leonard(knocking and entering)
Dialogue: I’m back.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry I yelled at you. It’s not your fault.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I went over to Mike’s to make up with him.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I know, I know that part.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: But he had already moved on.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Already, that was quick.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s what I said to the woman who had her legs wrapped around his neck.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, Penny, I am so sorry.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How could he do that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, well, you know, you did throw an 8 gig iPod… yeah, no, how could he do that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I swear to God, I am done with guys like that. You know, macho, with the perfect body and the hair, and the money.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, that must get old quick.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, just once, I would like to go out with someone who is nice, and honest, and who actually cares about me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What about me?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What about you what?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What about if you went out with me?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you asking me out?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Um… yes… I am… asking you out.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I was just going off your comment about the nice guy…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I know, I got that. Yeah, totally.

Speaker: Leonard(continuing through Penny)
Dialogue: …thing and honest but, it’s no big deal…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes what?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes, I will go out with you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Why not, I mean, what do I have to lose?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. That’s the spirit.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Show me your citrus peels. Gei wo kan, ni jud di zi pei. Show me your citrus peels. Gei wo kan, ni jud di zi pei. Show me your…

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny(tapping him on the shoulder)
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon(jumping in panic)
Dialogue: Aieee ya! Xia si wo le.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry. Look, do you have a second.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A second what? Pair of underwear?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I was just wondering if I could talk to you? It’s about Leonard.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why me? Why not Koothrappali or Wolowitz?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, Raj can’t talk to me unless he’s drunk, and Wolowitz is, you know, disgusting.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, I suppose he is.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All I’m saying is, you know Leonard the best.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not necessarily. I’m often surprised by my lack of familiarity with Leonard. Just the other day I discovered, he not only has a loofah, he hides it. Why do you suppose a man would be ashamed of having a loofah? I myself prefer to have my excess epithelial cells slough off naturally, but I don’t condemn those who seek to accelerate the process.(Time shift) And until recently I had no idea that despite his lactose intolerance, he can tolerate small amounts of non-fat ice cream without producing a noxious gas that I maintain in the right concentration could be weaponised.(Begins to unlock apartment door.)

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard might come home, can we talk in my apartment.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We’re not done?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ach, why not? We’re already through the looking glass anyway.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so, here’s the thing. I guess you’re aware that Leonard asked me out.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, he didn’t actually say anything, but when he came back to the apartment he was doing a dance that brought to mind the happy hippos in Fantasia.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s nice. Anyhow, the thing I wanted to talk to you about is, you know, since Leonard and I have become friends, I was just… want to sit down?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I wish it were that simple. You see, I don’t spend much time here and so I’ve never really chosen a place to sit.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, choose.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There are a number of options and, I’m really not familiar enough with the cushion densities, air flow patterns and dispersion of sunlight to make an informed choice.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, why don’t you just pick one at random, and then if you don’t like it you can sit somewhere else next time.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, that’s crazy. You go ahead and talk while I figure it out.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Um, here’s the thing. So, I’ve known for a while now that Leonard has had a little crush on me…

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A little crush? Well I suppose so, in the same way Menelaus had a little crush on Helen of Troy.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, yeah, I don’t really know who they are…

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well Menelaus was the brother of Agamemnon…

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I don’t care, I don’t care. The point is Leonard isn’t the kind of guy I usually go out with.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard isn’t the kind of guy anyone usually goes out with. Would you be open to rotating the couch clockwise thirty degrees?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. What I’m saying is, Leonard might be different in a good way. Obviously my usual choices have not worked out so well.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The last one worked out well for Koothrappali. He got a free iPod. Oh, glare!

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: But on the other hand, if things don’t go well with Leonard, I risk losing a really good friend. I mean, I guess he’s not looking for a fling, he’s the kind of guy that gets into a relationship for, I don’t know, like you would say light years.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I would not say that. No-one would say that, a light year is a unit of distance, not time.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you for the clarification.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Draft. You see people hear the word year and they think duration. Foot pound has the same problem, that’s a unit of work, not of weight.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Right, thanks.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a common mistake.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Not the first one I’ve made today.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. I think this will be my seat.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, do you have anything to say that has anything to do with, you know, what I’m talking about.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, let’s see. We might consider Schrodinger’s Cat.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Schrodinger? Is that the woman in 2A?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. That’s Mrs Grossinger. And she doesn’t have a cat, she has a Mexican hairless, annoying little animal, yip yip yip yip…

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon!

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sorry, you diverted me. Anyway, in 1935, Erwin Schrodinger, in an attempt to explain the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics, he proposed an experiment where a cat is placed in a box with a sealed vial of poison that will break open at a random time. Now, since no-one knows when or if the poison has been released, until the box is opened, the cat can be thought of as both alive and dead.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I don’t get the point.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well of course you don’t get it, I haven’t made it yet. You’d have to be psychic to get it, and there’s no such thing as psychic.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, what’s the point?

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just like Schrodinger’s Cat, your potential relationship with Leonard right now can be thought of as both good and bad. It is only by opening the box that you’ll find out which it is.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so you’re saying I should go out with Leonard.

Scene: The lobby. Sheldon is listening to an iPod.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, no, no. Let me start again. In 1935, Erwin Schrodinger…

Speaker: Leonard(pointing)
Dialogue: Two seats right there.

Speaker: Sheldon(to two oriental-looking people occupying the other seats)
Dialogue: Chong sho sha pwe.(Caption translates to “Long Live Concrete”.)Xie xie.(Thank you)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I think I’ve made a mistake.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can see that. Unless you’re planning on running a marathon, choosing both stuffing and mashed potatoes is a starch filled redundancy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, it’s about Penny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A mistake involving Penny? Okay, you’ll have to narrow it down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t think I can go out with her tonight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then don’t.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Other people would say “why not?”

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Other people might be interested.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m going to talk anyway.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I assumed you would.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Now that I’m actually about to go out with Penny, I’m not excited, I’m nauseous.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ah, then your meal choice is appropriate. Starch absorbs fluid which reduces the amount of vomit available for violent expulsion.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You also made a common grammatical mistake, you said nauseous when you meant nauseated. But go on.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, this date is probably my one chance with Penny, what happens if I blow it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if we accept your premise, and also accept the highly improbable assumption that Penny is the only woman in the world for you then we can logically conclude that the result of blowing it would be that you end up a lonely, bitter old man with no progeny. The image of any number of evil lighthouse keepers from Scooby Doo cartoons comes to mind.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re not helping.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Alright, what response on my part would bring this conversation to a speedy conclusion?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Tell me whether or not to go through with the date.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Schrodinger’s Cat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wow, that’s brilliant.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You sound surprised. Mmm, hou zi shui zai li du.(Your monkey sleeps inside me.)

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: come on in.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. You look very nice.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you. So do you.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I made an eight o’clock reservation.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, great, listen, um, maybe we should talk first.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Okay. But before you say anything, have you ever heard of Schrodinger’s Cat?

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Actually, I’ve heard far too much about Schrodinger’s Cat.

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good.(He grabs her and kisses her.)

Scene: Leonard approaches Penny’s door. He is wearing a suit. He knocks. Penny answers.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, the cat’s alive, let’s go to dinner.

Speaker: Sheldon(in Mandarin)
Dialogue: Show me your mucus! Your mucus!

Speaker: Owner(in Mandarin)
Dialogue: Blow your own nose and go away.

Speaker: Sheldon(in Mandarin)
Dialogue: This is not a tangerine bicycle.

Speaker: Owner(in English)
Dialogue: Crazy man. Call the police.

Speaker: Sheldon(in Mandarin)
Dialogue: No. Don’t call the library. Show me your mucus.(Leonard and Penny are seen entering, and then leaving again quickly.)Oxen are in my bed! Many, many oxen! Oy Vey!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So you see, what you’re eating is not technically yoghurt, because it doesn’t have enough live acidophilus cultures. It’s really just iced milk with carragenin added for thickness.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s very interesting.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s also not pink and has no berries.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, but it doesn’t really answer my question.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What was your question again?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you want some.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, right, no, I’m lactose intolerant.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, gas.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, good night.(They kiss. Camera cuts away to a wall mounted security cam above the lift. Leonard spots its movement and shuffles Penny away.)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There was a draft.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I didn’t feel a draft.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why don’t we just go into your….

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, you know what, maybe we should just slow things down a little.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, I didn’t mean to go into your apartment to… go fast.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I know, I… I know what you meant, it’s just… it’s only our first date.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, okay, sure, no problem, why don’t we just figure out where we’re going, and when we want to get there, and then rate of speed equals distance over time. Solve for R.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Or we could just wing it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That might work too.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Goodnight Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Goodnight.(He throws the camera a dirty look.)
Cut to inside the apartment.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He’s coming. Screen saver.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, hey, Leonard, how was your date?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Bite me. Sheldon, how could you just sit there and let them spy on me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They were clever, Leonard. They exploited my complete lack of interest in what you were doing.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You should thank us. When future generations try to determine why your relationship with Penny crashed and burned, this right here is the black box.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you talking about, the date went fine.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dude, she said she wants to slow things down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, so, she said she wants to slow things down. It’s like saying “I’m really enjoying this meal, I’m going to slow down and savour it.”

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, it’s like “this fish tastes bad, so I’m going to slow down and spit it out.”

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You being the fish.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not the fish.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh really, did you make a second date.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, we sort of decided to wing it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, even I know that’s lame.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, alright, let’s assume your hypothesis. We went to dinner, we talked, we laughed, we kissed, where could I have possibly gone wrong.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Think back, Leonard, the littlest things can set women off. Like, hey, the waitress is hot, I bet we could get her to come home with us. Or, how much does your mom weigh, I want to know what I’m getting into.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t say anything like that.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Good, ‘cos they don’t work.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: They also don’t care for it if you stare at them and hyperventilate. Sadly, that’s my home run swing.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, everything went fine. I didn’t even have to refer to my impromptu conversation starters. The woman across the hall is into me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let’s go to the tape. Look at her reaction to the goodnight kiss, no change in respiration, pupils un-dilated, no flushing of the chest.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Nice close up, by the way.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Interesting, her jaws are clenched, no tongue access, clearly a bad sign amongst mating humans.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s not a bad sign.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Please, you might as well have been two iguana with no dewlap enlargement.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And the worst sign of all is, you’re here and not there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not there because I’m taking things slow. Which, by the way, compared to you guys approaches warp speed. And take down that camera.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He was a lot more fun when he had no hope.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Give him time.
Credits sequence

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny(entering)
Dialogue: Hi.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, hi Penny. FYI, the hot water is inadequate on machine 2 so colours only, and 4 is still releasing the fabric softener too early in the cycle so I’d avoid using that for your delicates.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny(tipping all her laundry into one machine at once)
Dialogue: Thanks.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, good Lord. Why don’t you just take your clothes down to the river and beat them with a rock?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, may I ask you a question?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I would prefer that you not, but I won’t go so far as to forbid it.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, I heard yes, so… okay, here’s my question, has Leonard ever dated, you know, a regular girl.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well I assume you’re not referring to digestive regularity? Because I’ve come to learn that such inquiries are inappropriate.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I meant has he ever been involved with someone who wasn’t a braniac?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Well, a few years ago he did go out with a woman who had a PhD in French Literature.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How is that not a braniac?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, for one thing, she was French. For another, it was literature.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, do you think that if Leonard and I keep dating he’ll eventually get bored with me.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That depends.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: On what?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you have a working knowledge of quantum physics?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you speak Klingon?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you know any card tricks?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, okay, you know, I get it, Leonard has no business being involved with a waitress slash actress who felt so insecure that she lied to him about finishing community college.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would you lie about that?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, he was going on and on about this college and that grad school and I didn’t want him to think I was some stupid loser.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You thought the opposite of stupid loser was community college graduate?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, there are a lot of successful people in this country who are community college graduates.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but you were neither.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Right, okay look, this is between you and me, you cannot tell Leonard any of this.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re asking me to keep a secret?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well I’m sorry, but you would have had to express that desire before revealing the secret, so that I could choose whether or not I wanted to accept the covenant of secret keeping. You can’t impose a secret on an ex post facto basis.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Secret keeping is a complicated endeavour. One has to be concerned not only about what one says, but about facial expression, autonomic reflexes, when I try to deceive, I myself have more nervous tics than a lyme disease research facility.(Long pause.)It’s a joke. It relies on the hominymic relationship between tick the blood-sucking arachnid, and tic the involuntary muscular contraction. I made it up myself.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, look, if Leonard finds out that I lied, I will absolutely die of embarrassment.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Physiologically impossible.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh Sheldon, please, look, I’m asking you as a friend.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So you’re saying that friendship contains within it an inherent obligation to maintain confidences?

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, yeah.

Scene: The laundry room. Sheldon is folding shirts.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Interesting. See, one more question, and perhaps I should have led with this, when did we become friends?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I.e, I couldn’t become Green Lantern unless I was chosen by the guardians of Oa, but given enough start-up capital and an adequate research facility, I could be Batman.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You could be Batman?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sure.(In a gravelly voice)I’m Batman. See.

Speaker: Penny(arriving)
Dialogue: Hi guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Sheldon(looking the other way uncomfortably)
Dialogue: Hi Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, Penny, if you’re not doing anything Friday night I thought maybe we could go and see a movie.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, um, you know, I think I have the dinner shift on Friday.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What about Saturday?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, I’m not sure, the manager hasn’t posted the schedule yet, how about I let you know.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great. So you just let me know when you know. So…(she leaves)Oh God, I am the bad fish! What did I do wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why are you asking me, I have no information about your interactions with Penny other than what you provided me, nor do I have any method of learning such things.(Runs away.)

Speaker: Leonard(chasing him)
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nothing. You seem to be implying an informational back channel between me and Penny where obviously none exists.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No I didn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I just think you need to be careful how you phrase things, sir.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s going on with you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well I might ask you the same question. Why do you insist on attempting to drag me into matters which have nothing to do with me? But exist between you and Penny. A person to whom I barely speak.(His eye begins to twitch.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s wrong with your face?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s no reason to bring my looks into this. Good day, Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I said Good Day!(He leaves)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good day?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Also today we have a fresh caught Alaska salmon, and that’s served with a teriyaki glaze and sticky rice. Our soup of the day…

Speaker: Sheldon(appearing behind her)
Dialogue: You must release me from my oath.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’m working.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why don’t you take a minute to decide(leads her away)I can’t keep your secret Penny. I’m going to fold like an energy based anobo protein in conformational space. Like a renaissance triptych. Like a cheap suit.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, look, why is it so hard for you to keep one little secret?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m constitutionally incapable. That’s why I was refused clearance for a very prestigious government research fellowship at a secret military supercollider, located beneath a fake agricultural station 12.5 miles south east of Travers City, Michigan. Which you did not hear about from me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, just forget I told you about me not graduating from community college. Okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Forget! You want me to forget? This mind does not forget. I haven’t forgotten a single thing since the day my mother stopped breast feeding me. It was a drizzly Tuesday.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, look, you promised me you would keep my secret so you’re just going to have to figure out a way to do it.

Speaker: Sheldon(entering)
Dialogue: Leonard, I’m moving out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What do you mean, you’re moving out? Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There doesn’t have to be a reason.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, there kind of does.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not necessarily. This is a classic example of munchausen’s trilemma. Either the reason is predicated on a series of sub-reasons leading to an infinite regression, or it tracks back to arbitrary axiomatic statements, or it’s ultimately circular, i.e., I’m moving out because I’m moving out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m still confused.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, I don’t see how I could have made it any simpler.

Speaker: Howard(entering)
Dialogue: Hey, qu’est q’wass up?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We just got back from that exhibit of those plasticised human cadavers.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And some of those skinless chicks were hot.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If you’ll excuse me, I’m going to pack.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s kind of an overreaction to a little harmless necrophilia.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s not you, Howard, he says he’s moving out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What did you do? Did you change the contrast or brightness settings on the television?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Did you take a band aid off in front of him?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Did you buy generic ketchup, forget to rinse the sink, talk to him through the bathroom door?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Adjust the thermostat, cook with cilantro, pronounce the T in often?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Did you make fun of trains?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t do anything, he’s just gone insane.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, we all knew this day was coming.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was fast.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s my pre-packed disaster evacuation bag. Recommended by the department of homeland security. And Sarah Connor.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where are you gonna live?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Until I find a permanent place I will stay with friends.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Bye(runs out.)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well you can’t stay with me, I have a teeny tiny apartment.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, but isn’t hosting guests an aspect of Menushya Yajna, one of the five central religious duties or sacrifices of the Hindu householder?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I hate trains.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t be ridiculous, you love trains.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes I do, come on. See you later Leonard.(Sheldon drops keys in bowl and leaves without a word.)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This could work.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is a very old building.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sixty years. Used to be a watch factory.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh-oh.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t you worry about the residual radium from the luminous dials?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Not until now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t believe I didn’t bring my gieger counter. You know, I had it on my bed and I didn’t pack it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, if you’re not comfortable staying here, Sheldon…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m kidding, I packed it. It was a joke, I was subverting the conversational expectations. I believe they call that the, um, old switcheroo.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Terrific.

Speaker: Sheldon(referring to Bollywood singing on television)
Dialogue: Is that woman Aishwarya Rai?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, isn’t she an amazing actress.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Actually, I’d say she’s a poor man’s Madhuri Dixit.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How dare you. Aishwarya Rai is a Goddess. By comparison Madhuri Dixit is a leprous prostitute.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sorry, I didn’t mean to offend you. Obviously you’re not that familiar with Indian cinema.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: Voice
Dialogue: Strippergram.(Howard opens door. Outside are Raj and Sheldon.)

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Tag. You’re it.(Runs away.)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Shouldn’t you have put him in a brown paper bag and set him on fire?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny thinks I’m too smart for her, that’s ridiculous.

Dialogue: Hi.

Dialogue: What are you talking about.

é

Dialogue: So, Howard’s really in space, huh?

Dialogue: Mm-hmm, International Space Station. 250 miles that way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Right now, Howard’s staring down at our planet like a tiny Jewish Greek god. Zeusowitz.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I must admit, I can’t help but feel a twinge of envy. He can look out the window and see the majesty of the universe unfolding before his eyes. His dim, uncomprehending eyes. It’s like a cat in an airport carrying case.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, it’s not exactly glamorous up there. The water that the astronauts drink is made from each other’s recycled urine.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Must be nice. Nobody wants anything that comes out of me.

Dialogue: I wonder what he’s doing right this very second.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mm, conducting experiments in zero gravity.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Peering through his telescope at the birth of the cosmos.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Whatever it is, we know his life will never be the same.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I can hear you without the phone,

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m excited to talk to you, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How about calling her my wife?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: They do. That’s why we marry them.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ma, please. Everyone from NASA is listening to this phone call.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, Ma, great talking to you. Gotta go. Well, space is ruined.
Credits sequence.

Dialogue: Oh, yes. According to the Relationship Agreement, on the anniversary of our first date, he must take me to a nice dinner, ask about my day and engage in casual physical contact that a disinterested onlooker might mistake for intimacy.

Scene: Penny’s apartment. Penny is bleaching Amy’s upper lip.
