Scene: Penny’s apartment. Penny is bleaching Amy’s upper lip.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, boo-hoo. If Sheldon proposed to me during sex, my ovaries would grab on to him and never let go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, where do you stand on the anthropic principle?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Interesting question. On the one hand, I always thought…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You don’t even know what it is, do you? The anthropic principle states that if we wish to explain why our universe exists the way it does, the answer is that it must have qualities that allow intelligent creatures to arise who are capable of asking the question. As I am doing so eloquently right now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know what the anthropic principle is.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course. I just explained it to you. Now, where do you stand on it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where do you stand on it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Strongly pro.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then I believe that God created the world in six days, and on the seventh he made you to annoy me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, wait, Raj, where do you stand on the anthropic principle?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m all for it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Attaboy!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, hang on. Why do you believe that he knows what it is and I don’t?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, Leonard. Let’s not take a saw to the branch we’re sitting on, shall we?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, uh, if you guys are free tonight, I heard about a spa where you soak your feet n a pool full of little fish that eat all the dead skin right off them. I don’t need to tell you in Los Angeles, sandal season is year round.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually, I’m hanging out with Penny.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, okay. Sounds like it’s me and you, Sheldon. How about we sic some guppies on those puppies?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: As I’ve stated before on numerous occasions, the only sea creature I would even consider being eaten by is the Kraken, because the last words I would hear are “Release the Kraken.” That never gets old. “Release the Kraken!” Oh, chills. Besides, I’m having dinner with Amy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, okay. I’ll just go home and be alone. Which is cool. I eat alone, I sleep alone, I cry alone, so, cool.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Darn. If you weren’t busy, I’d ask you to join us.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Really? I can come? Thanks.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you sure you want to be bringing Raj on your date night with Amy?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, absolutely. I have a contractual obligation to provide Amy with conversation and casual physical contact, but nowhere is it specified that I can’t outsource that to an Indian.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, there’s my beautiful bride. Can you see me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I can. How are you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m amazing. I mean, this is even better than I dreamed. I look out the window, and it’s all so unbelievable.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Good for you. I just had a seemingly endless dinner with your mom.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah? That’s nice.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It was. Until I found out you never told her we’re not gonna live with her. Let’s talk about that for a minute.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, look, this pen is floating. How crazy is that?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You said you told her, but you never did!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, okay, I know you’re upset, but let me share something I’ve learned since I got here. You realize how small your problems are when you’re looking down on them from space. Now, come on, that’s got to make you feel better.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: How clear is the image of me on that screen?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Pretty clear.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Do I look like I feel better?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I mean, it’s not, like, HD quality.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Listen, mister, you’re gonna talk to your mother and you’re gonna fix this, or that thing I said I was gonna do to you the minute you got home, you can do to yourself.

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: Like he’s been doing since he got here.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, this place is so romantic.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m glad you like it. Raj picked it out.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, when you see him, tell him I say thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Tell him yourself.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yoo-hoo! Over here!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t understand. What’s he doing here?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I invited him.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: On our date? Sheldon, that’s not okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, it is. There’s a loophole in the Relationship Agreement.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You found a loophole?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry I started without you. I’m a little nervous. It’s been a long time since I’ve been on a date.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can’t believe I bleached my moustache for this.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You should go to my girl. She’ll knock out those sideburns for free.
Later.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, Amy, I don’t even think you and I have had a real conversation. Let’s use tonight to get to know each other a little better. You start.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Go home.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t understand.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, how could you do this? It’s our second anniversary.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s your anniversary? Oh, my God, I had no idea. Amy, please, let me make this right.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My pleasure. Waiter? A bottle of champagne and three glasses. Oh, boy, isn’t this romantic?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I hope that’s a rhetorical question, because I have no clue.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is great. What’s the occasion?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No occasion. You know, things have been a little weird between us, so I wanted to throw together a fun night just for you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That is so sweet.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I got all your favourites. Beer, wings, sliders. We can watch the football game. I even painted my stomach.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Go Sports?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, in case you were in the mood for baseball, I didn’t want to look ridiculous.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is awesome. I love it!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good, I’m glad.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Gosh, I worked my ass off today. This is exactly what I needed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great. Just relax and enjoy. Tonight is all about you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ah, thank you!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, where exactly are we in this relationship?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on. I just told you I had a hard day.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re right, I’m sorry. Let’s watch the game.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I just know the longer we wait to talk about it, the weirder it gets.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sweetie, can I just be the girl tonight?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Absolutely. You’re the girl, I’m the guy. Now, you watch your football game while I make you a little plate here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you.(Knock on door)

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll get it. Go sports.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hello-lo-lo.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you doing here? I thought you were out with Sheldon and Amy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I was, but it’s their anniversary and I didn’t want to be a third wheel, so I figured I’d come over here and hang out with you and Penny on your date.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, it’s not really a great time. Penny and I have some things we need to talk about.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, we don’t! Come on in!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sweet!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I can’t believe I shaved my stomach for this.

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: Hey, Froot Loops. You got a phone call.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: A woman who says she’s your mother but sounds like your father.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, Ma. You know, we could see each other if you turn on the computer.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can’t catch a computer virus.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What do you want, Ma?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, here it is. Bernadette and I are starting a life together and…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ma…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s not definite. I’ll talk to Bernadette.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Stop it, Ma. I’m sure I can get Bernie to come around.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, okay.

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: Oy. I can’t believe these people won the Cold War.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Now, can we please change the subject?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, I’m growing to like American football.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s fun, isn’t it?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, it’s not the balls-to-the-wall action of badminton or cricket, but hey, what is?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, who’s ready for another beer?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m good.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Girls.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I’m having the nicest time. You guys are like family to me. You know that, right?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s great. Get out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What? Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny and I have some issues we need to talk about.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh pish on your issues. You guys are fine. Yes, you hit some bumps along the way. I mean, Penny, you’ve always known how this man has felt about you, but you made him grovel for affection.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, hold on…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Now, don’t blame yourself. He was a groveller from way back. But the point is, the two of you got past it. And, Leonard, you go and propose to this poor girl in the middle of sex? That was some weak tea, dude.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Some people might say it was romantic.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, no. But yet, here you two are, still together. And that’s even after you and I had our crazy naked night.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s enough.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m just saying that after everything you’ve been through, you get to look into each other’s eyes and say “I love you.” And that’s beautiful.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually, to this day, she’s never really said it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, Penny. That’s ridiculous. You know you love him. You, you look him in the eyes and you say it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Raj.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh come on, you know you want to say it. Say it. Say you love him. Say it!

Scene: The hallway. Raj is ejected from the apartment.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I really thought she would say it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Have I ever told you you’re like a sexy praying mantis?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Every time you drink alcohol.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know what’s wonderful about the praying mantis? They devour their mate.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Your point being?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Dessert is served.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I just had cobbler.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know what? I’m done with this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: W-Where are you going?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m leaving.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can’t leave. I need you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. You’re my ride.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you either say something meaningful and from the heart, or you and I are done.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right. Please. Amy, when I look in your eyes and you’re looking back in mine, everything feels not quite normal, because I feel stronger and weaker at the same time. I feel excited and, at the same time, terrified. The truth is, I don’t know what I feel, except I know what kind of man I want to be.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, that was beautiful.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I should hope so. That’s from the first Spider-Man movie.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll take it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good. Now, I assume we’re splitting the cheque?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, Stuart.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, hey. I was actually just about to close up.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry. I’ll leave.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: No, no. It’s okay. Hang out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah, you’re my first customer today.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: All right. Great.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’m, uh, having a nightcap. You want to join me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What are you drinking?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Coffee liqueur in a Chewbacca mug. I call it a sad-tini.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Perfect for the night I’m having. Thank you.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hmm. Nice not to drink alone.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Amen to that. Sometimes I pour a little chardonnay into my dog’s water bowl.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: You’re kidding.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She’s kind of a mean drunk, but what are you gonna do?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: A little music?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sure. Mmm. Bossa nova. You listen to that with your hips as well as your ears.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Mmm.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh. Something about latin music just makes me feel like I’m on a white sand beach in Rio.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah. The sun, the waves, the beautiful bodies, tanned and glistening with sweat.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I should go.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, thank you for the drink.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, Stuart.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Do you want to hang out tomorrow night, maybe grab a bite to eat or catch a late movie?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah, I-I’d like to, but I’m a little tight on funds.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No problem. My treat. I’ll swing by after work.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I could do worse.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Aw, that’s such good news, Howie. Thank you for telling her.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, I’m a grown man. I’m gonna live with my wife. My mother’s just gonna have to learn to make do on her own.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Was she upset?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Who can tell? She yells everything. She might have been upset. She might have been hungry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thanks for fixing it. I love you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I love you, too. Sweet dreams. I’ll talk to you tomorrow?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Good night, Rocket Man.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: To infinity and beyond, baby.

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: Loops. You realize you just lied your ass off to your wife and your mother.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: Dimitri
Dialogue: What are you gonna do when you get back to Earth?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, I’m never going back.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a Frisbee-sized wormhole, Leonard. You can block it with a Frisbee. Calm down.
(Hands Howard the napkin)

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, it’s not a great time, what do you want?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon(in the apartment)
Dialogue: Hello to you, too. I’m sorry, but this is important.

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What is it?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Back to the Future II was in the Back to the Future III case, and Back to the Future III was, get this, in the Back to the Future II case.

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, did you do that, or am I in the house with an intruder?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I got to go inside. It’s getting rough out here.

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re dodging the question, I knew it was you. What was that?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What was what?

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This isn’t a very good connection, but it sounded like someone just released a kraken.

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, I’m hanging up now. You know there’s no such thing as a k…(Leonard is attacked and dragged into the sea by a huge tentacle. Sheldon wakes up in bed.)

Scene: On the deck of a ship on the North Sea, in the middle of a storm. Leonard is on a sat-phone.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock)Penny.(Knock, knock, knock)Penny.(Knock, knock, knock)Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What’s the matter?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Um, well, I was worried that you might be missing Leonard. And that might be causing you to have bad dreams, like the kind you’d get if you watched Clash of the Titans right before you went to bed.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sweetie, did you have a bad dream?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: To be honest, I did.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Back to the Future II was in the Back to the Future III case. Leonard did it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, wait. Perhaps I should sleep here so you don’t miss Leonard as much, uh, ’cause you’re being kind of a baby about it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know what? That would make me feel better. Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re welcome. Good night.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I think you’d be pleased to hear that this morning in the parking garage I saw this oil stain on the ground that was shaped just like my ex-girlfriend, Lucy, and I didn’t get upset at all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m proud of you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, you should be, ’cause she was looking good.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dear Lord, you’re an astronomer. Although you may have earthly woes, get your mind back on the stars. Gee, even the lowly dung beetle chooses to plot its course by using the Milky Way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Is that true?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Everything I say is true. Now, of course, the dung beetle also enjoys eating faeces, living in faeces and making little balls out of faeces, so, you know, pick and choose which aspects of its lifestyle you want to embrace.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, you can talk to girls now. It shouldn’t be hard for you to meet someone new.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How can I meet someone new when everywhere I look, I see Lucy’s face? Tell me you don’t see her smile in the crust of this chicken pot pie.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, will you stop it. Now, listen to me, there’s a welcome party for incoming post-docs tonight. Go to it and meet someone who isn’t made of grease or pie.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You think you’re so cool because your wife is a person?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, Bernie’s at a neuroscience conference with Amy, I’ll go with you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You would do that for me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Of course. You’re my friend. I want you to be happy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thanks. Oh, Sheldon, since Amy’s out of town, would you like to join us?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want you to be happy, too, but not enough to do anything about it.

Speaker: Bernadette(on phone)
Dialogue: Howie, stop. I can’t talk like that. Amy’s right here.

Speaker: Amy(on phone)
Dialogue: Sheldon, stop. For the last time, I will not bring home bed bugs.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: The hotel’s nice. There’s a pool, a gym, the bar looks like fun.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Because I looked in the bed, and there are no bugs.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Aw, I love you, too. If I don’t talk to you before you go to sleep, I’ll meet you in dreamland.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Good night. No, I will not consider sleeping in my garment bag.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny, did you ever wonder how Starfleet captains…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, now that I’ve piqued your interest, welcome to the exciting world of 3D chess.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why don’t you just admit you only want to play this game because you always play it with Leonard and you miss him?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You overestimate his significance in my life.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Mmm.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do I miss how he makes a face on my toaster waffle with syrup? No. Do I miss the way he fixes the zipper on my jacket when it gets stuck? I don’t think so. Do I miss how we say good night to each other through the walls of our bedroom using Morse code?(Taps out No in morse code on the table)

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I get it, I get it. You are an emotionless robot.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I try.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, let’s just get this stupid game over with.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Great. I’ll go first.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: By the way, how are you with zippers?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I really need to go to the bathroom, and this one’s gone all cattywampus.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wow, your work on jellyfish neural nets sounds so interesting.

Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: It is. You can download my paper off the university server.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I will. You can download my paper on the Van Allen Belts from the university server as well.

Speaker: Girl
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How’d it go?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, if you like dry, factual statements interspersed with painful moments of silence, it was bananas.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Check it out. Mrs. Davis from Human Resources is here. She’s probably on the lookout for sexual harassment.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, great. There go my chances of being sexually harassed.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I heard her husband left her for a hot, young undergrad.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s so much better than the old, ugly ones.

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: Mr. Wolowitz, Dr. Koothrappali.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Mrs. Davis, nice to see you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, I recently read a fascinating article on infidelity among penguins.

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So if the fact that your husband left you makes you feel unattractive, just remember, penguins get cheated on, and they’re adorable.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It was better when you couldn’t talk to women.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I was thinking of going to the lecture on posterior cingulate cortex lesions in the formation of autobiographical memory.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, brain lesions are fascinating. Unless they’re yours, then they’re a drag.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: To the advancement of science.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And to the sick and dying who make it possible.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: This is fun, we never really get to talk shop with Penny around. We usually just end up talking about boys.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Which is fine, but it’s nice to mix it up with a little intellectual conversation.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: From the two gentlemen at the bar.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, my gosh, boys bought us drinks, boys bought us drinks. Thank you, thank you, thank you so much.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Be cool.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You be cool. Guys are hitting on us, and not just to get to Penny.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re right. Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ooh. Bad move.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My queen can now take your rook from below.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So that means I lose, right? It’s over?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I make this move, but I won’t because we’re having too much fun.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, let’s take a break.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We’re all out of alcohol.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I wasn’t going to get alcohol. Gosh, I wonder what Leonard’s doing right now. I miss him so much.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if you’d like, we could call him. I mean that you could call him. As I’ve explained, the absence of my friends does not cause me pain. As rock and roll bad boy Paul Simon once said, I am a rock, I am an i-i-i-island.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m calling him.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, goodie, put him on speaker phone.

Speaker: Leonard(on board boat, at a party, dancing)
Dialogue: Excuse me, ladies, my pants are buzzing. North Sea, how can I kelp you?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny? Hey, it’s Penny. Everybody say hi to Penny.

Speaker: Everybody
Dialogue: Hi, Penny!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, it sounds like you’re having a good time.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Best time of my life.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Isn’t it five thirty in the morning there?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is it? Hey, everybody, it’s five thirty in the morning!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, okay, well, we were just calling you because we were missing you.

Speaker: Random voice
Dialogue: Iceberg!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh-oh, hang on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you in danger?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, it’s a drinking game. Whenever we see an iceberg, we take a shot!

Speaker: Everybody
Dialogue: Berg! Berg! Berg! Berg! Berg! Berg!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard, Leonard? I cannot believe we were missing that jerk.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You were.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So what happened? How’d it go?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s fine. I thanked them again and let them know we’re not available.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So I can drink this without having to give up the goodies?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yes, it’s all cool. Although, if you wanted to talk to one of them, no one would blame you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And why would no one blame me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t know what I’m saying.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, it sounds like you’re saying that I could do better than Sheldon.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Boy, these drinks are strong. Hoo, mama, I’m gonna be huggin’ the toilet tonight.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, tell me, I want to know what you meant by that.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I just meant that you’re not married and your boyfriend’s kind of, Sheldon.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And your husband is extremely Howard. What’s your point?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry. I have no point. That was a stupid thing to say. Can we please just go back to having a nice time?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We could, but unfortunately my brain is lesion-free and I remember that rotten thing you just said about my sweet baboo.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Come on. I apologize. Can we please just let it go?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Your husband’s weird and his clothes are ridiculous.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe it. All this time I’ve been doing nothing but sit around and miss that guy. And you know what the worst part is?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That you’re having to process your emotional pain without vodka?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. Yeah. But you know what the second-worst part is? He does not miss me at all.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Allow me to comfort you. At least you’ve got your health.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? That, that’s it? That’s comforting?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Um, uh, in a hundred years, you’ll both be dead and it won’t matter?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. Come on, you’re supposed to say, of course he misses you, the only reason he’s partying is to cover up his pain.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no, I don’t think that’s true at all.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is ridiculous. Why am I upset just because he’s off having a good time?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, perhaps you’re obsessively picturing him engaged in drunken coitus with another woman. Is that it? Did I get it right?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, that, that’s great. You can stop trying to make me feel better now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Actually, I can’t. Before Leonard left, he made me promise that I’d take care of you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He did?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s really sweet.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Plus, if I do a good job, he said he’d bring me back a sailor’s cap.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, now I miss him even more.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if it’s any consolation, I’m sure Leonard’s tormented every moment he’s away from your warm embrace and cherry lips.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, seriously?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, excuse me, Mrs. Davis?

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’d like to apologize for being insensitive. And for possibly making penguins seem like jerks, because 99% of them are stand-up guys.

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: Forget about it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, you, you and I, you and I have a lot in common.

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: Is that right?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, yes, I, I too am in the throes of heartbreak. Okay, fine, I’ll tell you about it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Here is a hot beverage to comfort you. It’s in a to-go cup. Make of that what you will.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Come on. It’s still early. Let’s do something.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I have been toying around with an idea for 4D chess.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How about we just talk?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right. In 4D chess…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. Come on, let’s talk about our lives. Tell me something about you I don’t know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I own nine pairs of pants.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, that, that’s a good start, but I was thinking maybe something a little more personal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I see. I own nine pairs of underpants.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How about I go first?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But I don’t want to know how many underpants you own. Although, based on the floor of your bedroom, I’d say it’s a thousand.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, look, here’s something people do not know about me. When I first moved out to L.A., I did a topless scene in a low-budget horror movie about a killer gorilla. Ugh! After I did it, I felt so ashamed. Thankfully, that thing never came out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve seen that. Yeah. Serial Apeist. Howard found it online the day we met you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, God.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And it was literally the moment you walked out the door. But I see the type of personal revelations you’re going for. Okay, here’s one I thought I’d take to the grave.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm. A while back, YouTube changed its user interface from a star-based rating system to a thumbs-up rating system. I tell people I’m okay with it, but I’m really not.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s your big revelation?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. Whew, I feel ten pounds lighter.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, you know what? I give up. I’m going to bed.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Here’s something else you don’t know about me. You just hurt my feelings.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What did I do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I opened up and shared something deeply upsetting to me, and you treated it as if it were nothing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I, I didn’t think it was a big deal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It is to me; that’s the point.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon, you are right. I’m really sorry. I should’ve known better.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Your apology is accepted.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you. How about a hug?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How about a hearty handshake?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now I know how you felt getting mauled by that sex-crazed gorilla.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Mm-hmm. It was rather flattering to have strangers send us drinks.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, that felt nice.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Maybe tomorrow morning we put on some hot pants and see if we can score us some free omelettes.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So, hypothetically, if, if we were to have gone with them, which one would you have picked?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I think I would have gone with the short one with the goofy haircut.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, good, ’cause I liked the tall thin one. He seemed intelligent, kind of a loner, maybe a little sexually inexperienced, like I’d have to teach him a thing or two.

Dialogue: Not my guy. I caught him staring at my rack. It’d be nice to be with a man who wants to know what’s underneath my cardigan. FYI, it’s another cardigan.

Dialogue: Your short sexed-up guy kind of sounds like Howard.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Your brainy virgin kind of sounds like Sheldon.

Speaker: Mrs Davis
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s exactly the same thing. Good night.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Mrs. Davis, I, uh, I must confess, I came here tonight in a futile attempt to pick up some lonely postdoc, but instead I got to connect with you at a human level. That’s a much better evening. You’re a lovely person.

Dialogue: Are you hitting on me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Good night.

Dialogue: There was.

Dialogue: Oh, that is so romantic.

Dialogue: Uh, sure, that’s why I did it.

Dialogue: Well?

Dialogue: Okay, fine. I did say that, and I think it’s true. I think if we worked together and lived together, we’d get sick of each other.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but to be fair, he only said the part about him getting sick of you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: For the love of God, why?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What exactly do you think you’d get sick of?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: His only options here are to fake a heart attack or have a real one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s nothing in particular. I…

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is it my voice? Am I too bossy? What?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: My arm is feeling numb.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nailed it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s the wrong arm for a heart attack, doofus.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: My point is, I’m sure there are things about me that would drive you crazy if you had to deal with them all day long.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Like looking me in the eye and lying to me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, well, come on, where am I supposed to look when I lie to you?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Find somewhere else to sleep tonight.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Bernie…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If it makes you feel any better, Amy and I are fine. I mean, really good.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, boys, how was the pyjama party? You guys jump on the bed and sing into hair brushes?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It wasn’t a pyjama party. It was just a couple of bros hanging out, giggling, eating cookie dough and watching Princess Bride.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Please, stop talking.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I mean, you know, Sheldon, none of this would’ve happened if I hadn’t tried to help you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, it also wouldn’t have happened if, in the early universe, hydrogen was a little more common or a little less common. This is fun. Your turn.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Amy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was kind of icy. You two okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, we’re fine. As Howard advised, she’s merely respecting our professional boundaries.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Smart. Take relationship advice from a man who spent last night braiding Raj’s hair.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, you make a good point. It would appear I was worried for nothing. Look at her, desperately wishing she was over here at the cool table. Don’t worry, little moth. The flame will come to you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, uh, on the off chance that Bernadette doesn’t call back and apologize, how do you feel about Mexican food for dinner tonight?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know. Sounds kind of heavy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s ’cause you always fill up on chips.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And this is Dr. Gunderson from Stockholm.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ah, Sweden. Yeah, home of my favourite Muppet and, uh, second favourite meatball. Okay, the Nordic reputation for lack of humour is well-founded. Boy, is his name Gunderson or No-Funderson?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Where are we going with this, Dr. Cooper?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, please, I’m your boyfriend. You call me Sheldon. That’s right, I am in a boy-girl relationship with this cute little lump of wool.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s a physical relationship, too. Hand-holding, hugging, even on hot days. Ow. Okay, here’s a new one. Apparently now we kick each other in the shin under the table. How do you like it when I do it to you? Not so much, huh?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Test subject D7, aka Betsy, fear response study. Image number one, Frenchman on bicycle carrying baguettes. No visible reaction. Image number two, sousaphone. Still no reaction. Okay. Let’s kick things up a notch. Image number three, crocodile with a mouthful of monkeys. Okay, now we’re talking.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dr. Fowler?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What do you want, Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m done with work, so… ugh!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, sorry, sorry, sorry. Sorry, uh, better?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, baguettes. Yes, I like baguettes. What exactly are you doing?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Determining baseline fear levels in capuchin monkeys by measuring their response to visual stimuli.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, goofing off. As I was saying, I’m done with work and Leonard’s not. So good news, you get to take me home. Play your cards right, I’ll let you drive me past the lot where the buses park at night.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can’t leave now, Sheldon. I’m very busy. Besides, why would I want to do you a favour after the way you treated me in the cafeteria? Image number four, boa constrictor.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What on earth are you talking about? My behaviour in the cafeteria was delightful. Maybe your friend Gunderson needs to head over to IKEA and assemble a sense of humour.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You embarrassed me in front of my colleagues on my first day here. Image number five, kitten in a teacup.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Aw. Embarrassed you?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know what? I don’t have time for this. Find another way home.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m starting to get the sense that you’re angry with me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Really? What tipped you off?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Couple things, actually. Your tone of voice, your body language…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Get out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, now, that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Image number six, woman giving birth.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bleugh!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s nine o’clock, where you been?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I had to take the bus home. Fell asleep and missed my stop.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, no.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Did you know that Los Angeles has a Little Sri Lanka?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I did not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I do now. They’re a lovely people. Although terrifying when you wake up face-to-face with them. If you’re hungry, I brought home some mutton and coconut milk.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why’d you get that? You hate lamb.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was asking for directions. Apparently, there was a communication problem.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I thought Amy was gonna drive you home.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I thought so, too, but she’s acting very strangely. I was discussing it with a Sri Lankan fellow on the bus, and he hypothesized that a tiger may have recently run across her shadow. Although he may have just been trying to drum up business for his brother-in-law’s witch doctor practice.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, Sheldon, what happened between you and Amy?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, can you believe she said I embarrassed her?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But you didn’t even hear the details.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’ve known you a long time, and I’m going to tell you this with all the love I can possibly muster. Amy’s right. You’re wrong.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But you don’t even know…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Doesn’t matter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But, now, but in my defence…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Doesn’t matter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re not listening to my side of it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, fine, Sheldon. What is your side?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Nope, got to go with Amy on this one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ooh, shrimp was spicy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You want a TUMS?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You got the tropical fruit kind?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, if I buy those, I just go through them like candy.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Tell me about it. One time, I swear I pooped out a stick of chalk.(Knock on door)I’ll get it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, hi.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I may have overreacted.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, well, I didn’t handle it so great, either.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s just sometimes I feel like you enjoy spending time with your friends more than with me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s not true.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s not? You spend all day together at work, and then you all hang out at night playing games, going to the comic book store. Last week, you two got a couples massage. So, when you said you wouldn’t want to spend that much time with me, it really hurt my feelings.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, wow. Yeah, no, I get that. I’m so sorry. Starting tomorrow, I am turning over a new leaf. Time with you is my number one priority.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why tomorrow?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, we’re real close to finishing off the new Batman game.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It is awesome. Uh, you should probably go after her.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Should I go after you?

Speaker: Bernadette(off)
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thanks for getting me in trouble.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock)Amy.(Knock, knock, knock)Amy.(Knock, knock, knock)Amy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, what are you doing here so late?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I couldn’t sleep because I kept thinking about what happened earlier between us. Also, I had one heck of a bus nap. Oh, speaking of which, do you want some mutton and coconut milk?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I cannot give this stuff away.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, this isn’t easy to say. All relationships are difficult, but even more so when you’re in one with a person who struggles with everyday social interactions. And frankly, who can strike some people as being kind of a weirdo.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re not a weirdo.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I wasn’t speaking about me. I mean, honestly, there’s no telling what will set you off. You know, introducing myself as your boyfriend. Giving you the opportunity to drive me home. Breaking the ice with your colleagues using ethnic humour, the funniest kind of humour.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s your point?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My point is, we’re a couple, and I like you for who you are, quirks and all.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I like you, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I should hope so. I don’t see anyone else banging on this door to put up with your nonsense. Not even a good-bye? You see, that’s the kind of thing that makes people think you’re weird. Poor kid. She just doesn’t see it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m not apologizing to Howard. He can come beg me on his knees.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, too. If I see him at work, I’m just going to ignore him.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, don’t worry. I talked to Leonard. He is gonna sit the guys down and set them straight.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Laser’s warmed up.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Pull.

Speaker: All
Dialogue: Yeah!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you working on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can’t talk. In the zone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you know what he’s doing?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Could be anything. Last time he was like this, he figured out electron transport in graphene. The time before that, he was making a list of who’s allowed in his tree fort if fe ever gets one. Still can’t believe I didn’t make the cut.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, Sheldon, you want to take a break? Your food’s ready.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, what are you doing? He’s both happy and quiet. It’s like seeing a unicorn and Bigfoot at the same time.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry we’re so late. Bernadette got stuck at work.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Great news. A raccoon virus just crossed the species barrier and now can infect humans.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why is that great news?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: In the pharmaceutical business we have a saying, mo’ infections, mo’ money.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait, Maybe you want to wash your little raccoon hands first.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, calm down. If I had it, I’d be dead already.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Guys, listen up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can’t listen, zone. Also don’t care.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Next week is the anniversary of my first date with Bernadette.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really don’t care.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I want to do something special, and I was hoping you guys could be a part of it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw, what horrible thing are you trying to make up for?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Just putting something in the bank for what horrible thing I do next.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, she’s gonna be back any second, so here’s the deal. I’m writing a song, and I was hoping we could all play it for her together.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aw.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, I love that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That is so beautiful.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: When did we get to the Cheesecake Factory?
Credits sequence

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s really sweet what Howard wants to do for Bernadette.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Hey, how come you’ve never done anything romantic to celebrate our first date?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, for starters, you’ve broken up with me so many times, which first date are we talking about?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ooh, somebody call the burn ward. And back to the zone.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And besides, I do romantic things for you all the time. Can you even name one romantic thing you’ve done for me?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can name tons.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sex doesn’t count.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh. I know, what about that bed-and-breakfast?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I took you there. All you did was…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I know what I did. I bet they had to throw out that rocking chair. You know, I can be romantic if I want to.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s fine. And also not true.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, just you wait and see. I’m gonna romance your freakin’ ass off.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s beautiful. Is that Shakespeare?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Zone.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He’ll figure it out when he falls off the roof.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I know you’re in the zone, but do you want some tea? All right, I can’t believe I’m gonna say this, but you haven’t spoken in hours and I’m starting to get worried. Please say something.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, prepare to be humbled and weep at the glory of my genius.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nope, it was better before.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look at it. I feel like my mind just made a baby. And it’s beautiful. It’s not like human babies, which are loud and covered in goop.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Holy crap, Sheldon, did you just figure out a method for synthesizing a new stable super-heavy element?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Did I? Well, that can’t be right. No one’s ever done that before. Except me, because I just did it. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, definitely better before.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So I’m almost done writing the song for Bernadette. Are you cool playing the cello?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If by cool you mean willing to, yes. If by cool you mean cool, clearly you’ve never seen me play the cello.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Great. Will you play the ukulele?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Of course. I’d be happy to shred it on my ax.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Or you could just play your tiny, ridiculous guitar.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Fine. I will melt her heart. And her face.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen. Uh, no doubt you heard about my little breakthrough. Now, if your plan is to hoist me on your shoulders and carry me around the cafeteria, please refrain. I don’t care for heights, motion sickness or the thought of your necks touching my buttocks.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Seriously, congratulations, Sheldon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, I read your paper online. That technique for creating a new heavy element is inspired.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, well, thank you. Believe it or not, I just learned a Chinese research team at the Hubei Institute for Nuclear Physics ran a test on a cyclotron, and the results were extremely promising.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, that’s incredible.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I know. They called it the greatest thing since the Communist party. Although I’m pretty sure that the Communist party made them say that. I like China. See, they know how to keep people in line.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, what happens next?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, more testing, more success, more fame. Yeah, but don’t worry, I will remain the same down-to-earth humble Joe I’ve always been.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good to know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now give me that cookie, I discovered an element.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you so much for coming.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You called the right person. I believe I have the perfect romantic evening for you to give Leonard.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, good, ’cause I’ve been really struggling with this.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As I’m sure you’re aware, the quickest way to a man’s heart is through his…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Pants, but Leonard says sex doesn’t count.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh. You poor thing. You have one arrow in your quiver, and you just can’t use it. Fortunately, another pathway to a man’s heart is through his stomach.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know if I want to cook for him. He’s kind of a picky eater. I mean, it’s too salty, it’s too dry, it’s too burnt and frozen at the same time. Okay, come on, what else would sweep you off your feet?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I’ve always had this fantasy that involves dancing. The sexual chemistry between my partner and me is electric. But boy, oh, boy, does my father not approve until he sees us in the big dance competition.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, that’s just the plot for Dirty Dancing. What else would you love? Other than being lifted over Patrick Swayze’s head.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, oh, uh, you could, uh, stand outside his window with a boom box in the air.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s from Say Anything.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Look, I’m a lonely guy, I watch a lot of movies. Look, Penny, if you truly want to be romantic, it needs to come from you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I get that, but why is this so hard?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, you’ve probably never had to do this stuff ’cause you’re young and beautiful and men have always thrown themselves at you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I’m trying to be sad about that. I can’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let’s see, what’s next? Okay, here. This is the Magic Marker I was using when I made the discovery.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t think the Smithsonian’s gonna want your marker.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And that’s why you’re not on a list for my tree fort. Ooh, guess who’s getting an article written about him in Physics Today? I’ll give you a hint. You measured the diameter of his suspicious mole yesterday.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’m so proud of you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, you should be. My discovery is spreading like wildfire. Unlike my mole, which is holding steady at the size of a navy bean.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s next?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is the very copy of The Handbook of Chemistry and Physics in which I looked up the reaction rates of mendelevium and…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And what?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. No, no, no, no.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve made a horrible mistake.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This table, it’s in square centimetres. I read it as square metres. You know what that means?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That Americans can’t handle the metric system?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, I was off by a factor of 10,000.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: But the Chinese team found the element.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, well, they shouldn’t have. My calculations were wrong. There must be some resonance between the elements I didn’t know about.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So you just got lucky?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sheldon Cooper does not get lucky.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You and me both, brother. It doesn’t matter. The element was found because of you, and that’s groundbreaking.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What matters is the greatest scientific achievement of my life is based on a blunder. I’m not a genius, I’m a fraud.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, Sheldon, in neuroscience, we’re forever finding something in one part of the brain that we thought was someplace else.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, great. Now I’m worse than a fraud. I’m practically a biologist.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: : You got to stop beating yourself up over this. I mean, you made a mistake, but it was a happy mistake.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s nothing happy about it. I’m being given credit that I don’t deserve.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, people get things they don’t deserve all the time. Look at me with you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, Leonard, this is going to haunt me for the rest of my life. Every science classroom, every periodic table, every textbook, this mistake will be staring back at me. Like that time you let Koothrappali wax your eyebrows. I’ve got to find a way to stop this thing.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Buddy, I don’t think you can. I mean, once it’s out there, it’s out there. This thing is like the science equivalent of a sex tape.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, frankly, I’d prefer a sex tape.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t know what a sex tape is, do you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Make sure you guys get to the restaurant by eight. Bernadette’s meeting me there at eight thirty and I don’t want to blow the surprise.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’ll be there.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Got it. Now, uh, I have a question about the song. I was thinking at some point I could bust out a little rap.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: E-Ni-Ni-Ni-Ni-No.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Come on, come on, you haven’t even heard it yet. Leonard, give me a beat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I will not.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, please?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, I want this to be romantic.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It will be. I don’t call anyone a ho, and the only time I use the phrase my bitch, I’m referring to you.

Speaker: Voice
Dialogue: There he is.(General applause)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Stop it. Stop celebrating me.

Speaker: Voice
Dialogue: Woo!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And no woos. Oh, not you, Dr. Woo. You’re fine. I want you all to know that you have no reason to applaud me. My so-called breakthrough wasn’t the result of my genius. It was nothing more than a boneheaded mistake. So please refrain from praising me for it in the future.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wait, I don’t understand. They didn’t find the element?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no, they found the element.(More applause)No, no, stop it. I don’t need to take this admiration from the likes of you people. How do I make them stop loving me?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Invite them to live with us.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Boy, Bernadette is gonna love this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. It must be nice to have someone do something so romantic.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, you know what’s not romantic? Rubbing it in someone’s face.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Actually, it can be, but I told you sex doesn’t count.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m getting worried about Bernadette. I’m gonna call and check on her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The National Science Foundation wants to give me a substantial grant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, that’s a big deal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know. When will this nightmare end?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, I get that you feel bad about all the attention, but still, what you did is amazing. We’re really proud of you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re not?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’ve been thinking about it, and you’re right. You don’t deserve any credit. All you did was misread some numbers on a table. A very easy table, too. Honestly, I’m embarrassed for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s the most romantic thing I’ve ever heard.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Damn it, everyone’s better at this than me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Congratulations, Dr. Fowler. You just made the fort.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Guys, there was an accident at Bernie’s lab.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, my God, is she okay?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, but she’s at the hospital in quarantine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Poor Bernadette.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, no.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hate to pile on the bad news, but I just got a raise.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, my God, Bernie, what happened?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, let’s just say the next time you move a dozen vials of raccoon virus to the fridge, make two trips.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You’re sure you’re okay?

Speaker: Bernadette

Dialogue: Oh. I forgot about this. My aunt made it for me when I started college.

Dialogue: Why? Because I got an ugly, itchy sweater, and my brother got a car? No, I was her favorite.

Dialogue: Hmm, I think I got them all. Nope, they’re not in there.

So in-in-in-instead of being a giant pain in the ass like you always are, what if this one time you just tried staying calm?

Dialogue: That seems like a reasonable request. Although so did, hey, Leonard, would you mind returning that DVD?

Dialogue: Okay.

Credits sequence.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, when you say you’re not going to freak out about the DVD, here’s what that means. Don’t fixate on it. Don’t wake me up in the middle of the night. Or nag me through the door while I’m on the toilet.

Dialogue: Okay, first, talking to you while you’re on the toilet isn’t exactly a picnic for me either, okay? Remember, when you can hear me, I can hear you. And second, you completely disregard how uncomfortable unresolved issues are for me. It’s, it’s like, a, an itch in my brain I can’t scratch.

Dialogue: Well, I don’t know how to do that.

Dialogue: Yeah, hang on, just give me sec.

Dialogue: I scraped gum off the bottom of that table. Only ’cause my manager saw me put it there.

Dialogue: Oh, you know, he’s good.

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Great.

Dialogue: Oh, I don’t know. I guess I thought it would be easier.

Dialogue: Yeah, I get that. I’ll go get you your water. When you say easier, you mean easier for you, right? ‘Cause it certainly didn’t make it easier for him.

Dialogue: Any chance I can get a different waitress?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry, this is rude of me. I will go get that water. See, see, see, see. Just now you expressed your feelings to my face. How come you could do that with me, but not Raj?

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: I don’t know your e-mail.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know what the worst part is? You’re sitting here, perfectly happy and he’s at home, a blubbering mess.

Dialogue: Oh, I thought you said he was okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I also said I was getting you water, but look at me still standing here. You know, I may be a bad waitress, but you are a bad person. Now, you want to hear the specials?

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: Please. Ha-ha, Oh.

Dialogue: I love you, Penny.

Dialogue: You know, it might be fun. You love hummus.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: I was going to mention it at the time, but then I thought, some day, this might be a teachable moment.

Dialogue: Aaaah! I, you, how can, what!

Dialogue: Mmm. You know, I’ve been told that a bald refusal of an invitation is rude and one must instead offer up a polite excuse, so I’d love to go, but, unfortunately, that sounds awful.

Dialogue: Come on, it’ll be fun.

Dialogue: Please? Bernadette’s bringing her dad ’cause her mom’s out of town, and I never have anything to say to that guy.

Dialogue: Oh, since you put it that way, I’d love to go, but that sounds even more awful.

Dialogue: It’d actually be nice to not hear Sheldon complain about my cooking all day.

Dialogue: Uh, excuse me, but every year you prepare a terrible meal and every year I criticize it. Do our traditions mean nothing to you?

Dialogue: I want to go.

Dialogue: Yeah, me, too.

Dialogue: I’m in.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Dialogue: Ugh, fine, I’ll go. But if her food is delicious, Thanksgiving is ruined, and it’s on you.

ward, the medicine’s not working.
