Dialogue: Why can’t you be fat, too?

Speaker: Fat Leonard
Dialogue: What do you want to do for dessert?

Speaker: Fat Raj
Dialogue: I think there’s still half a cake from breakfast.

Speaker: Fat Leonard
Dialogue: No, there’s not.

Speaker: Fat Stuart
Dialogue: Hey, guys.

Speaker: Fat Leonard and Raj
Dialogue: Stuart!
End fantasy sequence.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I just wanted to be in anyone’s story.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, but why are you fat?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: ‘Cause Leonard was fat.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Amy, what about you? What do you think you’d be doing if you never met Sheldon?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s hard to say, my life would be so different.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can say better. Sheldon can’t hear you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know.
Fantasy sequence in Amy’s apartment.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Happy birthday to me, happy birthday to me, there’s tears in the frosting, happy birthday to me.
(Stuart honks a party hooter at her.)
End fantasy sequence.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’ll stop now.

Speaker: Amy(tablet ringing)
Dialogue: How’s it going, Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s it. The baby’s here. It’s a boy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Congrats.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, thank you. I wasn’t sure I was gonna to make it. But my mother gave me some ice chips, my sister told me to breathe, and I just thought to myself, Sheldon, if you can make it through the Green Lantern movie, you can make it through this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, good for you, buddy. We’ll let you get back in there.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh no, no, I’m not going back in there. That baby is so irritating. He has literally been crying his entire life.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Aw, he’s already taking after Uncle Shelly.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon, you should go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, you always complain that you never had an intelligent role model growing up, and now you can be one for your nephew.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ugh, all right, I’ll go. But from what I’ve seen, his attention span is as limited as his bladder control.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You actually got him to do it.

Speaker: Rajj
Dialogue: Yeah, you keep saying how much Sheldon has affected all of us, but you’ve clearly had an impact on him.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: If that were true, I wouldn’t still be living alone. Well, not exactly alone. I do have a 50 pound sack of rice with one of Sheldon’s T-shirts on it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m telling you, Sheldon cares for you more than you think.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I wish I could believe you. I also wish there wasn’t a mouse living in Rice Sheldon.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hang on, I’m gonna give you a little early Christmas present. I’m gonna show you something, but if you ever told Sheldon he’d probably never speak to me again. So, if you want to tell him, that’s fine. Look.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t understand.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He made you his screensaver.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. Wow. I had no idea. He is so into me. Wait, wait, where’d I go?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, well, it’s you, Swamp Thing, Stephen Hawking, Spider-Man, but, look, you’re in the mix.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I am in the mix. And I’m the hottest one.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Who’s that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, Madame Curie.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s fine, she’s dead.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Just really glad you’re back.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Me, too. I got a lot of TV to catch up on.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I missed you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: To quote Han Solo, I know.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Did you miss me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I would’ve preferred to have you there with me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or instead of me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Did you hold the baby?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And? How did it make you feel?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Looking into the blank, innocent eyes of a creature that couldn’t begin to comprehend anything I was saying? Basically just another day at the office.
Fantasy sequence at the Cheesecake Factory.

Speaker: Fat Leonard
Dialogue: I’m gonna do it. I’m gonna ask her out.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And chocolate milk is gonna squirt out of my nipples.

Speaker: Fat Raj
Dialogue: Put up or shut up. You make it, I’ll drink it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You guys need anything else?

Speaker: Fat Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, your phone number and one more cheesecake.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I have a boyfriend. In fact, there he is now. Ready to go, sweetheart?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Not until I get my kiss.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: This is nice, that we all get to eat together.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hmm. Can we maybe put the phones down and have an actualhuman conversation?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We can, but thanks to Steve Jobs, we don’t have to.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Guys, guys, you’re never gonna believe this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I just got a part on a TV show.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What? That’s great. Guys.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yay, Penny.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s the show?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, NC… II… or, you know, NCSTD… I don’t know, it’s, it’s, you know, it’s the one with the letters and I’m gonna be on it!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s amazing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s your part?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, I play a customer in a diner and I flirt with Mark Harmon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Ooh, Mark Harmon, he’s a dreamboat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So it, it’s just flirting?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, yeah. Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, no reason. I just think it’s sexier when things are left to the imagination.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: He’s wrong.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So I read a study that says a man with a dog is three times more likely to get a woman’s phone number.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is it true even when the man lets his dog lick peanut butter off his tongue?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t see why not.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you’re really desperate to meet women and like having food eaten out of your mouth, I could set you up with my mom.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why is that funny? That’s just unhygienic.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s a joke.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t think so. I believe that a joke is a brief oral narrative with a climactic humorous twist. For example, uh, Wolowitz’s mother is so fat that she decided to go on a diet, or exercise, or both. See? The twist is that people don’t usually change. Well, they don’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, guys, don’t forget, my episode’s on TV tomorrow night.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We’ll be there.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can we bring anything?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s so sweet of you, but I was gonna steal food from here. You know, my treat.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait, if Howard’s mother is coming, then you should also steal marbles. Because she’s obese, and hippos are obese, and in the popular board game Hungry Hungry Hippos, they eat marbles. Maybe I need to dumb these down for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, do you think I’m funny?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. Do you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think I’m hysterical.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I take it back. That was funny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The philosopher Henri Bergson says it’s funny when a human being behaves like an object.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I bet that bit killed at The Chuckle Hut.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, he didn’t perform stand-up comedy, he was a philosopher.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, I think we’re zeroing in on your problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Perhaps I’ll spend some time developing a unified theory of comedy, which will allow me to elicit laughter from anyone at any time. Unless they’re German, ’cause that’s a tough crowd.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you set on people laughing with you? ‘Cause if you’re cool with at you…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t get it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Raj, when you said you were gonna bring a date to watch Penny’s thing tonight, I didn’t think you meant Stuart.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Really? I never for a second thought it’d be anything else.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I almost met someone last night, but I blew it. I was walking Cinnamon and this girl introduced herself, but she was so cute I panicked and said, wouldn’t it be easier if instead of talking we could just sniff each other’s butts?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, Stuart’s cute in his own way.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: When I was a baby, my mother called me her little possum.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Are possums cute?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you’re so intimidated by talking to attractive girls, maybe you should practice by talking to regular people.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You mean like fatties and uggos?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Or maybe just stop talking.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m serious. Go to the mall, talk to anybody, practice, that way when you eventually do talk to a cute girl, it won’t be so scary.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Or just keep dating the possum.

Speaker: Voice on television
Dialogue: Parsa doesn’t have those kind of resources.

Speaker: Second voice
Dialogue: No, and that’s why he had Erin Pace rewire it…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m so proud of you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We haven’t even gotten to my scene yet.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know, but you’re going to be a TV star and you haven’t left me yet. That takes guts.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t know about you, but I’m very uncomfortable with all this.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve never seen this show before and now I’m starting with episode 246? It’s unnatural.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Just think of the first 245 as the prequel.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, shh, guys, guys, this is it.

Speaker: Man on TV
Dialogue: I guess it’s you and me, kid.

Speaker: Mark Harmon on TV
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Woman on TV
Dialogue: I’m trying to make peace.

Speaker: Mark Harmon on TV
Dialogue: We’re good.

Speaker: Woman on TV
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: Mark Harmon on TV
Dialogue: Really? Because…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you kidding me?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, the diner scene. Where’s my diner scene?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, don’t ask me. Until I see the prequel, I’m lost.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, there was supposed to be a big scene with me and Mark Harmon, but it’s gone.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: They must’ve cut it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, Penny, I’m, I’m sorry.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That stinks.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sure you were great.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This doesn’t make any sense. I mean, I, I thought I did a, a really good job, I… Excuse me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve been studying how to make people laugh. They say that comedy is tragedy plus time. Let’s tickle some ribs.

Speaker: Penny(on phone)
Dialogue: No, Dad, I don’t think they cut me out of the show because I was too pretty. No, I don’t need you to come out and kick Mark Harmon’s ass. Daddy, I gotta go. I love you. Bye.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How you doing?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ugh, this is such a disaster. My parents had all my relatives over. They got one of those six-foot sandwiches, and got my brother a day pass out of rehab and now he’s missing and the sandwich is missing, and they’re probably in Mexico by now. So humiliating.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You still got the part. That’s a huge accomplishment.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, but this was supposed to be my break, okay? People were gonna see me in this show and it was gonna lead to bigger things. More auditions, more parts. Now none of that’s gonna happen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Honey, you only had, like, three lines. That wasn’t gonna happen anyway.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Unbelievable.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, come on, no, that’s not what I meant.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Then what did you mean?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t, look, you know, words don’t always have to mean things.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I think you meant that you don’t believe in me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nope. Uh, uh, I might not know what I meant, but I know that I didn’t mean that. Not this guy. Oh, no way.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I want you, right now, to give me your 100% honest opinion.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you think I have what it takes to really make it as an actress?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So you think I’ll be on TV and in movies and win awards.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Honestly?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes, honestly.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How could you say that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know, I got all confused when you said honestly.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, do I think that you are talented and that you are beautiful? Of course I do. But isn’t Los Angeles full of actresses who are just as talented, just as beautiful? All right, look, we’ll come back to that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, please. Don’t stop, go on. Tell me how I’m gonna be a waitress for the rest of my life.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That is not what I said. Look, I think you’re really good. I truly do. But this is an incredibly hard thing that you’re shooting for. I mean, the odds of anyone becoming a successful actor are like a million to one.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, thank you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Should’ve let Sheldon come.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is interesting. Apparently, a key component in some forms of humour is the element of surprise.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, that makes sense. The prefrontal cortex is responsible for planning and anticipation, and patients with brain lesions on their…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: BRAIN LESIONS!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you scared me. That wasn’t funny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or maybe you have a stick up your prefrontal cortex.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, the notion that you can read a few books and come up with a definitive theory of comedy is absurd. I mean, humour is a complex neurological…(Sheldon drops his trousers)Okay, that’s pretty good.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excellent.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: How about her?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No. No pretty girls. The point is to talk to regular people and work our way up to pretty girls.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Fine. How about that old lady with the walker?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That depends. On any level, do you think she’s hot?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: We’ll find somebody else.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Kumquat?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I guess.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ointment?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now, would you say ointment is more, equal to, or less funny than kumquat?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t think I want to go out with you anymore.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Will you please stop joking around? I’m trying to figure this out.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, how many words are you gonna go through?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All of them.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You didn’t get your part cut.

Speaker: Voice on TV
Dialogue: All right, baby, here’s the deal.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And you didn’t get your part cut. Yep, bunch of old guys rocking out in a band, all with erectile dysfunction, you didn’t get your part cut!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey. Can we talk?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We can, but the part of Penny might get cut.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was really crappy of me. What you’re trying to do is hard, but people do make it, and I really do believe you could be one of them.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And to show you how much I believe in you, I kind of got you an audition.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you serious? For what?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The new Star Wars movie.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? How did you manage that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There’s this thing online, you put yourself on tape and just send it in, anyone can do it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Come on Leonard, this is just a PR stunt.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So? Even if it is, you have a huge advantage because you’re an actual actress. Most of the people doing this are just weirdoes and nerds. Wolowitz sent his in two days ago.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really, let it go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, maybe it is a long shot, but sometimes long shots happen. Luke Skywalker was only given one chance to destroy the Death Star. He had to get a torpedo into an exhaust port that was only two meters wide, but with the help of The Force, he… wow, I can feel you hating me right now.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: How about that lady in the sweat suit, speed-walking?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, she seems friendly and easy to… never mind, she’s gone. You know, maybe talking to people is too hard.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: We could go over to that department store, practice on the mannequins.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t know. They’re dressed very stylishly. They’re probably stuck-up. This is ridiculous. The next person that walks by, no matter who it is, they’re the one. We’re gonna die here.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Where’s Sheldon?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: He’s home trying to use science to determine the basis of humour.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s interesting.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s exhausting. Do you have any idea how hard it is to laugh at a knock-knock joke that starts with knock-knock-knock, Amy, knock-knock-knock, Amy, knock-knock-knock, Amy?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: If you want him to stop, sometimes the easiest thing to do is just fake a laugh.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fake a laugh? Do you ever do that with me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No, of course not.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I’d be able to tell anyway.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t think you would.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Please, I’ve made plenty of girls laugh, sometimes just by asking them out.(Bernadette laughs uncontrollably)Yeah? Well, I fake my orgasms.

Speaker: Leonard(on phone)
Dialogue: Yes, how much for a hundred long-stemmed red roses? Really? How much for three?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I’ll call you back.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, I know you were just trying to help with your Star Wars thing. I didn’t mean to call it idiotic.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I don’t think you called it idiotic.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh. Sorry, I meant to. Anyway, um, I was just upset with myself. I wasn’t mad at you. I just feel like everything is falling apart.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on. It’s okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, it’s not okay. Look at me, okay? I took a temp job as a waitress forever ago, and I’m still doing it. I can’t quit, because guess what? I can’t do anything else. And I finally get my big break, and it goes away. I’m such a mess.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, you’re not.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? ‘Cause this morning at Starbucks, a pair of old underwear fell out of my pant leg. And it wasn’t the only one in there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, listen to me, this is just a minor setback.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, it’s not, okay? I’ve been out here for, like, ten years. I’ve nothing to show for it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, you have me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re right. I do have you. Mm. Let’s get married.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh. Leonard Hofstadter, will you marry me?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Um…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Did you seriously just say um?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, you know I love you but, but you’re, you’re drunk and sad and feeling lost.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so, so you don’t want to marry me?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That is not what I said.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, forget it. I take it back. Offer’s off the table.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who’s in the mood to laugh?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really not a good time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But I used science to construct the perfect joke.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m gonna go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny, don’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, no, I just need to be alone.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, a sandwich, a rabbi and yo mama walk into a bar. Where are you going?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: To my room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Should I follow you?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, wait.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I forgot to tell you the sandwich is promiscuous.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: How about those guys on that bench over there? They look pathetic. I bet we could talk to them.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s a mirror.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.

Speaker: Security Guard
Dialogue: Hey, fellas, mall’s closing.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Security Guard
Dialogue: Yeah. Good night.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, excuse me.

Speaker: Security Guard
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, do, do you like being a mall security guard?

Speaker: Security Guard
Dialogue: It’s all right.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, nice talking to you.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Smooth.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can’t sleep?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Would you like to talk about it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny proposed, and I didn’t say yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s a good question.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Does that mean the relationship is over?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why don’t you ask her?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because I’m afraid to know the answer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m sorry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s it? You’re not gonna make some dumb joke or some inappropriate comment?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. You’re my friend, and, I’m sorry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Did you just put a kick me sign on my back?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. That wouldn’t be funny at all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Star Wars audition, take one, starring Howard Joel Wolowitz, real-life astronaut. Vader is here, now, on this moon. I felt his presence. He’s come for me. He can feel when I’m near…

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: How many times do I have to tell you to replace the toilet paper when it’s empty?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m in the middle of something.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So am I.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s an outrage.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The university, they think they can do whatever they want. We just have to sit there and take it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You need to let it go, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You work tirelessly for someone, and this is what you get.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, my God, they’re just making you use your vacation days.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But I don’t want a vacation.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, listen, I don’t mean to diminish what you’re going through, but I’m a little distracted right now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, this again? So, Penny proposed, you didn’t say yes, and now you think you may have lost her love forever. How does this compare to me being forced to relax for a few days?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It doesn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m gonna go talk to Penny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m going to go inside, put on my coziest pajamas, curl up with a good book and wait for this nightmare to be over.

Dialogue: Gentlemen, I have the solution to our Comic-Con problem. We don’t need them. I’m starting my own convention.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, just buy scalped tickets with us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I told you. Buying scalped tickets is against the rules. If you get caught, you get banned from Comic-Con for life. Life, Leonard. You’re gonna feel pretty silly when we’re 80 years old, and you have to drive me down there and then wait in the car for three days.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do what you want. We’re getting scalped tickets.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I already found a guy online who’s willing to sell.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How do you know this isn’t a sting operation set up by the Comic-Con police?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: The same way I know that the people in the TV set can’t see me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, just come with us. You’re not gonna make your own convention.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, there was a time when Comic-Con didn’t exist at all until one lone dreamer with a unique vision made it happen. And you mark my words, I’m gonna rip that guy off.

Speaker: Sheldon(on phone)
Dialogue: Yes, I’m starting my own comic book convention, and I thought that your client, Robert Downey Jr., would be perfect to appear on our first panel. Oh, well, now, why are you saying no? You haven’t even asked him yet. You know, excuse me, but I sat through Iron Man 2. I believe he owes me two hours of his time. They hung up on me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Did you tell them that you’re holding your convention at a Marie Callender’s, and that every panellist gets a free slice of pie?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I didn’t even get to that part.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, even your friend Wil Wheaton thinks this is a waste of time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not true. Wil thinks this is a great idea. He was just concerned that he wasn’t a big enough celebrity to headline such an amazing event. Also, that’s the same day that he shampoos his beard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, buddy, I just don’t think this is going to come together for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You don’t know that. I still have plenty of solid leads on this list.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good luck.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, wait. I need you to call Stan Lee, Leonard Nimoy and Bill Nye the Science Guy, ’cause, legally, I’m not allowed to. Oh, and, also, Carrie Fisher, you know, ’cause I hear he can be pretty nuts.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe Leonard is spending hundreds of dollars on scalped tickets.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Last week, you spent that on a little dress.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, but those tickets only get him into Comic-Con. That dress gets me into anywhere I want.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Those tickets were pretty expensive. I had to give Howie an advance on his allowance. Now he’s never gonna put his toys away.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why can’t they do something sensible like Sheldon and start their own comic book convention? Also, who wants to throw me out that window?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, while they’re acting like teenagers, we could do something grown-up.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. You mean like a museum?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes, like a museum, but anything else.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, I know. There’s a nice hotel not far from here where they do afternoon tea.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Ooh, afternoon tea, how sophisticated of us.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, all right, if we’re gonna be fancy, I should probably put on clean underwear.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: La-dee-da, look who has clean underwear.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, we’re gonna stop at Target on the way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, since Sheldon’s not going to Comic-Con, maybe we could find a cool trio to dress up as.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mmm, what if we go as The Fantastic Four, and just tell people that the Invisible Girl is standing there with us.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, and I thought our days of pretending to be with women who don’t exist were over.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I am one step away from securing a huge guest for my convention.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Does that step include chloroform and a roll of duct tape?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t think that will be necessary for Mr. James Earl Jones. You heard me. The voice of Darth Vader, the Lion King’s dad, and FYI, the guy who says, This is CNN. Which also sounds like Darth Vader.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How are you gonna get James Earl Jones?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Simple. Earlier today, he tweeted that he’s looking forward to going to his favourite sushi restaurant for dinner. I googled an interview from four years ago which was conducted in his favourite sushi restaurant. That’s where he’ll be, and that’s where I’m going, and…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And that’s where Darth Vader’s gonna pour soy sauce on your head.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I don’t care if you get scalped tickets with us or not, but please don’t be creepy and go stalking this poor guy. You’re gonna get in trouble.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re the ones who are going to get in trouble. You’re buying non-transferable tickets. And from a stranger, no less. Not only can you get banned from Comic-Con, if caught, you could be charged with petty theft. You think about that while I’m warning James Earl Jones about the danger of posting his location on Twitter. He got lucky this time. There are some weirdoes out there.(To the Imperial March theme)Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, badala, baba, badalum, bom, badala, bom, bom, forgot my keys, bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum…

Speaker: Howard(on phone)
Dialogue: Okay, great. Bye. Our friendly neighbourhood scalper says he’s running late.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Does he sound like a criminal?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, did he say things like, youse guys, or, listen here, see?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes. He, he’s late because he’s on his way here from 1940.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m just saying, we don’t know who this guy is. What if he wants to steal our money or our kidneys, or make a suit outof our skins?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why would someone want to make clothes out of your skin?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t know. Maybe ’cause dark doesn’t show the stains?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, now you’re making me wonder if we should have met him at a neutral location.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why do you think I told him to come to your place?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: There sure are a lot of little kids here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe we thought this would makes us feel grown up.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I can’t believe the waiter thought I was your daughter.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, last time I got dressed up and had tea was when I was five. Just me, my teddy bear, Raggedy Ann and my hamster.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s cute.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It was. Till my hamster ate all her babies. It got less cute really fast.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Should we leave?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, there’s a bar in the lobby.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I could go for a drink.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Aw. Drinking in the afternoon, just like her mommy.

Speaker: James Earl Jones
Dialogue: Let me guess. You like Star Wars. You know, I’ve been in other movies. But you don’t care about those, do you? I have one thing to say to people like you. I like Star Wars, too. Care to join me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you. My friend Leonard said if I bothered you while you were eating, you’d think I was a creepy stalker.

Speaker: James Earl Jones
Dialogue: Well, your friend Leonard sounds like a real weenie.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He is, Mr. Earl Jones, he is.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, so, I’m on a Comic-Con message board, and there’s a post from a guy where he says he got caught using someone else’s badge, and Sheldon was right, he did get charged with petty theft. Guys, if I go to jail dressed as the Human Torch, that might send the wrong message.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe this isn’t a good idea.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I can text the guy and tell him we changed our minds.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Do it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay. We’re officially not going to Comic-Con.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hold on. We always do this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do what?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Chicken out. We’re, we’re so afraid of getting into trouble that we never do anything wrong.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s ’cause we’re the good guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Even Batman breaks the rules.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know I struggle with Batman.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I say, this one time, instead of wimping out, let’s be badasses.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, I’ll be a badass, but only if you pinky-swear to be one, too.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Howard, you in on this?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No need. I’m breaking rules all the time.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Name one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Last night. Drank my Pepto straight out of the bottle.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What about that little cup they give you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. What about it?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Are you impressed by that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: A little.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, me, too.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: You know, when I first read the script for Empire Strikes Back and Darth Vader told Luke he was his father, I thought for sure he was lying.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Me, too. But he wasn’t, was he?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: He was not. How messed up was that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So messed up.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: What do you say let’s go have some fun? My wife’s in New York, and I got a Lion King residual cheque burning a hole in my pocket.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, afternoon tea was a bust.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: On the bright side, every six-year-old there was jealous of my tiara. Not gonna lie, it felt good.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Let me ask you a question, when did you guys start feeling grown up? ‘Cause I am not sure I do.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Honestly, I thought when I got married I would, but I still kind of feel like I’m pretending. It doesn’t help that most of my clothes come from Gap Kids.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, so I’m an adult, and the other day I saw an old man slip and fall down, and I laughed. I mean, I laughed hard. Like, like, out loud. If he was conscious, he would’ve heard me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Gosh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I know. One of the tennis balls came off his walker and bounced right off his head. I mean, I, I almost wet myself. I guess you had to be there.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I think I have you both beat. Imagine trying to feel like a grown-up when you’ve never even been with a man.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, sex is not what makes you a grown-up.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah. Or you’d be the oldest one here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? Is that how you talk to your mother?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He just parked. He’s on his way up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good. This is exciting.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It is. I feel alive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. What if we do get caught, who cares? So we get banned from Comic-Con.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe slapped with a fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, no. I’d be an astronaut and a bad boy, how will women keep their pants on?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, maybe it’ll come up when I apply for citizenship. Oh, crap, what if it comes up when I apply for citizenship?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I wonder if we’d have to disclose something like this when we apply for grants.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He’s gonna be here any second, what should we do?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, you guys are such babies. I’ll handle this. If he thinks we’re not home, he’ll go away.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I thought you were a badass.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I lied about the Pepto, I always use the little cup.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is it true, as a child, you were a stutterer and were functionally mute for eight years?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: It is true.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Is it true they used scuba gear to create the sound of Darth Vader breathing?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: They sure did.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Is it true that you were pre-med in college and you almost became a doctor?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: That’s right.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, James, I could listen to your stories all night.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I mean, really, what’s so great about being grown up?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, for starters, we’d be splitting this check three ways.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m serious. Who wants to do all that stuff? Have insurance, pay mortgages, leave one of those little notes when you hit a parked car.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I told you it was Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on, it wasn’t me. Anyone could have knocked your mirror off, or whatever happened.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Maybe the guys are right. I mean, we spent the whole night trying to be mature, and it was kind of boring. I’m sure they’re having more fun than we are.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, God, I could really use exactly two tablespoons of Pepto right now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, Los Angeles. I’m on a Ferris Wheel with Darth Vader. And he’s nicer than you think.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In the jungle, the mighty jungle, the lion sleeps tonight…

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Ah-wimoweh, ah-wimoweh…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bring it home, Mufasa. Eee, eee, eee, eee, eee, um, um-a-weh.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Ah-wimoweh, ah-wimoweh…

Speaker: Sceme
Dialogue: Outside a house.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand what we’re doing.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Shh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Whose house is this?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Carrie Fisher. And she’s a little crazy, so get ready to run.(Rings doorbell)

Speaker: Carrie Fisher
Dialogue: It’s not funny anymore, James.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Then why am I laughing?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Ah, Sheldon, this is the perfect end to a perfect night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. But I think it could have ended with the karaoke.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: What were you trying to ask me at the strip club?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. How much does it cost to get them off my lap?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: No. Something about a convention.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, right. Well, my friends and I couldn’t get into Comic-Con this year, and I was trying to start my own convention, and I was going to ask if you would be a panelist.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Why don’t you and your friends come to Comic-Con with me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Of course. And San Diego is right across the border from my favorite city on Earth, Tijuana, where I’m taking you every night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ay-yi-yi.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: Ay-yi-yi, bang-bang.

Speaker: James
Dialogue: So, Beau Bridges is on my shoulders, and Jeff Bridges is on Marlon Brando’s shoulders, and remember, we do not have permission to be in the pool… hey, Sheldon, wake up. And Angie Dickinson is about to sic the dogs on us, and I go under the water and Marlon goes under the water, and the water raises about two feet and sloshes all over her patio, and the dogs freak out and run like hell, and then we run like hell. Oh, boy, that was a lot of fun.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry, who’s Angie Dickinson?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Item 28, your pet name for me. Time’s running out on this. You need to make a decision.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I submitted you a notarised list.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sorry, but Gollum and Flakey are not acceptable.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, you don’t like Princess Corncob, you don’t like Fester, you’re just impossible to please.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We’ll come back to that one. This brings us to the final item in our annual State of the Relationship Summit. Item 29, Valentine’s Day.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ah, the worst for last. Hmm. Classic Flakey.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Before you get upset, I believe I’ve come up with a way for us to celebrate the occasion that we both can enjoy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: People usually start a meeting with a joke, but you go ahead, end with one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I propose we spend a weekend at a bed-and-breakfast in Napa Valley.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hate every word in that sentence. Including in, at, we and a.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon. Why not?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: For starters, a bed-and-breakfast forces you to eat with strangers at your table.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: One step ahead of you, Bernadette and Wolowitz are going with us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, very well. What are the sleeping arrangements? We’ve only been dating for three years. If we were to share a room, people might talk.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I got you your own room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What if my room has a claw-foot bathtub?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It doesn’t. I know it makes you feel like you’re bathing inside a monster.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look, I appreciate the effort, but I’m still unclear how this trip is supposed to be enjoyable for me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We’re going to have Valentine’s Day dinner on a fully functioning vintage train.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Vintage? Be specific.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: An Alcoa FA-4 diesel locomotive leading a train of meticulously restored 1915 Pullman first-class coaches.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wow. I’m feeling the urge to hug you. And one, and two, all right, Gollum, we’re good.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Are you sure you guys don’t want to come with us to Napa? You could probably still get a room.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I think we’re just gonna have a quiet weekend at home.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Plus, I’m not sure it’s a great idea to take Penny to where wine comes from. What? It’s a joke. Oh, come on. We bust on each other. I wear dorky glasses, you might have a problem, it’s all for laughs.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That would really piss me off if I didn’t have a buzz going on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard, which pocket watch will you be wearing for dinner on the train?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, what?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m afraid if we wear the same pocket watch, it will be embarrassing.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t own a pocket watch.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, my. Well, then my apologies for bringing up this sore spot.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Since you two are gonna be around for Valentine’s, would you mind watching Cinnamon?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You have Valentine’s plans? Which came out sounding way more surprised than I meant. Here, let me try that again. You have Valent… See? I can’t do it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t have plans which is why I booked time on the big telescope that night.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, an evening looking at the stars, that’s still kind of romantic.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Except I’ll be alone.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m trying to put lipstick on a pig here. Work with me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’d be happy to watch Cinnamon.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you. Oh, and I’d like for at least one of us to see some action, so if you guys happen to have sex, it’s cool if she stays in the room.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, same goes for the two of you with Amy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What do you think, Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s magnificent. This is going to be the best Valentine’s Day ever.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m so glad you like it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m prepared to say I love it, as soon as I confirm there are no hobos aboard.

Speaker: Leonard(on phone)
Dialogue: Okay. Raj, I got it. Bye.(To Cinnamon)That was your daddy. He wanted me to say that he misses… Why am I doing this?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Happy Valentine’s Day.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ooh, flowers and chocolates? Somebody’s trying to get me out of my panties.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Don’t be surprised if you find five chocolates missing and three gross coconut ones with a bite taken out. It came that way when I bought it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Got you a little something, too.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw, jewellery. Oh, my God, Lakers tickets?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It gets better. Instead of me, you can take someone who will actually enjoy it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw. You are the best boyfriend ever.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. Seriously, please don’t make me go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Should we take this little party to the bedroom?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mm, don’t have to, we have the whole place to ourselves.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s true.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: In fact, if you want, we can do it right here on Sheldon’s spot.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That is the least sexy thing anyone’s ever said to me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: To the bedroom.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: And for the entrée, tonight’s special is a seafood risotto. Do you have any questions?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, I do. Uh, does this train car have the original link-and-pin coupler or the Miller Hook and Platform?

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I meant questions about the food.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, of course. Um, is the seafood risotto being served on a train car with the original link-and-pin coupler or the Miller Hook and Platform?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh, I think we’re gonna need a minute.

Speaker: Man in seat behind
Dialogue: Fun fact, it’s neither. They actually use the AAR type E coupler. If you listen carefully when the locomotive disconnects, you’ll hear the characteristic click-pshht-thunk of the knuckle.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Get out of town.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fun fact, I’m gonna jump off this train.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, Cinnamon, guess who just did it human style.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, my God.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s a little late, but I’ll take it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, Cinnamon ate the chocolates. That’s really bad for dogs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, crap. What are we gonna do?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We gotta get her to a vet right now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t have a vet. I have a podiatrist, an optometrist, an allergist, a dermatologist, a urologist. You’d think I’d have a vet.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. There’s one not far from here. Come on. Let’s go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. Koothrappali was right. We should have let her watch.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do another one, do another one.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Okay. Here’s my impression of the Amtrak Acela barreling down the Eastern Corridor. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s like there’s a train in your mouth. Howard: Oh, yeah. I’ve got one. Um, the Amtrak Wolverine coming into Chicago. Bwch-wch-wch-wch-wch-wch, bwch-wch-wch-wch-wch-wch. Ooo-ooo.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: I’ve been on that train. And I just was again.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: See if you guys can guess this one. Bang. Splat. Thud.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How many trains have you been on?

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Tons. A box fell on my head at UPS six years ago. Now I just collect disability and ride trains.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wow. Your life’s amazing.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Not always. A box fell on my head at UPS six years ago. Now I just collect disability and ride trains.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why do I even try?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m gonna fix this right now.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay. Just make it look like an accident.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Excuse me. You are at Valentine’s dinner with your girlfriend. Now get back over there and be with her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re right. That was insensitive of me. I have to go back to my table now. You should join us.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Great. Now there’s two of ’em.

Speaker: Lady Vet
Dialogue: How much chocolate did she eat?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: A whole box.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, to be fair, you ate a lot of it before you gave it to me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So the point is I may have saved her life.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: I’m sorry, is this a joke to you?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. Maybe to her.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: How big a box of chocolate was it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, something like this. I don’t know. It came free with a full tank of gas.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really? Do you know how much those Lakers tickets were?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you know how much gas is?

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, my God, Cinnamon, are you okay? I can’t believe you two. You do whatever it takes to save her life. If she needs new organs, I’ll buy any dog necessary and scrap them for parts.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: You’re the owner?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Owner, father, soul mate, and if anything happens to her, your worst nightmare.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Well, she’s not throwing up, which is a good sign. So, I’m gonna take her in back, put her on fluids and give her something to absorb the toxins.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. Okay, thank you. Oh, if she’s scared, you can sing to her. She likes Katy Perry. Oh, but don’t do Firework, that gets her all riled up.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Got it. Should have been a dentist.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Okay, what was the best four-ten-four U.S. Locomotive ever built?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Trick question. There never was one.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Or was there?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: In 1944, the Pacific Railroad built number 6131, which rearranged the drivers and cylinders, solving the problem of the Q-1, creating a duplex-drive four-four-six-four.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In what world is a four-four-six-four a four-ten-four?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: A world I don’t want to live in. Seriously, I no longer want to live in this world.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Hold on to your conductor’s hat. You crank the second and third axles, creating a pair of internal connecting rods, and boom, four-ten-four. If you think about it, the Q-2 was like the four-ten-four America never made.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I may never stop thinking about it. Amy, what are the odds we run into this guy?

Speaker: Waiter
Dialogue: Better than you think.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: You know, if you ask nicely, they’ll let you visit the engine room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I never want this day to end.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s feeling like it never will.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Hey, did I tell you what happened to me at UPS?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As if Valentine’s Day wasn’t bad enough, you try to kill my dog? And with cheap chocolate, no less?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It wasn’t cheap. It was free.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’re really sorry. It was an accident.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, we weren’t even out of the room that long.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, no, come on. It was a while. It was a while.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, is Cinnamon gonna be okay?

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: She’s responding well. We just want to keep her a little longer for observation.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: All right. Uh, would, would it be okay for me to see her? We’re usually in bed by now, and I want her to know that I’m here. Yes, we sleep together, and sometimes we spoon.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: It’s okay. I sleep with my dog, too. We’re not supposed to let people in back, but I think I can make an exception.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Come on. By the way, I sang her Katy Perry.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, yeah?

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: And I don’t care what that obnoxious parrot back there says. I crushed it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I think there’s something going on between the two of them.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe, but you also think nine minutes isn’t a while, so what do you know?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why? Because my boyfriend’s off playing choo-choo with some weirdo?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, to be fair, they’re both weirdos.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know what made me think tonight would be any different.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, just the fact that you got him up here still says a lot. To be honest, I bet Howie 200
bucks it wasn’t gonna happen.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m going to the Lego store to get a big-ass R2-D2.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: See? It’s not just Sheldon. They’re all idiots.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: She’s right.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So, your boyfriend’s a fixer-upper. Most of them are. I mean, look at this guy. You think he came like this? When I met him, he was a hot, goofy mess. Now, he’s been to space. That’s all me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I had a little to do with it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, sure you did. Who’s Mama’s big space man?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They’ve been in there, like, half an hour.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, for future reference, that’s a while.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How long should we stay?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know. I’m kind of hungry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I saw a Thai place next door.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh. Okay. Oh. Oh. Hey.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How’s she doing?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How is everything?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She’s gonna be okay; they’re gonna let me take her home.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, good.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: So I want you to keep a close eye on her for the next 24 hours. Here are a few warning signs to look out for, and if you see any of them, don’t hesitate to call.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh. Thank you for taking such good care of my little girl.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: My pleasure. Have a nice night.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, thank you for all your help.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. I’m sorry if you didn’t think we were taking it seriously. We love animals.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Oh, do you guys own any pets?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Vet
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I love you so much.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I love you, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: You guys missed a pretty great time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The conductor and I have the same pocket watch.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: It was crazy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dare I say loco? Oh, and, Amy, guess what? The conductor said as soon as he gets off work, he can come back to the bed and breakfast and play his banjo for us.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay. I need to speak to my boyfriend in private, like, right now.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: There’s a car with a glass roof. Want to go look at the stars?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, that sounds so romantic.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, give it a rest.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Let’s go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why are you still here?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me. I think you’re being a little rude.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m being rude? You’ve been rude to me this entire evening.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How is that possible? I’ve hardly spoken to you since we got on the train.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: I’m detecting a little friction between you two, and I don’t want to be a third rail. Get it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I get it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Leave.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What is your problem?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s Valentine’s Day. We’re supposed to be having a romantic weekend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, really? Because I remember you saying that this trip was going to be something we could both enjoy. Did you mean that, or were you just trying to trick me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Fine, it’s true. I deserve romance, and I didn’t know how else to make it happen.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if you want romance, then let’s have romance. Oh, look, there’s wine. Mmm. Grape juice that burns. Uh, now let’s gaze into each other’s eyes, hmm? You blinked. I win.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let’s see. What’s next? Oh, kissing’s romantic.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That was nice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good. Um, the conductor said if I come back to the engine room, he’d show me how to bring the train through a crossing.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, have fun.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you want to come with me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Really? I do.

Speaker: Man
Dialogue: Hey, guys, wait up.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: There you go. All cozy wozy. Here, let’s see what the doctor says to keep an eye out for. Hmm. Rajesh, I was dreading Valentine’s Day. Thank you for spending it with me. Yvette. Cinnamon, she-she gave me her phone number. If I’d known it was that easy, I would have considered poisoning you months ago. Oh, what should I say? Oh, I know. I’ll point out her name’s Yvette, and that she’s a vet. That’s hysterical. She’ll love it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, hey. You’re back. How was your trip?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It was wonderful.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great. What did you do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I made a new friend who likes trains as much as I do, uh, I kissed Amy on the lips, and, uh, the conductor played his banjo for me. Good night.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. I’m gonna need more details.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, well, my new friend’s name was Eric. Um, Amy lips tasted like the brownie we had for dessert. Oh, and the banjo-playing conductor was missing a finger, but he made up for it with his can-do attitude.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, hang on. Hang on. Are all those things equal to you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm. It never occurred to me to pick a favourite.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, give it a go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t answer that without collecting additional data.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Additional data. You dog.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not sure how listening to other nine-fingered banjo players makes me dog, but all right.
Following a “previously on” sequence.

Speaker: Sceme
Dialogue: Leonard and Penny’s bedroom.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard? Leonard?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You realize you and I could become brothers.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’re not gonna be brothers. We’re not gonna be stepbrothers. Go to sleep.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hope you’re right. ‘Cause a grown man living with his brother and his brother’s wife is weird.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Go to sleep.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. Do you think your father’s doing unspeakable things to my mother?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you saying that because the things are unspeakable?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Your parents are old. Anything unspeakable was finished by 9:30. Go to sleep.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry if this stuff is gonna make the ceremony awkward.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: God, I thought my brother fresh out of jail was gonna make everyone uncomfortable, but now this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, if you want me to sleep you’re gonna have to stop talking.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I’m gonna go pick up my family. Like an hour and half, two hours, depending on traffic.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, drive safe.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hey, and do yourself a favour, all right? When Beverly gets here, do not bring up last night. All right? As far as you’re concerned, you don’t know anything, you didn’t see anything. I want you just to play dumb.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It was nice of her to show us playing dumb with an example.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? Oh. Hi. Okay, hey there, I got, I’m sorry, I got to go now.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Penny, wait.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I wanted to thank you for going through all the trouble of planning a second wedding ceremony for me, but unfortunately I cannot attend.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, why? What’s wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Whuh, are we still doing the dumb thing? Okay, why, what’s wrong?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I just cannot stay here while your father goes out of his way to humiliate me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, golly, however did he humiliate you?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Stop it, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do I say stop what, or just throw in the towel?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I don’t see why I should have to watch your father parade around with some bible-thumping bumpkin.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, excuse me, that is my mother you’re talking about, however accurately.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, Beverley, aren’t you overreacting a little? All we know is they shared a cab and had a nightcap.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And turned their phones off.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not helping, buddy. Mother, Penny and I really want you to be part of this. Please stay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, plus if you leave, Alfred will know he got under your skin.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Well, we can’t have that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, also, if they did have coitus, we’ll all be needing a skilled psychiatrist.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It is funny when you think about it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe to you. You didn’t get a $500 traffic ticket.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Because you were driving like a lunatic.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, if thinking secret government agents are chasing you makes you a lunatic, then, yeah, okay.

Speaker: Raj(doorbell rings)
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll get it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It didn’t help that you couldn’t walk a straight line when the cop pulled you over.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I have performance anxiety. You of all people should know that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: I’m looking for Howard Wolowitz.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Howard Wolowitz?

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: I have the right address, don’t I?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Address?

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: Is he here?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Um, no.

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: Do you know where I can find him?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: May I ask what this is about?

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: No, you may not.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: Air Force Officer
Dialogue: Have him call me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Howard(off)
Dialogue: Raj, who’s at the door?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s not him.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I can’t wait for you to meet everyone. I told them all about you.

Speaker: Susan (Penny’s mother)
Dialogue: Like what? Do they know about your brother?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, not everything, just, like, the jail and drugs part.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Why would you do that?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: The world doesn’t need to know our problems.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, Mom, I’m sorry, but…

Speaker: Wyatt (Penny’s father)
Dialogue: Hey, look, they got Walgreens here, too.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: You really think it’s helpful to change the subject, Wyatt?

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Just trying to make this a happy trip, dear.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Well, quit it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, uh, Randall, can’t believe after all these years you finally get to visit me in California.

Speaker: Randall (Penny’s brother)
Dialogue: Well, good thing I was a non-violent offender, otherwise I couldn’t have left the state.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: All right, that’s enough jail talk.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Penny knows where I was, she sent me cigarettes.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: You sent your brother cigarettes?

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: He was cooking and selling crystal meth, Susan, I think we can let the cigarettes slide.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Stop trying to be the cool dad, you have a shirt with our cat’s picture on it.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Anyway, we’re here, slugger.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s great, now they know where I live.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What are you talking about? They’ve always known where you live.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, if you want to go off the grid, you have to move out of your mother’s house.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can we take a moment to discuss that I just lied to the government for you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. I would not have done that for you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howard, please just call the man, see what he wants.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All right, all right.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, make sure you tell him that you weren’t home when he came by and that your Indian friend gave you the message the moment you stepped through the door.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes, hello. Uh, this is Howard Wolowitz for Colonel Richard Williams.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I take it back, don’t mention me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hi, Colonel Williams, how can I help you? What? Oh, uh, yes, he is from India. No, I don’t know his immigration status. Relax, I’m still on hold. Speaking. Okay, sure, I can meet with you on Thursday. Caltech is fine. Yeah, and may I ask what this is about? I may not?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s what he said to me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Here you are, Mother.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m glad you decided to stay. It’s gonna be special for Penny and me to share this with you.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I can’t wait for this day to be over.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, special, like that.(Knock on door)That’s them. Please don’t make things any more awkward than they already are.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, so less or equally awkward, got it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, guys, come on in.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Oh, thank you.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: How is everyone today?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Good, and you?

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Good, good.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: I’m good, too.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, did you defile my mother or not?

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Sheldon. You’re being rude.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: If I may, I can assure you, your mother and I did nothing more than share a cab and a conversation.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Did that conversation include the phrase your genitals are a joy to behold?

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: That’s enough.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Look, I promise you, neither I, nor anyone, has ever said that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t know his girlfriend very well.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or what a joy it is to behold my genitals.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, you guys, uh, get settled in, then we’ll go across the hall and say hi to everyone.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: You know, It’s hard to believe I’ve never met Leonard.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Well, he probably buys his illegal drugs from a local vendor.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Not funny, Wyatt.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I thought it was really funny.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Well, fine, if everyone wants to make jokes about our problems, then I can, too. Knock, knock. Who’s there? Our family is an embarrassment.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: That’s not much of a joke.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Listen, Mom, I know you’re nervous, but I promise you, no one is gonna judge you or this family.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry. It’s just we’re meeting Leonard’s parents for the first time, and, and they’re academics and, and intellectuals, and I don’t want them thinking we’re white trash.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Well, what colour trash do you think they’ll believe?

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: How could you think that I would spend the night with a man I just met?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A man named Jesus convinced you to build a church in Africa. You’re kind of a sucker.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, nothing happened, right? It’s over. Until we get married a third time, you guys will never have to see each other again.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Well, you know, actually that’s not the case. Mary may visit me in New York.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Mm-hmm. And he’s never been to Texas.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Maybe we meet halfway.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? In the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia? I can’t be the only one that knows that’s halfway.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: You’re not seriously going to visit each other.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: And why wouldn’t we?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Oh please, you’re just saying this to antagonize me.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Oh, not at all. Mary happens to be a wonderful woman. And if it antagonizes you, that’s just a bonus.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mary, I’m sorry you’re in the middle of this.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: No, no, nothing to be sorry about. I genuinely like your father.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? But he’s a mediocre academic. And according to Beverley, his sexual prowess is sub-par. He’s basically Leonard with a bigger prostate.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you saying that my dad’s not good enough for your mom?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, while also getting in a solid dig at you. Pretty efficient, huh?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is ridiculous. I’m going across the hall.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But why should you get to go and leave me here with your bickering parents?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine, then you go.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Well, I don’t want to stay here with her. I’ll go.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: I’ll go with you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That still leaves me here with him.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hang on, hang on. We’re smart, we can figure this out. Okay, so: Mary and Beverley can’t be together. Uh, Alfred and Beverley can’t be together. Leonard and I can’t be together. Now, I could be with Alfred but I don’t like his face. Oh, here. I’ve got it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Who’s ready for a wedding?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Great, now I have to start all over.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: So how’s the world of pharmaceuticals treating you?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Pretty good. I actually just got assigned a much better territory.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: See what happens when you work hard?

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Hey, she just sells drugs. I had to make ’em.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Okay, that’s enough. No more drug talk for the rest of this trip.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: I’ll drink to that.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Haven’t you had enough?

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Penny drinks more than I do.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I learned from the best.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Aw.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Very nice, Wyatt. And you wonder why this one turned out the way he did.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: You see what I’ve gotta put up with.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: What you’ve gotta put up with? Why did you have to go to jail?

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: It’s called getting caught, Mother.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Hey, there he is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Oh, Leonard. It’s so nice to see you again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, you, too. Hey, everyone, this is my mother, Beverley.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: We are not white trash.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Are you excited to see your son walk down the aisle?

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Yes, I am. I’m just feeling a little guilty about all the trouble I’ve caused.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Oh, so am I.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You made God sad today, Mom.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, they haven’t done anything wrong. I think it’s nice they’re hitting it off.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, that’s still no reason to rush into anything. I mean, look at us. We took things remarkably slow. You and I, we didn’t even hold hands for two years.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It was a lot hotter than it sounds.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: You’re a patient young lady.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, hey. She’s mine, take a cold shower, grandpa.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why wouldn’t that colonel say what the meeting’s about? It has to be bad news.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Calm down, okay? Try not to think about it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s really stupid advice.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know that hurts my feelings.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Calm down, try not to think about it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why do I bother talking to you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, come on. What’s the worst that could come of this meeting?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know. They take the invention away, and I get nothing?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, that’s not so bad. You know what happened to the scientists that worked on the Manhattan Project? The government forced them to move to the desert. They had to live in secret, and when Oppenheimer objected to what they made him do, they destroyed his reputation.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s the point of that story?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I just read a book about Oppenheimer, seemed like a chance to show off.(Howard laughs)There he is, there’s my happy Hebraic homeboy. Yeah, that’s the smile I’m gonna remember when you’re living in the desert and I’m living with your wife.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: So, what do you do for a living?

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Mommy, you want to take this one?

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Um, Randall’s in between jobs.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: And court appearances.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: It’s nice to meet the woman who raised this fine young man. I’m looking forward to meeting his father.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Prepare to be disappointed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And he can’t wait to meet you, too. Can I get anyone a drink?

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Well, I could use another beer.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: You’re done. He’s done.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey. Is everyone getting to know each other?

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Nice to see you again, Dr. Hofstadter. I’m, uh, Leonard’s friend, Stuart.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Nice to see you, too.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hi, I’m Stuart.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Oh, I’m Alfred. Leonard’s father.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh. Oh, hi. Uh, I’m sorry, did you two want to sit together?

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I was wondering why the front row was available.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay, I think we’re ready.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why do people cry at weddings?

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: They’re practicing for what’s coming later.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Thank you for cleaning yourself up for your sister’s wedding.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Thank you for my new teeth.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: Welcome to the family, Leonard. Don’t lend your new brother-in-law money.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We’re here today to celebrate love.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Urgh.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Sigh louder, no one heard you.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Really, I can move.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not just Leonard and Penny’s love, but the love we have for them, as well as each other.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Speaking of love, STDs among the elderly are skyrocketing.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Love is patient, but it’s not gonna put up with all the side chatter, so let’s knock it off.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: At least she’s yelling at someone else for a change.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howard.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I understand everyone’s a little tense today, so I am just gonna get to the important stuff. Leonard, standing here with you in front of our family and friends is bringing up a lot of feelings. Like what a good idea it was to elope the first time. But also how incredibly happy you make me. Thank you for marrying me. Hopefully for the last time.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny, as a scientist, my job is to figure out why things happen. But I don’t think I’ll ever understand how someone like me could get to be with someone like you. You know, maybe I don’t
need to understand it, I just need to be grateful. I love you, Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Anybody have anything snarky to say about that? Didn’t think so.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: I’d like to say something. Beverly, I know that we don’t bring out the best in each other.
But something wonderful did come from our relationship. That young man right there.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I couldn’t agree more.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: That’s beautiful.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thank you. All right, let’s continue.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, excuse me, I need to say something to someone pretty special, and I just can’t wait any longer.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s happening.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, you and I have our ups and downs. But I have always considered you my family. Even before the recent threat of our parents fornicating like wrinkly old rabbits. I don’t always show it, but you are of great importance to me. Both of you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay. I now pronounce you husband and wife. And weird other husband who came with the apartment.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Thank you for taking us to the airport.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, I’m just thrilled we’re all getting along for a minute.

Speaker: Alfred
