Dialogue: Yeah, me, too. Beverly, I’m sorry if I upset you.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Water under the bridge, Alfred. Leonard, why don’t you get into the carpool lane?

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: Well, that’s a solid line. He can’t cross that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s okay. I can make it over.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: No, no, let’s plod along. It’ll make your father feel more comfortable.

Speaker: Alfred
Dialogue: What makes me comfortable is knowing I don’t have to wake up tomorrow morning and see your sour face.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Do the world a favour, and don’t wake up tomorrow morning.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was almost a minute.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: There’s a lot of traffic. Are we gonna be okay?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You’ll be at the airport an hour before your flight.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Good. Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Plenty of time for you to meet another geriatric boy toy.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Hey. I will not have you be disrespectful to me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes ma’am.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re mother’s an attractive woman. You need to get use to the fact that men are going to be interested in her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, and you need to drive the car and mind your business.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I will not have you be disrespectful to me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What, you’re not my mother.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: Don’t you be disrespectful to her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes ma’am.

Speaker: Mary
Dialogue: You’ll get there. You’ve just gotta put some zing on it.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Penny, I don’t know what I was worried about. You’re friends are just lovely.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, thanks, Mom.

Speaker: Susan
Dialogue: Although that Sheldon is a bit peculiar.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is he? I never noticed.

Speaker: Wyatt
Dialogue: He reminds me of that turkey we had who drowned looking up at the rain.

Speaker: Randall
Dialogue: Cops, cops, be cool.
Following a “previously on” sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look at this. Elon Musk has a theory that we’re all just characters in some advanced civilization’s video game.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So some alien kid spent his money on the asthma-and-glasses upgrade for me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, he doesn’t say it’s a good game.

Speaker: Howard(entering)
Dialogue: All right, we got a problem.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s up?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The Air Force contacted me about our quantum gyroscope. They want to have a meeting.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah. This military guy showed up at Howard’s door. He was terrifying.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, what did he say?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He gave me his business card and asked me to please pass it along to Howard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That doesn’t sound terrifying.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: To a white guy born here, no. If you are a brown guy whose name has a lot of syllables in it, terrifying.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You realize if the military declares our research classified, they can take the whole thing away from us.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And if that happens, we’ll never be able to sell it commercially.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: There goes our big payday.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I was counting on that money. I need to make as much as my wife so I don’t have to try so hard in bed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You do that, too?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. How do you think I stay this thin?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I think we are losing sight of the real issue. We are on the precipice of becoming faceless cogs in the military-industrial complex. Isn’t that exciting?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, you’re kidding, right?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not at all. In Star Wars, when the stormtroopers would march in perfect formation, harassing civilians, didn’t you ever think, hey, that could be me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, we could be contributing to a weapons system that oppresses mankind for the next thousand years.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, Howard’s on board. What do you think, Leonard?
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m worried about Howard. Ever since that guy from the Air Force showed up, he’s been a nervous wreck.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, we work at a giant pharmaceutical company. Get him some anti-anxiety meds.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: He won’t take any pills that aren’t chewable and shaped like a Flintstone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, when Leonard’s feeling anxious I make him take a long walk.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Does that help?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, for a while. Then he comes back.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t believe this.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: This guy from the office just congratulated me on being pregnant.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You did already know, right?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No one at the office did. Did you tell anyone?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. You told me not to.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I bet it was Barbara Chen in retrovirus. She might have heard me throwing up one morning. Every since she got the hearing aid, she thinks she’s so great.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why don’t you want anyone to know?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: ‘Cause I’m up for a major immunotherapy study, and if they find out I’m pregnant they might give it to someone else.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Would they really do that?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I know they would, they did it to Barbara Chen last year when I told everyone she was pregnant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wail till I Snapchat that my friends might be working on a top secret government project.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you crazy? You can’t put that on Snapchat.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Fine, I’ll put it on Facebook like a caveman.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know, maybe before our meeting we should talk to a lawyer.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s not a bad idea.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, you must have someone in your family that’s a lawyer.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why? Because I’m Jewish? That’s like me saying, hey, you’re Indian, doesn’t your cousin work in a call centre?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My cousin does work in a call centre.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And my cousin’s a lawyer.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We don’t need Howard’s cousin. No, we have me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re not a lawyer, Sheldon, you’re just a know-it-all.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I am not a know-it-all. I’m a person who knows lots of things and likes to correct other people when they’re wrong.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s the definition of being a know-it-all.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or in German, a Besserwisser.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How did you think you were gonna hide your pregnancy?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I had a plan. I kept leaving Dove Bar wrappers around to explain any weight gain.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Where did you get empty Dove Bar wrappers?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: From all the Dove Bars I ate. I’m pregnant. Try to keep up. I’m sorry, I have to go find out if my boss knows.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, whatever happens, we’re here for you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thanks. You guys are the best.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, drive safe. We love you. And give us a call… Oh, my God, it was me, it was me. I’m the one who blabbed she was pregnant!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I didn’t mean to. It just slipped out in front of her assistantone day. I…

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I forgot my coat.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, here’s your coat, honey. That’s such a cute jacket. Oh God, I feel so bad, I just lied to her.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, but you did it so well. That’s amazing, it’s like watching a sculptor, but your clay was lies.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is that really what’s important right now?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I mean, seriously, you have got to let me scan your brain when you’re being dishonest so I can see what lights up.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s super helpful, Amy. Thanks a lot. I can’t wait to do that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can see a clump of bitch cells lightin’ up from here.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Give me a second to call my cousin.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t see how a tax lawyer from Fort Lauderdale could be helpful regarding intellectual property.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: First of all, he’s in Boca Raton, which is better than Fort Lauderdale. But more importantly, he lasted two days on Jeopardy, so he’s clearly a smart guy.

Speaker: Howard’s cousin(on skype)
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, Marty. Thanks for talking to us.

Speaker: Marty
Dialogue: Hey, no problem. Thanks for going to outer space so no matter what I do my mom will be disappointed in me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I married a little Catholic girl, so we’re even. Anyway, this is Leonard and Sheldon. The three of us came up with the guidance system.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And this is my friend, Raj.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I’m not on the patent. I’m just here because there’s a bumblebee in my office.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I saw it. It’s big.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Anyway, like I said in the e-mail, this meeting’s on Thursday. Do you have any advice for us?

Speaker: Marty
Dialogue: Well, I don’t know much about patent law. But, uh, my advice is hear them out, offer as little information as possible, and whatever you do, don’t sign anything.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t sign anything? That’s your advice? Okay, so, uh, if during this meeting, one of us were to, say, complete an oil painting, you’d recommend that we leave that unsigned?

Speaker: Marty
Dialogue: That’s not what I meant.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s what you said.

Speaker: Marty
Dialogue: That’s not what I meant.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This must be how you practice law in Boca Raton, by saying things you don’t mean and meaning things you don’t say.

Speaker: Marty
Dialogue: Howard, why is he yelling at me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, you were on Jeopardy. Allow me to Alex Trebek this and put it in the form of a question: Who has been a complete waste of our time?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Marty, let me call you back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Someday, when I’m up on murder charges, you’ll be hearing from me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You don’t need him. I’ll represent you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey. What brings you by?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, had to go to a sales seminar on our new sleeping pill.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh. How was it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Fell asleep?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: In, like, two minutes. Yeah. So, how is everything going around here? Are you still upset about people finding out you’re pregnant?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m furious.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sure, sure. Uh, did you ever figure out who told?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No. I confronted Barbara Chen, but she claimed she didn’t know what I was talking about.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hmm. Well, I guess it’s just gonna remain a mystery, you know, like whatever happened in that seminar after they dimmed the lights.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It had to be Barbara. I’ve been trying to figure out a way to get back at her. Do you think using her work computer to Google how to be a prostitute is over the line?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh, you know, when I was in high school, there was this girl who was talking about me behind my back, so me and all my friends, we cornered her in the bathroom and forgave her.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What kind of revenge is that? This woman screwed with my job. She’s got to pay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, all right, honey, you know what? There was something I was too scared to tell you yesterday, and now I’m just balls-out terrified to tell you, but the truth is it wasn’t Barbara Chen, it was me. I’m the reason everyone knows.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why did you do that?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it was an accident.I am so sorry I lied.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Get out.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, you know, I also lied about the girl in the bathroom. Yeah, we actually dumped her retainer in the toilet and put it back in her mouth.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand why I can’t talk at this meeting.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: ‘Cause when you talk, it enrages people.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. Quick question. Am I allowed to exchange pleasantries upon meeting this colonel?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Am I allowed to inform him that Colonel Sanders was never actually in the military?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m getting enraged.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. Ooh. Can I use text-to-speech software?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Don’t speak.

Speaker: Sheldon’s phone
Dialogue: Aw, nuts.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I’m Colonel Williams. Thank you for meeting with me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: So, which one of you is the brains behind all this?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s a group effort, but I guess if we had to pick a main brain, it would be me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Strangled sound)

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: And because of the quantum vortices, this can run perpetually?

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Exactly. Yeah, you have a good grasp of the physics.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Well, I’m a scientist by training.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Really? You’re a physicist?

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Better. I’m an engineer.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where did you go to school?

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: MIT.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh. Well, hey, me, too.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: I should have known. Behind every great invention is an MIT mind. I’ll cut to the chase. The Air Force believes there’s an application for this technology, and we’re interested in funding your research.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, thanks, but you should know we’re a little concerned about this being used in weapons.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Oh, well, let me put your mind at ease. What we use it for is none of your business.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know how I feel about this.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Look, guys, it’s just a guidance system. It’s not like you’re handing us the Death Star from Star Trek. All you need to worry about is, right now, it’s this big, and we need it to be this big.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s a lot less big.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Yes, it’s this much less big.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m not even sure that’s possible.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Well, I ran it by some colleagues at MIT, and they thought they could get it done in four months.

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Four months?

Scene: The same, shortly after, demonstrating the quantum gyroscope.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, we’ll do it in two. Hi. I’m Dr. Sheldon Cooper. I’m the actual brains behind this project. Also, engineers aren’t real scientists, MIT’s a trade school, and the Death Star is from Star Wars, not Star Trek. But otherwise, thank you for your service.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi. Howard told me you were working late, so I brought dinner.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, thanks. You know, I just wanted to get some work done without people congratulating me about the baby every five minutes.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I spent my day alone in the lab waiting for a rat to die of anthrax.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Did you come here to bring me dinner or to gloat?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I came to see how you were feeling, but I’m guessing still angry?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m sorry. My boss wants to meet with me, and I’m stressing.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You really think they’re gonna start treating you differently?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Are you kidding? I’ve always been treated differently. Look at me. Listen to me. I mean, the first thought when you see me isn’t that’s a scientist, it’s I wonder if her mommy
knows where she is.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I am really regretting that I got you a Happy Meal.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’ve worked so hard to get where I am, and I don’t want to get sent back to square one because I’m pregnant.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I understand how you feel.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I wish there were some way I could make it better.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, you brought me French fries. That’s a start.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh, actually, I got you apple slices ’cause you’re pregnant.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Apple slices? What kind of lunatic goes to McDonald’s and gets fruit?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll be right back.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And a chocolate shake.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, Leonard’s mad at me, so I’m making him lemon bars.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Does he even like lemon bars?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not really. But I’m mad at him, too, so lemon bars it is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Something happen at the meeting?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: They made me promise I wouldn’t talk.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And you talked?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, now, see? You knew what was gonna happen. Why didn’t they? Anyway, now we’re committed to completing this project in a ridiculously short time frame, and everyone’s upset with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, if it makes you feel any better, Bernadette’s mad at me, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Mm. If it makes you feel any better, a parasitoid wasp known as Oobius depressus has been rediscovered after 101 years of presumed extinction.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why would that make me feel better?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would your Bernadette thing make me feel better? At least mine was educational.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Never mind.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look, I’m sorry. Tell me why Bernadette is upset with you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I told people at work that she’s pregnant. She wasn’t ready for them to know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why would you do that?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it just slipped out. I feel terrible.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: See, that’s exactly what happened to me, except that I said it on purpose, and I have no regrets.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Is it even possible to get this done in two months?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, maybe. I don’t know. We’ll have to work 12 hours a day, seven days a week.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Which means I won’t be able to make Penny breakfast every day, and she’ll realize my brioche French toast was the only thing keeping her in the marriage.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I love your French toast.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, thanks, man.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So, why did you guys even agree to the deadline?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We didn’t. Sheldon did.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And you just let him?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, the colonel said it was for the good of the country, and the funding is substantial.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, but mostly, there was an awkward pause, and I broke it by saying okay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So I guess I won’t be seeing you guys for a while.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, looks like it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wow. You’re going off to work with the military, leaving me behind. Now I know how all those army wives feel.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Would you stop? We’re just gonna be on the other side of campus.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And right here.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You are a deeply silly man.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He is so afraid of his feelings.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hi.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Got a minute?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, come on in.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I just wanted to apologize. I know what you did was an accident.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, and I’m sorry I lied about it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: For what it’s worth, you’re a great liar.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s what Amy said. So what’s going on with the research project? Are they gonna let you run it?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, my boss said he hadn’t decided yet, so I gently reminded him that he’s an old rich white guy, and I’m a sweet little pregnant lady who’s not afraid to crying front of a jury.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You threatened to sue?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey, I learned a long time ago, when you’re four feet eleven and eye level with every guy’s crotch, that’s where you punch.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s funny. I learned something totally different.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Do you know what? It’s just a research project. The most important job in the world is gonna be raising this child. It’s all I need to give my life meaning.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s so beautiful.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You believe me? Oh, good. 11 more chumps like you, I’ll have the jury eating out of my hand.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I never realized this building was classified.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe that’s because it’s classified.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wish we weren’t so far from my parking space.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The way you put away those lemon bars, perhaps that’s a good thing.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’d like to reinstate the you-not-talking rule.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why? It clearly doesn’t work.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I guess this is it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is that a retinal scanner?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let’s find out.

Speaker: Scanner
Dialogue: Howard Wolowitz, access granted.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No way.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Impressive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, my turn, my turn.

Speaker: Scanner
Dialogue: Leonard Hofstadter, access granted.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I didn’t even have to take my glasses off/

Speaker: Scanner(as Leonard and Sheldon try to fool it with one eye each)
Dialogue: Access denied.

Speaker: Leonard and Sheldon
Dialogue: It knows.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, oh, oh, oh, guys, hold me upside down.

Speaker: Scanner
Dialogue: Howard Wolowitz, access granted.

Speaker: All
Dialogue: Yay.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s pretty late. You think I’ve got time to run some more simulations on the cooling system?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sure, I’m still figuring out the thermo-acoustic expander.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, while you do that I am going to pump cerebral spinal fluid through my brain cells to remove the metabolic by-products of the day’s thoughts.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s called sleep and it’s my bedtime. Nighty-night, y’all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, hey, hey, you’re not going anywhere.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We only have two months to deliver this to the Air Force because of you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know, I was there.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, wake up, we’re gonna put in a lot of late nights.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How late?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I don’t know, midnight, one.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: One o’clock? I’m not a raccoon.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you’re tired, have some coffee.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? You have some coffee.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I am having coffee.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And look how irritable it’s making you!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Guys, we’re not gonna get anything done if we start fighting. Now, can you please try
to soldier through?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine.(Time passing montage)I don’t think I can go much longer.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s been three and a half minutes, wake up.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I had a bad dream that my best friend became a tyrant and forced me to stay up all night to work.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I had a good dream that when I carried you to bed, I let your head hit the wall and I laughed.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, we didn’t see you last night, we’re not gonna see you today, so we thought we could have breakfast together.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, that is so nice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ow, it does hurt.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, what are you guys gonna do today?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, Sheldon was supposed to go to this party with me this afternoon, but I don’t think that’s happening.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that was never happening.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll go. I like a party.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, to be honest, it’s not like a party party, it’s more like a gathering where scientists of different disciplines get together to share their work and keep current on what’s going on in other fields. I don’t know why I called it a party, sorry.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s okay, I’ll still go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t think you’ll be bored?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’ll have some wine and listen to people go on about crap I don’t understand. I mean, how is it any different than every single day of my life?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I won’t be there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: : Look at that, it is a party.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry I have to work all weekend.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s okay.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thanks again for breakfast.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I didn’t get to see you last night. It was the least I could do.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You shouldn’t have made the alarm code his birthday.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So, what should we do today?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, I appreciate it, but you don’t have to spend your day off with me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I don’t mind. Oh, you want go to the mall and look at baby stuff?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, come on, we could share a pretzel and get sideways glances from racist old ladies.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I get enough of that when I take Howard to my grandmother’s for Christmas.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, I know, why don’t we get started on clearing out the baby’s room?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Isn’t it a little early for that?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You have to get to it eventually.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, there’s so much junk in there, it’s embarrassing.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How can you be embarrassed around me? I’m gonna be in the room with you when you give birth.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t think you are.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You didn’t think I was gonna be in your kitchen this morning, yet here I am.

Dialogue: Psst, hey, kid.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Huh, what?

Scene: In the university, Sheldon is asleep against a vending machine.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no, thank you, those have caffeine in them.

Dialogue: Oh sorry, I thought you were cool.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I am cool. This is Yoo-hoo, chocolate milk’s delicious watery cousin.

Scene: In the university, Sheldon is asleep against a vending machine.
Speaker: The Flash
Dialogue: All right. But if you ever want to feel like you have superpowers, try one of these.

Dialogue: Superheroes take performance-enhancing chemicals?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I am facing a great deal of work. And I do like things better when famous people also like them.

Speaker: The Flash
Dialogue: Here. It’s on the house.

Scene: In the university, Sheldon is asleep against a vending machine.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The first one’s free? Flash, how do you stay in business?

Speaker: The Flash
Dialogue: You want to know my secret? I bought stock in Marvel.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi, Bert. This is my friend, Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Hey, come on in. I’ll gonna go turn on some rock music. That’s a geology joke.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bert’s a geologist.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: And a joker.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How early are we?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, actually, we’re an hour late.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I suddenly wish Sheldon was here.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t even know where to begin.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, in The Sound of Music, Julie Andrews says let’s start at the very beginning, a very good place to start.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, I was gonna start at the end. Thank God you’re here.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I think the first thing we should get rid of is that tone.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry. I should probably keep this in case we have a girl.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, that’s a nice one. Was it yours when you were little?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: My dad built it for me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wow, it’s so cute.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: This was the husband and this was the wife. They’d go out on adventures together. Cruises, skiing, horseback riding. That was really me just duct taping them to our dog.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, and did they have kids?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: They did, but the mommy and daddy didn’t like them, so they shipped them off to an orphanage I made out of a shoebox.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s not worrisome at all.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not every girl dreams about being a mom. Sometimes you think you’re never gonna have kids and one day you wake up and you’re pregnant. And it doesn’t matter that your career’s going great right now and that you and your husband never even got to go anywhere taped to a dog.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I skipped spin class for this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why is it taking him so long to get a drink out of a vending machine?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, it’s complicated. He finds pushing that little door and reaching up into the machine
uncomfortably intimate.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I am ready to work. To quote The Martian, let’s science the faeces out of this. That’s The Martian the book and The Martian the movie, not Marvin the Martian. Although to quote Marvin the Martian, I claim this planet in the name of Mars.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m fantastic, never been better. I had my first energy drink and I feel great. Hey, you guys want to wrestle? We can do arm, thumb, mud, sumo. Nah, we’re not fat enough, or wearing diapers.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You wanted him awake.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So should we talk to each other or mingle?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know where everyone is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I mean, I could see him eating one or two guests, but not a whole party.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Well, I guess this is kind of a bust. You don’t have to stay. I’m gonna start cleaning up.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay. I feel so bad about leaving him here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, it’s funny, I was just thinking the same thing about you.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Hey, listen, could you not say anything about this to the people at the university? You know, ’cause you’re you and I’m me, and it’s kind of embarrassing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, what do you mean she’s her?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Well, you know how Amy’s the coolest girl on campus, right?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Oh yeah, everybody thinks so.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? You tell me about your foot fungus, but this is a secret?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sure it’s just ’cause I’m dating Sheldon.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Mm, actually, I think Sheldon’s popular because he’s dating you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Now Sheldon’s popular? What is happening?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe we should break for lunch. What time is it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: According to the world’s worst cuckoo clock, it’s two.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My head hurts and I’m more tired than ever.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why don’t you just go home?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I can do this. I just, I just need another energy drink. Oh, no.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I want another one.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s a craving. That’s a sign of chemical dependency.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You only had one.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I know, but plenty of things are addictive after a single exposure. I mean, crack cocaine, nicotine, Pringles. You know once one pops one just can’t stop.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can’t develop a problem that fast.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You want to bet? Oh, great, now I’m addicted to gambling.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We can’t afford to lose any more time.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, this probably won’t work, but has anyone ever tried to just haul off and whup the crazy out of him?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s not helpful. It’s fun to think about, but it’s not helpful. Hey, Sheldon, we are on a serious time crunch. We can’t do this without you. Can you please pull it together?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry. Yes, of course.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just, please, bear with me if I display symptoms of caffeine withdrawal.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No worries.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You guys stink.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry I flipped out on you. I think it’s just hormones.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I think you were mean before you were pregnant, but it’s fine. So, uh, instead of cleaning out the room, why don’t we just decide on a theme for the nursery?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Does it really need one?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Of course it does. Didn’t your baby room have a theme?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, it doubled as my dad’s office, and he was a cop, so I guess the theme was bloody homicide photos.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh. Mine was Winnie the Pooh. But anyway, why don’t we just take a step back and start with a colour? Right? There are so many amazing ones. Red, blue, green, purple.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Are you just gonna name all the colours?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, not now.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t care what colour the room is.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, well, I’m just trying to help you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, you’re not, so just drop it.(Off)I’m clearly upset. Why aren’t you following me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sorry. Sorry.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: And when Amy started using a solution of chromic acid and white vinegar to clean all her lab equipment, all of a sudden, everybody was doing it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You trend setter.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Just the right idea at the right time.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, okay, so Amy’s cool, Sheldon’s cool. Tell me about Leonard.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard Hofstadter.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Oh, him. I guess he’s all right. Apparently he tricked some hot girl into marrying him.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That’s me, I’m her. You know, he didn’t trick me, he just wore me down.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: It makes sense you two are friends. I mean, hot girls always stick together.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And you thought this wasn’t gonna be a great party.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, I had no idea Caltech is exactly like my high school.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, it’s not exactly like it. We’re all extremely smart.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, you popular girls are mean.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m gonna get some coffee. You want some?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, you’re really going to have caffeine in front of me when I’m trying to get my life back on track?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, okay, let’s pretend you do have a problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You don’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but I do.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, you don’t. But let’s say you do. And don’t say you do, because you don’t. Now, wouldn’t you think that throwing yourself into your work would be the best way to deal with it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: With what?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Your problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I thought I didn’t have a problem.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That was painful to watch.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So where are we going?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t know.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. How Thelma and Louise of us.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Raj, why don’t I care about anything?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sorry?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s my baby. I, I should care about nurseries and colours, and I don’t. What’s wrong with me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, crime-scene photos near your crib spring to mind.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I keep waiting to feel excited, but it’s not happening. What if it never happens?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Bernadette, come on, look, you’re overthinking this, okay? You’re gonna be an amazing mom. Even if you don’t believe it, I know you have maternal instincts.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Once, I was supposed to babysit my brothers. Our neighbour found them naked in the backyard eating crickets.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Happy and well-fed. You see, that’s what I’m taking from that story.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, can I ask you a question?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is it about the rotational symmetries you should be figuring out or your fake caffeine problem?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard, can I ask you a question?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, I’ll just toss this out to the room. Um, I was thinking that the best way to fight my addiction is by weaning myself off in steps. Now, I couldn’t find a caffeine patch, but I did find what claims to be a mind-boosting caffeine suppository. You know, the interesting fact about the rectum…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon. We are dealing with an impossible deadline from the Air Force because of you. So have an energy drink, don’t have an energy drink. Order suppositories and shove ’em wherever you want, I don’t care.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You don’t shove them. They come with an easy-glide applicator.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right. Listen to me. We can’t do anything until you do your part. So get up in front of this whiteboard and do it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, you can.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I can’t figure out the math. I’ve been racking my brain for days, and I’ve got nothing.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Seriously?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t do it. I’m not as smart as I think I am. I’m so sorry. This is all my fault.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s okay, we’ll figure something out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But what if we can’t?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’ll be fine. You’ll see. Sheldon? Buddy?(Sheldon snores)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: When the baby gets here, you gotta teach me that.
Bert’s apartment.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thank you so much, Bert. This was great.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: My pleasure. You girls want to take home a two-gallon tub of potato salad?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I think we’re good.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Okay, well, thanks for coming by. You’re nice people.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, so are you. In fact, you know what? We will never take you for granite. Did you get that? Granite? A little geology joke.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: You need to leave. I’m in love with both of you now.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, pull over.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What? Why? Who are you calling? You’re gonna rat me out to Howard, aren’t you? You’re such a snitch, no wonder I don’t like you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Whoa, I’m calling my dad, okay? He’s got experience dealing with pregnant ladies because he’s an OBGYN. And experience with crazy ladies because of my mom.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli(on facetime)
Dialogue: Hello, Rajesh. Are you calling to ask for money?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What? No.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Are you calling to ask for things that cost money?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Great. What’s up?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This is my friend, Bernadette. She’s pregnant, and she’s a bit worried, so I thought maybe you could talk to her.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Of course. What seems to be the trouble?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Something’s wrong. I don’t care about any of the baby stuff every other mom is so into. Honestly, I’m not even sure I like babies.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Look, some people are baby people, and some people are not baby people. It doesn’t mean you won’t love your own baby.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: But I thought I’d be more excited.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Oh, being excited isn’t a guarantee of anything. Rajesh’s mother was thrilled when she was pregnant with him. After he was born, she doted on his every move. And you know what happened? He broke her heart, moved halfway around the world, and dates only poor white women. So you never know.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thank you. I feel better now.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well I don’t.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Good. Bernadette, I hope you have a daughter.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Um, I don’t really know how to say this.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Well, you could try starting with sir.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right. Sorry, sir.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He said start with it, not end with it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: Hmm?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We’ve hit a bit of a snag. We’re already behind schedule.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The computations required to overcome the deployability issues are more significant than we thought.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I understand that we’re under contract, and I don’t know what the consequences of violating that are, but, uh, we’re not gonna be able to deliver in the time we promised.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: How long do you need?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We, we’re thinking, two years.

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s it? You’re okay with that?

Speaker: Colonel Williams
Dialogue: What, you think you’re the first government contractor who isn’t gonna deliver on time? We’re still waiting for a big space laser Reagan ordered to beat the commies.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks for understanding, sir.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes, thank you so much.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We, we really appreciate it.

Speaker: Leonard(off)
Dialogue: All right, pressure’s off

Speaker: Howard(off)
Dialogue: Wanna see a movie?

Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: Popcorn’s on me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And there was water everywhere, it was such a mess.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That stinks. How long are you out of the apartment?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: About five weeks.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ugh, did you lose anything valuable?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, the pipe was over my closet, so all my clothes are gone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, so nothing. Great. Do they know why the pipe burst?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: They didn’t say.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Buildings that have a combination of copper and galvanized steel are susceptible to pinholes and corrosion caused by the mobility of ions in the water. Can’t have your head shoved in a toilet as much as I did and not pick up a few things about plumbing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, if you need a place to crash, you can stay with us.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Of course. You can stay in Leonard’s room, and we’ll stay at my place.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You’re sure that’s not an inconvenience?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, not at all.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And we live with Sheldon, so the word inconvenience has really lost all meaning.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So, technically, I’d be moving in with my boyfriend?

Speaker: Penny

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Stuart. He heard me talking about us going away. I guess he decided to invite himself over?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Should we say something to him?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe. How ’bout, hey, you look like a boiled chicken breast?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I meant like, what are you doing here?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Nah, that’s not gonna hurt his feelings.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why is nothing easy with him?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, here’s the thing you need to understand about Sheldon. He’s the worst.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I prefer to think of it as high-maintenance.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I prefer to think of myself as five-ten, but I still need to get all my pants hemmed.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I guess I should have known what I was getting myself into.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Don’t beat yourself up. You’ve never lived with anyone before.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s true.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And you’re starting out with Sheldon Cooper. That’s like getting your first pet and having it be, I don’t know, what’s a kind of pet that ruins your life?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You’re not making me feel better.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, even when Penny and I started living together, there was a learning curve. But I promise you, it does get easier.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: He put a sign up in the bathroom that says, number of days without Amy’s hair on the soap.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. My record was six.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is it me, or is there something fun about watching him just float there?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe this is why people get fish tanks. Who just turned the porch lights on?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is someone else here?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hmm. They must have left the tub on. Good thing I stopped by. Ah. Aaaaah! What are you doing here?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe Howard and Bernadette said I could be here.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Did they?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Answer the question, what are you doing here?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I had nothing else to do tonight. The last couple of months, I come here when I know they’re not home.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: They heard me in the bushes once, but they thought I was a raccoon.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I told you raccoons don’t say uh-oh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, one night, Leonard’s nose whistled so loud, I swear it was like sleeping on a train track.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Have you noticed it’s always an A-flat?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is it? Oh. It’s like his sinuses are right here in the car.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If we’re just going to drive around aimlessly, the least you could do is take me for ice cream.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I’ll take you for ice cream.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, see, why can’t Amy be that subservient? She has coitus one time, suddenly she’s Gloria Steinem. Anyway, I suppose an ice cream parlour will be a good place to meet other women.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, please, you’re barely interested in a physical relationship with one person. Why would you want to confuse and disappoint others?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Being with Amy has awoken the sexual creature within. When I see a pretty gal walking down the street, I think, hubba hubba, like any other guy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You kiss your mother with that mouth? ‘Cause it’s fine.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Here you go.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Shall we toast?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: To Howard and Bernadette, and the house key they never asked me to return.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You said you got it back.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, clearly, I lied.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So how’s your apartment?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Not great. The electricity’s out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So why don’t you get it fixed?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I called, and they’re like, pay your bill.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: If you ever need somewhere to crash, there’s always my place.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, no. I don’t want to be an inconvenience. You’ve got all your lady friends, and…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Actually, I’m single now.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: What? When did that happen?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s okay. It’s by choice. Well, their choice, and it’s not okay.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh. Sorry. I didn’t know.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Nobody does. I was embarrassed so I didn’t say anything.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why wouldn’t he tell us? Are we bad friends?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He’s in our hot tub drinking our wine.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, he deserves to be alone.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: So you’re back out on the dating scene now?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, a little.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, that must be fun. How’s that going?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m in a hot tub with you, so pretty bad.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Maybe I should just give in to his stupid bathroom schedule.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, don’t do that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: But you did.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Exactly. Learn from my mistakes. No matter where I am at 7:18am, there better be a toilet nearby.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s just so much easier to give him what he wants.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, true, but think of how much you’ve accomplished. Who got him to stop Purelling his pocket change?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And who got him to put things other than gloves in the glove compartment?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Me. It was mittens.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And who got him to try a turkey dog?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That was actually Koothrappali, but I did let him spit it out in my hand.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How can you stop now? That’s like walking out of Pinocchio right before he becomes a real boy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, you’re right. I’m in this relationship, too. I need to stand up for myself.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Of course you do.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And if he doesn’t like it, he can move back here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. He can try. He’d just need a good locksmith.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, who you gonna hit on? The girl in front of us got strawberry. That’s your favourite.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. No, if we both like it, I’ll spend the rest of my life opening the freezer and going, aw, no strawberry.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What about the girl behind the counter?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm? Well, she spends her whole day scooping. One arm’s probably bigger than the other.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is it possible you might not actually want to meet someone?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You are truly wise.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’d say wise beyond your years, but you’re getting up there.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right. Come on. What is really going on with you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny, I am going to tell you a story that I’ve never told anyone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was 13 years old, and on spring break from college.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Not relating. Go on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I came home early because they ran out of math to teach me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, now I’m with ya. Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My mother was at bible study. I walked in the house expecting to find it empty, and I heard a sound coming from my parents’ bedroom. When I opened the door, I saw my father having relations with another woman.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s awful.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know. It’s also why I never open a door without knocking three times. I mean, the first
one’s traditional, but two and three are for people to get their pants on.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, what happened with your dad?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We locked eyes, I ran to my room, and we never, ever spoke of it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You poor thing.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Since Amy and I have been living together, we’ve been bickering like my parents used to.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And you’re afraid you’re gonna do something like your dad did?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I need to prepare her now to save her from pain down the road.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Down the road? Sheldon, she wanted to share a toothbrush holder with you, and now you’re at an ice cream parlour trying to pick up women.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, anything can sound silly when you put it in that tone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Honey, instead of worrying about pain you might cause in the future, how about trying to fix the pain you’re causing her right now?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sure you’re right. I suppose I should apologize to you, as well.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That must have hurt watching me look for other women without ever even considering you. Please understand that I think of you as more of a nanny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Just finish your ice cream so I can get you home to bed.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I wonder if this is what it feels like to be Bernadette’s baby.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I don’t know. Bernadette’s baby doesn’t have a Jacuzzi jet hitting just the right spot.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Those jets are for my secret spot, not his.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What do you do in there?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s called relaxing, and that’s all you need to know.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, it’s getting late. Maybe we should head home.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah, you’re probably right.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You coming?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah, just give me a minute.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, you know how you’re wearing a bathing suit?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I kind of went the other way.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You jackasses just bought yourselves a hot tub!

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s a nice enough spot. You know, if I’m going to start standing up for myself, this is exactly the kind of thing…

Dialogue: We’re back.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, hi. Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How you guys doing?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’re doing good. I think Sheldon has something he would like to say to Amy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I wanted to apologize for my behaviour today. It, it was unnecessary. This is warm. Oh, and also, I am willing to forego the bathroom schedule.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. Really?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why does she get that? We never got that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you want him back?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m very happy for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, you should know I was never really interested in seeing other women. And to prove how serious I am about us, I’m willing to take our relationship to the next level.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy Farrah Fowler, will you share this toothbrush holder with me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I would love to.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Did we really need to be here for this?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Call me crazy, but I found it moving.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, have you ever heard of the Van Nuys Comic-Con?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: ‭Yeah. It’s a dinky little convention where they sell collectibles and get sad D-list celebrities to appear. Why?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I got asked to sign autographs there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s awesome. Is this for Serial Ape-ist?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it could be for the monkey movie. It could be my haemorrhoid commercial. The list does not go on.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: When is it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It doesn’t matter. I’m not doing it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What? Why not?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You just said yourself, it’s sad.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, but it’s not pathetic, that’s where I draw the line. Come on, we’ll have fun.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’ll have nerds fawning all over you. If you don’t love that, this marriage is in trouble.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I guess it wouldn’t hurt to meet some fans and make a little extra money.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Wow, An appearance by George Lucas… ‘s dermatologist. Oh, I want that autograph.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, with us living together, maybe we could think about having people over.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We have people over all the time. We have the maintenance people, the pizza delivery man, that UPS driver who feels the need to ask how parts of me are hanging.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know what I meant.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, fine. Let’s say that we were to entertain people. What type of gathering did you have in mind? Huh? A meal? Lunch? Brunch? Dinner? Afternoon tea? A formal tea? Hmm? Is it a party? And if so, what kind of party? Is it a cocktail party? A Tupperware party? Ooh, is it a surprise party? Oh, I hope it’s not a West Coast party, ’cause according to the man on the radio, a West Coast party don’t stop.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sorry I mentioned it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, don’t be. You get your hopes up, I knock them down. That’s called teamwork.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s a kick. That’s an actual kick.

Dialogue: What are you doing?

Dialogue: I felt a kick. There’s a baby in there.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, that’s where I put it.

Dialogue: Oh, I mean, I know you’re pregnant. I just never connected the idea of pregnancy and you actually having a baby.

Dialogue: Which MIT did you go to?

Dialogue: Oh, God, we are not ready to have an infant in this house. We don’t have a crib, we don’t have diapers, we’re not baby-proofed. Anyone can just walk in off the street and lift our toilet lids!

Dialogue: Howie, we have time to do all that stuff.

Dialogue: Do we? Look at you. Willy Wonka would roll you to the juicing room.

Dialogue: The next person kicking you will be me. Good night.

Dialogue: Are we even in a good school…? Ow!

Dialogue: I warned you, and I did it.

Dialogue: What’s all this?

Dialogue: Are you kidding? I once paid twenty dollars for Theo Sassler’s signature.

Dialogue: Who’s that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t even know. I just liked his name. Theo Sassler. Okay, and look at this. I even got a change maker. How much change you want, little lady?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, there’s so much I want to change.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, well, if it’s a dollar, you’re in luck.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s going on here?

Dialogue: You expressed an interest in having people over, and I feel I dismissed it too quickly. So, I took matters into my own hands, and I arranged a brunch.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, that’s so nice. Who’s coming?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, uh, Stuart, Bert from the geology lab, and Mrs. Petrescu from downstairs.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You mean the Romanian lady on the second floor?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. Oh, fun story, she grew up with ten siblings. Or possibly penguins. Her English is atrocious.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s an odd mix of people.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, for our first time hosting, I thought it would be wise to conduct a trial run. You know, like how I practiced for that Halloween haunted house by going into the bathroom at the bus station.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You never went into that haunted house.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You never saw what jumped out at me at the bus station.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, thank you, Sheldon. This is a fun surprise.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Well, the real surprise is how surprised you are that I’m great at surprises.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, that’s not a surprise at all. I mean, if I knew you were good at surprises, I would have
expected the surprise, and therefore not have been surprised, but as it is, I didn’t know, and therefore my surprise should be unsurprising.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t get me all randy. Guests are on the way.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey, where you been?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, we went and did a little shopping for the baby.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wait till you see the crib we found.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You bought a crib without me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You’re gonna love it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s the highest rated one on the market. I wouldn’t even call it a crib, I’d call it a Fortress of Solitude for babies.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sounds expensive.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, well, I may have gone a bit overboard, but you can’t put a price on safety.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Though if you did, it’s more zeroes than you’re expecting.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: But it’s the safest crib you can buy. And if you don’t like it, we can return it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: In our new minivan. Hey, what’s for lunch?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You bought a minivan?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s for the baby, and I didn’t buy it. The dealer loaned it to me for a 24-hour test drive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Though we did ding up the back pretty good with the crib, so you might have bought a minivan.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I don’t want to drive that. It’s such a mom car.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The guy at the dealership said they’re not just for moms anymore.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Then again, he did think you were my husband.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: They thought it at the ultrasound, why not at the car dealership?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Never been on this side of the table before. I feel powerful.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? I feel like I’m selling candy so our team can get new uniforms.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, so it’s four seventy-five for a signed black-and-white and nine ninety-five for a colour.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Alright, why not five and ten bucks?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I brought my moneymaker. Let me shake it.

Dialogue: Hey, that guy’s looking over here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. You think he’s your first autograph?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know. Be cool. He’s coming. He’s coming. Hi.

Speaker: Guy
Dialogue: Hi. I love your movie.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, thanks.

Speaker: Guy
Dialogue: It has got to be one of the worst things I’ve ever seen in my life.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Your love confuses me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Would you like an autograph?

Speaker: Guy
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Who do I make it out to?

Speaker: Guy
Dialogue: Daniel.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Daniel
Dialogue: I have to ask. Were you trying to be that bad, or are you just a terrible actress?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That did not clear things up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’ll be four seventy-five.

Speaker: Daniel
Dialogue: Keep the change.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: But I-I-I, oh. Nothing about that was good.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: There’s nothing to be afraid of, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The average cork speed is 25 miles per hour. If that is too fast around a school, it is certainly too fast around a kitchen.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Been 15 minutes. Just sayin’.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. I can do this. Just give me a moment… Oh! Mimosas coming up.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: I once left orange juice in my fridge so long, it tasted like a mimosa.

Dialogue: How old was it

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: It’s hard to say. I don’t remember much after I drank it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Would you like one, Mrs. Petrescu?

Dialogue: Yes. Drink is fun and good friends, Applebee’s.

Dialogue: She’s learning English from TV.

Dialogue: TV, good. Now back to you.

Dialogue: Hey, guys.

Dialogue: Hi, Stuart.

Dialogue: These are for you.

Dialogue: Oh, they’re pretty. Thank you.

Dialogue: Stuart, this is Bert from the Caltech geology lab, and this is Mrs. Petrescu from downstairs.

Dialogue: Nice to meet you.

Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Hey.

Dialogue: So, what did I miss?

Dialogue: Eh, we watched Sheldon try to open a bottle for 15 minutes.

Dialogue: 15 minutes can save you 15% or more on car insurance.

Dialogue: Anybody else coming to this thing?

Dialogue: What’s your name?

Dialogue: Jeff.

Dialogue: Okay.

Dialogue: My favourite part is your shower scene.

Dialogue: Yep, there they are.

Dialogue: Okay, let’s keep it moving.

Dialogue: Here you go.

Dialogue: Should’ve punched that guy.

Dialogue: Well, go ahead. He’s right over there.

Dialogue: Why do you do that? Can’t you let me have my moment?

Dialogue: Hello.

Dialogue: Hi. I like your movies.

Dialogue: Thank you.

Dialogue: I saw both of them.

Dialogue: I assume we’re still talking about the movies, but after today, who knows.

Dialogue: You think I could get a picture of us?

Dialogue: Oh, sure.

Dialogue: No. She cannot kiss. What is wrong with you people?

Dialogue: No, no, no. It’s not okay.

Dialogue: I’m her husband.

Dialogue: I am.

Dialogue: Yeah, he really is.

Dialogue: Hey, show her the trunk. Show her the trunk.

Dialogue: Imagine this, you’ve got the baby in one hand, groceries in the other, and you’re thinking, how am I gonna open this trunk?

Dialogue: I’m probably thinking, where’s my husband, and why isn’t he helping me?

Dialogue: You don’t need my help when you can open the trunk with a simple kick of the foot.

Dialogue: No, it’s a gentle kick, you’re doing it wrong. Here. Give me those.

Dialogue: Uh, maybe it was more of a circle?

Dialogue: It’s weird that guy thought you were a couple.

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: See? Easy. And look at all this cargo space. Now we’ll get the crib out and you can take it for a test-drive. I’m telling you, this van is gonna be… uuh-uuh, uuh-uuh.

Dialogue: Oh, is it your back?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, oh, anyway, let’s just get in and see if the GPS can take us to the nearest emergency room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So until Amy’s apartment is fixed, she and I are living here together.

Dialogue: I lived with my old girlfriend. She was a geologist, too.

Dialogue: Things didn’t work out?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: I came home from work one day and she had taken everything. I’m warning you, hide your good rocks.

Dialogue: My sister’s husband took all her things, too. Story at eleven.

Dialogue: Really, no one else is coming?

Dialogue: This is it. You are the practice round.

Dialogue: Practice round? For-for what?

Dialogue: Uh, no. He, he just means that you were the first people we thought of.

Dialogue: You know, exactly. We’ve never thrown a brunch before, and I wanted to work out all the kinks.
