Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, no, it’s, it’s important to me that you have the bedroom you want.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that means so much. I love you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I love you, too.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just hiding some stuff in your closet, don’t tell Penny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How much will it hurt?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s just a tiny skin sample. You saw me do it to myself.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: On a scale of one to ten, where one is a pebble in your shoe and ten is the monkey you thought was your pet biting your face off.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: A two.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Eating a whole Altoid?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, if I’m gonna synthesize a neural network from our skin cells, I need to harvest them. Now, I’ve done this dozens of times, but if you’re too scared you don’t have to.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, this is for science. I can be brave for science.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, jiminy, that’s cold.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Just think how happy you’ll be in a few weeks when I’ve converted our skin cells into functional brain cells.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, just warn me before you do it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay. Three, two, and we’re done.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You tricked me. You didn’t say one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It didn’t hurt, did it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, but three, two and we’re done is incomplete. You know those things bother me. It’s like hearing da-da-da-da-da-dah without yelling…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, fine, one.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you. Now yell charge and we can get out of here.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, my God, I just got it. Fun onions, Funyuns. Hold on. Is that a wobble? Yes. That’s definitely a gravitational wobble.

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: Uh, sorry, I could come back.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, no, it’s okay. I just found a wobble.

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: Oh, do I need a mop?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s a gravitational wobble. It could be a sign of an extrasolar planet that may contain life and someday be named after me.

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: Oh, well, if it has life, maybe it already has a name, huh?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, but it’s probably difficult to pronounce.

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: What is your name?
Raj; Rajesh Ramayan Koothrappali.

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: You think it would be more difficult than that?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Good point. And you are?

Speaker: Cleaner
Dialogue: Oh, uh, Isabella Maria Concepcion.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, well, nice to meet you.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Nice to meet you, too. You know, I have to say, based on the candy wrappers and the bags of junk food I see in this trash, working here was ten years old.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, please, show me a ten-year-old who knows to dip Tootsie Rolls in Nutella.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Bueno, um, I’m just going to empty your waste paper basket and then I’ll get out of your way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, please, allow me. That’s a lot of empty calories.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You’re welcome.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Okay, uh, okay, I have to go.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Good luck with your, um, space exploration.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you. Good luck with your future endeavours.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Did it work? Are they brain cells yet?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: If you’d give me a minute, I’ll tell you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, just let me look. Oh, my goodness. I see quivering black lines. Those must be neurons, oh, they’re so thick and beautiful.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Those are your eyelashes, move. Well, Sheldon, I see astrocytes. Our combined skin cells are now a primitive neural network.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have such a profound sense of creation. I, it’s like when I hatched sea monkeys, except that this is from my DNA, so this is like me monkeys.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: These cells come from both of us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but us monkeys doesn’t pop. Oh, oh, oh, oh, wait, we monkeys, there you go. Hey, when can we start running tests on it?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No reason we can’t start right now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What stimulus should we introduce it to first? Light, sound, temperature, oh, oh, let’s
expose it to images of me and you and see who it likes better.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, this is a rudimentary collection of neurons. I mean, it’s remarkable, but it’s still limited in what it can do.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I understand. She’s the mean one, I’m the fun one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Huh, they screwed up and gave us steamed broccoli.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, no, that’s mine.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really? The last green thing I saw you eat was a Skittle.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I can’t eat like a ten-year-old all the time.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re dating somebody, who is it?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What? What are you talking about?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You only watch what you eat when you’re afraid you might have to take your shirt off.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, she’s right. As long as I’ve known you, you’ve always been self-conscious about your cleavage.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s because you keep trying to stick pencils in it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, fine, don’t tell us.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: There’s nothing to tell.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How’s that broccoli?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s gross but I have to eat it because I met somebody.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Bam. Thank you. What’s her name?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Isabella.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, did you meet her at work?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, in the telescope room.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, so she’s an astronomer?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, which is why she was in the telescope room. Yes, this is all making sense. Good.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, that’s great, Raj. You must have so much in common.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, when do we meet her?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, no, this is brand new. We haven’t even been on a proper date yet.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, well, good luck with it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: How come you never eat broccoli?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m married, I don’t have to be attractive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, most people don’t realize this technique has actually been around for a few years.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Still, I can’t believe you can turn ordinary skin cells into functioning brain cells.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I turned this one into a functioning boyfriend, so sky’s the limit.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look, look, here I am standing next to the incubator. Uh, here is a microscopic view of the cells.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Look at that, put them in a tiny Flash T-shirt and it’s you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Aw. Yeah, this little guy can already recognize electronically transmitted images 20% faster than any other sample in Amy’s lab.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m running out of ways to act excited.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So, enough about us, how are things going with you?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Great, the doctor said the baby’s head is facing down now.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Good, you know, in case the exit isn’t clearly marked.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I have to say, it is nice to share this experience with someone who’s on the same journey. Although right now ours is testing off the charts while yours is floating around in its own waste.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Are you actually comparing my human baby to your brain in a bowl?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I didn’t make you waddle up four flights of stairs for the heck of it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You do realize my baby has functioning organs and can recognize voices.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but ours can recognize a specific data stream among background noise.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Mine has a fully developed immune system.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ours doesn’t need an immune system because it lives in a state-of-the-art German incubator.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, that’s enough.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, fine. Let’s just agree that both creations are special in their own way and it is foolish to try and compare them. Although, we didn’t need to have sex with Howard for ours, so we win.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This is fun. I have never cleaned a toilet before.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: You’re kidding.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, I grew up with a house full of servants and now I have a cleaning lady who is a lovely woman who I have great respect for.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: It’s okay, you’re allowed to have a cleaning lady.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, good, because she also walks my dog, buys my groceries and cuts my hair.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: I think that’s called a mommy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, so forgive me, forgive me for being nosy, but is, is there a wedding ring under those pretty rubber gloves?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: No, not for many years.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, so, you are unencumbered?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Just me and my son.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I love kids, how old is he?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Nineteen.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s a cute age. They can do so many things.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: He’s studying to be a lawyer at UCLA.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s wonderful. A lawyer, my sister’s a lawyer. Look at that, we have something in common.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Yeah, I guess we do.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe there are other things we have in common. Come dinnertime, do you enjoy eating food?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Ay, Rajesh, I think you’re very sweet, but I work two jobs and I don’t have time for dating.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, sure. I understand. Yeah, I’m very busy, too.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Oh, please don’t take it personal, I think you’re a very nice man.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I think you’re very nice as well.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Thank you for helping me. Good night, Rajesh.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, yes. Oh, okay. Uh, Good night. I don’t know, maybe it’s the fumes from the urinal cakes, but I feel like something is happening between us.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Good night, Rajesh.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. I’ll leave. But just know, every time I come in here, I’ll be thinking of you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Would you look at that? The image we gave it was 45% white noise, and it still managed to reconstruct it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ve never seen results like this before.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, we need to stop for magnets on the way home, this is going right on the fridge.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Aren’t you glad you participated in this?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I am. And you realize what the next step is?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Set up a second culture and try to replicate our results.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, no. We lock that door, lower our underpants a little and make a baby.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Make a baby? What are you talking about?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Clearly the combination of our DNA is exceptional. Our child could be the next step in the evolution of mankind. We’ll be able to get into any preschool we want!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’m not ready to have a baby.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, yes, you are. I track your cycle. For the next 36 hours you’re as fertile as a manure-covered wheat field.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wow. I, I can actually feel the egg crawling its way back up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t understand. I thought you’d be thrilled to procreate with me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Not right now.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I see what’s happening here. You’re playing hard to get.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not playing anything. We’re not making a baby today.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well. Oops, how clumsy of me. You know what? Let me get that. Hey. Where are you going? I, did you even look at my bottom?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Welcome.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, well, you said you didn’t have time to go out for dinner, so I thought we could have one right here.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Oh, Rajesh.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, come on, we’re in the telescope room. It’ll be like dining under the stars. You see this, uh, double zero? When it says zero one that means it’s twinkling. Sometimes it takes a while.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Rajesh, this is so sweet, but you, you know I’m working.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s why I already cleaned up in here and all the other rooms in the hall.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Well, I suppose that gives me a little time.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, please sit. I tried to cook you a meal from your homeland.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Oh, really? You made Cuban food?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That depends, do they have Mexican food in Cuba?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Now, when he said make a baby, is it possible he meant out of Legos?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No. He was explicit. Needlessly and freakishly explicit.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why does he need a baby? He’s already hairless and smells like talcum powder.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Could you two really have some sort of super-intelligent child?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, there is a genetic component, but that doesn’t guarantee anything.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s true. Sheldon’s father once picked a fight with a cactus.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, but that’s just his Earth parents. We don’t know anything about the ones that sent him here.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, we know they were smart enough to send him away.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, you’re talking about the person I love and have been avoiding for the past three hours. Oh, man.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh, Sheldon gonna get some.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, have fun with whatever nightmare’s behind door number two.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Would you care for a brandy?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t think so.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good choice, it’s disgusting.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, please stop trying to seduce me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who’s trying to seduce you? After a long day I always turn on smooth jazz and spray deer musk on my inner thighs.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I thought it smelled like a petting zoo in here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Anything you’d like to pet? Not my hair. There’s a lot of goop in it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, I’ve had enough.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, come back. I don’t know how to open the oysters.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So, um, what surprised you the most when you first came to America?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Well, I suppose how much people care about Oprah’s favourite things.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I thought that, too. But then I got my first waffle maker and never questioned her again.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: You know, I do have some time off this Sunday if you’d like to…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey! I saw your car… Oh, sorry. Am I interrupting?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: It’s okay. Uh, I should get back to work.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hi. Howard Wolowitz.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Oh. Isabella Concepcion.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, the astronomer. Raj told us about you. Hey, free toilet paper.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: You told him I was an astronomer?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: I understand. Time to go.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, p-please don’t.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: It’s okay, Rajesh, I’m a grown woman. I don’t have to waste my time with someone who’s embarrassed by me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I can keep this, right?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Isabella. Isabella wait, wait, let me explain.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: If you are embarrassed by what I do, why did you pursue me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sorry. Honestly, I didn’t think your job would bother me, but I guess it did. And I hate myself for that. But there’s a lot of things about me that would totally embarrass you.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: I doubt that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, prepare to be mortified. I let my dog eat food out of my mouth, not because she likes it but because I do. Also, I know they’re pretty, but I’m scared of butterflies.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry, just passing through. I think this fell off your cart.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Come on. What do you say? Let me make it up to you.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: You’re very persistent.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s my one move.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Okay. This Sunday night, you may take me to dinner at a nice restaurant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Great. Where would you like to go?

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: Your choice. It can be Pakistani food if you like.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Excuse me, but I’m Indian.

Speaker: Isabella
Dialogue: And now you know how it feels.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, were you turned on even a little bit?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It was like being hit on by Rat Pack Pee-wee Herman.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, is that a yes?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, I didn’t want it to come to this, but you have left me no choice but to employ the most passionate, seductive dance known to man. The flamenco.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: For God’s sake, you’re ridiculous.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You guys are aroused, right?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That was a close one.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Thank you very much. Thanks.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That is unbelievable. Good for Bert.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Damn, the MacArthur Genius Grant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Couldn’t have happened to a nicer guy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Everything is stupid and I want to go home.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s Sheldon’s way of saying he’s proud of Bert, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, it’s not even called the Genius Grant, it’s the MacArthur Fellowship. Just like it’s not Frankenstein, it’s Frankenstein’s Monster. Which brings us back to that hulking simpleton over there. And if anyone’s a genius, it’s me for the way I brought that full circle.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How much money did he win?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Over half a million dollars.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And he doesn’t have to use it for research, he can do whatever he wants with it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, good, maybe he can build a nicer bridge to live under.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Here he comes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Right. Be polite.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know how to behave.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, congratulations Bert.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, good for you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s amazing.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Thanks. I was as surprised as anybody. When they called and told me I won, I didn’t believe them. And then they said, no, you really won. And then I said, cool.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Someone call George R. R. Martin, this guy knows how to finish a story.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: I’ve gotten pretty good at telling it. Well, see ya.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Some genius. I zinged him with sarcasm, he didn’t even notice.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know, and it was the greatest sarcastic quip I’ve ever heard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, aren’t you a peach.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who leaves their bike in the hallway? You know, if I knew how to ride one, I’d steal it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ignore him, he’s just cranky because Bert from the geology lab won a big grant.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I heard him interviewed on the radio. You know, when they told him he won, he didn’t believe it, but then he did believe it. It was so funny.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who listens to the radio any more?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bert is studying the way microbes in rocks can survive in extreme environmental conditions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: They say it could be a potential indicator of life on other planets.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know what, I’ve met Bert. Isn’t he an indicator of life on other planets?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You used to make those jokes about me. Now everything is Bert, Bert, Bert.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, Sheldon, maybe if you take the time to actually read Bert’s research, you’d be less bitter about him winning.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You want me to read a geology paper?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Honestly, I just want you to be quiet but I’m all out of taffy.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You busy? There’s somebody out here who wants to meet you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Say hello to everybody’s little friend, remote control Stephen Hawking.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Where did you get that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I found him in an old box.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why would you buy it?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I didn’t buy it. I made it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Last question. What is wrong with you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s the big deal?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howie, it’s in poor taste.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, it’s not. Check it out, he says fun stuff.

Speaker: Remote-control Hawking
Dialogue: Hey good lookin’, want to go for a spin?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: His eyes also light up in the dark.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s always fun watching him read someone else’s work.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s like scrolling through the emojis on my phone.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeh, why? Eh, why? Oh, that’s why.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sounds like the night we had coitus.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hope you’re happy making me read this. Bert’s work is remarkable, and I’m more upset than ever. This is worse than when I had to admit that Cedric the Entertainer’s actually entertaining.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, it’s foolish to be angry that Bert’s work has merit.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, well I am angry. And you telling me not to be angry makes me angry. And do you know how hearing myself say the word angry over and over makes me feel?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh, ooh, ooh, angry?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I, I knew the answer. I got excited.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, buddy, why don’t we go for a walk, so you can calm down.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s a good idea. I guess everyone’s having them now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, I’m trying to help you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. You can walk ahead of me and scare off the pigeons.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You just wave your arms a little and they fly away, it’s not…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, Raj, I’m gonna show you something. Now, one of us thinks it’s offensive, the other thinks it’s hilarious and a great idea. But, I’m not going to tell you who likes it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This is tough, but I’m going to say it’s the guy who shows me YouTube videos of people getting hit in the nuts.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You’re crazy. I’ve worked with Hawking. He’s got a great sense of humour, and I think he’d like it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay, call him and show him. I dare you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I have no problem calling him.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Fine, then do it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fine, I will.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: While you’re bothering the world’s most famous scientist, be sure to show him how funny he looks getting stuck under our dishwasher.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What’s this button do?

Speaker: Remote-control Hawking
Dialogue: Gentlemen, start your wheelchairs.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You laughed when that guy got hit in the nuts.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I laughed because the guy was Leonard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I admire you, Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Really, why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re happy with who you are. You don’t get jealous of other people. Instead of being weighed down by ambition, you just float along like a dead body in a river.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I couldn’t just take the compliment. I had to ask why. You know, I do understand what you’re feeling. My brother and sister’s accomplishments have always been held over my head.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How did you deal with it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I wet the bed until college, but I don’t think that’s a quality fix.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t believe I was surpassed by a geologist. I mean, rocks. He studies rocks. If rock is so great, how come paper beats it? Leonard, I’m having a primal urge to throw this rock.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do it. Visualize it as your anger and, and toss it out of your life.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Perhaps I will. This rock encapsulates all my negative emotions. I will cast you far away. Feel free to take out a pigeon while you’re at it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Let it fly.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ow, ow, ow, ow, ow, ow, ow, ow…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I tried to let go of anger and threw a rock into my foot.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then he got more angry and kicked the rock with his other foot.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, and what happened to you?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I laughed so hard, I burst a blood vessel in my nose. It’s fine.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, it’s one thing to be envious, but now you’re injuring yourself. It has to stop.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Although if you are gonna do it again, please let me know, so I can get it on video.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, Sheldon, instead of fixating on what Bert has, you should appreciate all of the good things in your life. You’ve got love, you’re in good health, you’ve got a roof over your head.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but you’ve got all those things, and no one’s lining up to be you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Anybody else want to try? I’m gonna go make some more tea and question my life choices.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re up.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is getting old fast, Dolores, knock it off.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, do you really think calling me names is helpful?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I do, your life is fine you big baby.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Maybe you’re right.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If it helps, I’m questioning your life choices, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you, Penny. You know, I just need to keep reminding myself that Bert’s success is not my failure.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: There you go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And that men of his large stature are more susceptible to a wide array of life-threatening diseases.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: There you go.

Scene: Outside Amy’s lab. Howard knocks on the door.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s up?

Scene: Outside Amy’s lab. Howard knocks on the door.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m conducting a quick survey. Do you think this respectful and loving tribute to a great man is in poor taste?

Scene: Outside Amy’s lab. Howard knocks on the door.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do you think this is in poor taste?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Does it spin around and do tricks?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Then yeah.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: Barry
Dialogue: That is hiwawious. Give me the wemote contwol, I want to dwive him into the girls’ westwoom.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All right, we’re done. It’s offensive.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Top of the afternoon, gentlemen.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You’re in a good mood.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, it’s a new day. I have a new outlook. You know, I realized I don’t need to worry about other people. I just need to think more about myself.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, how will we ever get used to the new you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I’m glad to see you moving forward.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bert did quality research, and he deserves whatever accolades he receives.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What is going on? Did you upgrade his software last night?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I think he might be learning on his own.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Then the robot uprising has begun.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me, I need to pay Bert a proper congratulations.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: He doesn’t just look like C-3PO, now he walks like him.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bert? I wanted to let you know that I read your research, and your award is well-deserved.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Thanks. I’ve been hearing that a lot. Ever since I won, people think I’m great.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, just this once, you can count me as people, too.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: You know, as a MacArthur Grant winner, I’m allowed to nominate someone for next year.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really? I didn’t know that.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: So I was thinking, you know, engineers don’t get a lot of respect. Is your friend Howard working on anything cool?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I’m not sure. You know, you’d have to ask him. Excuse me.(Off)Aah. Leonard, I hurt myself again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Excuse me, I have to go take some pictures.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can’t believe you head-butted a water fountain.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I went to punch the water fountain, slipped in water in front of the water fountain, and hit my head on the water fountain.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I can’t imagine you being violent.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s not hard. Just picture the Three Stooges, and then take away two stooges.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m so disappointed in myself. Jealousy is completely illogical.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s a human emotion, Sheldon. Everyone gets jealous. I’m jealous of Leonard and Penny and Howard and Bernadette for being in such happy relationships.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What about me and Sheldon?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’ve always been jealous of how much money Raj’s family has.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you for saying that. Next to buying things, that is the best part about having money.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Ever since I met Penny, I’ve been envious of her looks.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw, thank you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s why I was so happy when you cut your hair off.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know what I mean. You were still hot, but more like a why’d that hot girl cut off all her hair, hot.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You liked my short hair, right?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. I loved it. Love you, love the hair, would love to change the subject.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Seriously, none of you liked it?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I thought it was brave. Does that count as liking it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, how come nobody’s talking about Howard’s dopey haircut?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I think he looks cute.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And I think you’re cute.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I think you’re both cute.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I think I hate all of you nerds.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sorry I’m moving slowly.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t mind. If you pull a butterscotch out of your pocket, it would be like I’m walking with my grandma.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no. A plaque? Nobody wants to see this.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, change plaque to mixed-race couple and you are my grandma.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t take this any more.(Knock, knock, knock)Bert.(Knock, knock, knock)Bert.(Knock, knock, knock)Bert.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, let’s do this, Bert? We need to talk.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: What happened to you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Rock, rock, water fountain. I am not proud of this, but I have been envious of your recent success.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Wow, I won the MacArthur Grant, everyone’s jealous of me. Once I get Lasik, I’ll be out of things to wish for.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was hoping by admitting my weakness to you, I’d somehow be unburdened.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Is it working?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. Now that you know my weakness, I hate you more than ever.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Well, you know, we’re both pretty smart. I bet if we put our heads together, we could come up with a solution.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We, hang on, you’re my enemy. Now, the enemy of the enemy is my friend. And right now, I’m my own worst enemy. That makes you my friend. Okay, I’m good to go.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Great. Now that we’re friends, want to see if we can get tickets to a taping of Ellen?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know what? This isn’t gonna work.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Sheldon, wait. You know, you’ve got a lot to be happy about. You’re at the top of your field, you have a great girlfriend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, that’s right. I have Amy. In the past, you’ve professed feelings for her. Does it eat you up inside that I have her and you don’t?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: It used to. But now that I’m rich and successful, I think I can do better.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe you punched Bert.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I didn’t punch him. He turned around, and I gave him a Captain Kirk karate chop. I’m not even sure he knows I did it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon, I’ve got someone here who might make you feel better.

Speaker: Stephen Hawking(on skype)
Dialogue: Hello, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Professor Hawking.

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: I understand you’re struggling with professional jealousy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thanks, Leonard, now he’s not gonna think I’m cool.

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: Don’t worry, I know how you feel. I have never won a Nobel Prize.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, wow, that doesn’t seem fair.

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: It’s fine. I’ve been on The Simpsons.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How do you deal with the success of your colleagues?

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: I remind myself every scientific advancement is a victory. Also, I was on Star Trek.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, it was a good one. He played poker with Sir Isaac, you don’t care.

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: Don’t waste your time on jealousy Sheldon, you’re too brilliant.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: How can you feel bad if Stephen Hawking says you’re brilliant?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t. Thank you, Professor Hawking. You are a gift to mankind. There should be statues of you everywhere. You know, the Lincoln Memorial has a big chair. We could swap you right in.

Speaker: Hawking
Dialogue: I always thought a motorized toy of me would be cool.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What a wonderful idea, how does this man not have a Nobel?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do not tell Wolowitz.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Way ahead of you.

Dialogue: A new study came out, and it said that laughing makes your brain work better. And I know that’s true because laughing has made me the smartiest. Although, on the other hand, babies laugh a lot, and they’re dumb.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do people know about her? ‘Cause she’s delightful.

Dialogue: If we’re going to be staying in this apartment, would you be interested in doing a little redecorating?

Dialogue: Oh, actually, I would.

Dialogue: Great, what’d you have in mind?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let’s take every single thing from the other apartment and put it in here.

Dialogue: Well, how about we start a little smaller? Like moving the furniture around.

Dialogue: You know, I have always thought that this couch would look fantastic on the curb in front of the building.

Dialogue: Look, we can’t just throw away Penny’s stuff, but we can ask if she wants any of it back.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I wonder how she feels about all this artwork.

Dialogue: It truly does capture the beauty of your friendship with Penny.

Dialogue: It may have appreciated in value. The artist killed himself shortly after painting that.

Dialogue: Yeah, it seems only right that she have it back.

Dialogue: I can’t wait to see the look on her face when I give it to her again.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Look, it’s the same smile she has in the painting.
Credits sequence.

Dialogue: Sounds right, a limited edition collectible worth hundreds of dollars and a thing that grew out of a thing we fished from the trash.

Dialogue: Although, Amy and I did just move in together, and a plant is a lovely housewarming gift.

Dialogue: Fine, take the plant.

Dialogue: Oh, we got a sword and a plant, our apartment’s really shaping up.

Dialogue: Stuart, you didn’t have to get us a baby gift.

Dialogue: A foot massage?

Dialogue: And that’s not me being creepy, that’s for either of you.

Dialogue: This is very nice Stuart, thank you.

Dialogue: How come this one’s on the back of an eviction notice?

Dialogue: Oh, yeah. Uh, now that you mention it, can I live here?

Dialogue: Stuart, we’d love to help you out, but this a bad time, we’re about to have a baby.

Dialogue: Or is that why this is a great time? Think about it, when that baby comes you’re gonna need all the help you can get.

Dialogue: Thank you, but I’m not really sure.

Dialogue: Hang on, maybe it’s not the worst idea. I mean, he did do a good job taking care of my mother.

Dialogue: Thank you. And it’s only temporary, just till I get back on my feet, or the baby goes off to college, whichever happens first.

Dialogue: Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper.

Dialogue: It’s one of a kind.

Dialogue: So if it breaks there’d be none of it?

Dialogue: Well, Leonard, you know, who should keep this? On the one hand, I love Mr. Spock more than you do. On the other hand, I care more about clocks than you do.

Dialogue: So you think you should keep it?

Dialogue: Thank you.

Dialogue: Thank you.

Dialogue: Oh, now, what about our 3-D chess set?

Dialogue: Let me guess, you want it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, no, I just didn’t think you’d want a physical reminder of a game you never managed to win. As a kindness, I should probably take all the games.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know what, Sheldon, take it. In fact, you can have everything, I really don’t care.

Dialogue: Are you sure? These items represent our shared times together.

Dialogue: Well, now they’re yours.

Dialogue: Leonard.

Dialogue: Well, you know what’s gonna happen, he’s just gonna come up with some reason why everything should be his.

Dialogue: For a man so good at predicting my moves, how come you stink at 3-D chess?

Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re, you’re being a little selfish. Why don’t you let Leonard keep a few things?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s not my fault I’m bad at sharing, I skipped kindergarten.

Dialogue: You know what? There is one thing I would like.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, take whatever you want.

Dialogue: I would like to keep the official flag of our apartment.

Dialogue: But you don’t even like flags.

Dialogue: Yeah, I like this one.

Dialogue: But I designed it.

Dialogue: But you made me order it because you were too well-known in the flag community and they’d jack up the price.

Dialogue: But you don’t even understand its symbolism.

Dialogue: Oh, I do. The, the field of blue represents you being miserable, and the lion sticking its tongue out means I’m happy about it.

Dialogue: Come along, Amy. I know when I’m not wanted.

Dialogue: Stuart, you cooked?

Dialogue: Hey, Raj.

Dialogue: Hey, Stuart. What are you doing here?

Dialogue: Oh, I’m living here again.

Dialogue: Do, uh, Howard and Bernadette know? Or is it like a possum in the walls kind of thing?

Dialogue: Okay, cool.

Dialogue: Anyway, come on in, dinner’s ready.

Dialogue: Oh, but I bought Chinese takeout.

Dialogue: Oh, okay. Well, if Bernadette wants her ankles to swell up even more, she can have that.

Dialogue: Is the Wi-Fi working for you?

Dialogue: Uh, hang on. I don’t think so, I’m clicking on one weird trick for a flat belly, but I’m still seeing celebrities who look like their pets.

Dialogue: Oh, I knew it, Sheldon changed the password.

Dialogue: Are you sure?

Dialogue: What a jerk.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re good at revenge, how do we get him back?

Dialogue: Well, my go-to move is usually sleep with the person’s boyfriend, but I kind of feel like I’m already doing that.

Dialogue: Sheldon, I know what you did, now change the password back.

Dialogue: Well, powder me in sugar and call me a doughnut, if it isn’t Leonard Hofstadter.

Dialogue: Sheldon, I’m warning you, I can play this game, too.

Dialogue: If it’s like your 3-D chess game, then you’re out of your length, width and depth. Amy, get the Neosporin, somebody just got burned.

Dialogue: All right, I tried.

Dialogue: All right, I tried. That should be the title of your autobiography. Ooh, a second-degree burn.

Dialogue: I’ve got the Neosporin. Who got hurt?

Dialogue: It’s a good thing you’re cute.

Dialogue: Yeah, we’ve been meaning to do that.

Dialogue: Oh, I know a CPR instructor who’ll come to the house.

Dialogue: I’m sorry, you mumbled something?

Dialogue: Hey.

Dialogue: What do you think you’re doing?

Dialogue: This is the level you’re stooping to.

Dialogue: Hey, what’s up?

Dialogue: I’m here to put the crib together.

Dialogue: Ooh, sorry, I already did it.

Dialogue: Why are you being like this?

Dialogue: Because I love Howard and Bernadette and if I want to keep mooching off them, I need to be helpful.

Dialogue: Hey, this pregnancy had an emotionally-needy third wheel way before you came along.

Dialogue: Why can’t there be four wheels?

Dialogue: Is this what you do when I’m not here, make really good points?

Dialogue: Look, just come in and help me build a baby swing.

Dialogue: Thank you.

Dialogue: So, there are fresh linens on the bed and, oh, well, now, I see you’ve met Theodore. Theodore, these are your new room mates, Leonard and Penny. They’re very honest, but I would not leave cash lying around.

Dialogue: Sheldon, what do you think you’re doing?

Dialogue: My room is paid up until the end of the month, so I can do with it whatever I please, which includes renting it out for a dollar a night.

Dialogue: It’s like the ’40s again.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Anyway, I’ll leave you be. I have to, oh, oh, he’s expecting a newspaper in the morning. Apparently, they still make them.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, Sheldon, this is over the line.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s true, but had I done something under the line, there wouldn’t be a man in your kitchen who can’t produce a single form of ID.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: Oh, oh, I have a receipt from a blood bank. I’m O-negative.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And now you know as much about him as I do.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, hey, Bernadette, the swing comes with two different mobiles. The giraffes are pretty cute, what do you think?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Great, go with the giraffes.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Although the high contrast of zebra stripes might provide better stimulus for a developing baby.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, you’re probably right, go with the zebras.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Good choice, boss.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: At least my nose is naturally brown.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey, could you please go to the market for me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Get Stuart or Raj to do it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howie, they’ve been doing everything for you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Mm, I know. It’s really making me lose respect for both of them.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Please just go to the store.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fine. Who wants to drive me to the store?

Speaker: Raj(off)
Dialogue: Me

Speaker: Stuart(off)
Dialogue: I’ll do it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Take Raj. Stuart is supposed to paint my toenails.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What do you think? Should we go to a hotel?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And just leave him here alone?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I’ll go to a hotel. Text me in the morning if you’re still alive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, Theodore, how long are you planning to stay exactly?

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: Oh, thanks to the coins I found in your couch, a day longer than I thought.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is ridiculous.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: I like the painting. Is that your mom?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, get out here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Will you keep it down? What kind of vengeful bed and breakfast do you think I’m running?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We lived together 13 years. How can you be so awful to me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m being awful? You’re the one who went out of your way to hurt me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because you were being selfish.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Dividing our belongings is difficult.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why? I said I didn’t care.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: Excuse me. It’s none of my business, but it sounds like a lot of this anger is coming from love.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, thanks, but nobody asked you.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: Well, I’m just gonna keep on talking. Seems like, with Sheldon moving out, you’re in a new phase of your lives and it’s easier to fight than to face the feelings that you have for one another.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I think he might be right. Also, who is that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have to admit, leaving you to move in with Amy has been harder than I thought it would be.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, for me, too. It’s not the same with you gone.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: If you’re looking for a new guy to live with.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’re good, thank you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So, no one’s gonna tell me? Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, I would like us to stop fighting about our possessions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I’d like that, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: In fact, I want you to keep the apartment flag, and I’m not just saying that because it touched your genitals.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You promise?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I do. And to show you that there are no hard feelings, I am willing to rub my genitals on it as well.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: Well if we’re rubbing genitals on things, that’s where I shine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Little lower to the left. A little more.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, still hideous.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I’m sure at some point, we won’t even notice it’s there.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, you’d think that, but after a while it starts showing up in your dreams.

Speaker: Theodore
Dialogue: I think it brings the room together.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, tomorrow who wants to paint the nursery?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ll do it.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Why do you get to do it? I’m the artist.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Just because you’re starving doesn’t make you an artist.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Just because I look sickly doesn’t mean I’m starving.

Speaker: Bernadette(off)
Dialogue: Howard!

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Guys, you heard her, go see what she wants.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I think I’m in labour.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, oh, okay, okay, uh, uh, uh, I can do this. We have a plan. Somebody please tell me the plan.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’ll get the hospital bag.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ll pull the van up.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Meet you outside in 2 minutes.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Team Baby, go.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I love you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I love you, too.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Are we hugging or having a baby? Let’s go.
After a “previously on” sequence…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, man, this is really happening. You doin’ okay?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Here comes another contraction.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Let’s pick it up.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: All right, hold on. I’m gonna drive like we do in India. Get out of my way, you syphilitic dogs.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Stop that, this isn’t India.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Fine. What do one point three billion people know about having babies?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry. I know you were just trying to help. I love you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I love you, too. We’re good.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy? Wake up.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s midnight. Happy birthday.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon. Okay, you can have this back in the morning.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is for you. I was going to wrap it, but touching Scotch tape gives me the heebie-jeebies.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll put in on the list with peaches and felt. What is this?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A functional MRI of my brain. I did Sudoku before they took it so I’d be ripped.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I love it. Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And it’s not just an MRI. The orbitofrontal cortex is lit up because I was thinking of you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We seem to be moving on to the annual coitus portion of your birthday festivities.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Is that okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I didn’t put on my come-hither plaid PJ’s for nothing.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You hate Scotch tape, but you love Scotch plaid. You are a mystery.

Dialogue: Guys, wake up. Bernadette’s having her baby.

Dialogue: Come on, we’re going to the hospital.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I guess, I guess we should stop.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah. I’m afraid so. Childbirth, looming coitus? This is a banner night for female genitals.

Dialogue: I’m the father.

Speaker: Midwife
Dialogue: Okay, Dad, how far apart are the contractions?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No idea. Ask him.

Dialogue: 12 minutes.

Dialogue: 12 minutes? Why are you here?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Aren’t we supposed to get here an hour and a half early?

Dialogue: This is a hospital, not the airport.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m sorry. It’s our first time.

Speaker: Midwife
Dialogue: It’s okay. This little one will be here before you know it. Do we know what we’re having?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, we’re keeping it a surprise.

Speaker: Midwife
Dialogue: Old school. Nice.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not that old school. He knows.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You see, I was at the doctor’s office, the folder was right there, so I took a peek.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And talking like this doesn’t make it less creepy.

Speaker: Midwife
Dialogue: Sweetheart, go home. Come back when the contractions are five minutes apart for an hour.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sorry, that’s ambiguous. Is it five minutes apart starting at the top of the hour, or five minutes apart starting with the first contraction, so essentially, like, 65 minutes?

Speaker: Midwife
Dialogue: I’m just throwing this out there, but home births are very popular these days.

Dialogue: Sheldon, what took you so long?

Dialogue: Wolowitz might hand out cigars. I had to find my bubble gum cigar so I could join in without looking foolish.

Dialogue: Damn, I need my inhaler.

Dialogue: No, I went down the stairs too fast.

Dialogue: Don’t come to the hospital. We’re headed home.

Dialogue: Oh, that was fast. Did she sneeze the baby out?

Dialogue: We showed up too early. We’ll keep you posted.

Dialogue: Okay, well, we’ll talk to you guys later. Bye. She said not to come. It’s gonna be a while.

Dialogue: Well, first deliveries can be slow.

Dialogue: I’m starting to rethink the Flash onesie I bought this kid.

Dialogue: I found it, but it’s empty.

Dialogue: Well, it doesn’t matter. We’re not going to the hospital now.

Dialogue: Are you sure? I’d really like to.

Dialogue: Well, should we, uh, head back up?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, uh, I don’t know. Sheldon, you don’t want to do that, do you?

Dialogue: It doesn’t matter what I want. It’s your birthday, you decide.

Dialogue: Oh, my God. It’s your birthday. Let’s do something fun.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh.

Dialogue: We could go to a bar.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well.

Dialogue: Okay, I can breathe again. Babe, they want to have sex.

Dialogue: Oh, of course. The annual birthday booty spectacular!

Dialogue: That’s a bit childish, isn’t it?

Dialogue: I’m sorry, and what flavour is your bubble gum cigar?

Dialogue: All right, well, you two go have fun.

Dialogue: If we find my backup inhaler, maybe we can get frisky.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, you sexy, wheezy little man.

Dialogue: All right, enough with the camera.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, this is not for me, this is for the baby. Some day she’s gonna want to see this.

Dialogue: I’m sorry, who’s gonna want to see this?

Dialogue: I, I said she, but lot’s of things are she, boats and cars, whales, like thar she blows!

Dialogue: You’re doing great.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Raj.

Dialogue: Well, okay, I’m gonna sign off now. This next part may contain some adult language.

Dialogue: How could you?

Dialogue: We made it this far without knowing, and you’ve ruined it.

Dialogue: Well, you guys have no idea how hard it is to know something like this and not say it.

Dialogue: You told me it was a girl, and I didn’t say it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Raj.

Dialogue: You were supposed to keep that to yourself.

Dialogue: Oh, yeah. I guess it is hard.

Dialogue: So, where were we?

Dialogue: Well, I believe we were kissing like randy teenagers, and your nose was whistling ever so slightly.

Dialogue: I’m sorry.

Dialogue: Very well.

Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Dialogue: I’m not sure. Earlier tonight, things began organically, and now it’s feeling forced, like all the Pirates of the Caribbean sequels.

Dialogue: Okay, that makes sense. I mean, the mood’s a little different now. We, we don’t have to rush.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I know, but just, Leonard and Penny think we’re doing it, and I don’t want to disappoint them.

Dialogue: And the mood continues to change.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, and also, I don’t want to disappoint you. I, you know, come on, it’s your birthday. I can soldier through this.

Dialogue: Hold on. I think I might have a little surprise that might help get things back on track.

Dialogue: Intriguing. Is back on track a hint that it has something to do with trains?

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: Because if it did have to do with trains, and you were gonna give…

Dialogue: Not even a cozy sleeper car on the Orient Express?

Dialogue: Stop talking about trains.

Dialogue: Who’s killing the mood now?

Dialogue: Hang on. I’m counting. It’s okay.

Dialogue: Maybe if we’re quiet, he’ll go away.

Dialogue: You’re gonna have to be quieter than that.

Dialogue: Can I look yet?

Dialogue: One second. All right, you can open your eyes. I thought I’d let Harry Potter make things hotter.

Dialogue: Wowza.

Dialogue: I got a Gryffindor robe for you.

Dialogue: What, a Gryffindor sleeping with a Hufflepuff? How scandalous. You naughty girl, you went to the Wizarding World theme park without me.

Dialogue: I did. Am I in trouble?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, you’re in trouble, you went to Wizarding World without me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wait, what just happened?

Dialogue: You know I’ve been wanting to go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, do you really want to argue with me on my birthday?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, you’re right. I’m sorry.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Ooh. Happy birthday to me.

Speaker: Raj(off)
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Is this about the baby?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No. People just keep kicking me out everywhere I go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Good. Then you’re used to this.

Dialogue: Hey, Bernadette’s water broke.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, everyone to the hospital.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You have got to be kidding me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Just try to relax, we’ll be there any minute. Stuart, stop driving like an old man. Speed it up a little.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’m not an old man, I just can’t see at night.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Here comes another one. Hey, Squinty, the gas pedal’s on the right.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: All right, hang on. If you see any pedestrians, just call ’em out.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Howard and Bernadette’s kid might be born on your birthday. How cool is that?
Yeah, but I thought this
baby was supposed to ruin their sex life, not mine.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This is not how I imagined this day going, I should be with them right now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, it is their child.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I know that. But to be fair, I’ve spent nine months helping Bernadette get ready for this baby, and Howard spent five minutes conceiving it. And I’m being generous.

Dialogue: Five minutes? We must be doing it wrong. It took us hours.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And, and the worst part is that they kicked me out and let Stuart stay.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I understand, but this is a special day for them. Can you just try and let it go?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She’s right. You know, I just learned Amy went to a theme park without me, but I’m not going to ruin her birthday. I’ll wait, and ruin 24 individual hours sprinkled throughout the year. Boop.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Deep breaths, slow breaths.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m so thirsty. Give me more ice chips.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Sorry. I thought these were room ice chips. I’ll go get some more.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh, Stuart, while you’re out there, don’t come back.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, what are we gonna name this kid? Now that we know she’s a girl, it kind of ruins my plan for Wally Wolowitz.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We could name her after your mom.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Debbie? No. She hated that name.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Did she have a middle name?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Melvina.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Let’s keep thinking.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ah. It sucks that she’s not here.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hm. She would’ve been the best grandma.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: She did always have candy in her pocket.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. I was 20 years old before I figured out Tootsie Rolls weren’t naturally warm.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I didn’t know her five minutes and she asked, are you a Milky Way or a Snickers girl?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thank God you answered right, we wouldn’t be here today.

Dialogue: It’s hard to believe Howard’s having a kid.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yeah. Penny, you’re the one who introduced him to Bernie.

Dialogue: How many times do I have to say I’m sorry?

Dialogue: It’s not just Howard and Bernadette. I mean, look how far we’ve all come.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hmm. You two got married.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon and I are living together.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: But if my mom asks, we have bunk beds.

Dialogue: Penny was a struggling actress when we met, and now she’s a successful pharmaceutical rep.

Dialogue: Okay, you don’t have to say struggling every time. You can just say actress.

Dialogue: Howard went to space.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bernadette got her doctorate.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, Howard and I are working with the government on our quantum gyroscope.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We’ve all come a long way. There’s a lot to be proud of.

Dialogue: For God’s sake, just drive in the knife, why don’t you.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: What’s your problem?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, you’re all thinking it, I’m the only one who hasn’t done anything worthwhile.

Dialogue: I was not thinking it. Although, now that you point it out, it is undeniable.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Raj, if it’s any consolation, I’m no better off than I was ten years ago.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, yay, I have a doctorate in astrophysics and I’m every bit as awesome as the pasty-faced owner of a comic book store.

Dialogue: Raj, show some compassion. Those are things that we think but don’t say.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry, Stuart.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hey, I’m in a hospital and I’m not the patient. I’m fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, Bernie, breathe. Remember what you learned in birthing class.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I remember thinking this is stupid, and I was right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Do you want me to get the nurse?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No. If one more person puts their fingers near my uterus, I’m gonna cross my legs and snap ’em off.

Dialogue: I’ve come to peace with my relationship with my parents. That was a big milestone for me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, speaking of personal growth, I recently tried eating Swiss chard. You know, I didn’t swallow it, but Amy said it counted.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hey. Still a loser or did you turn things around while you were gone?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, Raj, honey, you’re being too hard on yourself. When I first met you, you couldn’t even talk to women. I mean, you couldn’t even talk if one was in the room.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, great, now I can say things like I can’t believe you’re breaking up with me, why are you breaking up with me? Yes, I’ll still help you move.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Anyone else want to try?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Uh, yeah, I got something. Raj, not everybody could be a dog owner. Oh, what? Did your doggie break up with you too?

Dialogue: Hey, I bought M&Ms at the vending machine and two bags came out.

Dialogue: I bought the first one, it didn’t fall.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: She’s here, the baby’s here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: How’s Bernadette?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Tired, but great. They’re both great.

Dialogue: Does the baby have a name yet?

Dialogue: We have named her Halley.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: – Oh.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, like Halley’s comet.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Exactly. Also like the comet, Bernadette said she’s not gonna have sex with me for another 75 years.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s not a real thing, he’s just joking.

Dialogue: I’m gonna get back. Thank you for staying up, I can’t wait for Halley to meet her new aunts and uncles and godfather.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You hear that, Stuart? I’ve got a dog and a godchild, you have nothing.

Dialogue: Oh, look at all the babies.

Dialogue: Some will be successful, some may be homeless. It’s fun to think about.
Leonard; I wonder which one’s Halley.

Dialogue: Kind of hard to see the names.

Dialogue: Mm, that one kind of looks like Bernadette.

Dialogue: They all look the same to me.

Dialogue: Guys, she’s my goddaughter, I think I’ll know when I see her. That one.

Dialogue: Well, that was quite a day.

Dialogue: It was. Bernadette had her baby, I made it to Wizarding World, and now it is time to complete your birthday celebration. Hankius pankius.

Dialogue: I was afraid you’d be too tired.

Dialogue: Amy, I just saw a magic train and reported somebody for cutting the line. If that’s not foreplay, I don’t know what is.

Dialogue: Hey, can you help me put some of the food out?

Dialogue: Yeah. Let me finish packing this stuff up. You know how Sheldon is if he sees Christmas stuff lying around after New Year’s.

Dialogue: Yeah, but he doesn’t live here anymore.

Dialogue: Well, he doesn’t live at Walmart, but he still threw a tantrum when he saw Marshmallow Peeps after Easter. And that’s the same man who complains you can’t find Marshmallow Peeps after Easter.

Dialogue: Oh. It’s Bernadette. She says they’re running late. The baby threw up on Howard, and then Howard threw up on Howard.

Dialogue: Well, he didn’t throw up on the baby. That’s a win.

Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi.

Dialogue: Thank you, Sheldon, I’m feeling better now.

Dialogue: and this wine is why.

Dialogue: Well, now be careful, these are hot. i could explain the thermodynamics of why the cheese seems hotter than the crust, but instead I’m gonna keep it to myself.

Dialogue: Fine, go ahead.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy is free. She had a harp lesson on Saturday but it got cancelled. Boy, when you take an interest in people, you really uncork a geyser of nonsense.

Speaker: Bernadette (on phone)
Dialogue: Okay. Thanks, daddy. He said the only way to really fix an old floor like that is to tear it up and replace the whole thing.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That sounds expensive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hang on. No offence to her father, but he’s not an MIT trained engineer. Thinking and building is what you do.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: MIT’s motto is mind and hand, which just so happens was also my motto as a lonely teenager.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh come on, we just need to be more creative. What if you didn’t step on the floor at all? Like, what if you swung on a rope from the ceiling?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, um, okay, what if you rig up a pulley system and move yourself across the room in a harness?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I have one. What if you got a giant slingshot and flung yourself into the wall?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Is that supposed to be funny?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hold on. Yeah, that’s funny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, we’re heading out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll call you when we get to the hotel.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And if they have any of those tiny bottles of shampoo?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I will bring them home so you can show me how Godzilla takes a shower.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Have fun.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thanks. Are you ready?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Bye, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know what? I feel uncomfortable engaging in a public display of affection while their relationship is strained.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Go ahead, it’s fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Let’s go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll miss you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I’ll miss you too.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll miss you more.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if x equals the amount that you’ll miss me, then I’ll miss you x plus one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: If you miss me x plus one, I’ll miss you open paren x plus one, close paren to the second…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Here. You’re sad, so I made you tea.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And it’s just the way you like it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Earl grey?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Honey?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Unsweetened almond…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Good Lord, I made you tea, just drink it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sorry, thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, what can we do to cheer you up?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I really don’t know.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You want to play Jenga? Or, uh, Ticket to Ride? Hearthstone? What would you be the happiest losing at?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t want to play a game, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wow, and I remember when you loved playing games with me. Maybe Penny isn’t the only relationship you’re phoning in.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Its not that I’d stopped trying, its just how relationships progress. They start with infatuation, but over time mellow into something more comfortable.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm. Yeah, you’re right. It’s like when I first encountered the Pythagorean theorem. You know, I was blown away that the square of the hypotenuse was the sum of the squares of the opposite sides. But now I’m just like, eh.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, this grid represents the room. All we need to do is plot out where each squeak is, and we can find a quiet path to the crib.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It looks like a map from Dungeons and Dragons.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Mm. Except the creature in the crib is a level-nine poop monster.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, uh, you check for squeaks, and I will mark them down.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, space A3, here we go. It’s squeaking. Mark it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s nice to think that you grew up in this room and now your daughter’s going to as well.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Mm. I hope she has the same amount of sex in it I did. None. Next square.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why do you bounce with your hands in the air like that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s a tradition of my people.(Singing)If I were a rich man, ya ba dibba dibba dibba dibba dibba dibba dum.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Material Girl needs ot be retired, that is your karaoke song.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Would you like to play a driving game I invented?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is it about the failing state of my relationship with Penny?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Never mind. You know, Penny went to this spa to be away from you. Are you sure you should be going there?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t want to wait two days for us to work this out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well. You got married spur of the moment, I don’t see why your divorce should be any different.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I would pull this car over and kick you out, but If Penny dumps me, you’re all I got.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: When was the last time you got a massage?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon walked on my back two weeks ago, but that was just ’cause there was a spider on his pillow and he was trying to get away.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard stood on me once, too, but he was just trying to see the Rose Parade.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know the protocol, are you gonna be naked for your massage?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, yeah.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hmm. Then this is probably too many clothes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I came here to apologize.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Leonard, I really appreciate that, but I need a little time to myself.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. I don’t get it, you said make an effort, here I am making an effort.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello, Amy. It’s nice to see you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Nice to see you, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And that’s how you make effort look effortless.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right. Can you please just go and we’ll talk about this tomorrow?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t understand what you want.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m trying to figure it out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know what? If you’d like, I could whip up a quick relationship agreement. Well, I’m at a spa, I might as well do something relaxing.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, why don’t we give them some privacy?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well. Hey, later we’ll check out the minibar, I’ll show you how Godzilla gets drunk.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So, what we did was map out the entire room to identify every squeak. Watch. It’s easy,
once you get the hang of it. Step. Step. Hop onto Ottoman.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t do that in socks, I almost broke my neck.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Then simply sit, spin, stand, stretch, maybe in looser pants, then step, grab, tiny pivot, pull, and you’re there. Easy peasy, mac and… you get the idea.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You actually expect me to do this while holding a baby in the dark.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hold on, I don’t think she was impressed.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Bigger problems, I felt something pop.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s a cucumber in my water.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do they know it’s there? I mean, should I tell somebody?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s there on purpose. It’s refreshing.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Interesting. The world’s most boring liquid and the world’s most boring vegetable, but you put ’em together and bleugh.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh good, you’re here. Are you still fighting? If you get divorced, do I get two Christmas’s?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’re not getting divorced.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Listen, we realized, that, uh, we’re facing some new challenges as a married couple.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. And there are a few things we need to stay on top of. So we thought it would useful, and I can’t believe I’m about to say this, um.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Would you please help us make a relationship agreement? But one that’s tailored to us, okay, we don’t need a bathroom schedule.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Although a rule about him texting me from in there might help with the romance.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What do you say?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I get to write a contract? I say, let’s get this party of the first part started.

Speaker: Penny(after Amy laughs)
Dialogue: Do you really think that’s funny?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s in our agreement. I have to laugh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If you find this draft acceptable, then I believe your new relationship agreement is ready to be signed.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Article 8, subsection B, Leonard will restrict videogaming in underpants to hours Penny is not home. This includes boxers, briefs, thongs, G-strings or anything else that calls attention to his pasty little thighs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Does it really need to say that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I did this for free, let me get a little something.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Article 10, subsection C, if questioned Penny may not say that everything is fine if it isn’t. Other unacceptable responses include, it’s nothing, don’t worry about it, and, I said it’s nothing don’t worry about it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I think this all looks good.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Me, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh well, great then, here, you sign here, date here, and Penny, if you could initial here to indicate that you’re accepting Leonard in as is condition.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I remember signing our first relationship agreement.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Mm. You seem to be forgetting the no nostalgia clause.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Right, right. Got it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s going on with that woman you’re dating?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I broke up with her.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She said she didn’t want to see me any more and I found that insulting.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I thought things were going well. What happened?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t know, she didn’t even give me a reason.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s not a problem, we can figure this out. What are the reasons women reject Raj?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can we not play this game?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Doesn’t like games. That’s one.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ignore him. Yeah, sorry about the breakup.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s okay, I’m fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course you’re fine. Not every member of a species finds a mate. Sir Isaac Newton died a virgin, look at the contributions he made.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m not a virgin, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So now you think you’re better than Isaac Newton? Oh, no wonder women don’t like you.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re not being very nice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? He said he was fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sometimes people say things they don’t mean.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that’s a paradox. I mean if you meant what you just said, then that means you may not have meant what you just said.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Careful, I saw this on Star Trek. Smoke’s gonna come out of his ears soon. Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, boys. How’s it going?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I thought we were having a nice conversation, but it turns out I was being offensive.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So, normal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, what did you do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We were discussing Raj’s recent breakup and apparently, I was insensitive to him.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s okay, I’m fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Don’t fall for it. He’ll get you to compare him to a dead virgin, and suddenly you’re the bad guy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sheldon, when I said I was fine, I meant I didn’t want to talk about it any more.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then why didn’t you say that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Because that’s not what people do.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I would prefer if people told me exactly what is on their mind.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. No, you don’t, you really don’t. I actually can’t say don’t enough.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, it certainly would be easier. You have no idea what it’s like to struggle with recognizing emotional cues.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sure it’s extremely frustrating.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And also a little sad.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, now you’re just showing off.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You know, I just read that a team at MIT. developed a device that helps people read human emotions.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And you think we can get those guys to reprogram Sheldon? Cool.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s supposed to be accurate, like, 85% of the time.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, I find that hard to believe.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That a bunch of awkward scientists with no social skills would invent a machine to do it for them?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I take it back. I believe it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You if it’s at MIT, I can make some calls. Maybe we can get Sheldon a prototype.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A machine that reads emotions is intriguing. It could help me be a more considerate friend.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Wouldn’t that be nice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It could also help me identify my enemies, discover their fears and then I could use those fears to destroy them.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I like the first one.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Raj
