Dialogue: Now that Sheldon’s across the hall, have you decided what you’re doing with his old room?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I was thinking maybe a library or a gaming room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You could make it a train room.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t like trains. You like trains.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know, and Amy says I can’t have a train room.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, I just heard from the guys at MIT about that emotion reader. They’re sending a prototype for you to beta test.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wonderful. Although I’m not sure how I feel about being used as a guinea pig.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, when you get the machine, you can find out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe I could use it to understand why women keep dumping me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, you don’t need a machine for that, just send a survey card to all your ex-girlfriends and tell them if they fill it out they might win a prize.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s actually not a bad idea. Maybe I could even get them all together, sort of like a, a focus group, to find out what’s wrong with me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, Raj, that’s a terrible idea.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, I was joking.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really? Uh, little tip: jokes are often better when you end them with wocka wocka or ha-cha-cha.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, great news. The TV I want will fit in the gaming room, and if I leave the curtains open, I can watch it from work.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, can you hold off redoing the room? My brother’s coming out here in a few weeks.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. Yeah. Okay, sure. What’s going on with your brother?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: My dad asked if I can get him a job interview at my work.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Huh. Is that a good idea? I mean, you think they’ll consider someone who was in prison for selling drugs?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I sell pharmaceuticals. That’s just a really hard to spell word for drugs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I’m sure he’ll appreciate carrying his samples in a briefcase instead of his colon. How long do you think he’ll stay?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I, I’m not sure. Maybe a few days. Unless he gets the job, then who knows?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hmm. Who knows? That’s exciting. I’ll get to wake up every morning and see if he’s still here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You don’t have a problem with this, do you?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Of course not. I mean, he’s your brother.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Thank you, you’re the best. Mm.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Remember that when the new TV falls off the wall and crushes us both.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: This thing’s pretty cool. It interprets emotions using a wireless signal to analyse subtle changes in breathing and heart rate.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s amazing a machine can do that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. Now, when the robots rise up, they’ll know that I’ve been rooting for them the whole time.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The display is synced to your phone. Give it a try.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: All right. Now, I’m gonna look at some pictures to prompt an emotional response, and we’ll see if the machine can identify them accurately.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, remember, it can only detect happy, sad, angry and excited. Not other things you’re feeling, like, what have I done with my life?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, I’m looking at the first picture.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You are happy?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yes. I’m looking at puppi

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Aw. Somebody’s ignoring their tiny needle teeth, but all right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Try another one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay. What does it say I’m feeling?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sad.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yes. I’m looking at a picture of my grandma.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that makes sense, ’cause she’s gone and you miss her.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And you’re worried that turkey neck is in your future. What, now, see, now it says you’re mad. Make up your mind.

Speaker: Raj(on phone)
Dialogue: Okay, Emily. Yeah, sounds great. See you then.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is that Emily your ex-girlfriend?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah. I’m getting all my exes together in order to discuss why they broke up with me and how I can be a better boyfriend.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, God. You went through with that? What is wrong with you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We are going to find out.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why would you do that, Raj?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I want information in order to improve myself.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re not gonna get information, you’re just gonna get criticism that hurts your feelings.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t worry, I’m a grown man. I have a thick skin.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You’re so stupid.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, would you take a look at my brother’s résumé? I’m trying to help him clean it up a little.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, sure. He really worked with the Drug Enforcement Agency?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He didn’t know it till he was cuffed, but yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, Leonard, if you’re happy and you know it, no need to clap your hands, because I have an emotion detector.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How’s it working out?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Surprisingly well.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s great, I’m happy for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, wait, uh, hold on. Oh, what, you are. Aren’t you sweet?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s that? Are you working on your resume?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, it’s my brother’s. I’m trying to help him get a job out here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, ooh! And that makes Leonard angry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, it doesn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What, Leonard, please. I know an angry face when I see it. It’s this red frowny guy on my phone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? Are you really upset about Randall coming?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I said no.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s like you’re twins.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Leonard, if you’re mad about this, just tell me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine. You invited your drug dealer brother to stay with us for God knows how long and didn’t bother to ask me first.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He’s my brother. I didn’t think I needed your permission.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, hey. Now she’s angry, too. This thing works like gangbusters.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m not saying you have to ask my permission, but you could have talked to me about it before you said it was okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Like you talked to me about your gaming room?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Our gaming room. I was gonna put a scented candle in it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s still mad.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Stop enjoying their fight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You first.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: If you were this upset, why didn’t you say so when I told you?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Because I didn’t want to sound like a jerk.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, you sound like one now. I don’t see the big deal if my brother comes and stays for a while.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If you get him a job, he’s gonna live here forever!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He would get his own place.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Has he ever had his own place?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Did it have a metal toilet next to the bed?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It still counts. You know, how is this any different from you making me live with Sheldon?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, I shared my Honey Nut Cheerios with you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You gave me a bill at the end of every month.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Stay out of this. You and your stupid machine started this fight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You are lucky that this feelings machine doesn’t have feelings.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon, let’s go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gladly. Can we storm out?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I think it loses its impact if we’re chatting about it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. I’ll just give them the finger.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, first off, I want to thank you all so much for coming. Howard is here to interpret for Emily, and to take notes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, he doesn’t think it’s stupid.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, heads up, both of you are named Emily, so we’ll call you red-headed Emily, and you, red-headed Emily, Junior.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, you went out with him. I didn’t.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, uh, let’s get things started. Um, why don’t we go around the room, say your name, and why you broke up with me. Want to kick it off?

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Oh, okay. Um, I’m Lucy, and I broke up with Raj because I have severe social anxiety, and he kept trying to force me into uncomfortable situations.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Like this one?

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I did do that. I can be insensitive to other people’s boundaries. Howard, would you write that down?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Schmuck. Got it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, next?

Speaker: Claire
Dialogue: Okay. Um, I’m Claire. And I guess I broke up with you because you were just really needy. Also, you were incredibly vain, like, all the time you spent shaping your eyebrows.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, new rule, everybody only gets one. Uh, next?

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: Ooh, I’m not sure I’m comfortable sharing details about our relationship in front of Howard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh. He’s here to support me, so anything you have to say you can say in front of him.

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: Okay. Well, whenever you and I were in bed…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Howard, get out.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Not a chance. So, you were telling us how Raj was terrible in bed.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, dinner’s ready. I made beef loaf, because I know you’re uncomfortable with the non-specificity of meat loaf. Sheldon? Hey, are you okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s going on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I wish I never tried that device. And I know I said the same thing after the massage chair, but this time I mean it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sorry Leonard and Penny hurt your feelings.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s more than that. It’s me. I always knew I had trouble recognizing other people’s emotions, but that machine just made it so real.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, everybody has things that they need help with. Like me, I can’t see without my glasses. And right now you’re just a, a cute, pink smudge wearing a childish green smudge.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I thought I was getting better at it, but clearly I’m not.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yes, you are. There have definitely been days when I was sad and you could tell.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, but that’s shooting fish in a barrel. You’re kind of a sad sack. I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have said that. I’m just upset.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, see, right there, you knew you hurt my feelings. And I’m proud of you, for reasons I’m sure have something to do with my father. And if you don’t like that machine, get rid of it. Because I love you exactly the way you are.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I feel the same way about you. Now, put your glasses back on. You look weird.

Speaker: Howard(translating for other Emily)
Dialogue: I thought you were great, but, oh, my God, you were so dominated by your parents.

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, that used to drive me nuts. He’s kind of a mama’s boy.

Speaker: Claire
Dialogue: Kind of?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, that’s enough. Write down loving son.

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Can I just say something? Going out with Raj was one of the best things that ever happened to me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, I’ll take you back.

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Let me finish. It’s like I needed to go through that experience to know what exactly I don’t want in a man.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, that’s hard to hear, but I’ll still take you back.

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: You know, the same thing happened to me. After I broke up with Raj, I met Gary, who’s just amazing.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sorry, is that Gary with one R or two?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Would you stop writing? Wait, so, did all of you go on to better relationships after me?

Speaker: Lucy
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: Without question.

Speaker: Claire
Dialogue: Little before, actually.

Speaker: Howard(responding to other Emily)
Dialogue: Oh, wow. Don’t let him get away.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What did she say?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh, basically, she traded you for Bruce Wayne.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, maybe we should just end this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait, hang on. I just want to point out to everyone here, this is a man who is going to great lengths to better himself. Even at the risk of being humiliated. And I, for one, think that’s very brave.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, Howard.

Speaker: Emily
Dialogue: Honestly, I’m surprised you two didn’t wind up together.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, like you gals, I had to suffer through him to find Bernadette.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We owe you an apology.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, it’s fine. You needed a suitcase, I wasn’t home, you borrowed a suitcase.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That was six years ago. I’m talking about tonight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Well, I thought we were going in order.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, we got really angry at each other, and you just got caught in the middle of it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And, sorry about the suitcase.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, well, you should be. Your socks were still in it. I had to throw it away. Anyway, I, uh, trust that you’ve resolved your conflict.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes, we’re fine.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Mm, Penny’s gonna call her dad and tell him it’s not a good time for Randall to visit.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hopefully, he won’t be too upset.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, you’re his little girl, he can’t stay mad at you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: He won’t be mad at me. I mean, you’re the one who doesn’t want my brother to come, so…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So you’re gonna throw me under the bus?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’m gonna throw you so hard, I might actually win a stuffed animal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, guys, it sounds like you’re getting angry again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s because we are.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I don’t need an emotion machine. I am one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thanks, ladies, this was fun. Let’s not wait so long for another bizarre, awkward night.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, that was a waste of time. I’m such an idiot.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Don’t beat yourself up. That’s what I’m here for.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe I won’t settle down. Maybe I’ll just play the field.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, the field was just here. The field said no.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dude, come on.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, I’ll tell you what. I’ll make you a deal. 30 years from now, if you’re still single and things don’t work out with me and Bernadette, you and I can give it a go.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I appreciate the offer, but if things don’t work out with you two, I’m swooping in on her like a vulture.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Too late. Stuart called dibs.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But theoretically, if you and I were in a gay relationship, how would we tell people? Like, print up announcements?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know. What difference does it make?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I want to make sure we get invited to all the parades.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Those do look fun.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah. Well, if you want to march in a fishnet crop top, you better lay off that dip.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you didn’t want me to eat it, why’d you put it out?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It was for the girls. They broke up with me, I don’t care if they get fat.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m not gonna get fat.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, you want to bet? You never exercise.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Fine. Look, I’ll exercise right now. One, two. These are crunches, by the way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Very mature. Keep eating like that, you’re gonna have a heart attack.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay. How about if I eat like this?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You’re such a child.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, is that any way to talk to your future husband?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, I was being hypothetical, okay? I would never marry you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Please. When you see the ring I pick out, you’re gonna melt.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, right. Wait, is it rose gold? Actually, don’t tell me, I want to be surprised.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, did you wind up sending that machine back?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I did. You know, I’m not even sure how accurate it was. I took it to the train store, it said everyone was sad.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I finally got Halley to sleep.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, I just read a study that suggests new mothers are better at sensing emotions for up to two years.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s true. Pregnancy causes physiological changes in the brain that result in increased empathy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, all we need to do is get Sheldon knocked up.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We can’t. He was already fixed when I found him at the shelter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, uh, Bernadette, let’s test this theory. What do you think I’m feeling right now?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Let’s see. You’re better than us, a little bit sorry for us, but mostly glad you don’t have to be us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Keep filling this one with babies. She’s good.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, I’m zeroing out the electro-osmotic flow rate in the micro-fluidic channel.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Nicely done, Howard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, my wife is four-foot-ten and sexually satisfied, so clearly I know my way around tiny things.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Good for you, on the cutting edge of new technology and still making inappropriate comments about the mother of your child.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Those are just the things I say out loud.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, we need to stop immediately.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m looking at the math, and I think we can make the device between eight and ten percent smaller.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s great, but the Air Force approved the specs. We’re good to go.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. It doesn’t need to be smaller.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Shame on you. Where would we be if poodle breeders had that attitude? I’ll tell you. We would have the standard and the miniature poodle, but no toy or teacup. Which by the way, is not an officially recognized breed, but that’s just poodle politics.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Can we please stop talking about poodles?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. Candy bars. Now, do you enjoy a fun size? I know you do.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sheldon, we don’t need to make this smaller, and your work is done. Go home.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I don’t want to go home.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Fine, go for a little walk.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Then what?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just keep walking.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: At least it’s quiet when he takes bathroom breaks.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know. That’s why I keep refilling his water when he’s not looking.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You’re kidding.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t care if we’re in a drought, it’s worth it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, I do have a way to get him out of our hair. I’ve been holding onto this for a few years, but maybe now’s the time.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We can just lock the door, you don’t have to kill him.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You can’t kill him, he’ll just respawn at the last save point.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that was my sixth trip to the bathroom. As long as that’s not a urinary tract infection, that’s a personal best.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, uh, buddy, I got you a little present.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Go ahead, open it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Congratulations. The bearer of this certificate is entitled to the ultimate train experience at The Nevada Northern Railway. You are at the throttle. You are the engineer. You are running the locomotive. This doesn’t happen very often, but here comes a hug. Oh, dear, I have to tinkle again.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. Where were we?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: For Howie’s occupation, should I include that he was an astronaut?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, he mentioned it in his mother’s eulogy, so why not?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t believe you have to fill out a preschool application for an infant.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, the one at Caltech has a crazy wait list. I warned you, a lot of people apply when they’re still pregnant.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, I didn’t. I also skipped a birthing class to see Zootopia so back off.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Whoa. Just trying to help.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry. Howie’s back at work and there’s just so much going on.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Is there anything we can do?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sure. Open up a college fund, shop for life insurance, and in the laundry room, there’s a mountain of dirty laundry. Wash it or burn in, your choice. Ugh, be right back.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, no. I will take care of it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: While I’m gone, you can think about how mean you were to me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, you know what you need? A night away from all of this. You know, where you can just kind of relax and, I’m just gonna turn this off. Much better. Seriously, let’s plan a night, you know, give you a break. We could go dancing.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That sounds really nice.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. All this week, the Early Music Society of Pasadena is doing a joint concert with the San Gabriel Renaissance Choir.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, that’s the one to beat.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Good luck. People have been saying that for 600 years.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, you’re home early.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’ll never believe it. Leonard gave me the most incredible gift, a trip to a historic railway, and I get to operate an actual locomotive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wow. He finally used it. What’d you do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No idea. All I know is I’m gonna be working on the railroad all the livelong day.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I’m really happy for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, no. It’s not just me. No. The railway is four hours from the nearest airport, and guess who gets to drive me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I give up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No. I really give up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, oh. And guess where we get to sleep? Our choice of a turn-of-the-century railway bunkhouse or a working caboose. Now, the problem with a caboose is there’s no bathroom, but the problem with the bunkhouse is it’s not a caboose. On the first day, I get to drive a steam engine. Oh, and the second day, a diesel engine. Oh, and if I volunteer to do track maintenance and paperwork, they’ll let me stay as long as I want. So you might want to pack enough clothes for the rest of our lives.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Can I pee now?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, get this. I get to take a test based on a 125-page manual. I get to learn things like hand signals. Ooh. There’s forward, uh, reverse, set the brakes. Are you done yet? You’re missing

some great stuff out here. Oh, this is good. There are dozens of railroad crossings you have to blow the whistle for. But that is the figurative you, not the literal you. I’ll be blowing the whistle. Amy, get up. It’s time to go to work.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This train thing worked out better than I thought. He’s home studying the engineer’s manual.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s so peaceful without him here. Can I ask you how much that cost?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Four thousand dollars, worth every penny.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Colonel Williams. Sir.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: Just wanted to see how the guidance system’s coming along.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Great. We found a cooling solution that allowed us to get the size of the prototype down to the target specs.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: As a cooling solution, it’s pretty cool.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: Don’t do that. What’s this?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, nothing. Just some math we don’t need.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: This is a different approach. Are you trying to get the guidance system even smaller?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s just a theory. Uh, it’s not even worked out.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: Oh. I want this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: But we’ve already met the agreed upon specs. Going smaller would require weeks’ worth of new computations.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: So get the kid with the two shirts to do it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sir, uh, if I may, uh, we’ve put a lot of thought and effort into this current prototype. It’s a really elegant solution, and most importantly, it works.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: Yeah, I want this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, but that’s just a theory. It’s not even a complete thought.

Speaker: Col Williams
Dialogue: You both make excellent points, and thank you for presenting it so articulately. Make this.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The kid with the two shirts screwed us again.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right. You guys ready to get crazy?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, the bra under here ain’t beige.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay. You ladies have fun tonight.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Don’t worry about Halley. Uncle Stuart’s on the job.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Under the careful supervision of her godfather.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: My apologies. I didn’t mean to offend you, Don Corleone.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Like I said, you ladies have fun.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We will. Got my dancing shoes, got my breast pump. Let’s party.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, if you pump at the bar, I promise we’ll get free drinks.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Call if there’s any problems.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. She’s busy. You call Howard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Call me. Don’t call Howard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I would never call Howard.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Okay, instead of arguing all night, let’s just split up the baby chores.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, great. Um, I’ll put food in her top half, you deal with whatever comes out the bottom.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I can’t believe we have to ask Sheldon to come back and help us.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, boo-hoo. I spent four grand on a gift that only got rid of him for an afternoon. What is that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know, but if he yells It’s alive, we run.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, hey. If you knocked, I couldn’t hear you. I’m welding this locomotive engine. And if you didn’t knock, how about some manners?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How’d you even get that up the stairs?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I said to myself, I think I can, I think I can. And then I couldn’t, so I paid two men who promised not to come rob us later.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, look, Sheldon, the Colonel wants us to make the guidance system smaller, and we can’t do it without you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Interesting. Well, so I was right.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Open a window. It’s about to get smug in here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I would love to help you, but since I discovered the satisfaction of working with my hands on a train engine, I don’t think I can go back to theory. I’m an engineer now. And, hey, just to be clear, a train engineer. Not that goofy kind you are.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you can still go on the trip in a few weeks. Just help us out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sorry. I need to work on this engine so when I get to the train yard I won’t look foolish.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He’s worried about looking foolish. That’s a heapin’ helping of irony right there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, you know you’re not leaving physics. Why are you doing this?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, in the world of theoretical physics, you never finish. So much is unprovable. But when I was studying that railway guide, it was so tangible and so satisfying that something just clicked. Then it clacked. Then it clicked, then it clacked, click-clack clickety-clack, and here we are. Whoo-whoo.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, did you hear anything back from the Caltech preschool?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not yet, but we’re gonna apply to a bunch of others just to keep our options open.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, stop that. No more preschool talk. Tonight is about having fun.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Nothing says fun like being scolded.

Speaker: Bernadette(phone rings)
Dialogue: Oh, it’s Raj. Everything okay?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t worry. Everything’s fine.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hang up, we don’t need help.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t need your help deciding when we need help!

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Raj, what’s going on?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, so, I was just warming up some milk for Halley, and I thought it smelled a little funky, so I checked the date that you wrote on the bottle, and it says Flerbsday.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: It says Tuesday.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How is that a T?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m sure it’s fine, but if you’re worried, there’s extra milk in the freezer.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, yes, I will err on the side of caution and defrost a fresh batch.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: You’re wasting perfectly good milk.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Fine, you drink it.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: It’s just milk.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Stuart, don’t you drink my milk.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, give. Can you guys handle this or not?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, of course we can. Uh, you girls have a good time. She said I was in charge.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hmm. So we just throw this away?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What else are you gonna do with it? Put it in your coffee?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, I don’t take it black.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay. This is everything he had on the board. I’m sure we can figure the rest out.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All right. Hmm. Feel free to jump in. Hmm is all I got.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, we can get this. Is there any chance it’s upside-down?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe we can find another theoretical physicist to help us.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s classified. If we tell anyone, we’d get in trouble.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, I came up with that and hmm. You haven’t pitched anything.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just keep thinking. I got it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You really figured it out?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, but when we show this nonsense to Sheldon, it will make him crazy, and he’ll have to fix it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, you’re a genius.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, I know. That’s not even a math symbol. That’s just Charlie Brown’s hair.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sorry, guys. This club was so great, how could they turn it into a bookstore? I thought we got rid of all those.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Renaissance Choir’s looking pretty good right now, huh?

Speaker: Bernadette(on phone)
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Nothing to worry about. She’s just been crying for a little while, and I was wondering if you had any tricks to get her to sleep.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: She was sleeping just fine till you took a selfie with her.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She was blowing a spit bubble. It was adorable.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You guys got this? Do you need me to come home?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Wait. She’s settling down.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, okay, false alarm. Little parenting tip, sleeping babies hate flash photography.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is everything okay?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah. I may have just left my infant daughter with Patrick and SpongeBob.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, there’s another dance club nearby. I mean, I don’t know how you feel about Latin music, but according to their horas of operación, they’re open.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Maybe we should just call it a night.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You sure? They’re open till dos.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, we’re all dressed up. Why go home?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I’m just not really in the mood anymore.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What’s going on with you?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know. This is all starting to feel like a sad attempt to recapture our youth.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m not sad. I just wanted to get drunk and not wear sweatpants.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not sad. I mean, hello.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, maybe I’m the one who’s sad.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What are you sad about?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Maybe the fact that you went and had a baby.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re upset I had a baby?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, of course not. I just, I didn’t think it would make me have all these feelings.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What feelings?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Pressure. I mean, she’s looking at preschools, she has a minivan, she has a 401K. Before she talked about it, I just thought that was a race.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You think that stuff is fun? Being a parent is terrifying. I’m constantly worried, I’m always tired, and in a few minutes I’m gonna milk myself in a bookstore parking lot.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I get that, okay? It’s just, Leonard and I have been married for two years, and we’re no further along than when we were dating.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Come on. You’ve got so much to feel good about. You’ve got a great job now.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I guess I am making decent money.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You make more than I do.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You may not have a house yet, but your apartment’s great.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s bigger than mine.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And Leonard loves you so much, he married you twice.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not even engaged once. I don’t even know if Sheldon thinks about marriage. I’m not getting any younger. Honestly, I kind of thought by now, we might have had some sort of…

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Careful. The sound of crying can make me lactate.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sorry. I can’t help it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s gonna make me cry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And there they go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ew.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, Sheldon, turns out we didn’t need you after all.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s right. We figured it out all by ourselves. Wasn’t even that hard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, good for you guys. Look, I have a grease smudge on my hand, and I’m okay with it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aren’t you gonna look at the board to see how right we are?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, thanks. I’m busy trying to fix this fuel pump.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s a manifold.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Well, I guess it’s fixed.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just look at the board.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s wrong.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, no, what should we have done differently?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, first of all, you can’t use relativistic and non-relativistic vectors in the same equation.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Told ya. Can you fix it for us?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, but this is the last time. Nice try, blockheads.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon. You can’t turn your back on physics, and besides, you have no idea what you’re doing with this stuff.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: But if you really want to learn the mechanical side, I can teach you anything you want to know.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And instead of standing around watching, you can help us build your smaller guidance system.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And with all these new skills, you’d be able to fix any model train. You’d be the king of the train store.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me. I have a girlfriend. I’m already king of the train store.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, what do you say?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, what choice do I have? You need me. I’m like the crankshaft of this team.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s a turbo.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, whatever it is, it looks heavy. I’m gonna need you two to get it downstairs before Amy comes home.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I apologize that it’s so warm in here.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It is warm in here.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ve worked up a bit of a sweat.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Me, too.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: May I borrow your water?

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Sheldon(voice)
Dialogue: The light’s green.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Amy(now in her car)
Dialogue: Sorry.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: GPS says we’ll be at the railway in three hours.

Scene: The cab of a steam locomotive.
Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can get us there in two.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Go. Come on, Raj.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You can do this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s no way.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What is happening?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: This is an Euler’s Disk. It’s a physics toy that demonstrates angular momentum, potential energy, and kinetic energy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Aw, look at you watching sports.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We’re betting to see if Koothrappali can hold his breath longer than the disk can spin.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Its weight and smoothness, along with the slight concavity of the mirror, means it can spin for a long time.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: But Raj is from India, which means he’s no slouch at holding his breath.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I want in. Ten bucks says I’ll lose interest before that thing stops spinning.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon, I found a great restaurant for date night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Kind of busy right now.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, an Euler’s Disk, fun.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, we’re seeing if Raj can hold his breath longer than it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. Immature.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How ya doing?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s not gonna make it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes, he is.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, deep-sea divers holding their breath for several minutes have shown elevated markers of a protein that can signal brain damage.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, see, what’s happening here signals brain damage. My God, how long does this thing spin for?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ha, you’re interested. You’re out ten bucks.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s slowing down.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Dig deep, like when we bet you couldn’t fit into Howard’s pants.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He’s not gonna make it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yes, he is.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, Raj, it’s like your favourite movie, you’re just Waiting to Exhale. Yeah, I knew you could do it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And j, and just so you know, my favourite movie is Princess Bride.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli(on skype)
Dialogue: Hello, Rajesh. How are things by you?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Good, good. Uh, listen, I just wanted to let you know when you get my credit card bill, it might be a little high this month.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Well, you’re a grown man with a steady job. Why wouldn’t you spend all your father’s money?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, Daddy, you’re so rich and funny.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Yeah. So what else is going on with your life?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, well, I was dating a woman at the university, but we broke up.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: I’m sorry to hear that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I know you are. That’s why you just bought me a new iPad. And before you start, I am not interested in you arranging a marriage for me.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Oh, I gave up on that a long time ago.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You did?

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: It’s too much work. You’re an adult who can’t get by without an allowance from his parents. Women don’t want that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What are you saying, that you’re giving up on me? What kind of father gives up on his son?

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: I have six children, five of whom are married and self-sufficient. I don’t think I’m the problem.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t believe what I’m hearing. This is deeply hurtful.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: You’re also too sensitive. Women don’t want that either.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: The food here’s supposed to be great. Don’t fill up on chips.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I won’t. I only eat equilateral triangles. Isosceles, isosceles, oh, scalene. You didn’t see that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, look. It’s Bert, at the bar. We should go say hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Because that’s what you do when you see someone you know in a public place.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have multiple restraining orders that say otherwise.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, there’s a difference between greeting a friend and following a celebrity into a bathroom.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If the judge couldn’t explain it to me, I don’t see how you will.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi, Bert.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Oh, hey, guys. What brings you here?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, we’re having date night.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Nice. I’m meeting someone, too.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, really. Anybody we know?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: I doubt it. I met her on G-Harmony. That’s a Web site for geologists to find love.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s a real thing?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Yeah. Their slogan is we’re all about dating and not the carbon-14 kind.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, have a lovely evening.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Thanks. You, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If you think that’s more fun than talking to Zachary Quinto through a stall door, you’re crazy.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, we could’ve come to you guys. You didn’t have to bring the baby here.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, it’s okay. It’s good to get out of the house.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And the car ride puts her to sleep.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aw, that used to work with Sheldon.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, until someone left him in the drugstore parking lot and he freaked out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who forgot to crack the window?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, someone’s been shopping at Gucci.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, I saw something for Halley and I couldn’t resist.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s so sweet of you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s a crushed velvet baby cape.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, no, now we have two.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: That must’ve been expensive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, it was. But it’s my father’s money and I’m mad at him.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What’s going on with your dad?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And if you really want to hurt him, I look great in Chanel.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It turns out he doesn’t care if I’m married or if I’m single. He’s basically given up on me.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sure that’s not true.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It is. He stopped trying to find Indian girls for me to marry.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: But all you did was complain when he did that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, Leonard, he’s hurting. Let him feel how he feels.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, Penny.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Shoes, I’m a seven-and-a-half, boots, I’m an eight.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: MSN Search, AltaVista, and Ask Jeeves. You?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sorry, I don’t have a list of defunct search engines that I miss.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Hey. Looks like I got stood up, so I’m gonna head out.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, no. Are you sure you don’t want to give her a few more minutes?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Nah, G-Harmony recommends after two hours, it’s time to cut bait.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m so sorry.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bert, I insist that you join us.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: You really wouldn’t mind?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not at all. Amy?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Fine with me.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Thanks. I’ll go grab a chair.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, that was so sweet of you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I could deduce by his facial expression and body language that he was sad.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So the part where he got stood up didn’t clue you in?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You want me to look at him and listen to him?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My father thinks the reason I can’t make a relationship work is because I’m spoiled.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, is he waiting for someone to disagree?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Just because he helps me out doesn’t automatically mean that I’m spoiled.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, how much exactly does he pay for?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, I’ll tell you, but please don’t judge me. He pays for my car, my rent, and my credit cards.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m trying, but I’m judging.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe your dad’s right.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, women do like a man that can support himself.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But Bernadette makes more money than Howard. She basically supports him.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, maybe your dad’s right.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Good question. Let’s see. Infoseek, WebCrawler, oh, HotBot.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, literally any other topic.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: All right. How did you guys meet?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Actually, we met online.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Our-our first date was at a coffee shop.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Although, unlike your date, she actually showed up. Oh, he looks sad again.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Well, I really envy your relationship. Other than you two only having sex once a year, you’re the perfect couple.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You-you know about that?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Uh, yeah, everyone at the university does.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Were you aware of this?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No. No, I only told Leonard, Howard, Raj, Kripke, uh, Professor Wu, Professor Klein, and a lunch lady in the cafeteria. How everyone else found out is a mystery to me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why aren’t you talking to me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Because I’m mad at you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Well, now I’m sorry I asked.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, it’s humiliating. Thanks to you, my colleagues are gossiping about our sex life.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What is there to gossip about? We barely have one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s why they’re doing it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is it safe to assume you’re not speaking to me again? If you’re not answering because you’re not speaking to me, perhaps we could come up with a signal. That works.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You don’t need your dad’s money. You can get by on your salary.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Well, we work at the same place as you, and we’ve always been fine.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, please. Look in the mirror. You both look ten years older than I do.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, hang on. We can figure this out. Let’s just go over your expenses. How much is your rent?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t want to say.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is it really that high?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t want to say because I don’t know how much it is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You don’t how much your rent is?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: My father pays for it. Do you know how much your rent is?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, then double it, because my building’s a lot nicer than this dump.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do you know how much your car costs?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, how much do you spend on food?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The housekeeper does the shopping.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, my God, you really are spoiled.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m spoiled? Your baby has a cape that costs $300.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m going to bed.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, wait. This is our first fight as a couple who live together.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not sure of the protocol. Television teaches us that the man’s supposed to sleep on the couch, but of the two of us, you’re clearly more sofa-sized.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not sleeping on the couch because you don’t know what’s private and what’s not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This isn’t fair. You’ve discussed aspects of our physical relationship with Penny.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s different. She’s a close friend, not the lady in the cafeteria who cuts the crust off your sandwiches.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That lady has a name. I don’t know what it is, but one time I accidentally called her mom.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sounds like you’re gonna need a cheaper place to live.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: When you moved here, you didn’t have a lot of money. How’d you get by?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, sometimes you can get free food and Wi-Fi from the neighbours. Just know you might have to marry one of ’em.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, you guys let Stuart live with you. Why not Raj, too?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What, what are you doing? I, I, I schlepped the baby over, I brought imported beer. Why don’t you like me?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I thought we were best friends?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We are, that’s why I’m sad my best friend’s gonna be homeless.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m sorry, Raj. We really just don’t have the space.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What if he lives in your garage?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What if you stop helping?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Guys, I’m not living in a garage.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait. Why are we talking about our place when Sheldon’s old room is sitting there perfectly empty?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s a great idea.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Raj, if you need a place to stay, of course you are welcome here.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, but if I’m gonna just take advantage of my friends, I might as well keep on relying on my father.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, only if you’re sure. Whew.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock)Amy?(Knock, knock, knock)Amy?(Knock, knock, knock)Amy?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not exactly the welcome wagon, but I’ll take it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m mapping basic topics of conversation and with whom they can be discussed. I call these circles zones of privacy. Don’t Google that unless you want to see pictures of people’s genitals. This circle contains only me and you. It represents subjects we only share with each other, details of physical intimacy, bathroom habits. Although, as I’m saying it, I may need to add Dr. Fink in here.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Are you really worried about revealing secrets to Stephen Hawking?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I was just excited to list him as a friend.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I do appreciate you working on this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry you were embarrassed. And now I understand that some things are just between you and me, and in the event of redness and swelling, Dr. Fink.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s that little dot in the middle?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s reserved for thoughts I don’t share with anyone.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Interesting. You really have secrets you don’t tell me?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Can I hear one?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, they’re private.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why? Are they naughty?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A little.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Please?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. Two years ago I got my driver’s license.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What? Why didn’t you say anything?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I like being chauffeured around. It makes me feel important.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So when I got up at 4am. to drive you across the desert to an antique train museum, I didn’t have to?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, you didn’t. But keep in mind, I felt extremely important.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli(on skype)
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hello, Father. We need to talk.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I have come to an important decision. I will not be accepting your money any more. I’m a man, and I can take care of myself.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: That’s wonderful.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yes, that is wonderful. You will no longer be able to accuse me of being spoiled.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: I am so proud of you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dad, I’m trying to tell you off, and you’re ruining it with your delight and relief.

Speaker: Dr Koothrapalli
Dialogue: Sorry. Oh, no, my grown son is going to stop spending all my money. Where did I fail as a father?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s right. Keep asking yourself that. But I still love you very much, so don’t cut me out of the will.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, you brought your own lunch. Good for you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, I’m making a bunch of changes. This morning, I fired my dog walker.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh. How’s the dog gonna go to the bathroom?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, I gave her an Imodium. That’s tomorrow’s problem.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excuse me. May I have your attention, please? I have recently been made aware that my personal relationship with Amy Farrah Fowler has become water cooler gossip. And I just want to say, shame on all of you. We’re scientists. Our minds should be focused on the advancement of human knowledge, not the intimate details of other people’s lives.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: He’s right. And I’m sorry for the part I played in this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you, Bert. You’re a good man. That woman who stood you up and humiliated you last night really missed out.

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: That doesn’t paint me in the best light.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. Oh, I’m sorry. Correction, that woman not only had vigorous coitus with Bert, she also tipped him a dollar for a job well done. – That better?

Speaker: Bert
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, well, to sum up, focus on science, keep your nose out of other people’s business, and, uh, whoa, for a good time, call Bert.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What brought that on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, last night Amy was angry with me because I’d been foolishly telling people about certain personal matters.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s understandable.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I know that now. At first, I thought she was cranky because of her horrific menstrual cramps, but it turns out, no, she was genuinely mortified.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Interesting. Okay.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How bad is it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let me put it this way, do you own a barrel and suspenders?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Are you serious?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m not wearing this visor to play women’s golf.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, let me guess. You guys are drafting your fantasy accounting firms.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’re helping Raj figure out his finances.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, he has a job. How bad can it be?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, his rent and car lease are exceedingly high. You couple that with his penchant for dining out and shopping.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, wait, not shopping for clothes, right? Because look.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He also has a remarkable amount of credit card debt.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I thought your dad paid your cards.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I have a card for emergencies that I pay for myself.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What emergency happened at the L.A. Zoo?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s a penguin I sponsor. They’re losing their homes to global warming, and my car gets, like, seven miles a gallon, so I felt bad.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: What is Pink Cheeks?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s intimate waxing. Quit looking at that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Maybe you should find someone to help you get your finances under control.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Like a business manager?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, absolutely not. You can’t afford to hire someone who’ll forbid you from spending your money on foolish expenses. That is a foolish expense, and I forbid it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What if there’s someone who just likes controlling other people and stealing joy from their lives?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He sounds like a sociopath.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We don’t know, his mother never had him tested.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re talking about me. Very funny. Although I would enjoy drawing up a budget and forcing Raj to adhere to it without an ounce of compassion.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, wait, who’s gonna break it to the penguin?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, Sheldon. Yeah, I’m putting you in charge of my finances. I will not spend another penny that you don’t authorize.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well. Hey, Comic-Con tickets go on sale this Friday. You can’t buy one.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, better luck next time, Pink Cheeks.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You’re actually going to Comic-Con?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, Leonard wants me to do more stuff like that with him, so I thought maybe this year I’d tag along.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, that’s sweet. I bet you’ll have fun.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, do you want to come?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, thanks. I already live in a place all the nerds come to.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Please? I went to your boring thing last month.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: My aunt’s funeral?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Come on, even you checked your e-mail during the eulogy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I’m not going, but I do think it’s nice you want to.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s not that I want to go, I just think it’ll make Leonard happy. And if I have to watch him squeeze into an Ewok costume, so be it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Look at you, going to Comic-Con, talking about Ewoks. I really have become the cool one around here.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You actually think Penny will have fun at Comic-Con?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. Which will make me miserable, which is usually Sheldon’s job.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She’s gonna hate waiting in line for the panels.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And hate all the crowds at the panels.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She’s gonna hate the panels.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She’s gonna hate how often we say the word panels.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Why don’t you just tell her not to come?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, she’s so excited, I can’t do that to her.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What if you make it sound so bad she won’t want to go?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That I would do to her.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t believe Penny’s gonna get to go, and I’m not.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You can always watch the panels online. Oh, boy, we do say that a lot.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Panels. Just wanted to be included.
Raj; Come on, Sheldon, it’s Comic-Con. Just let me have the money for this, and I won’t ask for anything else.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You put me in charge of your finances. If you wanted someone weak and spineless you could walk all over, you should have asked Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: See? Miserable.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, you’re right, I got myself into this, but I’ve never missed a Comic-Con with you guys.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Your father may have spoiled you, but I won’t. If you want a ticket to Comic-Con, I suggest you figure out a way to earn the money yourself.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, you’re a grown man who’s highly educated. You could charge people money to punch you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Go ahead, make jokes. I don’t know why you think you’re going to Comic-Con, you just had a baby.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, so? So you think Bernadette’s just gonna let you jet down to San Diego for five days and leave her alone?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hang, hang on. So I have to bring Penny, you can’t afford it, Howard’s gonna get in trouble, and this guy gets to have a great time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m gonna go as Dumbledore.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Mm-mm, how’s my favourite girl?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What you doing?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Making lasagna.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, she’s sexy, she can cook. I’m such a lucky guy.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You want something stupid, or you did something stupid?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No. I just walked in here, saw how beautiful you are and had to tell you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, dear God, you’re cheating on me with Raj.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ha ha ha, never gets old. Okay, there is something I want, but it’s not a big deal.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, Comic-Con tickets go on sale this Friday, and I was hoping I could go with the guys. But before you say anything, I’ll make up for being gone by doing everything around here, I mean everything. I’m even gonna answer for you. Yes, Howard, you can go.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s so hard to say no to you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So I’ll say maybe.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What? Why?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You said tickets don’t go on sale till Friday, right?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You said you were gonna do all this stuff for me, right?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: See where I’m going with this?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: If you don’t know how to make lasagna, Google does.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Okay, so this is the main Comic-Con floor. It’s where all the vendors and exhibits are.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wow, that is a lot of people jammed in there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know. Sometimes Howard wears a striped shirt so we can play Where’s Wolowitz? Okay, now, This is us camping out in line for the Avengers panel.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, you really sleep on the sidewalk, huh?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. It can get chilly, but Raj figured out that if you pee in a bottle and put it in your sleeping bag, it helps keep you warm. Here’s the hotel room we all share.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, you and I would get our own room, right?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Every hotel is booked. But, yeah, see this space here between Sheldon’s feet and my head? That’s where you go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it’s no different than when Sheldon used to climb in bed with us during a thunderstorm.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Don’t worry, we won’t be doing much sleeping anyway. It’s like an all-night party. There’s trivia contests and Dungeons & Dragons. As we like to say, it’s off the chain mail.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I even said off the chain mail, and she still wants to go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s probably my fault. She may have heard about my cool Dumbledore costume.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Okay, I can give you 20 bucks for the whole box.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But you charged me hundreds for this stuff.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I know. And I did it with a straight face.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But I need to earn enough money so I can go to Comic-Con.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, all right. I’ll give you 25 bucks. That’s my best offer.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I have no choice.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: You know, if you want to make extra money, I could throw some work your way.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Really? I’ll do anything.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Great, you’re hired. First thing you can do is put price tags on these. Start the little ones at fifty.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, it’s no big deal. I can put up with anything for three days.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Comic-Con’s five days.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you kidding me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why don’t you just tell him you don’t want to go?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I can’t, it’ll break his heart. You know, he’s always making an effort to do things with me he doesn’t enjoy, like going outside.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: He is an indoor cat.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, maybe it won’t be that bad. Leonard says it’s really mainstream now. Comic books aren’t just for sad nerds any more. I mean, it is still a key part of their demographic.

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Bernadette(off)
Dialogue: Howie, can you get that?

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Howard(off)
Dialogue: Kind of busy.

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Bernadette(off)
Dialogue: Busy like I’ll be with the baby if you go to San Diego?

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey.

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What’s with the gloves?

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: They complete my ensemble. What do you want?

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m looking to make extra money and was wondering if you had any chores I could do.

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hang on. Bernie, can I outsource my chores to an Indian guy?

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No.

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s house. Raj rings the doorbell.
Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I tried.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, I was thinking, if you want to do a couples costume, we could paint ourselves green and be Hulk and She-Hulk. Or we could paint ourselves blue and go as Nightcrawler and Mystique.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Is there any scenario where we’re not in full body paint?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, if you want us to look like losers.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, um, are you sure the guys are okay with me coming?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, of course, why?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: This is just something you usually do together, and if I’m screwing it up, I don’t have to go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, why? Do you not want to go?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Why? Do you not want me to go?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I want you to go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, good, ’cause that’s what I want, too.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Now we’re going as Hulk and She-Hulk. I don’t want to take my shirt off at Comic-Con.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If I may speak for Comic-Con, we don’t want that either.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Is that nice?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, but it’s honest, and it sounds like you could use a little more honesty in your relationship.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, it’s more complicated than that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m always honest with Amy. The other day she said she was self-conscious about the beauty mark on her shoulder, and I said, you know, you can call that a beauty mark all you want. When there’s hair growing out of it, that’s a mole.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do you think she’s as honest with you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I should hope so. When she called me an insensitive jerk, I’d like to think she meant it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: There’s got to be other ways you can make a quick buck.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, you’d think. Ooh, maybe I could sell my blood and sperm.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I really should wear a bell around my neck so you guys can hear me coming.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Here, let me help you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, Double Stuffed Oreos, I remember when I could afford you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: There she goes.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Stay, I’ll get her.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I appreciate it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’s fine. She and I can cry together.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: He’s such a sweetie.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know, I wish there was some way we could help him.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: If he could find a girl with a job, all his problems would be over.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s working out great for me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Penny says they’re ready to go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Very well. Prepare for a long night of deceit.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, women can wear make up, it’s not lying.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was talking about Leonard. And if make up is so truthful, why is it called concealer?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wait, wait, wait, what’s Leonard lying about?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: He doesn’t really want Penny to go to Comic-Con. He’s just doing it to make her happy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Really? Because she doesn’t actually want to go. She’s just doing it to make him happy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So they’re both trying to make each other happy, and the end result is they make each other sad? That’s hilarious. I can’t wait to tell them.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, you’re not gonna tell them anything. You’re gonna stay out of it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Because it’s between them.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if you haven’t noticed, I’ve been between them for the last ten years.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, babe, you want to drive?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sure, or you can.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, it’s fine, I know you don’t like the way I drive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t have a problem with your driving.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you listening to this? They deceive each other about everything.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Shh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Just so you know, that guy in the parking lot hit me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He wasn’t in a car, but okay.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Just say you want to drive.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I honestly don’t.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Amy, do us a favour, please drive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sure, happy to.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If you want to drive, just drive. I don’t see why this has to be so complicated.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s not complicated. Amy’s driving, that’s it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s not it because you’re clearly upset.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re the one who seems upset.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why would I be upset?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Because you don’t want her to go to Comic-Con.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is an interesting way to stay out of it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, you don’t want me to go?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I just don’t think you’re gonna have a good time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, well, get this, neither does Penny, that’s why she doesn’t want to go. You set ’em up, I knock ’em down, good job.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why would you say you wanted to go if you didn’t?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I just thought it would make you happy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: O-o-o-okay, hold on, so if you don’t want to go and I don’t need to bring you, is everything good?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hold on, I’m trying to decide if I’m mad at you. No, I’m happy I don’t have to go.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: All right, problem solved.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not entirely, the fight over who’s going to drive is still…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, my God, stop talking.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: The place looks great. Did you guys get a maid?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Kinda.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Dinner’s almost ready. If you like meatloaf, I’m sure you’ll like its cousin, bowl of meat.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, if you’re still looking to make money, I will pay you to burn that jacket.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, but it doesn’t look like I’m going to Comic-Con this year.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, with as much debt as you have, probably not next year either.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howie?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sure. This is for you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What’s this?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s back pay for all the babysitting and taking care of Halley you’ve done.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: There’s more than enough in there to cover Comic-Con.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Um, I also take care of Halley.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And you live here for free.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I do, ma’am, thank you, ma’am.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This is so generous of you, I, um, I don’t know what to say.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Now you can come with us.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, there’s room in the bed by Sheldon’s feet.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As much as I appreciate this, I can’t accept it, okay? Halley’s my goddaughter, I don’t take care of her for money.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I would.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Keep it. Consider it a gift.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hold on. Is it back pay or is it a gift?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What’s the difference?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: When the IRS questions us in separate rooms, we need to have our stories straight.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It doesn’t matter. I’m not keeping this. I’m trying to pay my own way and be responsible. Taking handouts won’t help that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So you’re not going to Comic-Con?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’ve been plenty of times. If I miss one, it’s fine. I’m a big boy.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m a big boy, and if I missed one, I’d throw a big-boy tantrum.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know what? I’ve gone 12 times. Maybe I’ll sit out this year, too.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Maybe you and I can do something fun that weekend.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh, how about white-water rafting?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, how about we compromise and go on the Small World ride at Disneyland?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know what, I’m not gonna go either. I’m a father now. I’d rather spend time with my family.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You just don’t want to go alone with Sheldon.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m gonna go check on dinner.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sounds like everyone’s staying home. What do you say?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nuts to that, I’m going to Comic-Con.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: By yourself?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not necessarily. I have four months to find some new friends.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’ll go with you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s very kind of you, Stuart. Check back in with me in July.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: There’s my pretty girlfriend.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m not going with you to Comic-Con.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? Can’t a man just be happy to see his woman and pat her on her second most erogenous ball-and-socket joint?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: He can, but it’s still not changing my mind.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, maybe what’s in my pants will change your mind. It’s a list of this year’s panelists. It’s long, isn’t it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Aw, man, did you see this post from Raj?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? Is it another video of him and his dog Lady-and-the-Tramping some spaghetti?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No. He can’t afford his apartment, and he’s asking if anyone knows of a cheap place to live. I want to say India, but it seems mean.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: What’s so funny?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Raj is looking for a cheap place to live, and I wrote India.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Don’t post that, be supportive.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Maybe you should be supportive of my hilarious jokes. Fine, what should we do?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We’re smart. I’m sure we can think of something.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You want to let him live here?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, we’re smarter than that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know our apartment’s small, but I think we can make room.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, Sheldon. We are not getting a life-size Spider-Man statue.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We do have Sheldon’s old room. If he really needs a place to stay, I guess we should offer it to him.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re a good friend.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Am I still a good friend if I wait and hope that Howard offers him a place to live first?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You’re an even better husband.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know if the roles were reversed, he would do it for me.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Where would he stay? We already have Stuart.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, we can make some space in the garage. Maybe put a cot out there, get him a space heater, maybe a hot plate.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That sounds awful.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let’s hope he thinks so, too.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: For the last time, no Hulk, no Batman, no life-size statues.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wow. I’m starting to think you didn’t mean it when you said you wanted to spruce up the place.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Raj(answering phone)
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Howard
