Dialogue: Hey, uh, so we’ve been talking, and if you need a place to stay, we’d be happy to fix up the garage for you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That would be amazing. I was literally just looking at my moving boxes, trying to pick one to live in.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know it’s not ideal, but you’d have plenty of space for your furniture, and there’s this cool button that makes an entire wall go up and down.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I cannot thank you enough.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It is our pleasure.(beep, beep, beep)Hey, can you hold on one sec? Hello?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, buddy, you still looking for a place to live?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, yeah. Why do you ask?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, we have the extra bedroom, and if you need it, it’s yours.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, my God, that’s so generous.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s the least we can do.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I really appreciate it. Uh, can you hold on one second? Hey, so, Howard, what’s the bathroom situation gonna be?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, there’s a sink out there, that takes care of half your problems.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But I can use the downstairs bathroom, right?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. We barely use it, so it’ll be like it’s yours.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Cool, cool, yeah, yeah, hold on one second.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, what’s it like sharing a bathroom with Penny? Is there hair everywhere? Does she use your loofah?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t have a loofah.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, well, if I move in, you can’t use mine. Hold on a second. Hey, Howard, uh, how’s the Wi-Fi in the garage?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know. Why are you asking all these questions?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, to be honest, Leonard’s on the other line, and he offered me their spare bedroom.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Great. Go live there.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But you made the garage sound so fun.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I just didn’t want you to feel bad about it. Unless Leonard’s apartment also has a raccoon that chews its way in on cold nights, go there.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: One second. Okay, I think we’re close. How do you feel about a mini-fridge in my room?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, pal, you want to live here or not?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, uh, hi, Penny. Yes, please.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hi, uh, Penny, this circular is addressed to occupant, but with our apartment switch, it’s unclear whether it’s yours or mine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What’s it for?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Roofing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s yours.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, thanks. Just throw it out. Speaking of occupants, I’m given to understand Raj will be moving into my old room.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, for a little while.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What about his dog?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: She’ll be in her crate, it’s not a big deal.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I suppose that’s acceptable.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, Sheldon’s getting a little better with dogs. He even took a picture with Pluto at Disneyland.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If real dogs gave me buttons, I’d like them, too. Well, I think it’s very nice that you’re helping out our friend.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And I think it’s nice that you’re taking whatever medication Amy’s clearly giving you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And what is that supposed to mean?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, it’s like that science thing. For every action, you have a gigantic and annoying reaction.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just when I thought you couldn’t get any hotter.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If you’re implying that I’d have some problem with him moving into my room, you’re wrong. Raj is in a difficult financial situation, and I’m glad that he’s making changes to improve it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do not adjust the dosage. You nailed it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Don’t listen to them. What’s weird is that Penny almost got a science fact right.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I mean, it’s unfair; people just assume I’m going to be upset by Raj moving into my old room.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: But you are, aren’t you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I’m outraged.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Talk to me. Tell me what’s going on.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, that’s been my room since before I met Leonard, and now someone else is going to be living in it. And that someone else is not me. And you know how I feel about people who aren’t me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: There are a lot of memories wrapped up in that room. For me, too. The first time you told me you loved me was in that room.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wrong. We were standing outside my room in the hallway.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And there is the love of which I speak.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I realize it’s irrational, but with Raj moving in there, I’m feeling a bit replaced.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, this isn’t an easy time for him. He’s losing his apartment, he’s in debt, he’s probably humiliated.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, probably. But until we know for sure, how can I feel better?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can I get anyone anything at all?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Raj, you don’t have to serve us.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s the least I can do for helping me carry my stuff up.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It was really no problem.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Not for you, box of towels.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Anyway, thanks again.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, look at that. You’ve got a Raj, we’ve got a Stuart. Maybe we should take them both to the park and let them run around together.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know. Yours looks like he has worms.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You ready to go?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All set.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: A housewarming gift for Raj.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, a bunch of fake snakes better not spring out of it, ’cause that was a lousy anniversary present.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s nothing like that. I just, I thought about Raj’s situation, and I had a change of heart. You know, and regarding your gift, you said surprise me, and, boy, did I. Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Perfect timing. Food’s ready.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, wait, before we eat, I have a little welcome to the building gift for Raj.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Wait, is anything gonna jump out of that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No. I already asked.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, Sheldon. It’s a blank notebook.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I had some of my best ideas in that room, and I’m sure you will, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: He also never had sex in that room. That’s something else to look forward to.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: This means a lot.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I know this is a difficult time for you. You’re losing your apartment, you’re in debt, and you just, you must be humiliated.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, good grief. She is such a stickler for citing sources. Those were Amy’s words.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I know, I know, good grief was originally said by Charlie Brown, geez.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You’re right, I am humiliated. Thanks for pointing it out. You’re such a jerk.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can you believe this guy?

Speaker: Everyone
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I thought that was gonna break the other way.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon. Maybe we should just eat at our place.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fine. You took my room. You turned my friends against me. I hope you’re happy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What do I have to be happy about? My life’s a wreck.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How come he can say it and I can’t?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Just keep walking.

Speaker: Beverley(on skype)
Dialogue: Hello, Sheldon. What a pleasant surprise. How are you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Honestly, I’ve been better. Do you have time? Leonard says you’re very busy these days.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Oh, I just say that because he prattles. What’s going on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, our friend Raj moved into my old room, and it’s brought up a lot of negative feelings for me.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Mm. Well, what do you think the loss of your room represents?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Beverley, you know I hold you in high esteem. Can we skip the part where you pretend not to know the answer, and get to the part where you tell me the answer?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Very well, but, uh, if you don’t mind, I’d still like to pause for effect. Now, you’ve recently moved in with Dr. Fowler, yes?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Clearly, your old room represents an escape hatch, and without it, you’re forced to confront the terrifying reality of being trapped in a relationship with Amy forever.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hadn’t thought about that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And don’t start thinking about it now.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Hello, Amy. Your defensiveness may indicate similar insecurities about your relationship with Sheldon.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s not true.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: She said defensively.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: This isn’t about me and Sheldon. This is about Rajesh moving in with Leonard and Penny.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Interesting. They’ve found a need to take yet another room mate. Seems they’re avoiding some harsh realities themselves.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I had no idea all our relationships were such a disaster. Boy, you’re good.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: That is the word on the street, dear.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Maybe moving in was a bad idea. I haven’t been here one day, I’m already causing problems.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You didn’t do anything. It’s Sheldon.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You didn’t do anything, it’s Sheldon. That’d make a nice needlepoint pillow.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, relax. We’re happy to have you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you, but how do I know you’re not saying that just to be nice?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you actually pay for that haircut?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: That’ll do it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, Raj, I owe you an apology. Look, could you please put your dog on a leash?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sheldon, she’s fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, then at least hold her still so I can pretend she’s stuffed. Raj, I let my emotions get the best of me, and I unfairly took it out on you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you. I appreciate that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I can’t take all the credit. I spoke with Leonard’s mother, and she made me feel better.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know who you talked to, but that wasn’t my mother.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Beverly pointed out that I’m experiencing insecurities in my relationship with Amy, in the same way that Leonard and Penny are in their relationship.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What are you talking about? We’re fine.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, you’re fine as long as you have a buffer living with you to distract from your marital problems. It used to be me. Now it’s Raj and his attack Tribble. Anyway, I’m sorry for everything. Oh, and FYI, if you cry while they’re fighting, they’ll take you to McDonald’s.

Speaker: Beverley(on skype)
Dialogue: Hello, Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Why are you saying we have marital problems? We don’t have marital problems.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: I see. You must be yelling at me out of wedded bliss.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Look, just because we took our friend in does not mean that Penny and I are afraid to be alone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, this is a special circumstance.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Sheldon mentioned you tried to get your brother to live with you, as well.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, well, a circumstance can happen twice and still be special.

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Do you agree with that?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, now that you point it out…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you kidding me?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We do seem to keep finding room mates.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Now you’re taking her side?

Speaker: Beverley
Dialogue: Dear, I would never come between you and Leonard. That’s for your parade of room mates to do.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Howard? Howard? It’s me, it’s just me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, I texted you, but you didn’t respond. Leonard and Penny were arguing.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Not on my watch.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s fine. It’s just Raj. You can hit him with the bat, but it’s fine.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: And if my heart stops, just let me go.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sorry, guys. Sheldon was upset, Leonard and Penny were fighting, I just wanted to go some place where I wasn’t causing problems.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’ll say it again. India.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can I just stay in the garage?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Don’t do that. We’ll make up the couch for you and figure out something in the morning.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Come on, I’ll get you some sheets. Then I’ll see if I can beat my high score on the blood pressure machine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Never should’ve had all these kids so close together.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I can’t sleep.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Beverley believes I unconsciously consider my old room an escape hatch.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Is that bothering you?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I don’t care for unconscious thoughts. My brain and I are best friends. It should tell me everything.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I mean, how it relates to our relationship, not the bromance between you and your brain.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What if she’s correct? Doesn’t that say something troubling about us?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know. I just think you’re the kind of person who likes a contingency plan.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That is true. Did you know I figured out in which order I would eat all my friends in the event of an apocalypse?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You need to stop hanging out with your brain so much. It’s not a good influence.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: If you’re looking for spare change, I already cleaned it out.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, didn’t think this is where my life would be.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Me, either. I’m in a bedroom and you’re on a couch. I’m actually winning.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, we’re both down on our luck. Maybe you and I should try to get a place together.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Okay, listen to me. There is no reason to leave here. This is great. Everyone’s nice. It’s comfortable. If all goes according to plan, this is my retirement home.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wouldn’t you feel better about yourself if you were more independent?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Better than I feel in their steam shower? I don’t think so.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny would be the entree. Then Leonard’s basically a cheese course. And because I love you, you’re dessert.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I want to say aw, but I’m gonna say ew.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, you see, I’m doing this so I can stop being spoiled and, you know, grow as a person.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Good for you. This sandwich has six dollars worth of ham in it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t you even feel a little bad sponging off your friends?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hey, look, I went to art college, I tried to make it as a graphic artist, a comic book artist, and you know what I got for my efforts? A visible rib cage. I’m not kidding. You could see my heart beating.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, no offence, but I didn’t go to art school. I have a PhD in astrophysics.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, great, it’ll be easier for you to look up at the stars without a roof over your head.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Did you know Raj moved out last night?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What? Why?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Leonard and Penny, I’m sorry for all the trouble I’ve caused. I went to stay at Howard’s. PS Cinnamon’s with me, but if you feel like messing with Sheldon, tell him she’s loose in the building.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I feel terrible.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Should we go bring him back?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, you’re the one worried having someone live with us is a sign of problems.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, that was just because my mother got in my head. It’s like being possessed, but instead of Satan it’s, actually, it’s the same thing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, so we’ll ask him to come back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, great.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Don’t you want to get dressed first?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Just one second. Help, Cinnamon’s loose in the building.

Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: Amy, quick, lock the door.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’re so sorry if we made you feel uncomfortable. We really weren’t fighting about you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I just never want to be a burden on my friends.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Me, either. Don’t want to be a burden. Hey, is that the baby? I’ll go check.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You are not a burden, and we want you to come back and stay with us.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But I also upset Sheldon, and he’s not gonna want to come over if I’m there.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: More reasons for you to stay.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Halley’s fine.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You know she’s at my parents’ house, right?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: And she’s having the time of her life.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you ever want to change things up, you’re always welcome here.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Just not in our bedroom, you dumbass.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I appreciate it, but I think staying with Leonard and Penny makes more sense for everyone.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Then it’s settled.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: And just so you know, it’s only temporary. I’m not gonna get too comfortable.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Good. Nobody needs a mooch living in their house forever.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hey, that’s no way to talk about your baby.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know what? I’m proud of us. Yeah, with Penny and Leonard taking in Raj, and Stuart living with Howard and Bernadette, we’re the only couple of our social group who doesn’t need to fill the holes in their relationship with a third party.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yup, we’re killin’ it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You know, downward-facing dog comes from the Sanskrit phrase adho mukha shvanasana.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that’s beautiful. What does it mean?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Downward-facing dog.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, I guess they don’t have Sanskrit for butts up and heads down.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, we wrote the Kama Sutra. If it involves butts, there’s a word for it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I thought we were getting breakfast before work.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, right, sorry.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s my fault. I asked Penny to do yoga with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: If you want, I can get ready in five minutes.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s cute that you think that. Don’t worry about it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hey, can I ask you a favour? Would you mind taking Cinnamon for a walk?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sure. You’re living here for free, I guess I owe you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Bye, Cinnamon. Be a good girl.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, bye, sweetie.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, bye, Leonard.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Okay, and tree pose.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, she’s done.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Things have been going really well with the infinite resistance gyroscope.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s great. How so?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, the project is classified. I can’t tell you. Oh, I suppose I could redact the classified parts. All right, um, I came up with an elegant solution to the(honks horn)I used the(honks horn)And then I(honks horn)And that did it.(Car passes honking horn)Wow, I wonder what they’re redacting.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why don’t you ask me what I’m working on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, very well. What have you been working on? And feel free to honk during the boring parts.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m doing some experiments to show that the signal to move a muscle occurs before you know you even decided to move it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So you’re attempting to pinpoint where consciousness resides in the brain.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yes, I’m trying to figure out to the nanometer and the attosecond, precisely where and when an event of awareness takes place.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, what do you know? Here I was, waiting to be bored with biology, and instead you tickle my intellectual fancy. Which, unlike my body, is an okay place to tickle.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, when I was six, I wanted to marry the gorilla from Good Night, Gorilla. Maybe I was onto something.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, the most interesting thing just happened with this spoon.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Unless it was singing Be Our Guest, I doubt it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I picked it up without thinking about it. Which raises a neuroscientific question, when did I decide to pick it up?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: The bigger question is, what are you gonna eat with that spoon? You didn’t get any food.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He does raise an interesting point.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy is studying the time lag between intent and awareness, and I realized that applies to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics. Now, I recognize there will be a time lag between me saying that and you Googling what it means, so I’ll wait.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I understand it, Sheldon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, me, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, I spaced. Are we still talking about the spoon?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s nice to see you taking an interest in Amy’s work.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, don’t get me wrong. Neurobiology’s nothing more than the science of gray squishy stuff. But, you know, when it connects to physics, gas up the Ford, Martha, we’re going for a drive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So did you confront Jennifer?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I was going to, but she called in sick. And guess who else called in sick.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Paul.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Paul.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Who’s Paul?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, you met him at the office Christmas party. He’s married to Nancy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, sure. Wait, Nancy?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I bet Jennifer gets a promotion out of this, which is so unfair because I work twice as hard as she does.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Don’t worry, Jerry won’t be fooled by that type of behaviour.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Jerry?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It didn’t work for Randy, it didn’t work for Tina, it sure as hell isn’t gonna work for Jennifer.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, I hope not. I just hate when people play those kinds of games.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Tina?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: With your sales record, you have nothing to worry about.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I went to your office Christmas party?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, I like harp lessons, but I’m thinking of switching to elevator repair lessons. What are you working on?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was thinking about your experiment on the neuroscience of decision making, and I realized, if we connect it to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics, we have a chance to disprove the role of consciousness in the Copenhagen Interpretation.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wait, are you saying if we combine my experiment with your calculations, we can determine the precise moment in time when the wave function collapses?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It could be the most inspired combination since I mixed red Icee into my blue Icee. It was like drinking two sevenths of the rainbow.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, this is really interesting.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, and this one won’t stain my teeth purple.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, we’ve never collaborated professionally before. Are you worried it might affect our relationship?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That is a valid point. Perhaps we should establish some ground rules.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, that would make me feel better.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, let’s start right now. Uh, rule number one, no using sexuality to get your way.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s a ridiculous rule.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, how is that?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can actually feel the toxins being pulled out of my skin.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, this is a moisturizing mask.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, well, then I can actually feel the moisture going into my skin.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, I hope you don’t mind, I used a little of your eye cream last night.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I thought someone looked brighter and tighter.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’d still like to know who Jerry is.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Don’t worry about it. Hey, after this, how about we all go out and do something together?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That would be great. Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You want to go shopping?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Ooh, yes. Fun.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Or we could do something we’ll all enjoy, like play a board game.
Montage of shopping scenes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I believe I’ve made some progress on our ground rules.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, good. What are they?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, uh, number one, in matters of physics, I have the final say. In matters of neuroscience, you have the final say. Unless I disagree. Oh, here. Number two, when we publish,
my name goes first. Oh, subsequently, if we win any awards, I speak first. I don’t want to be talking when the orchestra plays us off.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Can I see that?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, of course. I’ll get that back. Like all my underwear, that notebook says Property of Sheldon Cooper.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, if we’re gonna have ground rules, I’ll tell you the first ground rule. I make the ground rules.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’d write that down, but I can’t now, can I?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I mean, they didn’t say anything, but I just kind of felt like I was being a weird third wheel.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Huh, so you can tell what that feels like. Interesting.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Anyway, I figured I can hang out with my friends and have fun, too.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, if your idea of fun is riding in a minivan to Target for diapers, things are about to get nuts.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, it’s just nice to be with people who are happy to have me around. Isn’t that right, Halley?

Speaker: Halley
Dialogue: (cries)

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, at least someone had the courage to say it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you, you are a good citizen. Told you. Go ahead, throw my underwear out the window. Same thing’s gonna happen.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Terrific. Do you want to hear our new set of ground rules?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Fire away.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Number one, we’re on the same team, we’re not in competition.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s smart, because Sheldon 1, Amy 0.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Number two, disagreements can happen politely. There’s no need to call an idea stupid.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Aw, someone drew a penis in it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Are you listening?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry, go ahead.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Number three, to avoid getting frustrated, we take built-in breaks and reward our successes with a small treat.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ooh, that sounds fun. Now, we’re talking about real treats, right? Not Bible verses like my mother used to give me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Whatever you want. So, shall we get to work?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Biology and physics coming together, this is like the peanut butter cup of the mind. Oh, I know what I want my treat to be.
Montage of Sheldon and Amy working together.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Wow. Look at that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, this is remarkable.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So we’re agreed, it’s complete garbage.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: By the way, your name can go first.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I mean, I’m glad they’re getting along, but it’s starting to make me uncomfortable.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, are you worried he’s like another man in her life?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: A little, until I saw them in matching tops.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Nice. 174 diapers. That ought to get us to Wednesday.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, have you talked to them about it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, what am I supposed to say, stop having fun without me?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: This one says that every time I go out. See? I listen to you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Look, Raj just gets along with women.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I know, but he was my friend first. It’s like she’s stealing him and they’re just having the best time doing all their dumb girly stuff together.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You sure you don’t fit in? You sound like a catty bitch to me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know where we went wrong.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, the math is so inelegant. I’m not even sure it makes sense.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, don’t give up. Maybe we can fix it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can you stop breathing so loud? I can hear your nose whistling.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can hear your face talking, so we’re even.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, either blow your nose or teach it to play Camptown Races.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Fine. Fine. You want me to blow my nose? Here, I’ll blow it. Better?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I can still hear it. Oh, wait, that’s me. Never mind, it’s fine.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, you’re exhausting. I knew working together was a bad idea.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hold on. I see what’s wrong here. We did the propagation only to the occipital lobe, not to the prefrontal cortex.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That would mean that this delayed parameter should be increased 250 milliseconds.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, that is much better. Yeah, boy, if good ideas came out of your brain the way mucus comes out of your nose, we’d be in good shape.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Now, take a sip, swirl it around your mouth, and try to notice the flavours, the tannins, the textures. Well?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I probably should have spit out my gum first.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah. You know, the last couple of weeks have been pretty rough, but, uh, staying here with you guys has really helped take my mind off of it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Mm. Well, we’ve loved having you around. Right, sweetie? Leonard?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: When did he leave?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s rude.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You know, it’s nice to spend time with people who don’t talk about work like it’s some kind of soap opera.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Jennifer still trying to sleep her way to the top?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You should be happy someone wants to do the stuff with Penny you don’t want to.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, I wish I had that with Howard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Wait. What? What do I make you do?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Let’s see, the magic store, the Doctor Who convention, the National Belt Buckle Collector’s meet and greet.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It said right there on the invitation, buckle up for fun. It’s not my fault you didn’t listen.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sure I’m overreacting.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re entitled to feel how you feel. If you don’t like it, you should just talk to her.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t want to sound like a jealous baby.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, then maybe you shouldn’t talk to her.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I had a feeling you were using the wrong computational model, but I didn’t say anything ’cause you’re so sensitive.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just because I am easily bothered by light, heat, sound, smell and the way birds look at me does not mean I’m sensitive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, I wonder what kind of success we’d have if we defined measurement as the first moment that an action potential is seen by the visual cortex.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That is a daring and insightful solution.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We’re finally making progress. I wish we could do it without fighting.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What if the fighting is the reason we’re making progress?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I suppose it’s conceivable that the hormones associated with our fight-or-flight response could be sharpening our cognitive processes.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, if that’s the case, then your grandparents mumble and have bad posture.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: How dare you speak that way about my Grammy and hey, wait a second. Wait. Delta T could equal alpha sub-zero.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It seems we have a choice to make. Abandon all ground rules in the name of science, or give up collaborating for the sake of our relationship.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: There’s only one clear choice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Science it is.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, you bonehead.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Name calling, that is perfect. Now, when I get to this equation here, really let me have it. You know? If it helps, I’m not the sharpest dresser.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Anyway, I know it’s silly, but since Raj moved in, I’ve been feeling a little left out.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, sweetie, that’s crazy.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No, no, Penny, don’t dismiss his feelings.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. I just feel…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hang on, I’m not saying that his feelings aren’t crazy. I just don’t want him to think that this isn’t a safe place.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, to be truthful…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, why wouldn’t this be a safe place? I mean, he’s surrounded by his wife and one of his best friends.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t want to speak for Leonard.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you. I…

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: But when you’re insecure, no amount of external validation can ever make you feel safe.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, you’re right. You know, you’re really sensitive about this kind of stuff.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m a good listener.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, Olsen twins…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I mean, I’m sitting right here. You’re talking about my feelings and somehow leaving me out of the conversation.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I’m sorry. What did you want to say?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know, you pretty much covered it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Can you read them back?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Revised ground rule number one, we are on the same team, but it is a competition.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Excellent. Excellent. And on a related point, you’re going down, punk.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Revised ground rule number two, there are definitely stupid questions, and those who ask them can be told so right to their stupid face.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I love that one.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thanks, babe. Number three, fair topics for insult include educational pedigree, scientific field, intellectual prowess, and mamas.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, that list is strong. Like your mother’s urge to be promiscuous with sailors.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, Leonard, if you’re not busy tomorrow, I have to do a little reception after work.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, I would, but we need to make a push on the air force project.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, are you sure? We’re celebrating our new ADD drug, and it’ll probably be over in, like, six minutes.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Did you say you guys are working on the guidance system tomorrow?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, why?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, Sheldon said that he was gonna work with me on our quantum perception project.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We’ve had this planned for a week.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, he reconfirmed with me this morning.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Guys, before this gets ugly, remember, the winner gets Sheldon.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, Raj, do you want to go with me tomorrow?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Are you asking because you want me there or out of pity? Actually, never mind, don’t answer. I’d love to.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why did you tell Leonard you’re working on the gyroscope tomorrow?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because I am.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: But you said you were working with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Uh-oh. Someone’s got two dates to the nerd prom.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I have a plan to work on both projects simultaneously. And for your information, the summer conference on algebraic topology at Caltech is nerd prom.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m sorry, what is this plan you have?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m not needed at both places at the same time. And I can also free up extra hours with simple tricks, such as using a minimal amount of words to convey my point.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: When does that start?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Soon. See, I could’ve said in the near future, but I didn’t say in the near future, because in the near future is three more words than soon. In, one, the, two, near, three, future, four. See, in the near future is four, soon is just one, four is more than one, saving time already.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Genius. I was gonna say, why does anyone think Sheldon’s a genius? But I didn’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I’ve got Amy up and running. Shall we get to work?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh, before we do, what are you wearing, oh, friend who we pretend is normal?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: These are hydration backpacks. For efficiency, whenever I’m thirsty I have access to water. When I’m hungry, I have lentil soup.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s getting harder to pretend.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Anyway, Sheldon, we’re at a decision point to run the xenon stream through the cryo-cooler or through the vacuum filter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Run down the pros and cons of each for me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, if we run the xenon stream through the cryo-cooler, it’ll be cooled immediately before it reacts with the conduction.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, sorry, uh, carrot chunk.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You can just feel the time being saved.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Ah, I’m back, you got me for eight minutes.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, this is silly. You can’t expect us to do quality work with you popping in and out like this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The coefficient isn’t lambda, it’s lambda sub one. And over here, you should consider the possibility that the brain itself is in two different quantum states. And lastly, do you have any little soup crackers?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The rate of spinning for the central axis centrifuge has to be four revolutions per second.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It can’t be four revolutions, it’s got to be seven.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Seven? Look at the board, it’s four.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, my God, it’s seven.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Seven.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s five and a half.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Son of a bitch, it’s five and a half.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: BRB. That’s short for be right back. I’m saving so much time.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The two signals meet up in the corpus callosum and T equals zero. And I know a boy who just earned a slurp of soup.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Incredible. Sheldon, I didn’t expect that you could work on both projects, but I, I was wrong.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I felt the same way about the spork. Uh, solids and liquids handled by one utensil? That’ll never work. Spoiler, works.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I got to admit, we didn’t think you’d be able to do two things at once.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I felt the same way about the platypus. You know, bird and mammal in the same creature? No way. And spoiler, way.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, thanks again for letting me use your laptop last night.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Was just doing my taxes.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Actually, if I could, if I could just check one more…

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Already cleared the browser history.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: You’re a good woman. What you working on?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Trying to catch up on office e-mails before I go back.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh, that’s right, maternity leave’s almost over. Ah, you excited?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, I mean, I’ll miss Halley, but it’ll be nice to get out of the house, be intellectually stimulated. Go out to lunch instead of, you know, be lunch.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: That’s great, good for you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, I mean, with you and my parents, she’s gonna be fine.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Ah, of course she is.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And that day care is great.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: It is. I went to check it out, and they are very cautious about letting strange men with no kids peek in the windows.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Plus, I, I think I’m setting a good example for Halley, to show her that women can be mothers and still have satisfying careers. Sure, she won’t know where I went or if I’m ever coming back. That’ll just make the ten minutes between when I get home and her bedtime even more special.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Uh, other than burp you or give you a bottle, I don’t know what to do right now.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s okay, I’m just being emotional about this. Can you not tell Howard?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, don’t you think it’d be healthier if you told him what’s going on with you?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Don’t you think it’d be healthier if you had your own apartment, grown man?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Your secret is safe with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, since when do you do laundry on a Thursday?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I had an accident at work, I slipped and fell on my soup sack.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You know, there was a time I would say what’s a soup sack? But I’m glad we’re past that.(Sheldon sneezes)You know, there was a time I would say God bless you, and then you would say if you must invoke an imaginary deity, how about Thor? And I would say, how do you know I didn’t mean Thor? And then you would say Touché, and that there ends the tale of why I no longer say
God bless you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, we have had some fun, haven’t we?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. So, Leonard tells me you’ve had a busy day.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm? Oh, I did. It hasn’t stopped. I figured out a solution for our navigation system while I was pre-soaking lentils out of my pants.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Are you getting sick?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course not. I’m too busy to be sick.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, you’re pretty delicate. Maybe you shouldn’t be pushing yourself so hard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m fine.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right. Well, we’ll just pretend that you didn’t catch a cold watching Frozen.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That didn’t happen.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You also got a nosebleed watching Up.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just do your laundry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Stuart, you didn’t have to make dinner.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Yeah, well, I felt bad about upsetting you this morning. And to be honest, I’m not the biggest fan of your meatloaf.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, what’s for dinner?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Meatloaf.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, cool.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Stuart made it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, cool. Hey, I was thinking maybe we take Halley to the zoo this weekend, get in a little family time before you go back to work.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sounds great.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Speaking of which, for day care, it’ll be easy for me to drop her off, unless you want to do it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hmm, guess it should be me.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I can’t do it. They have a picture of me on file now.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Of course, why?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I don’t know, you seem a little upset.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No, I’m fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Why don’t you think she’s fine? She sounds fine, she looks fine. If I saw her on the street I’d say, damn, that girl’s fine.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re sick, go back to bed.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I am fine. Here, eat your toast.(Sneezes)Sorry.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s okay, now I don’t need butter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, perhaps I am a little under the weather. It’s nothing a little cold medicine and tea can’t fix.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You need sleep.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What I need is to get to work.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I don’t want your germs around me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? You hold my hand, you kiss my mouth, but you draw the line at a hundred and two fever? What happened to our love?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, are you okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s going on? How’d I get here?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I don’t know, we came home from work and we found you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Home from work? What time is it?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: It’s nine o’clock.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Nine o’clock? What happened to eight and seven and all the other o’clocks?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wait, you don’t remember?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I remember waking up in the morning, Amy rubbing Vicks on my chest. And her hands were like two frozen chunks of tundra. I took some cold medicine to… I took cold medicine.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You did seem a little loopy when you showed up at the lab.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: At, at the lab? Why am I naked from the waist down?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I don’t know where your pants are, but we did find your underwear in a pot on the stove.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: My pants are missing, I don’t remember anything. Penny, this is your youth. What do I do?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know, check your body for tattoos?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, would you be a lamb?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She’s kidding.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait, wait. Where’s my bag? My phone and my wallet are in my bag.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It’s right here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Where’s my notebook? My notebook’s gone. Oh, no.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, it’s just a notebook, what’s the big deal?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s the big deal? It’s full of classified information about the air force project.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: How could you lose that?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s okay, I’m sure we’ll find it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, it’s got to be around here somewhere.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Maybe it’s wherever your pants are.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Nope, pants in the microwave, no notebook.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Ah, hello.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, something’s going on with Bernadette. She say anything to you?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, nope, not a word.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Come on, be honest. Did you tell her I tried her breast pump?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: No, but I did mention it to my therapist.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, I know she’s mad at me about something.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, what have you done that would upset her?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, gosh, how much time do you have?

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Well, why don’t you just start with the worst thing?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hmm, let’s see. Mm. Okay, here we go, six years ago, I got a call that Bernie’s great-aunt, Trixie, died.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And I forgot to give her the message.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: That’s terrible.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: The terrible part is, ever since then, I’ve been sending Bernie Christmas cards from Trixie.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh Howard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Let me finish, and one card had five dollars in it I took from Bernie’s purse.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: The notebook isn’t in the bathroom.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I can’t find it, either. How can he not remember a day?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, people who are abducted by aliens lose time. I mean, maybe it happens to the aliens, too.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, it’s not across the hall.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s it. I’m in breach of my security clearance. I’m going to prison. And you know what happens to people like me in prison. I’ll be forced to be some large man’s tutor.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You’re not going to prison.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: But, boy, it is funny to think about.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You really can’t remember anything?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m trying.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Hey, let me see your phone.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, it’s, it’s possible it was tracking everywhere you went.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Phones can do that?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, it depends on the privacy settings.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, that, that’s so cool. How do you, how do you turn that thing off?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Relax. I know when you go for a run, you stop for a donut.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t even run there, I drive.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hang on, I can see every place you went.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What does it say?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, you were in the building, you were at the university, then you were somewhere on Colorado Boulevard.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Wait, hang on. Did you go to a cowboy bar?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I, no, that is preposterous. Maybe.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, how’s it going?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Good. Love you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Love you, too.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Love you more.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay, you won. Can I finish what I’m doing?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Sure, sorry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Something on your mind?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, no, nothing. Okay, well, maybe I’m just feeling like something’s bothering you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Nope, all good.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Prove it, make love to me right now on the kitchen floor.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No, what is wrong with you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Aha, you are upset. I don’t know a lot about women, but I know I upset them.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Howard, I’m sorry if I’m being weird, but it has nothing to do with you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It doesn’t?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No. I didn’t want to tell you, but I’m having a really tough time about going back to work.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh. Okay, well, I get that. It was hard for me when I went back.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It was?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Of course. I missed you and the baby and being able to watch Ellen every day.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I just don’t know what the right thing to do is. If I go back to work, I’m abandoning Halley. If I don’t go, I’m giving up everything I worked for. It’s like there’s no right choice.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Look, I don’t know what the best decision is, either. But whatever we choose, if we’re not happy, we can undo it.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I guess.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And the best part is Halley won’t remember a thing. Babies are cute, but they’re dumb. I mean, I go like this, she thinks I’m gone, then magically I’m back. I mean honestly, why are we saving for college?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m not crazy about you calling our baby dumb.
Howard; Well, she gets it from me. Speaking of which, I have some news about your Aunt Trixie.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Does this place look familiar?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s hard to say.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon’s back.

Speaker: Bar patrons
Dialogue: Sheldon!

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s getting clearer.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: You gonna buy another round for the house?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, no, thank you. We now know why MasterCard sent me a fraud alert.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ask him.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Um, yes. Howdy, partner. Do you happen to recollect if I left a notebook in these here parts?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: These here parts?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s called fitting in. By the way, good luck.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: Here you go.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, thank goodness.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: One top secret quantum guidance system.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You understood the math?

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: No, but Sheldon told me all about it. He told everybody.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That’s just great.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: Oh, don’t worry, he made us pinky swear we’d keep it a secret.
Flashback

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I swear.

Speaker: Everyone
Dialogue: I swear:

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not to tell anyone.

Speaker: Everyone
Dialogue: Not to tell anyone.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The top secret military information I’m about to tell you.

Speaker: Everyone
Dialogue: The top secret military information I’m about to tell you.
End of flashback

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We really need to skedaddle. Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Barman
Dialogue: See you. Should probably erase this.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you for making me tea.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You’re welcome. How is it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yummy. And warm on my back.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Do you need anything else?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know exactly what I need.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Fine. Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur. Happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr, purr, purr.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s nice. Now in German.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Weiches Kätzchen, warmes Kätzchen, das nie und nimmer murrt. Liebes Kätzchen, müdes Kätzchen, schnurrt, schnurrt, schnurrt.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Great. Now Mandarin.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sings in Mandarin. *

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now Navajo.
* (I have been unable to find a proper transcription of the Mandarin lyrics. If anyone who speaks Mandarin is able to send me a full transcription, I will include the lyrics here.)

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, we’re about to go live, everyone on their A-game, good energy. Hello. I’m Dr. Sheldon Cooper.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: And I’m Dr. Amy Farrah Fowler.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And welcome to a special retrospective, where we will take a look back at the history of Fun with Flags on an episode we’re calling…

Speaker: Together
Dialogue: Fun with Flags: Behind the Flags: A Retrospective.

Speaker: Howard(singing)
Dialogue: Wondering how it all began?

Speaker: Raj(singing)
Dialogue: You’ll need a good attention span.

Speaker: Howard(singing)
Dialogue: For information and entertainment.

Speaker: Raj(singing)
Dialogue: That’s equally effective.

Speaker: Together(singing)
Dialogue: It’s fun with flags, behind the flags, a retrospective. Flags.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Mind you, when we say behind the flags, we don’t literally mean these flags. That’s just where we have dinner.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Now, I’m sure many of you are wondering how Fun with Flags began.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So let’s hear from some people who were there at the very start. How, Howard, flashback sounds.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Could have played that on my harp.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Just roll the clip.(On voiceover) Sotell us in your own words about that magical moment when Fun with Flags was born.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I honestly don’t remember.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Sure you do. I was telling you both the story about how Haiti and Lichtenstein discovered they had the same flag. It was at the Summer Olympics of 1936, and two plucky nations…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, wait. I remember.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, and do you remember what you said?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yes. Please find someone who cares.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And that’s exactly what I did. I found a lot of someones.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Almost 200. Many of them on purpose.

Speaker: Sheldon

Dialogue: Howard, I’m trying to make myself uncomfortable, not everyone else.
