Dialogue: So you wanted to learn something physical and you came to Howard Wolowitz?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, the circus arts are very physically and mentally demanding. Have you ever tried to juggle?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yes, I’m juggling my love for you and my embarrassment of you right now.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And it’s hard, isn’t it? So the key is, the moment one ball is at the top of its arc, you toss the next one. Hmm?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay, I think I got that.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Uh, hold on. There’s an old saying in juggling.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Is it I’m going to die alone?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No, it’s if you want to have fun, start with one. Yours we think, but we do not say. All right, just toss it up and catch it a few times, get comfortable with it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. Just to be on the safe side, am I in any danger of getting juggler’s elbow?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you sure? ‘Cause I’m feeling a twinge.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: See, that wasn’t so bad. He even picked up the check.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah. Although, when he was trying to figure out the tip, I’m pretty sure I saw smoke coming out of his ears. You’re not really considering working for him, are you?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, maybe, I mean, it seems kind of perfect. I have sales experience, and I’ve been a waitress, so I have restaurant experience, and if he’s figuring out my Christmas bonus, we could buy a boat.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Don’t you think it might be a little weird to work for someone you used to date?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You work with Sheldon, you tell me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, it’s weird.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, are you seriously jealous of me working with Zack?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, I’m not jealous, I just think you have got a good thing going where you are right now, and you make great money and you haven’t slept with any of your co-workers.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Great, so you want me to stay at a job I’m not happy at?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You okay? You kind of look like Zack trying to figure out that tip.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Of course I don’t want you to be unhappy, but I also want you to be smart, and working for an ex-boyfriend isn’t very smart. You don’t have to stop, just slow down, I’ll jump out.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Amy, look, I’m on a unicycle!

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: How did you get from croissants to a unicycle?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hurt myself juggling.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Where did you get it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard said I could borrow it, Bernadette said forever.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Have you tried letting go of the rope?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What, are you crazy? I’m on a unicycle.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: All right, well, have fun.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait, I need help getting down.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, what do you want me to do?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Drag out our mattress and put it over here, then go across the hall, get their mattress and put it over here. But before you do any of that, scratch my nose.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So you told her she was being dumb?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, I told her she was being not smart. Which was dumb.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why did you even go to dinner with the guy?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: We covered this, I’m dumb.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So he’s my ex-boyfriend, who cares? I can’t believe Leonard would be so insecure.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Really? I have no trouble believing that at all.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And Zack’s engaged. Leonard has no reason to feel threatened.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We’re talking about the same Leonard, right?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So you think it’s fine if she works for Zack?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I don’t know, maybe.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, he is much more attractive than Leonard.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yes, but that’s gonna be true of a lot of guys she works for.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, but she also used to sleep with Zack.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Again.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I would never let Howard work with an ex.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What, you wouldn’t trust him?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I wouldn’t trust her. He’s thin and sexy like a Jewish greyhound.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah, that, that is the sexiest dog.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: And I’d like to think Howie wouldn’t take a job I was uncomfortable with.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: ‘Cause he’s scared of you?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Terrified.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You know what? I’m with Leonard, this isn’t cool.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I disagree. Penny is a strong, independent woman. The more you try to control her, the more she’ll push back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So you think it’s okay?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, no, she’s gonna leave you for someone, might as well get it over with.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m returning this stuff to Howard.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. Well, Bernadette made me promise if you didn’t want it, we’d give it to a homeless clown. What happened to learning the unicycle?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, I stopped that, it was dumb. Uni, bi, tri, menstrual, all cycles are dumb.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You said juggling was dumb, too.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, it is. If I wanted to hold three things at once, I’d wear cargo pants.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, is it possible that when things get really difficult, you just give up?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Are you calling me a quitter?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, if you honestly…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This conversation is over.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: His mother warned me. Everybody warned me. Actually, he warned me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You want to talk?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: That doesn’t seem to be where I shine. How about I just give you one of these?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Look, we can have a reasonable conversation and I won’t get mad. I don’t like it after sex, and I don’t like it now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, sorry.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. All right, just come here. Look, I get me working with Zack is weird and I don’t want you to be uncomfortable.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, thanks. And I don’t want you to be stuck at a job you don’t like.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Then what do we do?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, I don’t love it, but if you really want to take this job, I’ll find a way to deal with it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No, I know you’ll try, but it’ll make you miserable, which will make me miserable, and I’m just gonna stay where I’m at for now.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, you’re, you’re unhappy there and then you’re gonna blame me for making you stay, and it’s fine, I’ll just, I’ll suck it up.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You don’t need to do that, it’s okay.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, see, now I feel terrible, like I’m being selfish and holding you back. What? Say something. Yeah, that is pretty annoying.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I made you tea.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’m sorry I called you a quitter.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s okay, I stopped being upset about that. And no, the irony is not lost on me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What are you reading?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This article says the peak age for making a Nobel Prize-winning discovery is 40.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So I’m running out of time.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s ridiculous, you’re a brilliant man. The best years of your life are still ahead of you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, you have to say that, you’re sweet on me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, if you’re really worried about your career, maybe you should consider spending a little less time with video games and comic books.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, I thought you were sweet on me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, fine, let’s say you never win a Nobel Prize. Let’s say you spend your life doing solid scientific research surrounded by friends and loved ones who appreciate you, not for what you’ve accomplished but for who you are as a man. Wouldn’t that be a life well-lived?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re so cute. I’m gonna go learn how to walk on stilts.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So many warnings.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, are you sure about this?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Absolutely. I just want you to be happy. And maybe a little turned on about how selfless I’m being.

Speaker: Zack(on phone)
Dialogue: Penny, what’s up?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Hey, uh, so I’ve been thinking about it and I want to take the job.

Speaker: Zack
Dialogue: Oh, bad news. When my fiancée found out that I was offering a job to my ex-girlfriend, she said it was a stupid idea and threw a shoe at me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, so there’s no job?

Speaker: Zack
Dialogue: Nope, just a little bump on my forehead.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, thanks anyway. Bye. Well, his fiancée thought the idea of us working together was stupid. You were right, I was wrong. Aren’t you gonna say anything?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Not if I want to be doing this later.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey, I didn’t know you were home. Where you been?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I went to see your mom.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Seriously, where were you?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I just told you, your mom’s.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, since you find my magic tricks so embarrassing, I got to wondering what cool hobbies you had as a kid.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh. What’d she say?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: She didn’t say much of anything. But she said a lot.(Through ventriloquist’s doll)Hi, Bernadette, remember me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: First of all, that’s not what she sounds like, she’s from South Carolina.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I can’t believe you made fun of me all these years while you were a closeted ventriloquist.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Okay, it’s not like I wanted to be a ventriloquist. I was in beauty pageants and I needed a talent besides spreading rumours that the other contestants were pregnant.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, since you enjoyed getting rid of all my stuff, you know, maybe we should throw this little lady in the wood chipper.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No. And the little lady has a name.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Which is?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Tammy Jo St. Cloud.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Tammy Jo St. Cloud. Oh, and I’m a dork for juggling.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Sorry, you’re not a dork.(Through doll)You’re a clown.(Bernadette)Tammy Jo, don’t say that, you’ll make him feel bad.(Doll)Look at him, what reason he got to feel good?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All right, very funny.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Don’t listen to her, she’s been in a box for, like, 25 years.(Doll)Yeah, back when his haircut was fashionable.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That’s enough, put her away.

Speaker: Bernadette(as Doll)
Dialogue: Oh, big daddy, I don’t think so. You marry Miss Bernie, you marry me. We all family now.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: All right, you’re freaking me out.

Speaker: Bernadette(as Doll)
Dialogue: Don’t be that way. If you don’t mind a few splinters, we can have us a ménage à trois. Ooh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m doing it. I’m doing it. I’m tall and I’m doing it.(Waking up in bed)Ah, man.
After a “previously on” segment.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Champagne, champagne.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And for the world’s tallest second grader, apple juice.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you. No bendy straw, some party.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hey, a toast. Thank you all for your support while we worked on our Air Force project. And please know that we could not have done it without you, so cheers.

Speaker: All
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, it’s nice of you to acknowledge us, but this is your accomplishment.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, you guys did this all on your own.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Without me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: To success without Raj.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So what happens next?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Phase two, we test it, perfect it, and hope to live long enough to see the movie based on our lives starring more attractive versions of us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah, I’ll definitely live long enough. Vitamin C.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: First thing tomorrow morning, we’re back at it.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Without me.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I hope his character doesn’t make it into the movie, he’s kind of a bummer.

Speaker: Computer Voice
Dialogue: Leonard Hofstadter. Access granted.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hmm. I don’t care if this thing is burning out my retinas, it makes me feel special. Now, before we field test, I think we…

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: What the hell?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Where is everything?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Who else has access to this room?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: It’s a secure lab in a classified facility, only the U.S. government and us.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: This is disconcerting.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: But the movie did just get good.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sir, I, I, I’m sorry but I just don’t get it. You came into our lab in the middle of the night and took our prototype and all of our research and didn’t even tell us?

Speaker: Col. Williams
Dialogue: Sounds like you get it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: But why would you do that?

Speaker: Col. Williams
Dialogue: You guys completed phase one, we’ll take it from here.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Where did you move it?

Speaker: Col. Williams
Dialogue: I can’t tell you that.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Are you implementing phase two?

Speaker: Col. Williams
Dialogue: I can’t tell you that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Wait, so you’re just going to take all the work we’ve done for the last year and toss us aside?

Speaker: Col
Dialogue: Williams: That one I can tell you, yes.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: This is all very upsetting.

Speaker: Col. Williams
Dialogue: I’m sorry to hear that. As you know, the primary focus of the United States military is people’s feelings.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: If that’s sarcasm, please save it for our enemies.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I may be moving out soon. I think I found a place to live.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry to hear that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Really? You kept sending me apartment listings.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Um, well, I, yeah, you got me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Where are you moving?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And when? But also where?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Bert has a room for rent.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: So you’re gonna be roommates with Bert?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, no, it’s, uh, pretty private, actually, it’s over his garage. So the only time I’ll see him is when he pulls his car in, does his laundry or practices drums in my dining room.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, good for you. I actually have a little news myself.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, we’re just gonna circle back to when he’s moving out? Okay, that’s cool.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I was, uh, asked to be a visiting researcher at Princeton.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Hey, that’s amazing.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Good for you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thanks, but the thing is I’ll be gone for a few months and I don’t know how Sheldon’s gonna feel about that.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on, he’s a grown man, he can take care of himself.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You really believe that?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Once again, you got me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How can you work on something for a year and they just take it?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I can’t believe the Air Force would treat us like that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know, I have a good mind to stop paying my taxes. It’s too bad I enjoy doing them so much. The Air Force did it again. They’re erasing our lives.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Third floor, wrong apartment.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Although, if anyone’s gonna clean out your apartment and disappear, it’d be Penny.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: She might disappear, but she’s definitely not cleaning anything.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s okay, everything’s here.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, hey, what’s going on?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You won’t believe it, the military confiscated our project.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re kidding. Why would they do that?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: They wouldn’t say.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I feel so betrayed. You know, all my life I thought Uncle Sam was a friendly uncle who brought you presents. Turns out he’s the other kind.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, I’m so sorry.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you. Can we just talk about something else?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, what’s going on with you guys?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Give us some good news.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Amy’s got some news.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yeah, um, Raj is moving out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, no. When?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You doing okay?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Want me to put on some Neil Diamond? That always makes you feel better.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: No. Then you’ll get all sexed up and I’m not in the mood. I mean, an entire year wasted.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You might be forgetting another accomplishment of the past year.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh. Yeah, yeah, we brought life into the world.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Really? That’s the importance you put on us having a baby?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I’m happy about it, but, I mean, it’s not like I did much. I mean, after the first three minutes it was pretty much all you.

Speaker: Penny(on phone)
Dialogue: So, did you tell him about Princeton yet?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No, I’m waiting till he’s in a good mood.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, sweetie, you might not live that long.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know, maybe I shouldn’t go.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, stop it, he’ll be fine.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I guess. And he’ll have you and Leonard right across the hall the whole time.
Penny; Oh, damn, wait, you know, maybe you shouldn’t go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Got to go. Morning.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I apologize for exceeding my allotted bathroom time.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Are you feeling okay?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Not really. Apparently grief can make one less regular.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, I’m sorry to hear that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, I sat and I sat, but to no avail.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, the more details, the more sorry. Well, maybe this’ll cheer you up. I made your favorite oatmeal, plain.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What’s the occasion?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: No occasion, I just wanted to do something nice for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You’re so kind. You know, I don’t know how I ever got by without you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. That’s sweet, but you, you did just fine on your own.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I thought that, too, but I’ve come to realize, I am completely dependent on you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re, you’re being silly.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, to wake up every morning and know you’re there is a great comfort to me. Mmm, tasteless. How do you do it?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You know, what you need to do is put this Air Force project behind you and just dive into something new.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, there is our quantum cognition experiment. You and I could spend more time on that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh, I don’t know, I mean, let’s say we succeed in proving that our consciousness creates reality. I mean, what will we have really accomplished? You know, a loaf of bread’s still three bucks.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m confused. You’re always saying that you want to spend more time with me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That is true, I have said that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, a lot, it’s very annoying. Has something changed? Um, is there something that you’re not telling me?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I was offered a summer research fellowship at Princeton.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Princeton? A fine institution. The place where Albert Einstein taught. And where Leonard got his PhD, so it may have gone downhill.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yeah, that’s the one.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, that’s wonderful. Congratulations.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Well, I haven’t accepted it yet. I wanted to talk to you first.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What is there to talk about? You have to take it. It’s important.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So are you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Thank you, but I’ll be fine.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Are, are you sure?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I may have lost my guidance system and my girlfriend, but I still have a colon full of yesterday’s meals to keep me company. Although, thanks to your high fibre breakfast, I’m sure that’ll be leaving me, too.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Really? He doesn’t put raisins or banana slices or anything in it?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t think plain oatmeal was the point of that story.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I mean, I like a little brown sugar.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Guys.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re still gonna go, right?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know. Sheldon’s so vulnerable right now.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, come on. Look, if the roles were reversed, he’d be on the first train to New Jersey, or the second train if there were teenagers on the first one.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Well, distance might be nice. The last time a big project ended for Howie, he wouldn’t stop following me around. He even went with me to get a mammogram.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, what’s wrong with that?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No, he wanted to get one with me, like some kind of weird couple’s massage.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: And yet you bore his child. Neato.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You’re excited about this opportunity, right?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Of course. I get to be part of the first team to use radon markers to map the structures that…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, a simple yes will do.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: You have to go.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I know, but what if Sheldon…

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, listen to me. Your relationship can handle being long distance for a while. It’s not like you two are very physical.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey, you don’t know what goes on behind closed doors.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: A lot of lectures?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: All right, so you know.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I’m telling you, if you don’t go you’ll end up regretting it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Hey, wait up.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, great.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You left something at home. A big hug.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I found it right next to these kisses.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: It’s too late for me. Save yourself.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: So, are you excited to have your own place again?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I am, but I’ll miss you guys.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ah, we’ll miss you, too.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: You could try saying that without smiling.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: I’m trying. This is the best I can do. What are you doing?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What does it look like? I’m playing sad harmonica in an apartment as empty as my heart.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I got the blues. My baby done left me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon. Amy’s only gone for a few months. And now that I’m moving out, your old room is empty, so you can stay there whenever you want.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, could I talk to you in the hall for a sec?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Yeah, sure.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Sheldon, you’re being silly.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Am I? Yesterday I had an Air Force project, a girlfriend who lived with me, and my good friend Raj right across the hall.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Do you really care about that last one?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, but that list was sounding a little thin.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Instead of dwelling on the negative, think about this. Your girlfriend was given an amazing opportunity, which gives you an opportunity to show her that you’re a loving and supportive boyfriend.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So trick her.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: All right, let me start again. Uh, you and Amy…

Speaker: Raj(outside)
Dialogue: Can I get my stuff? Sounds like it’s gonna be a while.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I missed you.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Come here, let’s talk.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Ooh. Sounds serious. Have I been a bad boy? Am I gonna get a spanking ’cause you know.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Just listen. I don’t know if you realize this, but whenever you’re between projects, you tend to get a little insecure.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: A little clingy.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I know and I’m sorry.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Oh, oh, oh, okay, stop. Stop. I love when you’re affectionate, but this is not coming from a good place.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Well, excuse me, but what did you do when you worked on that allergy drug for two years and the FDA shut down your project?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I signed us up for ballroom dance class.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, and what did you do when they took you off the antifungal team?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I made us have a baby.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Bring it in.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: And now the movie just got rated R.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hey. You going somewhere?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, but you are, so I got you this as a present.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sheldon, that isn’t necessary.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: No, it is. Leonard pointed out to me that I’m not always a loving and supportive boyfriend, so here’s some quality luggage.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: The salesman said it could survive a plane crash, so perhaps you should fly inside it.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Does this mean you’re okay with me going?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m not looking forward to it, but it is a wonderful opportunity and you need to take it. Besides, Princeton is in New Jersey, so it’s not like you’re gonna want to stay. Uh, I know it’s not your birthday, but if you’re interested…

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Okay. Oh, and just to be clear, I’m not being intimate with you in order to keep you from going.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I wasn’t thinking that.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, no, it’s just, I’m just warning you, you know, if you find yourself 3,000 miles away and craving a hit of this, you know, I can’t Skype it to you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s a risk I’m willing to take.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: All right, then. Let’s go to the bedroom, remove our clothes, fold them neatly and engage in frenzied lovemaking.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What if we don’t fold our clothes at all?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Or, what if we fold them?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Well, here’s your key back.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: As soon as I have the place set up I’m gonna have you guys over.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Oh, we would love that.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I really can’t thank you enough for taking me in. You know, I was in a pretty low place in my life.

Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: Oh, Amy, you naughty vixen.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Anyway, uh, as I was saying, I was at a pretty low place in my life and, uh, if it wasn’t for friends
like you…

Speaker: Amy(off)
Dialogue: My goodness, that form of stimulation is highly efficient.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I can’t compete with that. Bye.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Should we give them their privacy?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I want to, but I don’t think I can.

Speaker: Sheldon(off)
Dialogue: Whoopee!

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I’m good now.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Okay, the car is waiting. Do you want to walk me downstairs?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course. Here, here, let me. I’ve been doing a little research on New Jersey, and I was delighted to learn that their chief agricultural product is sod.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm, yes. Yeah, perhaps I’ve been harder on them than they deserve.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Do you think it’s possible you might enjoy being on your own for a little while?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: It’s hard to say. I’ve never really lived by myself. What if I become strange and eccentric?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I’ll love you no matter what.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Howard Hughes saved his urine in milk bottles.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: We’ll cross that bridge when we come to it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And you’ll text me when you arrive at the airport?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And when you’re at the gate?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And if you see any actors from Game of Thrones in first class?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know what they look like, but sure.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And don’t forget to Skype me when you arrive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I won’t.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And every morning.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now of course, my 9am is your noon, so let’s avoid the whole good morning, good afternoon minefield, and let’s just say hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Good thinking.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And just remember, I am proud of you and I support you in all that you do.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Thank you. That means a lot.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, and one last thing. If you find yourself working with a male scientist who’s as smart as me, as tall as me and has hair like Thor, well, then I want you to step away from the situation and call me immediately.
Following a “previously on” sequence.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How are you settling in?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Pretty well. Princeton has a beautiful campus.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Now, I’ve learned some fun facts about New Jersey to help you make small talk. Would you like to know the state bird or the murder rate? They’re both shocking.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Actually, I want to hear about you. How are things at home?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I’m a lot less likely to see an Eastern Goldfinch or be murdered, I’ll tell you that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I miss you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I miss you, too.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s so strange, earlier today I ended a sentence with a preposition and you weren’t there to correct my grammar.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m sorry you had to go through that.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: In fact, that’s when I started to really miss you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: You know you just split an infinitive.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Did I? Are you gonna teach me a lesson?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I am. It is naughty to put an adverb between the word to and the verb stem.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: What are you gonna do about it?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’m going to admonish you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Vigorously?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That’s the only kind of admonishing I do.
Credits sequence.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: How’s Sheldon doing with Amy gone?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Well, the last three nights I’ve had to take him to get a haircut, to the train store, and to a Walgreens in Arcadia where they still have the good ibuprofen. Now ask me how I’m doing with Amy gone.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: How are you doing with…

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Shut up.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: If you’d like, we can help you out.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh, that would be great.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: I mean, not me, I’ve got a wife and child, but this one posts video of himself flossing on Instagram.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: It was a tutorial. And yes, I’m happy to keep Sheldon company.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Great. Tonight he wants to look at ladders at Home Depot.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Oh, why does he need a ladder?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He doesn’t; he just likes looking at them. Bring a book.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Gentlemen. You may remember Dr. Nowitzki, She’s back at Caltech for her postdoc.

Speaker: Ramona Nowitzki
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Hi. Oh, let me bring a chair for you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, thanks. Dr. Nowitzki’s going to tell me about the work she did at CERN. And she brought me this duty-free Toblerone.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Oh. I love those.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Let’s sit somewhere else.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: What just happened?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: A stranger just lured Sheldon away with a candy bar.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Wait, isn’t she the grad student that used to follow him around?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. Back before he hit puberty and grew man parts.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: So what do you guys think that’s about?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Knowing Sheldon, nothing.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: So, tell me about your scalar dark energy experiment.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Not ’til you tell me about your latest paper on quantum loop theory.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh. You must be one of those dessert before dinner people.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: He just made her laugh, something’s wrong.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Do you see the way she’s looking at him?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Yeah. Like Bernadette used to look at me.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I keep telling you, close the bathroom door.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Ah, did you see that? She just touched his hand and he didn’t swat it away. What is happening?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Okay, the simplest explanation is usually the right one.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Which is?

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: That ain’t Sheldon.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Not only did they eat together, Leonard said he made her laugh.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s nothing, Howie said she touched his hand.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Did he Purell?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I cannot believe Leonard mentioned the Toblerone but left that part out.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Should we call Amy?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: I don’t know; we shouldn’t worry her if it’s nothing.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I guess we could wait till we have more information about this girl.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Yeah. Do you think living with Amy has somehow stirred up Sheldon’s sexual appetite?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Ugh. How can you think that? Why would you even put those words together?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, then we agree. He’s not making any moves, it’s this Dr. Ramona chick.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Nowitzki. I googled her, she’s pretty cute.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Really? All I got from Leonard was the Toblerone bar had nuts.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And get this, I saw an articulating ladder with dual-leg leveling, which delivers stability and adaptability to uneven terrain.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Sounds like a big night.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yeah. Raj made the funniest joke, he said, which is the best ladder to use to hang myself?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: So you’re keeping busy? You’re not lonely?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, not at all. I’ve had outings with Leonard and Raj in the evening, and, oh, I had lunch
with Dr. Nowitzki.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Who’s he?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, Dr. Nowitzki is a woman.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Oh. Really? Uh, when did you meet her?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Many years ago. Back when she was a grad student. She’s always been a huge fan of my work, and now she’s doing research at Caltech.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Huge fan, you say?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes. I think you’d like her. She’s extremely intelligent, just like you. Unlike you, she’s tall, blonde and used to be an Olympic swimmer.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s terrific. I’ll call you right back.

Speaker: Penny(answering skype)
Dialogue: Oh, hey, Amy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I gave you one job. Keep an eye on him. How hard is that?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We thought you meant not letting him run out into traffic.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Which he only did once.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Why didn’t you tell me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: We didn’t want you to worry.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Should I worry?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: No. Come on, it’s Sheldon. Nothing is gonna happen.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: That’s what you said to me when I started dating him. And then five years later, bingo bango, something happened.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, but you’re gonna be back in three months.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: You don’t get it. I’ve been smacking that ketchup bottle for a long time. All she’s got to do is tip it over and point it at her fries.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, what do you want us to do?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I don’t know. Might be the New Jersey talking, but this Nowitzki broad needs to disappear.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: That’s ridiculous. As far as we know, all that happened is two scientists had lunch.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Yeah, but one of those scientists is a tall, blonde Olympic swimmer.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Come on. Looks don’t matter to Sheldon. Because he only has eyes for you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Nice try.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Thanks. I was scrambling.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: It’s unbelievable. Sheldon has lunch with another woman and somehow my wife yells at me.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Penny laid into me, too. Apparently, I’m overly fixated on premium Swiss chocolate bars.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Can you even eat those things?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: If I take a Lactaid a half-hour before and some Pepto right after.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Sounds like a lot of work.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Eh, I’m worth it.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Guys. Focus. Should we do something about Nowitzki?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Uh, well, she’s single, so if somebody else asks her out and she says yes, then we know she’s not into Sheldon.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: I’ll do it.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: No offence, Stuart, but the woman’s a doctor.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: So? Doctors like me. Whenever I see mine he calls in a bunch of other doctors to have a look.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: She’s not that kind of doctor.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Oh. Well, her loss. I’ve been called a genuine medical oddity.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Actually, I was going to suggest me.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: Great. Anybody’s better than, mmm.

Speaker: Stuart
Dialogue: Excuse me. They took out my spleen and gallbladder, not my feelings.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Dr. Nowitzki. Good to see you.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Good to see you, too.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: May I join you?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Good to see you.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: We should call Guinness, that might be a record.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: She’s clearly having a working lunch and preferred to eat alone.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Dr. Cooper, over here.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I could have made her very happy.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You kept walking. I think you did.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Do you really think there’s reason to worry?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Yeah, she’s definitely going after Sheldon.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I made a play for her and she shot me down.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, well, that doesn’t prove anything.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Yeah, there’s a million reasons a woman would shoot Raj down.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Like, really, a million?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Fine, hundreds.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: The point is this could be nothing and we are all overreacting.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, everybody. This is my friend, Dr. Nowitzki.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Hi.
All; Hi.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: We just went swimming.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: And you actually got in a pool?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I was scared, but I told myself it’s just a big bathtub. Then I got scared again ’cause there are all these strangers in my bathtub.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: I was proud of him, a lot of people don’t put their face in the water on the first day.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, I was hiding from a bee, but it still counts.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Can I just squeeze in here?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: So, Sheldon, have you talked to Amy?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Yes, we skyped this morning and I’m sure I’ll check in with her before I go to sleep.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Sheldon talks about her all the time. I can’t wait to meet her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That is true. She keeps asking how long Amy’s going to be gone.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Uh, so, Ramona, tell us about yourself. Do you, do you have a boyfriend?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Leonard, your wife is sitting right here. What are you doing?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: No, my work doesn’t leave me a lot of time for relationships.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: I think you made that very clear.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: She was part of the American team at CERN.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: I had a front row seat when they detected the Higgs boson.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Do you know, I’ve corresponded with Peter Higgs. Would you like to see some of his letters?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I’ll get them.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Well, hang on, I’ll come with you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, fun. Like a play date.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, correct me if I’m wrong, but isn’t that exactly what we were supposed to stop from happening?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: I threw my body at them, what else did you want me to do?

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You think you should call Amy?

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: You got fingers and a mouth, you call her.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Here you go.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Are these all from Peter Higgs?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hmm? Oh, no, no, no. They’re from many famous people. See? Oh, like this one. This is from Patrick Stewart. It says if I come to his house again, I get to meet his dogs. Oh, excuse me.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hello, Sheldon.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Oh, hello, Amy.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: I was missing you again.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I miss you, too. Hey, this is good timing. Remember that Dr. Nowitzki I told you about? She’s right here.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: She’s what?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: So nice to meet you.

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Hang on.(answering phone)Hello. A little late, Leonard. Sorry.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What is Leonard doing calling you at this hour?

Speaker: Amy
Dialogue: It’s not important.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I must tell you, that seems a little inappropriate. Don’t you agree?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: See? We both think so.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right, this is making me crazy. Somebody’s got to go over there.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: You got feet and legs, you do it.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Will you go with me?

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: To do what? Shake a can of nickels at them?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: We’re being ridiculous. There’s no way a woman that attractive is trying to seduce Sheldon Cooper.

Speaker: Howard
Dialogue: You done trying to make yourself feel better?

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: No. I haven’t played the race card yet.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Hey, I hate to break up the party, but Amy says I’m tired and have to go to bed.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: It was nice seeing everybody. Thank you for dinner.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: Leonard
Dialogue: Our pleasure.

Speaker: Raj
Dialogue: Whatever.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Walk me to my car?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We’ll all go.

Speaker: Bernadette
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Pardon. I just need to., yeah.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That was fun. It was like Mario Kart.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: We need to talk.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: What? Is this about Leonard and Amy? I don’t like it either.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay, I know you don’t have a lot of experience with women, but Ramona seems to have a romantic interest in you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That doesn’t make any sense. She knows I have a girlfriend.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, sometimes women don’t care. Sometimes it makes them want a guy even more.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: That may be true, but Dr. Nowitzki’s just a friend. In fact, I wouldn’t have even noticed she’s a woman if she hadn’t worn that bathing suit that highlighted her bosom.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Okay. Um, let’s try this. Think of yourself as one of those limited edition toys people like to collect.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I already do.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Well, then you get it.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Because there’s only one of me, I’m more valuable.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Although, Amy’s already taken me out of my package and played with me.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Let’s forget the toy thing, okay? Um, maybe…

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Penny, look. I appreciate your concern, but I don’t think that’s what’s happening.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: All right. What do you think is happening?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: I think Dr. Nowitzki is a friendly colleague. I think you and Leonard need to see a marriage counsellor. And I need to update my résumé to include swimming as a special skill.

Speaker: Penny
Dialogue: Don’t look at me like that, I tried.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Hey, did you eat yet?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Uh, breakfast yes, lunch no. I did have a cough drop, but that really rides the line between sucking and eating.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Well, perfect. I made us sandwiches.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: How thoughtful. Thank you.

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: Mmm. No big deal, I enjoy spending time with you.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: And I with you. Question, are you seeking a romantic relationship with me?

Speaker: Ramona
Dialogue: What if I were?

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: Well, that would raise a number of problems. We’re colleagues. I’m currently in a relation… Excuse me a moment.

Speaker: Sheldon
Dialogue: (Knock, knock, knock)Amy.(Knock, knock, knock)Amy.(Knock, knock, knock)Amy. Will you marry me?
